Thanks friends for remembering me...and wishing everyone on this list a new=
 year full of love and light.

2007 was a challenge for me.  I've had many meetings with the dark one but =
this is the closest I came to actually dying.  Don't know why, through war,=
 the AIDS plague and now this, that I have been spared while others surely =
more worthy than I have passed.  The good die young

I have much to be thankful for.  It is very painful for a dancer to lose th=
e use of his/her legs but I am still alive and working to bring back streng=
th to my mind and body.  I can now walk without the use of a cane, albeit l=
ike a duck.  Thought I would have to sell my ride -- a pimped out six speed=
 manual -- but I'm driving her again.  Why, even my mojo is returning.

Best of all, I have good friends and a loving partner.

Much love,

Apollo

From: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: BASSDROP, Thurs 1/10 @ Shine

BASSDROP
Thursday, January 10th
@ Shine
1337 Mission St. @ 9th
9pm - 2am
21+
FREE as always

We're kicking off 2008 with a bang and we've invited two bay area
party rockers to throw down with us at our first Bassdrop for the new
year. On the decks will be Audio1 and Aleks, alongside your favorite
EB residents.



Audio1
(Social Seen / Primary Element)

The original b-boy known as Audio1 digs deep to take you to the roots
& soul of the Hip-Hop culture, giving the listener an eclectic mix of
classics old and new, with b-sides, exclusives, and old skool breaks
blended to perfection with shaolin b-boy techniques. While his roots
are in Hip-Hop, Audio1 is more well known as one of the top jungle DJs
on the West Coast. He combines precise cuts, scratches, and beat
juggling with fast paced mixing covering diverse styles from ragga and
hardstep amens to grinding techstep with a healthy dose of futuristic
b-boy styles thrown in for good measure. You can spot him with his
partners in crime, DJ Greg J, Kevin Kind and/or DJ Ajax, as they take
you on a journeys thru HipHop, Rock, Mashups, R&B, Crunk, Hyphy,
House, Baltimore Club, 80s & Old School party jams.

Audio1 will be giving away free mix CDs!

Check out Audio1 on Myspace:
http://myspace.com/djaudio1

Download his Mega Club mix here:
http://www.social-seen.com/clubmix/

Download his 80s Classiks mix here:
http://www.djmainframe.com/audio1/mixes/demo/Audio1-Blend80sClassiks.mp3



Aleks
(Nocturnalism / A10 Recordings)

While most 12 year olds are busy playing video games and thinking what
after-school sport they might want to try, Aleks took hold of his
first set of turntables and grew up on the decks. Collecting records
throughout adolescence, his music tastes quickly grew towards
electronic music and began playing Breakbeats, and later branched out
to include UK Hardhouse, Techno, and NRG. He continued to grow a name
for himself all over Central California, producing his own club nights
from 1998-2000.

Aleks has played with some of Northern California's best production
companies with top billing like TELIC, Audio Metamorphosis, Sound
Asylum, Preserve, Stilldream, OmniEra and Nocturnalism Entertainment.
Although Aleks has now been DJing for over half his life, he has taken
his love for music to the next level by producing his own tracks.
Check out a wide variety of his work, ranging from breaks to hardhouse
& everything in between here.

Check out Aleks on Myspace:
http://www.myspace.com/djaleks

Download his most recent breaks mix:
http://a10records.djsemaj.com/madbeats/Aleks%20-%20A%20New%20Beginning.mp3



Aaron Jae
(Evil Breaks / Space Cowboys)

Check out his "Live at the Hoe Down" recorded live at Burningman '07:
http://aaronjae.com/?go=disc&d=19

and his last CD mix "Crunky":
http://aaronjae.com/?go=disc&d=18

-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

Message-ID: <4236.71.198.250.91.1199337913.squirrel@secure.saturn5.com>
Date: Wed, 2 Jan 2008 21:25:13 -0800 (PST)
From: "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Reply-To: osby@viberation.com
User-Agent: SquirrelMail/1.4.10a
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] My Yummy Welcome 2008 review  :n)

So for NYE.. I went to :AN UNDERGROUND RESOLUTION: & WOW... it was fuckin'
Dope!!!  I'll be honest... I was mainly on ly in 2 rooms... the Mafia tent
& the Revolution room... I mean... the Mafia tant had all the yummy hip
hop, down tempo, Jungle, & oh gosh.. there's like2 genres i'm hella
missing, but yeah... I totally got my Sexy Groovy on in there...  I mean..
there were people in ther even having sex too.. HELLO 2DAY.. & they
seriouslky took it down down on those chairs & beanbags.. woo... so then
the REvolution room... Oh YUM!!!  TECHNO, JUNLGE, ELECTRO, TECHNO, TECHNO,
TECHNO!!!!!  I danced alot... but I mean.. there was sooo much Family
there & oh man... alota old school heads that popped up & like lololmao...
ok... i hella just hella giggled 'cause yeah... it was a happy thing,
mondo fuckin' happy man...

OK.. so like back in Nov... me & Forest had this like mondo conversation &
both decided that we both needed to build our steam irons & iron out the
wrinkles in our lives... so i started building & getting stuff done...
then like right before Christmas, I had these thoughts about the steam
iron... then like I thought about resolutions & thought to myself that i
don't really need to make resolutions to make my life better.. but i do
have to start like be more ummm...

ok... so like i mondo wrote this earlier to a friend of mine... "i need to
start living my life & a mind set framed mentality... but I need to just
be strong, do what i need to do to succeed in all my endevores, don't look
back with regret, & always move foward! I realized last year that I
focused way too much on my faults, mistakes, and things that weren't
accessible instead of working on what I can make possible, my strengths,
and my achievements! So I hope i can do this to myself & get on with my
life instead of living life full of regret and missed opportunities. I'm
kind of excited about this 'cause it's just time to get things in order!"

ok... so yeah... after the shindig @ SOMarts.. hung out @ Sticky's pad...
oooooooooh... so my Yaya came into town for the shindig too w/ 2 of her
Sac Homies & we kinda kicked it all night.. YAAAAAY... so yeah... ok.. so
yeah... after all the fun, dancing, & people... a few of us headed to
Sticky's pad (me, Yaya, Javi, ^& Daniel).. chilled there for a while..
then we went to the beach to chill out.. lol.. some random people started
hoped in our car & kicked it with us.. then we went to the Haight & Javi
ate some indian food... then we went to Gold Gate Park- Richmond side...
then we went to Berkeley & Javi ate Chinese food... lol... yeah... it was
a new years day adventure...

Yeah... it was an Awesome Mondo Groovy way to bring in the new year~  I'm
really excited actually to just go on & see what happens next!!!  YAAAAY

Happy HArdcore New Year SFR!!!  Love You all!!!  Hope y'all had a Bad Ass
time bringin in the new year!!
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

zero ground was also amazing! i think i realized for the first time that
dubstep/downtempo needs to be listened to on very very lound subs.  there
are frequencies you just can't hear, but can feel, and there's just a total
experience behind feeling the music vibrating through every part of your
being

 I just happen to be listening to some Cumbia music (spanish, origins centra=
l america)=C2=A0 that my aunt was rocking out at a birthday party. The sampl=
e that is being used in Heater was pretty much taken from this song. I tryed=
 to get a little more info on the track but, aunt was too busy party-ing. Al=
l the info i got is that the song came on a compilation cd that had several=20=
composers and that this particular cd was about a year old. I will try to ge=
t some more info when i get a chance.

-----Original Message-----
From: filter.sf@gmail.com

Sent: Mon, 31 Dec 2007 8:41 pm
Subject: Re: [sfraves] A Berlin Story.










Record review of the year ::::


Samim - Heater <http://www.residentadvisor.net/review-view.aspx?id=3D4721> [=
Get
Physical <http://www.residentadvisor.net/record-label.aspx?id=3D403>]

[image: 23 - Samim - Heater]
Video: Samim =E2=80=93 Heater <http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DNZ806mlFoMY>
"This is the one with the accordion in it. It's being played at every party
you go to and it's causing a bit of a stink because accordions are not
exactly techno, are they? It's also got a man making monkey noises on it,
and it's really catchy, which means that now that everyone is playing it,
it's going to start annoying the shit out of people very, very soon. A bit
like 'Geht's Noch?' or 'Erotic Discourse' did. But to be fair, I promised I
wouldn't write this review until I'd heard 'Heater' out. Unfortunately, I
got my chance in Berlin, where the track had the awkward effect of making
all the white people in the room suddenly dance *whiter*. Club Weekend
turned into an old worlde barn dance, with woodcutters jigging with
milkmaids for six minutes. Hmm. Overall then, 'Heater' is a fun little
listen, but dancing to it makes you feel like an idiot." =E2=80=93 Jeremy Ar=
mitage




























On 12/30/07, Osby Oi Oi Jamz <osby@viberation.com> wrote:
>
> OK... Chel-C.. YUMMY YUM YUM McYUMMERSON!!  I Love that!!!  OK.. Girl..
> when i go to Germany & I"m gonna talk to you about where to go where form
> where I'm at & Make my way there!!!  That was Awesome!!  Hello 2Day.. i'm
> so happy for you!!!  BIG FUCKIN UPS TO THE UNDERGROUND!!!  YAAAAY!@!!!
> --
> Take Care <3
> Peace=3D->Jus' Me =3D-> O=C2=A7bY {8O)
>
>
>
> Chelsea Faith wrote:
> > Hello again friends. Thought I would share my Saturday night report,
> live
> > and direct from East Berlin. Osby isn't the only one who can share
> stories
> > of Saturday night debauchery here...
> >
> > On Saturday, I met up with some friends at my friend Martin's record
> shop
> > in
> > Friedrichshain. We drank champagne and listened to some records
> > before walking down Revalerstra=C3=9Fe to a club called Rosi's.  This pl=
ace
> is
> > so
> > typically Friedrichshain - A big, one-story brick building, placed off
> the
> > street, behind a wall, with a crumbling facade and an equally rough
> > interior. It seems to me that having a hole in the floor or in the wall
> is
> > a
> > standard feature for clubs on the East side of town. There was a big
> patio
> > area outside, which I'm sure must be a blast in the Summer, when they
> have
> > a
> > soundsystem set up out there. Tonight there was no soundsystem on the
> > patio,
> > it was quite cold, but the outdoor grill was open and people were
> standing
> > in line to get themselves a bratwurst and a beer.
> >
> > Inside, the place looked much like an oldschool Oakland warehouse space,
> > decked out with crazy projections everywhere and those trance-inducing
> LED
> > bricks that can light a room any color of the rainbow. Tall ceilings,
> > brick
> > walls, cement floors, and lots of little secret hang out rooms behind
> > beaded
> > curtains. At midnight, the place was still completely empty, as parties
> > here
> > don't really get going until after 2am.  I sat with my friends in some
> old
> > movie theater seats up against the wall. The music was typical Berlin
> > techno
> > early in the night - Minimal, touching on melodic, but still dark and
> > driving.
> >
> > By 2am the place was packed, and we went to check out an acquaintance
> who
> > was DJing in the smaller room.  This room was totally reminiscent of the
> > Dungeon, having low ceilings with that yucky ceiling tile stuff that you
> > find in office buildings. The DJ was playing sparse, glitchy,
> > electro-influenced tech-house, which I was told is being called Fidget
> > House
> > these days. I've heard the term here and there, but didn't really know
> > what
> > it was. Sort of a more techy offshoot of electro-house, from my
> > perspective,
> > though I only heard this music once, so I am not an expert on the
> subject.
> >
> > We weren't really that into the music, so we decided this:  If we heard
> > either RUOK, or Heater (that god-awful minimal track with the accordion
> in
> > it), we would leave. It was kind of a joke, kind of not. Talking about
> > these, my least favorite current minimal anthems, reminded me of my
> > previous
> > night out, at a club called Zur M=C3=B6belfabrik, in Mitte. This place i=
s
> > another
> > typical East Berlin club - A former furniture factory, found below
> street
> > level, with lots of brick and cement, and of course the obligatory holes
> > in
> > the wall. I told my friend about my surprise when I heard the DJ playing
> > Marc Houle's "Techno Vocals," a track I saw as a novelty record and
> didn't
> > really take seriously. (In case you're not familiar, the track is a
> parody
> > of the trend in minimal techno to make tracks with these really
> > pitched-down
> > vocals in them. The refrain goes "Why are all the vocals pitched down so
> > low? This is the way we make techno!"  Yeah, funny. See here:
> > http://www.discogs.com/release/1075727)  I was genuinely surprised to
> hear
> > a
> > DJ playing it at a real techno club, this record is such a piece of
> shit,
> > really. A shitty parody of some other shitty tracks, something that will
> > have little to no relevance a year from now.  So, just as I'm finishing
> > telling him this, the DJ starts to mix in the next record, and I hear
> "Why
> > are all the vocals pitched down so low, low, low?"  I totally jumped out
> > of
> > my seat with surprise, laughing. It cracked me up. I couldn't help but
> > exclaim, "I can't believe he's playing this shit!!" Hilarious.
> >
> > So, the verdict was that the music wasn't really doing it for us, so the
> > two
> > of us that remained from our party walked out to grab a falafel and hit
> > the
> > next club.  We walked through the outskirts of F'hain, in a quieter and
> > more
> > industrial part of town. The first club we reached was closed, so we
> > walked
> > on to the the Plan B club, which was also closed. It was about 5am, and
> I
> > was ready to go home, so it was ok with me. The two of us began to walk
> > towards Warschauerstra=C3=9Fe to catch a train home, when this guy comes=
 up
> to
> > us
> > as asks if the party is around here. Neither of us knew what he was
> > talking
> > about, but as we stopped walking and listened for a moment, we heard
> that
> > familiar sound coming from the next block:
> "wmmph-wmmph-wmmph-wmmph".  We
> > walked over to this run-down building covered in scaffolding.  It looked
> > abandoned and empty. A couple of street punks were sitting outside,
> > smoking
> > cigarettes. The front door was unlocked, so we walked in. We went up
> > several
> > flights of stairs, to the top floor, where much to my surprise, was this
> > amazing underground loft party. What luck! The place looked a lot like
> > Overworld in Oakland, for those of you who remember that space - an
> open,
> > dark, dirty loft. There were lots of TVs stuck up in the rafters, with
> > live
> > visuals, and projections of circuit diagrams all over the walls.
> Hammocks
> > were strung up here and there, and there were lots of different chill
> > areas
> > with benches, futons, chairs, etc. This was the first place I have ever
> > seen
> > in Berlin with blacklights - it felt like home! I sat down on a park
> bench
> > with a beer in my hand and rested my feet on a broken wood box covered
> in
> > bottles. The coat check consisted of a row of nails on one of the
> rafters,
> > where a line of long black coats and scarves were hanging. At the bar
> they
> > were serving cheap German beer and afri-cola with jaegermeister. The way
> > the
> > place was set up, with all the projectors, TVs, netting, lighting,
> > soundsystem, and such, it appeared that this was a regular party spot,
> not
> > just a one-off thing.
> >
> > I went over to the the dancefloor to check out what was happening, I had
> > heard a few people say that the "Ha-pa-na" was really going off, so I
> > wanted
> > to find out what this was.  A Japanese guy was playing a live p.a. set
> of
> > stripped down, hard, heady, minimal techno. It was the real shit! Not
> any
> > of
> > this clubby minimal tech-house stuff, this was pure techno. Gorgeous.
> >
> > The people here were peaceful, respectful, fun, and open, the way it
> > should
> > be.  Berlin can be a little intimidating at first, because some parts of
> > the
> > club scene are very exclusive. I was shocked coming here for the first
> > time
> > in 2002, when I had to be 'picked' to get into the first club I went to
> -
> > this was contrary to everything I knew about dance music events. We're
> all
> > a
> > family, and everyone is welcome, right...?  We're united by music,
> dancing
> > together as one, aren't we...? Not always so.  So I was a little bummed
> > out,
> > thinking Berlin wouldn't open its arms to a freaky hippie raver girl
> from
> > San Francisco. But, here, as in many cities, if you dig deep enough, you
> > can
> > find the beating heart of the underground. Here at this loft party, I
> > could
> > talk to anyone, everyone was kind, no fights, no drunken outbursts, no
> > creepy guys hitting on me, just a bunch of good people having fun and
> > being
> > free.  Totally brought me back to my early days of raving. What a
> > fantastic
> > party!
> >
> > I left as the sun was coming up, and caught the train back to my flat,
> > watching the last stars burn out from the sky. What a great night!
> >
> > That's all for now.  I hope all of you have a fantastic New Year's Eve!
> >
> >
> > Love Chelsea
> > reporting from Berlin, city of joyous techno and delicious falafel.
> >
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Nobody Listens to Techno - February 22nd

This isn't my party, but I thought some folks on here would be interested.

--

On February 22nd, 2008...

NOBODY LISTENS TO TECHNO!!

San Francisco Bay Area, California
10pm - 6am

That's right, we're doing a 100% Techno party. Breaking the mold and
trying something new, and hopefully fucking up your eardrums in the
process.

Your DJs for this night!

Ben Haus (Acid Totem) - Techno
DJ Tronic (Resistance Recordings) - 100% Exclusive JumpTek Set!
Idiotbox (5-MeO / Acid Totem) - Relentless Hard Techno
Cloudskipper (C.M.Beatz / OmniEra Entertainment) - Hard Techno / Schranz
Blue Soul (5-MeO / Devine Resonance) - Swedish Hard Techno
Second Base as Nagris Dodes (Nocturnalism) vs. Bemaniac as Nudist
Emeril (Digital Blasphemy / Church Of Hardcore) - Schranz
Haste - Acid Techno


$5 will get you in to experience something new here to the Bay Area.
That's right, $5. Not $5 plus $1 surcharge for a presale ticket, but
$5. At the door. All night. No exceptions. $5 will get you in to have
a good time and listen to some great hard dance music.


-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Let me just interject and say it may be "new" to certain EDM subscenes to
experience an all Techno party in SF.  Definitely not something new for the
21+ scene though.  I'm kind of concerned playing at set of 125bpm techno may
be viewed as playing downtempo at 2am- when comparing it to what others will
likely be playing at this party.    O_o   We'll see!

> --

> On February 22nd, 2008...
>
> NOBODY LISTENS TO TECHNO!!
>
> San Francisco Bay Area, California
> 10pm - 6am
>
> That's right, we're doing a 100% Techno party. Breaking the mold and
> trying something new, and hopefully fucking up your eardrums in the
> process.
>
> Your DJs for this night!
>
> Ben Haus (Acid Totem) - Techno
> DJ Tronic (Resistance Recordings) - 100% Exclusive JumpTek Set!
> Idiotbox (5-MeO / Acid Totem) - Relentless Hard Techno
> Cloudskipper (C.M.Beatz / OmniEra Entertainment) - Hard Techno / Schranz
> Blue Soul (5-MeO / Devine Resonance) - Swedish Hard Techno
> Second Base as Nagris Dodes (Nocturnalism) vs. Bemaniac as Nudist
> Emeril (Digital Blasphemy / Church Of Hardcore) - Schranz
> Haste - Acid Techno
>
>
> $5 will get you in to experience something new here to the Bay Area.
> That's right, $5. Not $5 plus $1 surcharge for a presale ticket, but
> $5. At the door. All night. No exceptions. $5 will get you in to have
> a good time and listen to some great hard dance music.
>

Cloudskipper's sound's been changing a lot recently, moving away from all
the vocal hardcore and the new stuff that's been replacing it at candy
parties. I heard a 'bouncy techno' set he played under a certain freeway
overpass that blew hella heads away. I'm kinda looking forward to seeing him
play techno -- good to see a skilled DJ evolving...

>>> parties. I heard a 'bouncy techno' set he played under a certain freeway
>>> overpass that blew hella heads away. I'm kinda looking forward to seeing 
>>> him
>>> play techno -- good to see a skilled DJ evolving...

No worries Nico... I'm moving towards 30, and both BlueSoul and idiotbox are
on their way to their mid 30's  : X    I reckon you'll hear the most refined
sound from those two as they've been going to/playing at raves since the
early-mid 90's.  Bluesoul is also a really talented producer, never heard
him play harder techno though-  should be interesting!

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Sat.Jan.5th [KONTROL] presents the new sound of Detroit w/ Ryan Elliott + more!

------=_Part_50743_29858571.1199442087724
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Saturday, January 5th, 2008

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup


DETROIT INVASION!

With the incessant journalistic nods to its birthplace-of-techno
roots, it would be easy to assume Detroit is a city stuck in its
own musical past. But its thriving and continually evolving scene,
represented this month by four of the D's finest "new school"
talents, has proven that nothing could be further from the truth.
Repping the Spectral, Paxahau, and Beretta camps and beyond,
please join us for this special evening showcasing the new
sounds of Techno City.


featuring:

===> RYAN ELLIOTT
spectral sound . ghostly international : detroit

===> KEITH KEMP (live)
beretta grey . gravid digital : detroit

===> RICH KORACH
paxahau . movement . d records : detroit

===> ERIC CLOUTIER
subtrak . untitled . moodgadget : detroit/nyc


with [KONTROL] residents:

---> NIKOLA BAYTALA
s.w.a.t . robsoul . junior boys own

---> ALLAND BYALLO
nightlight music . auralism . leibe*detail

---> SAMMY D
classic . utensil . dirtybird . magnificent 7

____________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________


full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

[ground.KONTROL] on Western Addition Radio:
http://www.westaddradio.com/kontrol/


January flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K31/K31F.jpg

January flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K31/K31B.jpg

January poster:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K31/K31P.jpg

____________________________________________________


RYAN ELLIOTT

Detroit DJ Ryan Elliott has gained notoriety over the past few years by
programming sets that are as well crafted and sophisticated as they are
danceable. From ice cold minimal techno to summery house beats, Elliott has
played both big rooms and martini bars with equal success. As a DJ, Ryan is
adept in the late night hours, finding the balance between heavy floor
tracks and elegant crowdpleasers. Utilizing three decks, multiple audio
sources, and outboard effects are par for the course, and Elliott employs
them with the utmost skill to keep crowds engaged.

With a fervent interest in the emerging international techno scene, he is a
walking dictionary of artists, labels, and releases. Elliott held his
Tuesday night events at Ann Arbor's Goodnight Gracie with Matthew Dear from
2002 to 2004, bringing back energy to the city's nightlife. Ryan Elliott was
also asked to be a resident at Detroit's weekly Untitled alongside Dear,
Tadd Mullinix, Mike Servito, and Derek Plaslaiko. In 2005 he began a new
residency at Detroit's Oslo, and created a stellar 33-track mix for the 2xCD
edition of the Spectral Sound Vol. 1 compilation.  This year he delivered
one of the most talked about sets at the DEMF, tag-teaming with good friend
Matthew Dear on the Detroit Stage.


Ryan's web page (with charts, links, etc.):
http://www.ryanelliott.net/

2007 Interview for Resident Advisor:
http://tinyurl.com/2gsas9

VIDEO: Ryan Elliott @ the DEMF, 2007 (w/ Matthew Dear):
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5EJaSs0upUw

VIDEO: Ryan Elliott at the afterparty to his 10-hour birthday set!:
http://youtube.com/watch?v=Yxz0QZZ2T14

AUDIO: Ryan Elliott DJ mix, September 2005
http://percussionlab.com/Audio/RyanElliottMix.mp3

________________________________________________


KEITH KEMP

A Detroit native, Keith's exposure to electronic music via Industrial
pioneers Skinny Puppy and Brian Eno sparked an early infatuation with
synthesizers and audio software. Club life after high school inspired
Keith's interest in spinning records, connecting the dots to Detroit artists
such as Plastikman, Underground Resistance and Carl Craig.  He has since
focused on various creative areas of electronic music: DJ, producer,
operating his label Gravid Digital, and performing his own music live.

DJ: Keith's gigs have seen him headline alongside almost every prolific
producer to have graced the electronic music stage in the past decade. A
highly regarded technical performer, Keith's sets combine his love of house,
Industrial and German minimalism with Detroit techno. Sharing his taste in
quality music with people as a DJ, he has traveled across the United States
and performed at the Detroit Electronic Music Festival in 2002 and 2005.
After strictly DJing for a few years, he took the next logical step by
cutting down his schedule and returned to his machines, working hard on his
own unique take on electronic dance music.

LIVE: Blending the ethics of minimal techno with the moods and feel of house
music has helped Keith in the creation of a live p.a. His passion for music
technology, whether hardware or software, has allowed Keith to continually
develop his live performances in a modern micro-house sensibility. His live
performances are best described as a deft fusion of percussion programming,
sub-atomic bass lines, and melodic flourishes.  Keith regularly performs
live for revered Detroit promoters Paxahau and Freshcorp.


Keith's website (w/ discography):
http://www.keith-kemp.com/

Keith's MySpace page:
http://www.myspace.com/keithkempkemptracks

AUDIO: Keith Kemp - Live PA @ DEMF 2005, Detroit
http://www.graviddigital.com/Kemp/mpthree/kkemp_livepa@DEMF_Detroit_2005.mp3

________________________________________________


RICH KORACH

Rich Korach discovered underground electronic music in 1994, finally
encountering the sound for which he had been searching. A native to the
Detroit area, Rich witnessed sets from the early pioneers of techno: Derrick
May, Kevin Saunderson, John Acquaviva and Stacey Pullen. Drawing influence
from Detroit's elite, Rich became an active DJ in 1997. His sets are
characterized by seamless transitions between elements of House and Techno,
creating new subgenres with every mix.

In 2004 Rich became one of a few select Paxahau resident DJs while
conjointly leading the merchandise divisions for Paxahau, DEMF and D
Records. Being a resident Paxahau DJ gave Rich greater opportunity to
display his unique capacity for DJ'ing, earning opening sets for such
luminaries as: Josh Wink, Michael Mayer, Mathew Jonson and Richie Hawtin.
Rich consistently evolves his sets, incorporating the latest effects
components to create buildups, rearrange sounds, and make his performances
that much more unique. His precision, timing, and technical aptitude have
acquired both national and international attention resulting in spots at:
the Detroit Electronic Music Festival, Ibiza, Berlin, and all across the U.S.



Rich's MySpace page:
http://www.myspace.com/richkorach

AUDIO: Rich Korach live @ The Oasis, Oakland 2007:
http://tinyurl.com/yovnth

________________________________________________


ERIC CLOUTIER

In a genre and movement all too predictable with the same fifty records
playing forever on a continuous loop, Eric Cloutier is quietly making
himself stand out amongst Detroit's next generation of producers and DJ's.
He began on the same circuit of Detroit parties and clubs most have
traveled, eventually establishing residencies at Ann Arbor's Necto and
Detroit's prominent after hours party spot, The Works. He also performed at
both 2004's Movement festival as well as 2006's Detroit Electronic Music
Festival, and has shared the decks with fellow Detroit DJ's Matthew Dear,
Derek Plaslaiko and Ryan Elliott. In 2005, he was handpicked as a chosen
replacement for the next batch of DJ's at Detroit's monthly "Untitled"
parties. He has since gone on to be label manager for the label Subtrak,
which is slowly making waves amongst deeper minimal fans. Tasteful yet
mildly abrasive, his blend of minimal techno infused with dub sensibilities
firmly entrenches his sound in Detroit's rich past while looking towards the
future.


Eric's website:
http://www.elementeight.net/

Eric's MySpace page:
http://www.myspace.com/elementeight

AUDIO: Eric Cloutier - Let The Beat Kontrol Your Body (promo mix made
specially for Kontrol) :
http://www.elementeight.net/audio/eric_cloutier_-_let_the_beat_kontrol_your_body.mp3

________________________________________________

http://www.kontrolsf.com

Subject: [sfraves] Justice.... Might I recommend 

Best new band I have heard in like forever. It is
bizarre that they are "christian" dance music
producers according to their myspace page, and
confirmed by the fact that they play with a giant
lit-up cross on stage... but honestly, it's the
freshest sound I have heard in a long time. Taking
chances, integrating new sounds, and keeping a tough
groove together in what sometimes feels like an odd
way... but that always works....

Check it...

what its like to be them. remember they are the future so if they're 
into this new thing, its pretty good, and its just not your style, you 
should at least try it it on and see if it fits. kind of how i'm feeling 
about dubstep. its fad-ish for sure, as far as i can tell, but there's 
some potential in it. or a better example would be digital techno.. i'm 
calling it that because its not very minimal and the sound format isn't 
very new. i couldn't get into it at all i was longing for the rolling 
drums.. but then i started hearing some shit that wasn't as punk rock 
(ipsa ergo: random guy who stole ableton and made beats on his laptop) 
and actually was done professionally, i was very impressed.

sean

ps.  some party at Jelly's on January 25th.  all old school techno.
no tracks made after 1992 or something like that.


On Jan 4, 2008 11:54 AM, Sean Ocean <seanocean@defsf.com> wrote:
> u just r old. shit happens and life goes on... and on. just don't forget
> what its like to be them. remember they are the future so if they're
> into this new thing, its pretty good, and its just not your style, you
> should at least try it it on and see if it fits. kind of how i'm feeling
> about dubstep. its fad-ish for sure, as far as i can tell, but there's
> some potential in it. or a better example would be digital techno.. i'm
> calling it that because its not very minimal and the sound format isn't
> very new. i couldn't get into it at all i was longing for the rolling
> drums.. but then i started hearing some shit that wasn't as punk rock
> (ipsa ergo: random guy who stole ableton and made beats on his laptop)
> and actually was done professionally, i was very impressed.
>
> sean
>
> nico wrote:
> > I feel old around the young raving massive.  :(
> >
>

Subject: [sfraves] Classic Techno Night, 1-25-08

here's what the flyer says:


Classic Techno Night
Exploring all Funkin' Boundaries of Underground Electronic Dance Music
No Music Created after 1992

01-25-08

$5 All Night
21+
10pm - after hours
Jelly's Cafe - 295 Terry Francois Blvd, Pier 50, SF

With DJ Matt Edwards
4 hour DJ set!  All Classics All NIght Long!
+ more DJs TBA

During the late 80s and early 90s there was  a world wide explosion of
all different genres of electronic dance music, ranging from acid
house, techno, progressive house, funky house, tc.  the attempt this
night is to merge all those classic genres.  If you want to hear the
sounds of th scene in the early years, you definitely don't want to
miss this night of classic EDM.

the US (enough to get coverage on JK), but there other choonz
don't move me as much as D.A.N.C.E. and their remixes of other 
tracks don't hit as much, imo. We'll see what they do in the
future, though. I definitely think they're a band to watch.

I'm close to the financial district / chinatown, and all my windows were
rattling louder than I've ever heard in an earthquake.  The light poles were
swaying more than I'm comfortable with.  Today's precipitation reminds me of
thunderstorms back in houston, where i'd actually think twice about leaving
the house when it was raining.
-jasonh

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Is the weather really as bad as they are saying?

The bike trail on the inside of levee that I take to work was 
under about 9-10 feet of water. Water is spilling out over the 
levees all over the place here in the south bay.

The EZ-up in my backyard flew away and ended up by the nearby 
7-11. (okay I made that one up)

One of my co-workers wives had to evacuate Redwood City for 
flooding from the bay. I hear parts of Downtown SJ are out of 
power.

My clients in Tahoe told me today snow clumps the size of 
baseballs are dumping there.

Weeee, whata ride :-)

-terry

I live a little below sutro tower in the twin peaks area, it was the
heaviest winds I've ever heard/witnessed before.  Fallen tree branches
everywhere, one of the trees in my complex was blew over and was blocking
the entrance to our garage until someone came through with a hacksaw.
Electricty's been off since 8am, and just came on about 9:20pm.  I was
living the good life with my generator though.  Entire complex was dark
except for our household, watching the warriors on the big screen-

Subject: [sfraves] Video decoding help...

Terry at al...

My parents gave me a dvd with all of our old family
Super 8 movies on it. It is burned as a standard DVD.
If you look at the folders, it has a video folder with
files named like : VTS_01_3.VOB, VTS_01_0.IFO, and
VTS_01_0.BUP.

I would like to rip the actuual video off of the disc,
so that I can load it into some other software and
compose a score to it... as it has no sound.

How can I do this? 

Software wise,I would lve to simply use IMOVIE, but
have the entire ADOBE suite of products, and can
certainly use a music program to sync music once the
video is ripped if necessary.

Thanks for the help.

I had gotten that from google but wanted some input
first. I have worked so much with audio and video, I
cannot believe I don't already have the knowledge to
do this... But when I work with video, I have always
had a video tech/engineer at my side and never had to
do any of the video stuff...

to decode it... as the format must be universal on the
disc... Are the dvd files encrypted somehow? Is the
format purposefully not portable? Is it just a simple
imovie not allowing common dvd codecs to be imported
issue? Some or all of the above? 

If you care to explain, I'd appreciate understanding
what is going on for future reference... and I am
DL'ing handbrake as we speak.

thanks again,

References: <218661.87826.qm@web36803.mail.mud.yahoo.com> <7a86c50c0801051047i128650dfy29ea7869003337e0@mail.gmail.com> <20080105110418.Q12127@taz3>

MIME-Version: 1.0

	format=flowed;
	charset="iso-8859-1";
	reply-type=response
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2900.3138
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2900.3198
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 06 Jan 2008 03:52:15.0316 (UTC) FILETIME=[869FF940:01C85017]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Video decoding help...

I'm not familiar with Cinematize but if it can use the MPEG2 codec of 
Quicktime Pro MPEG Component (an extra cost), then you will be able to 
reintegrate an MP2 audio stream of your design back into the MPEG2 video 
stream without incurring the quality hit you'd get from re-encoding the 
whole wad.  The only way to use MPEG2 in any Quicktime container natively is 
with the MPEG2 authoring component which is an extra purchase from Apple.

For my money (free !), I'd rip the video stream from the DVD/VOBs with 
Handbrake, ffmpegX, or whatever you want.  Import the resulting MPEG2 stream 
into your favorite composition suite, then when your're done, export just 
the audio to an MP2 audio stream.

Afterward, take your M2A and original M2V file and reintegrate them into a 
DVD using Sizzle.  Done this a gazzillion times with a drag-n-drop 
Applescript routine I wrote to take .TY movie files I ripped from my Tivo 
back in the day and turn them into a DVD in one shot.

But bottom line is there's many more than one way to skin this cat.

Good luck !

-=dave

Subject: [sfraves] Unsafeway

So, I know that there are other people on this list who refer to Safeway 
as Unsafeway.  (I've generally preferred the term Slaveway myself, due 
to their union positions.)  But tonight I've changed my tune.  Seems 
like another homicide has happened in their parking lot next door to 
where I live (30th st and mission, btw.)  Around 2am I heard what 
sounded like rifle shots (WTF happened to simple handgun shots??)  And 
not too long after the ambulance showed up along with probably 10 or so 
police cars.  There are still 5 plus policemen there, so 1:15 minutes 
later.  Which is why I am assuming it was a homicide rather than a 
simple shooting.

In any case, I'm holding out hope that this is not truly what happened, 
and whoever was shot will survive.  While at the same time I can't help 
but ponder whether or not one is statistically more safe shopping at the 
mom and pop corner store rather than the suburban oriented chain store. 
Anyone know of a source for those statistics?

http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php

money in the basket, and leaving.
-- Ed Begley Jr

personally i don't think we are safe anywhere, we just have to be more cautious with our surrounding's..all the mom &pop stores have been robbed at least once and have had some sort of shooting outside..and this is berkeley..
i mean my yoga studio got robbed last sunday, and that use to be my safe haven away from home, now it's a just a job that i can't wait for my shift to be over quickly..

i use to think socal was bad...but sf/eastbay beat it to a tee..

at least in socal ppl are still segregated into their own spot/hood...call me racist, i don't care..i mean you don't go into watts cuz u know you'll be robbed in a sec..this coming from me is bad...i've had enuff of this town when it comes to mug ins, shootings, robberies, ..2 years ago..i got beat up by 4 girls on the bus in richmond..in front of my kids, bcuz i was according to those girls i was mexican..
i mean my 13 yr had his yearbook camera stolen right off his neck at berkeley high school...blah...

i've never judge people by their color and unfortunately it's starting to peak out..

hate me for my email..i don't care..yep i'm getting a sour taste of things here now..

besides all that..the only thing the bay has to offer is it's uniqueness in musik..you have it all...so party on...

Date: Sun, 6 Jan 2008 08:01:18 -0800 (PST)
From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: adriana <eesiad1@yahoo.com>, "J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>,
  sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <449452.38736.qm@web32406.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Unsafeway

You have to consider the circuimstances of the crime.  I didn't coin the term "Unsafeway" but some friends of my wife did (anyone remeber DJ Jelo aka Jeff Elo? Blame him...) to refer specifically to the Safeway at 30th and Mission.  Its an appropriate title unfortunately as my car was involved in a previous murder that occured there and was impounded for 48 hours.  That incident wasn't a robbery or anything of the sort, but rather a gang related murder that happened to occur in the parking lot because some of the individuals involved were from the "30th St Gang" supposedly.  I don't know what happened this time, but I'd guess something similar.  

I don't think these incidents fundamentally imply that major supermarkets are less safe than mom and pop markets however.  While a supermarket has much more cash on hand than a mom and pop corner store would, it is also better secured.  Many markets now have in store bank branches as well.  This makes them juicy targets for sophisticated or simply very dangerous criminals specializing in armed robberies.  However, some markets have "man trap" doors, most have advnaced surveillance systems, and some have armed guards.  

Check your SFPD crime map (http://www.sfgov.org/site/police_index.asp?id=23813) and you'll see that the area around 30th and Mission has a pretty high density of crime and violent crime in particular when compared to other areas of the city.  Moreover, the area around the market seems to have a somewhat higher density of incidents than the surrounding area, consider the cluster of assaults around the intersection of Virginia and Mission.  

A similar cluster of crime occurs around the Market street Safeway, but much less violent crime.  Consider a third location, the Safeway at Noriega and 30th Avenue.  You'll observe a much lower density of crimes and violent crimes in particular.  The Market Street location has a large recycling station that attracts a lot of homeless people and drug addicts to the area actually, but stilol ther eis less violent crime.  So you can see that its not simply the presence of the Safeway that drives crime volumes, but also the specific location of the supermarket.

Why?  One can speculate, but in general the literature supports the theory that this is likely due to the home location of the perpetrators.  That is the criminals probably tend to live near 30th and Mission, but not near Market and Church or Noriega and 30th.  Criminals in general are fairly lazy, they don't like to travel too far to commit crimes.  Moreover, gang violence tends to occur near the homes of gang members.

The crimes near the Market Street and Noriega Safeways seem to be targetted robberies (the criminal likely traveled to the location to commit the crime) and vehicle related robberies.  Compare this with the cluster of asaults at 30th and Mission.

I understand that some members of the 30th Street gang used to rent an apartment just up Virginia on the left FWIW.  

I don't know the specific location of the crimes Adriana mentions, but I'd bet similar reasoning would apply.  If you are getting robbed frequently, its because you live near ciminals.

See also: Harcourt, Bernard E. and Ludwig, Jens, "Broken Windows: New Evidence from New York City and a Five-City Social Experiment" . University of Chicago Law Review, Vol. 73, 2006. in which the "Broken Windows" theory is largely disproven.  Criminals commit crimes even when you move them to new "nicer" neighborhoods and the frequency doesn't change much.

Regards,

Peter


----- Original Message ----
From: adriana <eesiad1@yahoo.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Unsafeway

personally i don't think we are safe anywhere, we just have to be more cautious with our surrounding's..all the mom &pop stores have been robbed at least once and have had some sort of shooting outside..and this is berkeley..
i mean my yoga studio got robbed last sunday, and that use to be my safe haven away from home, now it's a just a job that i can't wait for my shift to be over quickly..

i use to think socal was bad...but sf/eastbay beat it to a tee..

at least in socal ppl are still segregated into their own spot/hood...call me racist, i don't care..i mean you don't go into watts cuz u know you'll be robbed in a sec..this coming from me is bad...i've had enuff of this town when it comes to mug ins, shootings, robberies, ..2 years ago..i got beat up by 4 girls on the bus in richmond..in front of my kids, bcuz i was according to those girls i was mexican..
i mean my 13 yr had his yearbook camera stolen right off his neck at berkeley high school...blah...

i've never judge people by their color and unfortunately it's starting to peak out..

hate me for my email..i don't care..yep i'm getting a sour taste of things here now..

besides all that..the only thing the bay has to offer is it's uniqueness in musik..you have it all...so party on...



"J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote: So, I know that there are other people on this list who refer to Safeway 
as Unsafeway.  (I've generally preferred the term Slaveway myself, due 
to their union positions.)  But tonight I've changed my tune.  Seems 
like another homicide has happened in their parking lot next door to 
where I live (30th st and mission, btw.)  Around 2am I heard what 
sounded like rifle shots (WTF happened to simple handgun shots??)  And 
not too long after the ambulance showed up along with probably 10 or so 
police cars.  There are still 5 plus policemen there, so 1:15 minutes 
later.  Which is why I am assuming it was a homicide rather than a 
simple shooting.

In any case, I'm holding out hope that this is not truly what happened, 
and whoever was shot will survive.  While at the same time I can't help 
but ponder whether or not one is statistically more safe shopping at the 
mom and pop corner store rather than the suburban oriented chain store. 
Anyone know of a source for those statistics?

I guess I was questioning the impact of the congregation factor that=20
Peter kind of spoke to earlier.  It seems that folks might be more=20
likely to congregate for longer periods of time in big box stores=20
parking lots as opposed to around mom & pops without those same lots.

High Cost of Low Price" there is an extensive segment on how people get=20
killed all the time in Walmart parking lots; that Walmart knows this;=20
yet Wamart does nothing to put in any type of security cameras or other=20
things that may prevent this.

Not that I'm a fan of Orwellianizing the US in a London fashion.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Unsafeway

That's strange as hell.  I actually used to live around there for a  
couple of years....  on Winfield street right up the hill from that  
Safeway.  And I never felt particularly uncomfortable or unsafe, and  
never really had any problems, and didn't even notice the "gangsters".

In fact, I still miss that apartment.  It was my first, here in The  
City.  And I used to joke that Bernal Heights was such a great  
neighborhood because, in addition to Cortland, I also had all the  
advantages of the Mission but, being 200 ft up the hill, random drunk  
people weren't staggering up to my doorstep and peeing on my car.

I guess it must have gone downhill since I lived there.  Seems that we  
need another round of gentrification to clean up the place.  (Here on  
Treasure Island too... it's gone downhill here since I've lived here.)


cya,
john

ble.=20

going to commit them regardless of location. Obviously if big, open, crowde=
d and busy Safeway parking lots that they could easily be identified at wor=
k for crimes, the criminals don't really care about where they commit those=
 crimes.

groundswell of regular people following the leaders, there are no
leaders, just talents.

and is currently studying for his MFA in Experimental Sound Practices
and Integrated Media at the distinguished California Institute of the
Arts." That's in Valencia (not Ventura), near el ciudad de los
angeles.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Unsafeway

Well, if you've got the sort of trash there who are going to run in  
gangs, own and carry guns, and SHOOT people;  I'm sorry, but the  
neighborhood needs to be cleansed.

It's not like that means turning it into a suburb either.  Look at the  
vast improvement in the Hayes Valley area since the city took out the  
section 8 and started redeveloping the neighborhood.  Granted, the  
place still has a ways to go.  But it's been a dramatic improvement so  
far, with narry a suburbanite to be found.  In fact, it's rapidly  
turning into one of my favorite parts of the city.  Seems like every  
time I go there, there's a new cool shop, restaurant, bar, or cafe  
that I just HAVE to try.

If you want to bitch about "suburbanization", look at Mission Bay.   
But I don't see any particular reason why the success of Hayes Valley  
couldn't be duplicated elsewhere, while avoiding the pitfalls of  
Willie Brown ridiculous legacy project by the ballpark.


cya,
john

Interesting that I haven't seen Rodenbush on any LA techno party rosters.

Seems like the only real way to make a real career in electronic music while
remaining US bound is to combine production skills with other multi-media
skills for greater messaging impact through commercial + artistic
application.

He's a step ahead as usual.

-SK

On 1/6/08, Giles Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> > SF is and always has
> > been a weird place for techno.
>
> Too true. All the creativity and expertise to power something greater,
> but none of the punters filling clubs and buying records. Without a
> groundswell of regular people following the leaders, there are no
> leaders, just talents.
>
> According to the Googlewebz "Rodenbush continues to develop his craft
> and is currently studying for his MFA in Experimental Sound Practices
> and Integrated Media at the distinguished California Institute of the
> Arts." That's in Valencia (not Ventura), near el ciudad de los
> angeles.
>
> Anyway. Back to getting my lurk on...
>
> --

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: BASSDROP - Thursday @ Shine - Free

BASSDROP
Thursday, January 10th
@ Shine
1337 Mission St. @ 9th
9pm - 2am
21+
FREE as always

We're kicking off 2008 with a bang and we've invited two bay area
party rockers to throw down with us at our first Bassdrop for the new
year. On the decks will be Audio1 and Aleks, alongside your favorite
EB residents.



Audio1
(Social Seen / Primary Element)

The original b-boy known as Audio1 digs deep to take you to the roots
& soul of the Hip-Hop culture, giving the listener an eclectic mix of
classics old and new, with b-sides, exclusives, and old skool breaks
blended to perfection with shaolin b-boy techniques. While his roots
are in Hip-Hop, Audio1 is more well known as one of the top jungle DJs
on the West Coast. He combines precise cuts, scratches, and beat
juggling with fast paced mixing covering diverse styles from ragga and
hardstep amens to grinding techstep with a healthy dose of futuristic
b-boy styles thrown in for good measure. You can spot him with his
partners in crime, DJ Greg J, Kevin Kind and/or DJ Ajax, as they take
you on a journeys thru HipHop, Rock, Mashups, R&B, Crunk, Hyphy,
House, Baltimore Club, 80s & Old School party jams.

Audio1 will be giving away free mix CDs!

Check out Audio1 on Myspace:
http://myspace.com/djaudio1

Download his Mega Club mix here:
http://www.social-seen.com/clubmix/

Download his 80s Classiks mix here:
http://www.djmainframe.com/audio1/mixes/demo/Audio1-Blend80sClassiks.mp3



Aleks
(Nocturnalism / A10 Recordings)

While most 12 year olds are busy playing video games and thinking what
after-school sport they might want to try, Aleks took hold of his
first set of turntables and grew up on the decks. Collecting records
throughout adolescence, his music tastes quickly grew towards
electronic music and began playing Breakbeats, and later branched out
to include UK Hardhouse, Techno, and NRG. He continued to grow a name
for himself all over Central California, producing his own club nights
from 1998-2000.

Aleks has played with some of Northern California's best production
companies with top billing like TELIC, Audio Metamorphosis, Sound
Asylum, Preserve, Stilldream, OmniEra and Nocturnalism Entertainment.
Although Aleks has now been DJing for over half his life, he has taken
his love for music to the next level by producing his own tracks.
Check out a wide variety of his work, ranging from breaks to hardhouse
& everything in between here.

Check out Aleks on Myspace:
http://www.myspace.com/djaleks

Download his most recent breaks mix:
http://a10records.djsemaj.com/madbeats/Aleks%20-%20A%20New%20Beginning.mp3



Aaron Jae
(Evil Breaks / Space Cowboys)

Check out his "Live at the Hoe Down" recorded live at Burningman '07:
http://aaronjae.com/?go=disc&d=19

and his last CD mix "Crunky":
http://aaronjae.com/?go=disc&d=18



-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

Hey fuckhole....

I pay more than a hundred thousand dollars a year in
federal taxes... I'm guessing you pay nothing.

I've never been to New Orleans.

I re-settled five families from Katrina at a total
expense of $25,000 to me. 

Was it their fault they got hurricaned? Was the Army
Core's fault? If so, should we just fuck-em.

And as an aside fuckhole... there is no way to get to
BM without driving on STATE highways....

The comment was a do unto others comment... something
that was supposed to let people know about the
suffering of the people in an area they travel once a
year, yet know nothing about. BM has an affect on the
surrounding areas, from traffic, trash, gas and water
supply, etc... 

And lastly... and again... I have nothing against
Burners... although so many assholes attack everyone
outside the clique that I am beginning to think that
my beliefs about the separation of org and people may
be far less correct than I thought... The attendees
are proving to be assholes, at least in how they talk
to me....

Eric

From: Holt Sorenson <hso@hsomusic.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20080107234324.GI16184@nosneros.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Stream Live NOW!! / This week on KZSU / Mix Released

BigLove with Jack Wang - Today from 3PM-6PM PST
-----------------------------------------------

This week, guest DJs Amit Shoham, DJ Durben, and Homero
Espinosa will be serving up house music to keep you bumpin.

Amit Shoham is a well know Bay Area DJ/producer and one of the
founders of record label Tarantic Records and has many releases
to his name. More information at Amit can be found at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/sh/C

DJ Durben has been a member of the SF scene and has laid down sets
in the underground and at clubs such as 1015 Folsom, The Sound Factory,
Peach, The Rouge and TempleSF. DJ Durben has recently began producing
tracks as well. More information about DJ Durben can be found at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/sh/A

Homero Espinosa is a DJ/Producer that is currently signed with Yerba
Buena Discos and recently had one of his tracks licensed for release
on Mark Farina's upcoming mix cd on Ministry of Sound. You can
read more about Homero Espinosa at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/sh/B


Eclecktronik Groove with Holt Sorenson - Tonight from 12AM-3AM PST
------------------------------------------------------------------

Tune into another great live set sent over the airwaves and wires
with KZSU resident Holt Sorenson. You can check out Holt's mixes and previous
shows at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/mixes/

If you're looking for his guest mix from Epiphany of Sound or Big Love,
it has recently been posted at the site above.

Next week, Holt will host DJ Frankie Jr. on his show. More information
about DJ Frankie Jr. can be found at:
http://hsomusic.com/sh/D
http://hsomusic.com/sh/9

You can check out his promo mix here:
http://hsomusic.com/sh/8


Epiphany of Sound with J.C. - Thursday the 10th from 9AM-12PM PST
-----------------------------------------------------------------

J.C. will host Ruoho Ruotsi, a local techno DJ/producer whose projects
draw upon the visceral aesthetics of dub, techno, garage and the
impractical rhythmical leitmotifs of experimental electro-acoustics,
fusing them into imaginative new musical opportunities.

bio:
http://www.defchild.com/releases.php?id=ruohobio

sets & livepa:
http://www.defchild.com/music.html

discogs:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Ruoho+Ruotsi

reviews:
http://www.defchild.com/reviews.html

links:
http://www.myspace.com/ruohoruotsi


As always, you can tune in to KZSU on 90.1 on your FM dial or browse
to http://kzsulive.stanford.edu/

--
Holt Sorenson/Eclektronik Groove
hso@hsomusic.com
hsomusic.com - myspace.com/hsomusic
KZSU (kzsulive.stanford.edu) show on Mon Nite/Tues Morn. 12-3AM


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

We saw Durben close out Temple on Saturday. There was someone playing live over his set, don't know the guy's name.

BUT, they were fucking awesome. There's still something magical about soulful house @ 2 AM in SF, no matter wtf you're at, or how many people are there. ("What to doooo. . .Suddenly I'm with you. . .")

It was a perfect wind down for Scott Binder (Cybersutra) @ Supperclub (One of the most-rockin', up & coming DJ's I've seen in awhile) earlier that night. 

Thanks for the post, good stuff. LOOKING FORWARD TO ECLECKTRONIK GROOVE TONIGHT!!! (BTW, I put out a mix awhile back called Eklectric, but you get bonus points for the "k," K?)

PEACE

chuck

Holt Sorenson <hso@hsomusic.com> wrote: BigLove with Jack Wang - Today from 3PM-6PM PST
-----------------------------------------------

This week, guest DJs Amit Shoham, DJ Durben, and Homero
Espinosa will be serving up house music to keep you bumpin.

Amit Shoham is a well know Bay Area DJ/producer and one of the
founders of record label Tarantic Records and has many releases
to his name. More information at Amit can be found at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/sh/C

DJ Durben has been a member of the SF scene and has laid down sets
in the underground and at clubs such as 1015 Folsom, The Sound Factory,
Peach, The Rouge and TempleSF. DJ Durben has recently began producing
tracks as well. More information about DJ Durben can be found at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/sh/A

Homero Espinosa is a DJ/Producer that is currently signed with Yerba
Buena Discos and recently had one of his tracks licensed for release
on Mark Farina's upcoming mix cd on Ministry of Sound. You can
read more about Homero Espinosa at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/sh/B


Eclecktronik Groove with Holt Sorenson - Tonight from 12AM-3AM PST
------------------------------------------------------------------

Tune into another great live set sent over the airwaves and wires
with KZSU resident Holt Sorenson. You can check out Holt's mixes and previous
shows at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/mixes/

If you're looking for his guest mix from Epiphany of Sound or Big Love,
it has recently been posted at the site above.

Next week, Holt will host DJ Frankie Jr. on his show. More information
about DJ Frankie Jr. can be found at:
http://hsomusic.com/sh/D
http://hsomusic.com/sh/9

You can check out his promo mix here:
http://hsomusic.com/sh/8


Epiphany of Sound with J.C. - Thursday the 10th from 9AM-12PM PST
-----------------------------------------------------------------

J.C. will host Ruoho Ruotsi, a local techno DJ/producer whose projects
draw upon the visceral aesthetics of dub, techno, garage and the
impractical rhythmical leitmotifs of experimental electro-acoustics,
fusing them into imaginative new musical opportunities.

bio:
http://www.defchild.com/releases.php?id=ruohobio

sets & livepa:
http://www.defchild.com/music.html

discogs:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Ruoho+Ruotsi

reviews:
http://www.defchild.com/reviews.html

links:
http://www.myspace.com/ruohoruotsi


As always, you can tune in to KZSU on 90.1 on your FM dial or browse
to http://kzsulive.stanford.edu/

--
Holt Sorenson/Eclektronik Groove
hso@hsomusic.com
hsomusic.com - myspace.com/hsomusic
KZSU (kzsulive.stanford.edu) show on Mon Nite/Tues Morn. 12-3AM

your meakness and insecurity would overwhelm you in
person, as apposed to what you write from your
workstation.

thought or comment out of context, wrap it into a
personal attack on you, and then lash out.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Hey Burners....

i think civility goes a long way if you're dealing with a topic where
you are suggesting that a community of people (that you've voiced
dislike for in the past) organize an effort to assist a town in need.
especially when that is based on your assumption that these people are
somehow connected to and should show compasion for said town.

eric could have just as easily said:  "to the burningman attendees on
this list, you may not be aware, but the town of Fernley was recently
devestated by flooding.  i'm not sure, but i think Fernley is visited
by many burningman attendess due to it being one of the last towns on
the highway to Black Rock City.  if you and members of your community
to visit Fernley on your way to and from Burningman, perhaps you'd
consider donating to their emergency efforts.  even greater, maybe a
fundraising event could be put together to help the people of
Fernley."

that would be being civil and would have avoided this entire fiasco.
to me, Eric was baiting the list.  maybe he wasn't, but that's the
tone i picked up, loud and clear.

To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SFR has outgrown it's usefulness to me

sorry, but this most recent banter is the last straw for me.  i've
been on this list a long time, since about 99 i think.  i only
unsubscribed for a few months when i was living abroad in China.

not that SFR has ever been perfect or lacked a certain element of
drama, but i have to say that i really think it's gone to pits in the
last year or so.

we talk less about music and parties, and more about our personal
gripes with each other and members of our own community.  there is so
much energy wasted on the bullshit name calling and arguing.

there are numerous other communities out there that are friendly and
open where i can talk about our shared enthusiasm for music, without
fear of starting a flame war.  i have never gotten tired of going out
and dancing my ass off to music that i love and surrounded by smiling
faces.

but i'm tired of being on this list.

to my friends, i know i'll see you around and will be in contact in
any number of ways.

goodbye SFR.  sorry to leave, but you just ain't what you used to be.

-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

http://www.evilbreaks.com

> this list, you may not be aware, but the town of Fernley was recently
> devestated by flooding.  i'm not sure, but i think Fernley is visited
> by many burningman attendess due to it being one of the last towns on
> the highway to Black Rock City.  if you and members of your community
> to visit Fernley on your way to and from Burningman, perhaps you'd
> consider donating to their emergency efforts.  even greater, maybe a
> fundraising event could be put together to help the people of
> Fernley."

reason to not like me.

SUPPLIES, MEDICAL ASSISTANCE, ETC... TO OFFER SOME
ASSISTANCE TO THE TOWN THAT WAS DESTROYED. HOPING THAT
SOME "BURNER" FROM THE LIST WOULD TAKE IT UPON
THEMSELVES TO TALK TO THE "MAN" SO THEY COULD MAKE THE
EFFORT LARGER.

I wrote, that's the only thing I can even imagine
someone being bothered by... and I have no reason to
believe that is a derogatory statement. In fact, I
have been told that is what attendees "go by." So....
nothing there either.

people attacking me for something I did not say. And
you, along with Peter and Sariion took an effort from
me to help out a town destroyed by flood and made it
into a HATE ON ERIC day of drama for no reason.

Save the speech on civility and tone. After stoking
the fire, as you VERY MUCH DID, don't pretend to take
the high road with a lecture about talking to people
in the correct way.

You made every effort to make it out that I was taking
a jab at Burning Man. I was asking people to help out
those in  need. ANd, yes, I assumed that people who
travel by a place every year might have some
compassion for the people there. 

Rather than attempt to back-peddle and pretend to be
on the high-road, you should ask yourself why you
thought it was a cute idea to take what I said out of
context and add your SFR status to the negativity by
questioning what MAN and USE "really" meant?

names to messages.

Eric

From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com

  "The Twilight Laser Outpost \(West\)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFR has outgrown it's usefulness to me

It seems 2008 has started off a little "hot" here on SFR...Why is everyone so hot all of sudden? 

I think that's pretty interesting in the context of Giulani ad that Ben Haus posted earlier.  Assasinations in Pakistan and confrontations with the Iranian Revolutionary Guards.  Scary times I think.  Fear and war are in the air.

FWIW, IMO, etc...I think SFR could and should be useful to discuss rave related issues, politics(!), music, and technology.  IMO there are plenty of interesting things about any/all of these areas to discuss.  personally I can't think of any other local forum where you actually could have an intellectual discussion from time to time about these topics.  I still think SFR potentially has value as that place.  

Also, while I understand Bam's sentiment here somewhat, I think the decline in usefulness of SFR is not directly related to this particular flammage.  The ongoing historical "Burning Man sucks" conversation is actually on topic for this list and therefore should be allowed to continue or flame out as the case may be with out censorship.  And while civility is nice, its not always what is happening.  Just my opinions of course.

With that all of that said, losing Bam who is one of the few peole on the list actually hosting successful events these days would suck I think.  I sincerely hope that Bam will reconsider, stay around, and help to make SFR more useful in 2008.

Peace,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
To: The Twilight Laser Outpost (West) <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, January 7, 2008 8:10:08 PM
Subject: [sfraves] SFR has outgrown it's usefulness to me

sorry, but this most recent banter is the last straw for me.  i've
been on this list a long time, since about 99 i think.  i only
unsubscribed for a few months when i was living abroad in China.

not that SFR has ever been perfect or lacked a certain element of
drama, but i have to say that i really think it's gone to pits in the
last year or so.

we talk less about music and parties, and more about our personal
gripes with each other and members of our own community.  there is so
much energy wasted on the bullshit name calling and arguing.

there are numerous other communities out there that are friendly and
open where i can talk about our shared enthusiasm for music, without
fear of starting a flame war.  i have never gotten tired of going out
and dancing my ass off to music that i love and surrounded by smiling
faces.

but i'm tired of being on this list.

to my friends, i know i'll see you around and will be in contact in
any number of ways.

goodbye SFR.  sorry to leave, but you just ain't what you used to be.

-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

----- Original Message ----
From: Ben Haus <benhaus@gmail.com>
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
Cc: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>; The Twilight Laser Outpost (West) <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, January 7, 2008 9:32:16 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFR has outgrown it's usefulness to me

Oh man, don't inject my earlier posting for the unrelenting onslaught of flaming!  I've been hoping all of this would cool down, but it continues to spread each time I check my email.  Hopefully things will start heading in a more positive direction in the coming days/weeks.  



On Jan 7, 2008 9:06 PM, <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

It seems 2008 has started off a little "hot" here on SFR...Why is everyone so hot all of sudden?

I think that's pretty interesting in the context of Giulani ad that Ben Haus posted earlier.  Assasinations in Pakistan and confrontations with the Iranian Revolutionary Guards.  Scary times I think.  Fear and war are in the air. 

FWIW, IMO, etc...I think SFR could and should be useful to discuss rave related issues, politics(!), music, and technology.  IMO there are plenty of interesting things about any/all of these areas to discuss.  personally I can't think of any other local forum where you actually could have an intellectual discussion from time to time about these topics.  I still think SFR potentially has value as that place. 

Also, while I understand Bam's sentiment here somewhat, I think the decline in usefulness of SFR is not directly related to this particular flammage.  The ongoing historical "Burning Man sucks" conversation is actually on topic for this list and therefore should be allowed to continue or flame out as the case may be with out censorship.  And while civility is nice, its not always what is happening.  Just my opinions of course. 

With that all of that said, losing Bam who is one of the few peole on the list actually hosting successful events these days would suck I think.  I sincerely hope that Bam will reconsider, stay around, and help to make SFR more useful in 2008. 

Peace,

Peter


----- Original Message ----
From: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
To: The Twilight Laser Outpost (West) < sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, January 7, 2008 8:10:08 PM
Subject: [sfraves] SFR has outgrown it's usefulness to me

sorry, but this most recent banter is the last straw for me.  i've
been on this list a long time, since about 99 i think.  i only 
unsubscribed for a few months when i was living abroad in China.

not that SFR has ever been perfect or lacked a certain element of
drama, but i have to say that i really think it's gone to pits in the
last year or so.

we talk less about music and parties, and more about our personal
gripes with each other and members of our own community.  there is so
much energy wasted on the bullshit name calling and arguing. 

there are numerous other communities out there that are friendly and
open where i can talk about our shared enthusiasm for music, without
fear of starting a flame war.  i have never gotten tired of going out 
and dancing my ass off to music that i love and surrounded by smiling
faces.

but i'm tired of being on this list.

to my friends, i know i'll see you around and will be in contact in
any number of ways. 

goodbye SFR.  sorry to leave, but you just ain't what you used to be.

--

< Brandon / DJ Bam >

In reading all the negativity that's reared its ugly head today, it seems
a good time to bring up a recent time of much more fun.  Well, that and I'm
finally recovered from all the parties. :)

Yes, awesome time.  Caught our own redstickman and Forrest banging in the new
year, much fun all over(well, I somehow missed spending much time in the
"main gallery" room, but the others, wow!)  I even enjoyed the trance room
(which happened to be the last to go silent).  Only bummer was that one DJ
laptop disappeared, does anyone know if it ever turned up?  If not, I think
it'd be great for everyone who showed to chip in to help replace.  The guy
worked NYE for us, and someone apparently decided it was ok to take advantage.

Ray

> Usually, this happens when you just hit the "reply" button.
> If this does not work, simply copy the address and paste it into
> the "To:" field of a new message.
>
> or click here:
> mailto:sfraves-uc.1199774266.eanmjhamejkkpejllnem-grindingbassline=hotmail.com@hyperreal.org
>
> I haven't checked whether your address is currently on the mailing list.
> To see what address you used to subscribe, look at the messages you are
> receiving from the mailing list. Each message has your address hidden
> inside its return path; for example, mary@xdd.ff.com receives messages
> with return path: <sfraves-return-<number>-mary=xdd.ff.com@hyperreal.org.
>
> Some mail programs are broken and cannot handle long addresses. If you
> cannot reply to this request, instead send a message to
> <sfraves-request@hyperreal.org> and put the entire address listed above
> into the "Subject:" line.
>
>
> --- Administrative commands for the sfraves list ---
>
> I can handle administrative requests automatically. Please
> do not send them to the list address! Instead, send
> your message to the correct command address:

> To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
>   <sfraves-subscribe@hyperreal.org>
>
> To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
>   <sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
>
> Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
>   <sfraves-info@hyperreal.org>
>   <sfraves-faq@hyperreal.org>
>
> Similar addresses exist for the digest list:
>   <sfraves-digest-subscribe@hyperreal.org>
>   <sfraves-digest-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
>
> To get messages 123 through 145 (a maximum of 100 per request), mail:
>   <sfraves-get.123_145@hyperreal.org>
>
> To get an index with subject and author for messages 123-456 , mail:
>   <sfraves-index.123_456@hyperreal.org>
>
> They are always returned as sets of 100, max 2000 per request,
> so you'll actually get 100-499.
>
> To receive all messages with the same subject as message 12345,
> send an empty message to:
>   <sfraves-thread.12345@hyperreal.org>
>
> The messages do not really need to be empty, but I will ignore
> their content. Only the ADDRESS you send to is important.
>
> You can start a subscription for an alternate address,
> for example "john@host.domain", just add a hyphen and your
> address (with '=' instead of '@') after the command word:
> <sfraves-subscribe-john=host.domain@hyperreal.org>
>
> To stop subscription for this address, mail:
> <sfraves-unsubscribe-john=host.domain@hyperreal.org>
>
> In both cases, I'll send a confirmation message to that address. When
> you receive it, simply reply to it to complete your subscription.
>
> If despite following these instructions, you do not get the
> desired results, please contact my owner at
> sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org. Please be patient, my owner is a
> lot slower than I am ;-)
>
> --- Enclosed is a copy of the request I received.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFR has outgrown it's usefulness to me

------=_Part_9597_2090988.1199777785762
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I'd hate to add anything into the fray, but this is an *internet *mailing
list. There is no need to ruin your day over something written by someone
that you don't even know. If the (or any other for that matter) list doesn't
meet your expectations, then perhaps tell people (politely, mind you) that
you have a problem. If it continues to fall short of expectations, then
maybe consider leaving. It may be a little unnecessary to write an angry,
whiny goodbye message. I think if people wanted to know why someone left,
they would ask. The action speaks for itself.

Also, if something that someone writes on an *internet* mailing list
emotionally troubles you, then it may not be something that you'd enjoy.
Although speaking from personal experiences, this mailing list ranks low on
my drama continuum; there are many worse places on the internet.

Lastly, and I speak for myself when I say this: drama is not a problem
(especially on the internet). If someone tries to provoke you or just types
plain stupid stuff, then I just either ignore it or type a reply. If the
provoking continues despite my best efforts to express myself, then I just
leave the discussion. Drama is not a problem.
