From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: Mark <vileru@gmail.com>, Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <925664.70208.qm@web32414.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFR has outgrown it's usefulness to me

All good points, but often easier said than done.  Sometimes something that someone writes on a mailing list gets under your skin or is simply so tiresome you feel the need to respond.  That's OK, just remember its a mailing list as Mark points out.  Respond when you have to but don't take it personally.  

And you can easily set up rules to ignore or delete messages from people that just annoy you too much.  Back on the WELL we used to call them "bozo filters" which I think is a good name for them.

I really don't like to do this very often myself because it can destroy the continuity of a conversation, but I've unfortunately had to set up rules to ignore postings from two people here on SFR that frankly just irritate me too much.  I don't blame them FWIW, I just prefer not to hear anything these two individuals have to say.  That's my choice.  One of them is a recent addition; I suspect you all know who he is.  

Now I never even see anything either of these people post unless someone else reposts it.  I am much happier without any drama and I still get the information (party reviews, Apollo and NYC's posts, BSPs, etc.)  and random shit from everyone else that I want. 

So set up a bozo filter if you have to, or leave if you want to, but don't let it get you down either way.  

Happy 2008!

Regards,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Mark <vileru@gmail.com>
To: Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, January 7, 2008 11:36:25 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFR has outgrown it's usefulness to me

I'd hate to add anything into the fray, but this is an *internet *mailing
list. There is no need to ruin your day over something written by someone
that you don't even know. If the (or any other for that matter) list doesn't
meet your expectations, then perhaps tell people (politely, mind you) that
you have a problem. If it continues to fall short of expectations, then
maybe consider leaving. It may be a little unnecessary to write an angry,
whiny goodbye message. I think if people wanted to know why someone left,
they would ask. The action speaks for itself.

Also, if something that someone writes on an *internet* mailing list
emotionally troubles you, then it may not be something that you'd enjoy.
Although speaking from personal experiences, this mailing list ranks low on
my drama continuum; there are many worse places on the internet.

Lastly, and I speak for myself when I say this: drama is not a problem
(especially on the internet). If someone tries to provoke you or just types
plain stupid stuff, then I just either ignore it or type a reply. If the
provoking continues despite my best efforts to express myself, then I just
leave the discussion. Drama is not a problem.

Subject: [sfraves] SFR List drama

Well, for once I'm at a loss for words.

There's really no sense in moderating anything, since the 
daggers have already been thrown, so I guess we just let the 
list run its course, and cool-off.

Eric got his answer with Stickman's post:

http://www.burnerswithoutborders.org/global-action/bay-area-bwb/fernley-levee-break

So yes, they are mobilizing in assistance to the town they use 
en route to BM.

It saddens me to see negative discourse like this, because I 
believe in all of you, and the potential of this list. But if 
you guys want to fight, or bail on the list, I really can't stop 
you.

We've weathered worse, and there are certainly better ways to 
channel our emotions. But we're all adults here, so you guys 
figure this one out, or not.

-terry

Holt Sorenson <hso@hsomusic.com> wrote: BigLove with Jack Wang - Today from 3PM-6PM PST
-----------------------------------------------

This week, guest DJs Amit Shoham, DJ Durben, and Homero
Espinosa will be serving up house music to keep you bumpin.

Amit Shoham is a well know Bay Area DJ/producer and one of the
founders of record label Tarantic Records and has many releases
to his name. More information at Amit can be found at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/sh/C

DJ Durben has been a member of the SF scene and has laid down sets
in the underground and at clubs such as 1015 Folsom, The Sound Factory,
Peach, The Rouge and TempleSF. DJ Durben has recently began producing
tracks as well. More information about DJ Durben can be found at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/sh/A

Homero Espinosa is a DJ/Producer that is currently signed with Yerba
Buena Discos and recently had one of his tracks licensed for release
on Mark Farina's upcoming mix cd on Ministry of Sound. You can
read more about Homero Espinosa at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/sh/B


Eclecktronik Groove with Holt Sorenson - Tonight from 12AM-3AM PST
------------------------------------------------------------------

Tune into another great live set sent over the airwaves and wires
with KZSU resident Holt Sorenson. You can check out Holt's mixes and previous
shows at:
http://www.hsomusic.com/mixes/

If you're looking for his guest mix from Epiphany of Sound or Big Love,
it has recently been posted at the site above.

Next week, Holt will host DJ Frankie Jr. on his show. More information
about DJ Frankie Jr. can be found at:
http://hsomusic.com/sh/D
http://hsomusic.com/sh/9

You can check out his promo mix here:
http://hsomusic.com/sh/8


Epiphany of Sound with J.C. - Thursday the 10th from 9AM-12PM PST
-----------------------------------------------------------------

J.C. will host Ruoho Ruotsi, a local techno DJ/producer whose projects
draw upon the visceral aesthetics of dub, techno, garage and the
impractical rhythmical leitmotifs of experimental electro-acoustics,
fusing them into imaginative new musical opportunities.

bio:
http://www.defchild.com/releases.php?id=ruohobio

sets & livepa:
http://www.defchild.com/music.html

discogs:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Ruoho+Ruotsi

reviews:
http://www.defchild.com/reviews.html

links:
http://www.myspace.com/ruohoruotsi


As always, you can tune in to KZSU on 90.1 on your FM dial or browse
to http://kzsulive.stanford.edu/

--
Holt Sorenson/Eclektronik Groove
hso@hsomusic.com

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

I wanted to apologize.  Although I don't feel my actions were unjust I
realized I caused more harm than I should have by feeding the trolls and/or
baiters.  In essence, yes, I took the bait, I really should have just left
things alone.  I won't go naming names, I just realized that as just as I
believe my actions were, I was immature by bringing myself down to the level
of the baiter/s.  As Terry said, we're all adults, and I've realized that
perhaps my actions, while provoked, were rather childish, and I would like
to formally apologize.

------=_Part_3837_10947338.1199832213908--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Hey Burners....

I always laugh at the wrong things but... you know me :)

 From the site:

"There's talk of a work weekend this weekend, to get a lot of people  
on site helping at once. It's too cold from what I understand for  
people to stay in travel trailers, so folks may end up in a hotel-"

Excuse me?  People who go out in to the desert for a week voluntarily,  
now think it's "too cold to stay in a trailer"?
...
BWAHAHAHHAHAHAHAHAH!

Ok well- I'm sure you all must know what willpower of mine it took to  
stay out of "Eric Spire 2008 - Jews Did 9/11".

And I'd really like to write diatribes about how donating a bit of  
something you've got an incredible surplus of isn't really admirable  
in the holistic "self sacrifice" sense, or about how constantly  
talking about doing so actually exposes some very deep issues about  
how one draws their own self-worth, or about the simple witnessing of  
the greatest display of backpedaling I've ever seen- so severe that it  
re-machined the hub and the bike now works in reverse!
But yeah- I'm just not going to.

Eric- you're good friends with people I consider good friends.  People  
who I think are good guys, and who think I'm a good guy too- and they  
think you're a good guy.  So by proxy, I think you're a good guy too-  
and I chalk this up to temporary insanity :)
I'll buy you a gin and tonic should we ever meet in person.

Since that fateful day when I made a solemn vow to myself a while back  
to not respond to anything political on this list, I've found myself  
with little to say and absolutely nothing to glean- so I think I'll do  
the unsub dance as well.
I'm off to this new thing called My Space or something- it's more than  
a mailing list- you can create your own page and change the colors  
around and stuff.  And meet new friends and send them messages.

-N7

interesting flame war.  get out and get some sun, everyone.

i want to present, or perhaps re-present something, that i've  
mentioned before, and i'm trying to search for the link but i know  
you can go to sites like devvy.com to do research, anyway, 100% of  
your income tax dollars go to pay interest on the national debt, not  
to pay for roads, or the military, or socialized medicine, or to bail  
out mexico, etc.  you have a host of other taxes to pay for that  
stuff, gas tax for the roads, which leads to the question of why do  
we have toll roads *at all* ... and not to mention the general hidden  
tax called inflation ...

WITH ALL THAT SAID i think supporting the people of Fernley, NV and  
keeping the government and their evil lead infested FEMA trailers out  
of there is a damn good idea and i'll consider giving even though  
i've never been to burning man and you'll likely never see me at  
one.  no offense to the burners, it's just probably not for me and i  
am pretty sure i know that.

now why don't we all cool off with a nice 'Coke vs. Pepsi' thread?   
personally i've been getting into jarritos!

Yeah, like we need more of our money going to the defense budget; or the
immediate need to eliminate young people dancing at nighttime. I'm surprised
that his position in the primaries has been right next to Ron Paul; that's
an embarrassment.

Heh, I wish the elections were done in a way different than a nationwide
vote. Maybe this is selfish, but I have a problem with the populace - who
mostly get their information from Fox News or any other tv news for that
matter - choosing the guy that will be the top official of this nation.
Honestly, if you go and ask some people why they like their candidate of
choice, most of their replies will be based on their *feelings* towards
them. "I respect his values," or some crap like that. Great! Let's elect our
president based on our feelings, rather than logical reasons and the
person's past history. No wonder Bush got elected... TWICE.

FLAME ON!

On Jan 8, 2008 7:25 AM, <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

> All good points, but often easier said than done.  Sometimes something
> that someone writes on a mailing list gets under your skin or is simply so
> tiresome you feel the need to respond.  That's OK, just remember its a
> mailing list as Mark points out.  Respond when you have to but don't take it
> personally.
>
> And you can easily set up rules to ignore or delete messages from people
> that just annoy you too much.  Back on the WELL we used to call them "bozo
> filters" which I think is a good name for them.
>
> I really don't like to do this very often myself because it can destroy
> the continuity of a conversation, but I've unfortunately had to set up rules
> to ignore postings from two people here on SFR that frankly just irritate me
> too much.  I don't blame them FWIW, I just prefer not to hear anything these
> two individuals have to say.  That's my choice.  One of them is a recent
> addition; I suspect you all know who he is.
>
> Now I never even see anything either of these people post unless someone
> else reposts it.  I am much happier without any drama and I still get the
> information (party reviews, Apollo and NYC's posts, BSPs, etc.)  and random
> shit from everyone else that I want.
>
> So set up a bozo filter if you have to, or leave if you want to, but don't
> let it get you down either way.
>
> Happy 2008!
>
> Regards,
>
> Peter
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Mark <vileru@gmail.com>

> Sent: Monday, January 7, 2008 11:36:25 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFR has outgrown it's usefulness to me

> I'd hate to add anything into the fray, but this is an *internet *mailing
> list. There is no need to ruin your day over something written by someone
> that you don't even know. If the (or any other for that matter) list
> doesn't
> meet your expectations, then perhaps tell people (politely, mind you) that
> you have a problem. If it continues to fall short of expectations, then
> maybe consider leaving. It may be a little unnecessary to write an angry,
> whiny goodbye message. I think if people wanted to know why someone left,
> they would ask. The action speaks for itself.
>
> Also, if something that someone writes on an *internet* mailing list
> emotionally troubles you, then it may not be something that you'd enjoy.
> Although speaking from personal experiences, this mailing list ranks low
> on
> my drama continuum; there are many worse places on the internet.
>
> Lastly, and I speak for myself when I say this: drama is not a problem
> (especially on the internet). If someone tries to provoke you or just
> types
> plain stupid stuff, then I just either ignore it or type a reply. If the
> provoking continues despite my best efforts to express myself, then I just
> leave the discussion. Drama is not a problem.
>

Would you consider the personalities of a candidate's followers as
reasonable support for favoring another candidate? I don't see the
connection...

Back to Kucinich though: I haven't found any credible dirt on him. There was
an attempted recall of him when he was mayor of Cleveland, but it seems like
the recall was launched by his opponents for malicious reasons. Anyone want
to convince me otherwise?

*On 9 January 2008, Marco wrote:

> Why is it that the vast majority of "Libertarian" candidated always come
> across as right-wingers that use the pro-pot agenda to appeal to the left?
>
> Maybe it's just me, but there hasn't been one single Libertarian candidate
> that has been worthwhile thus far (in ANY campaign).

*The Libertarian stance has gained support because people are realizing that
we waste incredible amounts of money in our government. A massive portion of
our spending goes to *administration.* Our government's system of paperwork
and approvals is horrendously outdated and impractical. I don't necessarily
endorse Paul, nor do I plan on voting for him; but he has brought up
significant points on many major problems within our government.

Mark <vileru@gmail.com> wrote: Would you consider the personalities of a candidate's followers as
reasonable support for favoring another candidate? I don't see the
connection...

Back to Kucinich though: I haven't found any credible dirt on him. There was
an attempted recall of him when he was mayor of Cleveland, but it seems like
the recall was launched by his opponents for malicious reasons. Anyone want
to convince me otherwise?

*On 9 January 2008, Marco wrote:

> Why is it that the vast majority of "Libertarian" candidated always come
> across as right-wingers that use the pro-pot agenda to appeal to the left?
>
> Maybe it's just me, but there hasn't been one single Libertarian candidate
> that has been worthwhile thus far (in ANY campaign).

*The Libertarian stance has gained support because people are realizing that
we waste incredible amounts of money in our government. A massive portion of
our spending goes to *administration.* Our government's system of paperwork
and approvals is horrendously outdated and impractical. I don't necessarily
endorse Paul, nor do I plan on voting for him; but he has brought up
significant points on many major problems within our government.

On Jan 9, 2008 2:04 PM,  wrote:

> conversation.  No offence to any Paul supporters here, I am refering to some
> people I've met at events, handing out his literature, etc.
>
> Regardless of the merits of his ideas Mr. Paul has some very strange folks
> supporting him.
>
> Peter

I've noticed that the TV pundits keeping jabbing at his UFO sighting;
implying that he's some wacko. The problem is that whenever people hear UFO
they associate the term with flying saucers and aliens, which is not the
case. Unidentified Flying Object: that's all it means. If you've ever looked
up at the sky and said, "Hey, what's that in the air?" then congratulations,
you've seen a UFO.

Anyways, I'm curious as to why you wouldn't vote for him; would you mind
sharing?

I absolutely look at a candidates supporters as part of my decision process.  After all, the candidates supporters are the one's financing his or her candidacy.  Follow the money as they say.

Maybe its just me, but I want to know who they are, why they support the candidate, and also what exactly they actually believe in.  

E.g. http://www.davidduke.com/general/3339_3339.html

Would you consider the personalities of a candidate's followers as
reasonable support for favoring another candidate? I don't see the
connection...

Back to Kucinich though: I haven't found any credible dirt on him. There was
an attempted recall of him when he was mayor of Cleveland, but it seems like
the recall was launched by his opponents for malicious reasons. Anyone want
to convince me otherwise?

*On 9 January 2008, Marco wrote:

> Why is it that the vast majority of "Libertarian" candidated always come
> across as right-wingers that use the pro-pot agenda to appeal to the left?
>
> Maybe it's just me, but there hasn't been one single Libertarian candidate
> that has been worthwhile thus far (in ANY campaign).

*The Libertarian stance has gained support because people are realizing that
we waste incredible amounts of money in our government. A massive portion of
our spending goes to *administration.* Our government's system of paperwork
and approvals is horrendously outdated and impractical. I don't necessarily
endorse Paul, nor do I plan on voting for him; but he has brought up
significant points on many major problems within our government.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Mark [mailto:vileru@gmail.com]
> Sent: Wednesday, January 09, 2008 9:57 AM
> To: Marco
> Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Giuliani TV Ad
> 
> Paul isn't exactly my candidate of choice, but his platform is light-years
> ahead of Giuliani's. Name me a better candidate on the Republican side,
and
> explain why and maybe you can convince me.

Final Nails in the Ron Paul Campaign Coffin

By STEVEN ARGUE
 
Since I wrote the article:

The Ron Paul "Revolution", an Extreme Rightwing Threat
http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2008/01/05/18470186.php

New information has surfaced regarding Ron Paul's pro-fascist agenda.

That information is discussed in the following January 7, 2008 MSNBC
interview conducted by Tucker Carlson with the New Republic's Jamie
Kirchick.  In it he gives an inside look into his controversial piece on
presidential candidate Rep. Ron Paul, R-Texas, due to hit newsstands on
Friday. 

http://antironpaul.com/

The following are newly released copies of Ron Paul's extreme right
newsletter to which Jamie Kirchick refers:

http://www.tnr.com/downloads/March1990.pdf
http://www.tnr.com/downloads/January91.pdf
http://www.tnr.com/downloads/October1990.pdf
http://www.tnr.com/downloads/June1990.pdf
http://www.tnr.com/downloads/August1990.pdf

In addition to these revelations, in New Hampshire Ron Paul also failed to
repeat anything close to the 10% vote he achieved in Iowa.

Somewhat surprisingly, there are a large number of liberal minded anti-war
people who have urged a vote for Ron Paul. 

They are liberal "support the lesser viable evil" types that see Ron Paul as
more viable than any anti-war Democrat (arguably Kucinich and Gravel). 

Additional questions have always existed if Ron Paul really was viable, or
if he really was a lesser evil.  New Hampshire and the latest revelations
ought to put both questions to rest. 

But for me there are always more important questions than if a candidate is
viable or a "lesser evil". I think that building a long-term movement for
real change is much more important than backing a candidate of any degree of
evil. For me that includes deflating illusions in the corporate politicians
of the Democrat and Republican Parties, getting out information on
candidates to the left of the Democrats (the real anti-war and
anti-corporate candidates), and urging further actions such as protests,
strikes etc.

Simply put, there is nobody worth supporting in the racist, sexist,
homophobic, anti-worker, anti-poor, and capitalist Republican Party.  Never
has been, never will be.  Get over it.  In fact, there is nobody in the
corporate Democrat and Republican Parties that are worth supporting.  I
discuss some of the candidates that may be worth supporting in the following
article:

The Case for Socialized Medicine in the United States, 
And the Struggle to Achieve It 
By STEVEN ARGUE 
http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2008/01/02/18469739.php
 
And just for fun, here's the Ron Paul Time Machine!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7884Z6-FiMY

"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Content-Disposition: inline

I saw the expository on MSNBC yesterday, but I wasn't too quick to accept it
as absolute truth, since the verbal evidence they provided was lacking. They
threw sound-bites around that didn't provide concrete evidence, so I was
skeptical. I haven't read the links in your message yet, so I can't make a
thought-out response just yet.

But even if his agenda may be corrupt, the issues that he raised are still
legitimate. The points he made about government administration expenses are
still true. And his opinion that Middle Eastern aggression is probably due
to our involvement there since the 50s is still probably more true than the
ridiculous claims by the other Republican candidates, that say the
aggression is due to things like jealousy or a hatred of freedom.

Now a bit of my personal opinion: Paul is not electable. His platform
wouldn't stand a chance in the federal government; our Congress would never
vote to abolish the income tax, or eliminate several government agencies.
Not to mention, his platform would screw over a lot of people. Abolishing
the income tax and eliminating agencies would easily cut thousands of jobs.
His platform is entirely impractical, and far too idealistic; it would
require an entirely new federal government.

Despite the fact that I do not* *support Ron Paul, I think he has certainly
brought important issues into the presidential race. I mention him because
of these important issues he has shed light on, and not because I have any
admiration of him.

> Somewhat surprisingly, there are a large number of liberal minded anti-war

>

> as
> more viable than any anti-war Democrat (arguably Kucinich and Gravel).
>
> Additional questions have always existed if Ron Paul really was viable, or
> if he really was a lesser evil.  New Hampshire and the latest revelations
> ought to put both questions to rest.
>
> But for me there are always more important questions than if a candidate
> is
> viable or a "lesser evil". I think that building a long-term movement for

> of
> evil. For me that includes deflating illusions in the corporate
> politicians
> of the Democrat and Republican Parties, getting out information on
> candidates to the left of the Democrats (the real anti-war and
> anti-corporate candidates), and urging further actions such as protests,
> strikes etc.
>
> Simply put, there is nobody worth supporting in the racist, sexist,
> homophobic, anti-worker, anti-poor, and capitalist Republican Party.
>  Never

If tweakers and zombies happen to vote for strong candidates that are
qualified for leading a nation, then that would just be a coincidence that
I'd ignore. Just because a certain group leans towards a person does not
provide justifiable evidence about that person's character. Just in my life
experience, I've associated with plenty of people that I do not necessarily
agree with, yet no one has accused me of advocating their opinions. To judge
someone by those who accompany them is stereotyping... (you've all heard
birds of a feather etc).

P.S. Please note, I'm speaking in generalities and I'm not trying to
advocate Paul with the comment.

What do you mean when you say "traits?"

Anyways, I would never make a decision based on the persons someone
associates with; ALTHOUGH I would consider their allegiances a clue. If you
go anywhere online - especially youtube - it's painfully obvious that a lot
of Paul fans want to shove Paul's ideology down people's throats, and anyone
that questions his ideals is subject to one-liners like the ones presented
in this video: http://youtube.com/watch?v=tW4b7_JBe5E

By watching youtube, it becomes clear that many of his supporters lack
debate skills; ALTHOUGH you cannot possibly push a blanket summary onto all
his supporters due to anecdotal evidence. Every candidate has crackpot
supporters... every candidate. I wasn't expecting to push forth this much of
my opinion in this discussion, but I think we might be onto a good
discussion...

P.S. I reviewed the previous links about Paul's racist/fascist/etc. history,
and it's clear that the accusations are true, which is disappointing (no,
not because I secretly support him, but because it's disappointing when any
public representative fails those that he/she represents). However, it
should be noted that there is no perfect, unblemished candidate. I just
found information on some very questionable stances and votes made by
Kucinich; if anyone is interested, then send me a private message and I'll
email you the link. However, I still favor Kucinich as my candidate of
choice thus far.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFR has outgrown it's usefulness to me

Ya know... i do agree with Brandon actually... i mean.. i remember many
times in the like the past 2-3 years when things started changing & like
people weren't so posty about their weekends really or the music &
everything slowly started becoming like a mondo NRR bitchfest yada yada
Hello 2Day... i mean.. I reemember when Lara & Leslie used to get mad @ me
all the time when i used to like post NNR stuff about my laundry etc...

But seriously y'all... yeah,  i hella miss the old school days of when we
used to like be all about who what where when & how & stuff.. I mean... i
was really proud to be part of SFR 'cause ya know how like I mean... we
used to have this hella mondo unity & we were "the list" that if you were
on, then i mean... you got respect from people.. I know i did 'cause I was
well.. 1 of the things that people I'd meet, there were all "YOu're Osby
from SFR" & SFR was always the CoOL  thing 'cause of what we stood for!!! 
Like now when someone says "You're Osby from SFR"... sometimes I'm like
partly embarrassed 'cause of what the list is now, but still try to hold
on to some pride for the nostalgia that it holds I guess...

I mean.. maybe it got way to family on here that people just got
comfortable???  But it doesn't take alot to also post about the music
stuff too.. right???  I'm on enough like NRR boards & lists that i really
don't need the list that started it for me to like become 1 of those too.

Well... my 2 cents... I still <3 SFR.. but yeah... we need to like not
have every thread become this Vlad Feelgood flame war!!  OK???

I mean.. some of you even like would tell me irl that you would go on this
list just to be an asshole like you were on all the other hyperreal lists
& ya know... it was probablyu funny @ the time.. but seeing you act this
way is hella disheartening man 'cause it seems like you care more about
fuckin' drama than you do music :(

Subject: [sfraves] I feel you, Osby

Just remember why we're all on this list.  The music, the ability to dance 
to it, and why we all became friends to begin with.

All these noob school shit-talkers who are turning some old residents off to 
the list ... well, there's an answer to that.  Delete their posts and don't 
allow it to cloud your opinion of the soul of SFR.

With that, it doesn't matter a whole hell of a lot what happens on this list 
because the vast majority of us see each other at the same parties.

*shrug*  I'm guessing the people who are angsty don't know about them so 
we're all pretty safe.

love always

I will be signing autographs in San Francisco this weekend, probably =20
at that coffee place, what is it called, I think Bean There, around =20

butts over there.  No, I'm kidding, I will probably be there though =20
it's a pretty convenient place and lower Haight I've found is less =20
congested than upper.

By the way, I still haven't found a place, though I am enjoying the =20
Comfort Inn for a few nights here in Santa Cruz, they have the outdoor =20
pool here turned up god awfully high, at least 85 degrees, if not 90, =20
it's actually hotter than the hot tub, believe it or not.  I went for =20
a swim yesterday like 3 times, I gotta get me a house with one of =20
these.  And a garage so I can do the maintenance on my cars.  Did you =20
know that doing your own car maintenance is not that difficult?  I've =20
gotten to the point where I don't want some pimple faced kid even =20
changing my tires, they don't even check for proper inflation.  And =20
proper rotation ... well I notice a lot of people don't rotate their =20
tires.  Back to inflation, it says right on my drivers side door what =20
to inflate them to.  34 in the front, 42 in the rear.  So I want =20
everyone, right now, to go out to their cars, and check the inflation, =20
when the tires are cold, and did you rotate them at 3 or 5000 miles.

Anyway, that's enough I'm just rambling on.  I've got to go read stuff =20
for class.  Maybe see you soon.

--

So 20 years ago, 1 in 25,000 children had autism.  Now it's 1 in 75, 2 =20
years ago it was 1 in 168.  The media then tries to spin it and say =20
it's overdiagnosis.  Oh really?  When I went to public school, there =20
was maybe one autistic child in my school, I had been invited to speak =20
at high schools and middle schools, and I've got families that have =20
kids that go to school, they've now got whole classrooms for autistic =20
children, not just special ed, I take my children to a movie, =20
Ratatouille, they have row after row of the autistic children, they're =20
just everywhere.  You see them everywhere.  You see them at the hike =20
and bike trail.  You see them at the shopping mall.  You see them at =20
the gym.  You see them being wheeled around, these poor kids.

You'll be on vacation, with a woman and two of her children who both =20
have it, and I say, "when did your child become autistic?"  "Oh, well =20
Jimmy was just fine until 18 months" and I say "after the shots?" and =20
she says "yea, he had a siezure.  They think it might be the shots."

Oh, gee, I wonder?

- Alex Jones, Alex Jones Radio Show, 1/8/08

--0-672820993-1199990534=:26976
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

First off, you should go into preferences > advanced > import and select the type of encoding you want Itunes to do when you import.  I believe the default is the Apple proprietary format, I usually change it to wave.

Then, doesn't it just pop you up with an import dialog when you insert a CD?  Or have some check boxes next to each track, and maybe an "Import" button on the File menu?

>From there, I'm sorry, if you can't figure out how to get your music onto Itunes I can't really help you. :)

Anyone have a direction to point me in?

THANKS IN ADVANCE!!!

PLUR...bitches.

- Marco

  First off, you should go into preferences > advanced > import and =
select the type of encoding you want Itunes to do when you import.  I =
believe the default is the Apple proprietary format, I usually change it =
to wave.

  Then, doesn't it just pop you up with an import dialog when you insert =
a CD?  Or have some check boxes next to each track, and maybe an =
"Import" button on the File menu?

  From there, I'm sorry, if you can't figure out how to get your music =
onto Itunes I can't really help you. :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Giuliani TV Ad

I'm not on a really fast internet connection, so I will have to look  
at all these Ron Paul is a racist links later on.  But even with that  
said, I wouldn't believe a word of what MSNBC and Tucker Carlson, who  
apparently tried to say Ron Paul got donations from a brothel, when  
it was him with some hookers or something I'm not sure of the whole  
story there either.  I've been on the road a lot.

But what I am hearing about but apparently the entire mainstream liar  
for hire media establishment is not covering is there is serious  
evidence of election fraud in New Hampshire and that both Barack  
Obama and Ron Paul got screwed out of higher ranking places.  There  
was a town where an entire family voted for Ron Paul and the city  
recorded no votes for him.  There is a private citizen ready to pay  
the money for a full recount of the entire state to find out if this  
is an isolated incident or if it's more widespread.

Also, it's coming out, and this is documented, that the company  
responsible for the electronic voting machines in New Hampshire is  
directed by a convicted drug dealer.  And this is not the first case  
of Diebold hiring convicted felons to run the voting machines.  I  
don't know about you but I'd rather know that hardened criminals are  
not in the business of handling our votes.  They could elect Dick  
Cheney President for all I care as long as it's a goddamn fair  
election.  And we don't have that in our country right now, we  
actually haven't in years, and it's time people start making noise to  
change it, because it's only going to get worse.

Well that's my .02 you all know I can ramble on forever but I want to  
give other people a chance to speak.

> for hire media establishment is not covering is there is serious 
> evidence of election fraud in New Hampshire and that both Barack Obama 
> and Ron Paul got screwed out of higher ranking places.  There was a 
> town where an entire family voted for Ron Paul and the city recorded 
> no votes for him.  There is a private citizen ready to pay the money 
> for a full recount of the entire state to find out if this is an 
> isolated incident or if it's more widespread.
>

> responsible for the electronic voting machines in New Hampshire is 
> directed by a convicted drug dealer.  And this is not the first case 
> of Diebold hiring convicted felons to run the voting machines.  I 
> don't know about you but I'd rather know that hardened criminals are 
> not in the business of handling our votes.  They could elect Dick 
> Cheney President for all I care as long as it's a goddamn fair 
> election.  And we don't have that in our country right now, we

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Giuliani TV Ad

Cosmo Kramer, please.

Just because you dismiss this extensively well researched documentation 
published in William F. Buckley's National Review, (the Nation's leading 
Conservative Journal, for decades, btw), of Dr. Paul's racist, sexist, 
homophobic, paranoid, newsletters as "old crap", (despite it being Hot 
Off The Presses Brand New), that you say has the amount of thought going 
into preparing them as being practically nil, doesn't necessarily make 
it so.

Whatever.

But nice try. I admire your spirit, moxie, and unwillingness to go down 
without a fight, no matter how flawed your thinking, and refusal to face 
basic reality, is.

OK, let's assume that you're right, and the Good Doctor doesn't have a 
racist bone in his body, and he wants all of America's Black, Red, 
Brown, Yellow, male and female, Pick-A-Ninnie Peoples to go as far as 
his or her talents and abilities will take them.

Sure, I can do that, but then, because I'm confused and I just 
understand something here, so help a a brother out and please, please, 
riddle me this...

How is it that of all the candidates in this field it's The Doctor that 
is attracting the highest amount of psycho, crazy, White Supremacist, 
Nazi, Neo-Nazi and KKK leaders and followers with a significant amount 
of them contributing cold hard cash to his campaign?

What's up with that?

Say what you want, but generally where there is smoke there is fire, y'know.

And The Nile is *just* a river in Egypt, and Global Warming is a 
complete myth and fairy tale.

I don't know how up to speed you are on your Ayn Rand aphorisms, but 
this seems to be a clear-cut, classic, text-book case of having to:

"Go back and check your premises."

As far as "the People waking up" goes, you must be high.

Less than 5% of all eligible voters have even bothered to watch any of 
either the Republican or Democratic Debates on the TV and it's doubtful 
that that number is going to significantly increase, and even if it 
does, most Americans don't and won't vote anyways.

Voter turn-out in 2004 was 60% and in 2006 a paltry 40%.

They've been lulled to sleep with their lousy, heinously over-priced, 
American educations, cable TV, The Sisters Spears, anti-depressant 
medications, mortgage and credit card debt, crap, dead-end service 
industry jobs and all the other life shit that keeps them running on the 
hamster wheel to even begin to be able to pay attention to any of this shit.

Come this November, the election is not going to be decided by any 
defining issue but by who runs the best commercials that are going to 
running non-stop on the TV, the Great American Experiment of Democracy 
is dead and finished, and the quicker that reality is embraced the 
quicker a way out will present itself, but I guarantee you that it won't 
be Doctor Paul that will lead the vanguard of that particular revolution.

You can take that one to the bank.

Again, thanks for playing, the entertainment value that Ron Paul has 
brought to "the process" this election cycle has been priceless.  :-P

....

The facts that you provide are true, and I can't disagree with them.
However, there are voters that do take an active role in the election
process, and they should not be discredited by a blanket statement. I'm not
going to vote for Ron Paul; but now I am more concerned than before about
how the candidates plan to deal with deficit spending and administration
costs.

Not that it matters anyhow. A president can have a great platform, but if
Congress doesn't like it, then there's no chance that any of that will
happen. How many presidents have actually carried out the platform that got
them elected? You can't just elect a president and think that that will fix
everything; there's also a Congress in Washington...

Democracy is broken. It is not the servant; it is now the slave.

>> outdoor
>> pool here turned up god awfully high, at least 85 degrees, if not 90,
>> it's actually hotter than the hot tub, believe it or not.  I went for
>> a swim yesterday like 3 times, I gotta get me a house with one of
>> these.  And a garage so I can do the maintenance on my cars.  Did you
>> know that doing your own car maintenance is not that difficult?  I've
>> gotten to the point where I don't want some pimple faced kid even
>> changing my tires, they don't even check for proper inflation.  And
>> proper rotation ... well I notice a lot of people don't rotate their
>> tires.  Back to inflation, it says right on my drivers side door what
>> to inflate them to.  34 in the front, 42 in the rear.  So I want
>> everyone, right now, to go out to their cars, and check the  
>> inflation,
>> when the tires are cold, and did you rotate them at 3 or 5000 miles.
>>
>> Anyway, that's enough I'm just rambling on.  I've got to go read  
>> stuff
>> for class.  Maybe see you soon.
>>

>>
>> So 20 years ago, 1 in 25,000 children had autism.  Now it's 1 in  
>> 75, 2
>> years ago it was 1 in 168.  The media then tries to spin it and say

>> was maybe one autistic child in my school, I had been invited to  
>> speak
>> at high schools and middle schools, and I've got families that have
>> kids that go to school, they've now got whole classrooms for autistic
>> children, not just special ed, I take my children to a movie,
>> Ratatouille, they have row after row of the autistic children,  
>> they're
>> just everywhere.  You see them everywhere.  You see them at the hike
>> and bike trail.  You see them at the shopping mall.  You see them at

I haven't heard Frances Moore Lappe do any interviews in a while, but  
she feels similarly, that is we live in a thin democracy, where  
people think they can show up every 4 years, vote, and that's it.   
Then they wonder why police run around tasering everyone and breaking  
into the wrong houses and shooting 90 year old women to death that  
hadn't done anything wrong.

If anyone can show me another candidate for President, however, that  
will get us out of the Iraq war and say no to more spending of my  
money and they have the voting record to prove they've done this in  
the past, I'll consider voting for someone besides Ron Paul.  Dennis  
Kucinich from what I've heard likes gun control, you all know how I  
feel about that already, I've already stated my opinions about  
Ghouliani, and I used to be misinformed about the Clintons, but  
thanks to the internet I am much more informed and see right through  
their little game.

>>>>> Cheney President for all I care as long as it's a goddamn fair

Hey Guys and Gals,

I am really enjoying the more "pltkl" discussion now taking place on this
list - and with the "interesting" times ahead, and I'd hate to see some of
the vibrant conversers go by the wayside if they opt to not stay here due
to inner-squabbling and or, lame-ass personal attacks, or your fetish for
rss feeds.

Soooo, in light of that, I'm wondering if there might be interest in the
formation of new list or subset of SFR that is solely for the purpose of
ripe insights around the p-word. I think with a few basic rules of conduct
and guidelines, it could be fun and hell, maybe something
worthwhile...outside techno, of course. ;-)


SK

-- 

www.myspace.com/filtersf

when they said "Keep your politics out of my music"

I don't mind healthy political debate, but I can't see why people can't just 
be mature enough to discuss that crap here and start threads with the 
appropriate "NRR" , and for those who aren't interested, they can filter or 
delete the threads like responsible little adults.

Of course, thaz just me....

I guess I wasn't clear about this. I didn't mean to say SFRavers were too
wuss to handle having the occasional political thread as a part of this
list. I just didn't want to lose anybody who was thinking of leaving due to
last week's nastygramathon.

What I should probably ask is, how secure is this list and how comfortable
are folks expressing themselves fully here? Would there be any interest in
creating other options and are there really any options?

SK

also before you move your songs to yuour ipod, besure to right click> get
info> click the options tab> adjust volume (since it might be a lil low on
your ipod & click the other tabs to adjust the inofo on song, etc) then
right click again> convert to AAC> then put the AAC file on your ipod..
hella saves space!

Subject: [sfraves] ::NOW PLAYING::invincible techno internet radio LIVE! ON THE AIR

this week we have rolling though the blissfactory, live on radio 
integrated, three very excellent innately talented techno djs and 
producers currently hailing from the bay area that should not be missed!

8ish-10pm PST  DJ Saya   from FILTER SF.Tokyo
every set by saya is a smooth and laid back techno ride with an emphasis 
on drive and interesting track selection that is never boring and 
screams quality 100%

10-11pm PST  Ruoho Ruotsi   from defchild records http://defchild.com/  
LIVE P.A.
i ran into ruoho ruotsi at a club and he tossed me a couple defchild 
releases one was his. when i put it on the platter. i was really taken 
by the funky and tech-y techno emanating from those grooves.. ranging 
from techno tools to funky stand up and dance tracks i immediately found 
a place for it in my box and i haven't taken it out of my crate ever 
since i met him.

11-12am PST  DJ Perla   from Spain   (special live PA set!! first west 
coast appearance)  http://www.myspace.com/perladanceusted

this dj and producer has some of the best some of the  best original 
techno tracks currently in the bay. his skills are clean and tight. all 
his tracks are cool groovy and hypnotic, really easy to lose yourself 
in.. all the while giving a sense of professionalism that alot of 
producers who've had the same amount of experience lack. the best part 
about perla is that he is has so much potential.. he's only been 
producing for a short number of years but already he's poised to take on 
the likes of nathan fake, alex smoke, & daso if the world will let him.



Tune in at http://www.zer01.net:1200/
Every Friday from 8pm - Midnight PST

              def@defsf.com

strobe and hitting the smoke machines and turning on the big red light

>>> hamster wheel to even begin to be able to pay attention to any of this
>>> shit.

>>> defining issue but by who runs the best commercials that are going to
>>> running non-stop on the TV, the Great American Experiment of Democracy

>>> quicker a way out will present itself, but I guarantee you that it 
>>> won't

>>> revolution.

For now I'm tossing my hat in with Ron Paul.

Not because of his party, but because of his voting voting record.  
Mainly, the fact that he actually does his job.

Also, not a career politician, but a doctor, who left politics and came 
back.  Hard to find anything wrong with the guy beyond being goofy looking.
He wants us out of the war, he wants America to stop being the global 
police.  Free internet, no RealID, Keep your tips, more state rights (eg 
Stem Cell research). 

Some are going to yell about his closing the border policy.  I happen to 
agree with it.  The policy should be the same for EVERYONE regardless of 
race, creed, religion, country of origin.  All visa's should be enforced 
EQUALLY.  Maybe I'm wrong, and people can call me a racist or something, 
but I like equality.

On Jan 12, 2008, at 9:03 PM, J.C. wrote:

> Than we won't talk about that racism thing.
>


Is anyone listening to what RP says about racism?

"Racism is simply an ugly form of collectivism, the mindset that  
views humans strictly as members of groups rather than individuals.  
Racists believe that all individuals who share superficial physical  
characteristics are alike: as collectivists, racists think only in  
terms of groups. By encouraging Americans to adopt a group mentality,  
the advocates of so-called "diversity" actually perpetuate racism.  
Their obsession with racial group identity is inherently racist.

The true antidote to racism is liberty. Liberty means having a  
limited, constitutional government devoted to the protection of  
individual rights rather than group claims. Liberty means free-market  
capitalism, which rewards individual achievement and competence, not  
skin color, gender, or ethnicity.
More importantly, in a free society every citizen gains a sense of  
himself as an individual, rather than developing a group or victim  
mentality. This leads to a sense of individual responsibility and  
personal pride, making skin color irrelevant. Rather than looking to  
government to correct our sins, we should understand that racism will  
endure until we stop thinking in terms of groups and begin thinking  
in terms of individual liberty."

http://www.lewrockwell.com/paul/paul381.html

it's safe to say he's had to deal with a lot of aftermath, even from 
safe clean abortions.  personally I'm on the line on the issue.  I'm 
adamently opposed to abortion as a form of birth control.  I agree with 
freedom of your body, but I'm also real big on personal responsibility.

chnage legally, even if the president trys.

personal freedom, Patriot act, expanding federal powers.  Many of these 
apply to the SFRave scene and other groups.  Utah Rave anyone?

Paul is the first candidate in years I didn't feel was a lesser evil.

I know that the president is elected by the electoral college, but the
presidential nominees are not. I believe this is problematic because if the
masses pick incompetent nominees, then that would default us to having an
incompetent president. The nomination process needs revamping; which would
also probably require a revamp of party politics as well. However, revamping
will probably never happen, so we're resigned to accept inadequacy in our
executive office. I love it when nice people (like politicians and
partisans) take a working system designed by the founders, and exploit it to
the point that the original system does not carry out its intended purpose.

On Jan 12, 2008 10:30 PM, Shatter <shatter@sonic.net> wrote:

> What you want and support is the Elector system of presidential
> elections.  The people don't put the man in office, the electors do.
>
> The founders felt the common man was not informed enough or took enough
> time to research and listen to the candidates to put it to a popular vote

The racism thing is interesting. 

Here's what I find interesting in a political election:  YOU ARE NOW 
ALLOWED TO EVOLVE, GROW OR CHANGE. 

Why did I caps that?  because that's how it is.  Anyone else, is allowed 
to change over time.  I mean, some of you are young on this list, but 
the guy I was at 19 is not the man I am today.  Some of what I believed 
in back then I still do, other thing, gads no.  Would I have wante dto 
kick my own ass?  maybe.  That's my point.

Instead of defending a politician, I'll go witha radical, and how 
everyone sings the priases of his changes in life:  Malcolm X

He started out as a thug.  Went to prison
He came out a Black Supremist.  he went to mecca
He came back as a man of peace who didn't care about race, creed color 
and saw that all of man could be at peace living together.

Had he ran for an office he would have been raked over the coals for his 
beliefs of youth.  Never mind he was black in the 60's and running 
wasn't an option..   my point stands.

Now, from Ron Pauls website

http://www.ronpaul2008.com/issues/racism/

It's a good read, and I agree with this.  I've been yelling about it for 
a while. celebrate Diversity?  No thanks.  Why focus on what's so 
different about us.  Its' like the people at goth clubs that go out of 
their way to tell my friend how good it is to see "people like him" as a 
goth club".  By this they mean, a black guy.  They're trying to be nice, 
but really, it's offensive.  It's like the 'Apologetic White People' 
that go out of their way to apologize for everything wrong in the world 
as if it's all their fault because of their parents.  Give it a rest.  
If it'll make them feel better we can built them a big giant cross to 
nail themselves to just so they can truely feel guilty.

crap. digressing.  stopping now.

Point is, I care more about what the politician has said and done in teh 
last 10 years.  Hows their voting record?  Hows their congressional 
attendance?  how's their personal budgets?  Did they vote the way 
contributions told them or did they stand firm on the platform they 
campaigned from?  Do they even bother showing up to Vote?

I mean, all Hillary has done since elected into office is run for 
president.  Has she even worked one day doing the job she jerry mandered 
into?  All those dead people that voted for her got robbed.

--S

for.  They put their chosen candidate out there.

itself.  They could in effect, only allow card carrying party members to 
vote as opposed to people registered.  IIRC many states and districts 
the vote cast is nothing more than a statistical poll taken and there 
are times the popular votes doesn't sway with how the caucus official cast.


Mark wrote:
> I know that the president is elected by the electoral college, but the 
> presidential nominees are not. I believe this is problematic because 
> if the masses pick incompetent nominees, then that would default us to 
> having an incompetent president. The nomination process needs 
> revamping; which would also probably require a revamp of party 
> politics as well. However, revamping will probably never happen, so 
> we're resigned to accept inadequacy in our executive office. I love it 
> when nice people (like politicians and partisans) take a working 
> system designed by the founders, and exploit it to the point that the 
> original system does not carry out its intended purpose.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Giuliani TV Ad

Err, the bong of peace sounds like a good idea, perhaps in the tradition of a Rastafarian "reasoning session."  And I would like to think I the forces of evil would indeed lose any sort of dance competition.  But in fact this is not at all what I was talking about.

What I was talking about is that many of the powers that be agree with former Czech Prime Minister Jiri Paroubek who said that ravers and techno heads are "obsessed people with anarchist proclivities and international links" who "provoke massive violent demonstrations, fuelled by alcohol and drugs, against the peaceful society."  In other words ravers are anarcho-terrorists with links to a global terrorist "raver" organization.   An these terrorist ravers are operating globally!  E.g. http://history-is-made-at-night.blogspot.com/2007/03/indian-rave-bust.html

Sound far fetched?  Ok maybe that's just some nutbag in the Czech Republic talking you say, and well India is a backward place anyhow.  Maybe you think this "ridiculous" idea can't effect us here.  Wrong.  Remember that not very long ago an armed paramilitary force attacked a rave in Utah arresting many of the participants, beating down anyone that tried to photograph the events as they were transpiring.

And what were these anacrhist raver terrorists doing?  Were they planning an attack on a national monument?  Training their terrorist cadres to murder innocent civilians?  Nope.  They were on private property dancing and having a PARTY.  I guess the Beastie Boys were right about having to fight for the right to party after all.

In the United Kingdom, the original home of raves, they have been made completely illegal.  Consider these somewhat recent links: http://vjforums.com/showthread.php?t=16472  and  http://www.urban75.com/Rave/festivals.html  

Here in the US, the Joe Biden's RAVE act has accomplished a similar objective.  A tragic death at a recent party on McCormick's island in Pennsylvania not only resulted in the arrest of the organizers with the police charging them with one count of "reckless endangerment" for every person at the party, but they also arrested and jailed 50 party goers simply for being there.  Think it can't happen here in lefty San Francisco famous as "Sodom by the Bay"?  Think again...

http://www.brugerforeningen.dk/bfny.nsf/pagesuk/C7FBF53835CA6BEF41256B45007F09E1?OpenDocument&K=Harm%20Reduction&S=UK

If it can happen in New Orleans, it can happen here.

What I am suggesting is that we support candidates that don't want to make raves more illegal than they already are.  That accept personal choices and responsibility and that don't support jailing people for personal choices which do no harm to others.

I am suggesting that we remember why we came here in the first place (raves remember those?) and that we consider supporting candidates who's values are aligned with that reason.  

One positive thing about Ron Paul, he does say he's against the war on drugs.  Now I am not promoting drug use, but the fact that some people do take drugs at raves has been used as the reason to restrict them and to make them essentially illegal.  Its time to end this losing "war" against ourselves known as the War on Drugs.

How many of the candidates have taken a stand on this issue that we can all live with and respect here?  I think the answer might be two: Ron Paul and Dennis Kunnich.

And why does this all matter anyway?  After all its just a party with people getting fucked up and dancing.  Right?

"In a world where most every authentic expression of youth culture is commodified by a media conglomerate and sold back to teens at the mall, rave culture stands as one of the few, relatively uncorrupted outposts for America's kids." 
-- Douglas Rushkoff


Best,

Peter

Thanks for the clarification; I wasn't sure how the nomination process works
nationwide. However, even if it is up to the party to nominate their
presidential candidate, will they nominate the most competent person that
can assume the role of president? One would hope that the party's would
deliberate this nomination process with reason, but in reality that is not
the case. We all know that there is plenty of inner conflict in the parties.
I think the question to ask is: are the parties looking to benefit us with a
competent president, or are they looking to benefit themselves? If this
question can be thoroughly answered, then I think it will indicate whether
the current system works or not.

Now, I won't go put out a question without taking any effort to answer it.
And my answer to most political questions is: follow the money-trail, and
where it ends will hold the answer.

On Jan 13, 2008 2:18 AM, Shatter <shatter@sonic.net> wrote:

> ya, well...  thats' sort of what the party Caucus is supposed to be
> for.  They put their chosen candidate out there.
>
> Also, the way the party selects a candidate is totally up to the party
> itself.  They could in effect, only allow card carrying party members to
> vote as opposed to people registered.  IIRC many states and districts
> the vote cast is nothing more than a statistical poll taken and there
> are times the popular votes doesn't sway with how the caucus official
> cast.
>
>
> Mark wrote:
> > I know that the president is elected by the electoral college, but the
> > presidential nominees are not. I believe this is problematic because
> > if the masses pick incompetent nominees, then that would default us to
> > having an incompetent president. The nomination process needs
> > revamping; which would also probably require a revamp of party
> > politics as well. However, revamping will probably never happen, so
> > we're resigned to accept inadequacy in our executive office. I love it
> > when nice people (like politicians and partisans) take a working
> > system designed by the founders, and exploit it to the point that the
> > original system does not carry out its intended purpose.
> >

No, they did not discontinue the use of thimerosal in vaccines in  
1999, the drug companies made available certain lots of vaccines  
thimerosal-free.  In fact, if you go to the FDA's own website, they  
even talk about how the vaccines have mercury in them and what they  
think the acceptable level is.  Now I don't know about you, but after  
reading the study and watching the video on how mercury destroys  
synapses in the brain, I don't think any level of mercury is an  
acceptable situation.

http://www.fda.gov/Cber/vaccine/thimerosal.htm

Subject: Re: [sfraves] regarding the recent "08" discussion topic

people I think are going to come and go from the list no matter what,  
just like they come and go from the scene, my friend that actually  
introduced me to raves asked me the other day if raves still go on  
and i had to tell him, well i think so, there's still an sfraves.

i'm a pretty big believer especially after seeing this list go on for  
so long that open discussions are the way to go just flag it with the  
nrr tag if it's not rave related.  by doing this, you run the risk of  
having the occasional flame war that causes people to feel a little  
weird once in a while but i think living through that pays off  
because they'll eventually cool off and grow from the experience,  
myself included.

i don't really worry about whether the list is secure or not, i'm  
105% certain the government has read my posts.  but i'm not going to  
live in fear.  that's how the evil shadow black op slingin'  
government wins, by setting up automated policing everywhere and  
trying to give you the idea that if you say the wrong thing men in  
black uniforms and ski masks are going to haul you away to the  
gulag.  too many of us know what's really going on now.

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> Err, the bong of peace sounds like a good idea, perhaps in the tradition of a Rastafarian "reasoning session."  And I would like to think I the forces of evil would indeed lose any sort of dance competition.  But in fact this is not at all what I was talking about.
>
> What I was talking about is that many of the powers that be agree with former Czech Prime Minister Jiri Paroubek who said that ravers and techno heads are "obsessed people with anarchist proclivities and international links" who "provoke massive violent demonstrations, fuelled by alcohol and drugs, against the peaceful society."  In other words ravers are anarcho-terrorists with links to a global terrorist "raver" organization.   An these terrorist ravers are operating globally!  E.g. http://history-is-made-at-night.blogspot.com/2007/03/indian-rave-bust.html
>
> Sound far fetched?  Ok maybe that's just some nutbag in the Czech Republic talking you say, and well India is a backward place anyhow.  Maybe you think this "ridiculous" idea can't effect us here.  Wrong.  Remember that not very long ago an armed paramilitary force attacked a rave in Utah arresting many of the participants, beating down anyone that tried to photograph the events as they were transpiring.
>
> And what were these anacrhist raver terrorists doing?  Were they planning an attack on a national monument?  Training their terrorist cadres to murder innocent civilians?  Nope.  They were on private property dancing and having a PARTY.  I guess the Beastie Boys were right about having to fight for the right to party after all.
>
> In the United Kingdom, the original home of raves, they have been made completely illegal.  Consider these somewhat recent links: http://vjforums.com/showthread.php?t=16472  and  http://www.urban75.com/Rave/festivals.html  
>
> Here in the US, the Joe Biden's RAVE act has accomplished a similar objective.  A tragic death at a recent party on McCormick's island in Pennsylvania not only resulted in the arrest of the organizers with the police charging them with one count of "reckless endangerment" for every person at the party, but they also arrested and jailed 50 party goers simply for being there.  Think it can't happen here in lefty San Francisco famous as "Sodom by the Bay"?  Think again...
>
> http://www.brugerforeningen.dk/bfny.nsf/pagesuk/C7FBF53835CA6BEF41256B45007F09E1?OpenDocument&K=Harm%20Reduction&S=UK
>
> If it can happen in New Orleans, it can happen here.
>
> What I am suggesting is that we support candidates that don't want to make raves more illegal than they already are.  That accept personal choices and responsibility and that don't support jailing people for personal choices which do no harm to others.
>
> I am suggesting that we remember why we came here in the first place (raves remember those?) and that we consider supporting candidates who's values are aligned with that reason.  
>
> One positive thing about Ron Paul, he does say he's against the war on drugs.  Now I am not promoting drug use, but the fact that some people do take drugs at raves has been used as the reason to restrict them and to make them essentially illegal.  Its time to end this losing "war" against ourselves known as the War on Drugs.
>
> How many of the candidates have taken a stand on this issue that we can all live with and respect here?  I think the answer might be two: Ron Paul and Dennis Kunnich.
>
> And why does this all matter anyway?  After all its just a party with people getting fucked up and dancing.  Right?
>
> "In a world where most every authentic expression of youth culture is commodified by a media conglomerate and sold back to teens at the mall, rave culture stands as one of the few, relatively uncorrupted outposts for America's kids." 
> -- Douglas Rushkoff
>
>
> Best,
>
> Peter

Mark wrote:
> Thanks for the clarification; I wasn't sure how the nomination process 
> works nationwide. However, even if it is up to the party to nominate 
> their presidential candidate, will they nominate the most competent 
> person that can assume the role of president? One would hope that the 
> party's would deliberate this nomination process with reason, but in 
> reality that is not the case. We all know that there is plenty of 
> inner conflict in the parties. I think the question to ask is: are the 
> parties looking to benefit us with a competent president, or are they 
> looking to benefit themselves? If this question can be thoroughly 
> answered, then I think it will indicate whether the current system 
> works or not.
>
> Now, I won't go put out a question without taking any effort to answer 
> it. And my answer to most political questions is: follow the

>> competent person that can assume the role of president? One would 
>> hope that the party's would deliberate this nomination process with

packed clubs in the metropolises of China, rocking boat parties in the =
old heart of Paris, nude beaches in California and now FiX.=20

> From the article:
"Ron has been one of the biggest opponents of overcompression in the industry 
as people have rushed to bring techno music into the ridiculous loudness war 
that the rest of the record industry is engaged in currently. His mastering is 
both dynamic and warm and has been praised for it's definition in the low end. 
A kick drum on an NSC mastered record is a beautiful thing to behold. He's a 
real living legend in this industry yet he remains humble and is still one of 
the most interesting figures in this industry that i have ever talked to. A 
true classic character."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Techno mastering guru Ron Murphy passes away

i think there was a time where people were mocking the compression 
mastering war techno style by overusing compression as an effect. i got 
alot of records with this squashed sound.. very stone-y. still to this 
day i think the compression effect is used as a nice contrast to the 
more lilting flowery detroit styled synth lines i've been hearing as of 
late.

techno fanatik at large,
sean ocean
dj disconnect

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Giuliani TV Ad

Many of the technical resources used in the War on Drugs (i.e. airborne surveillance platforms, data mining software) are multi-purpose anyway.  So I suspect that any apparent "diversion" of resources is just a change in what people are talking about. 

I haven't read anything about DEA staff or budget reductions.  See http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/516/2007_top_ten_major_stories_in_the_drug_war

FWIW

Peter

=47=72=6F=6F=76=65

=68=73=6F=6D=75=73=69=63=2E=63=6F=6D - =6D=79=73=70=61=63=65=2E=63=6F=6D=2F=
=68=73=6F=6D=75=73=69=63
=4B=5A=53=55 =28=6B=7A=73=75=6C=69=76=65=2E=73=74=61=6E=66=6F=72=64=2E=65=

Another side side note, I hope this isn't a recent repeat like  
yesterday's.  Oh well, no one's perfect.  Look out the window and  
notice how foggy it is this morning ... happy Tuesday.

Refer to this article for this quote, a rather disturbing report ...

http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/11/17/police_to_search_for_guns_in_homes/

--

I just have a queasy feeling anytime the police try to do an end run
around the Constitution.  The police have restrictions on their
authority and ability to conduct searches. The Constitution was
written with a very specific intent, and that was to keep the law out
of private homes unless there is a written document signed by a judge
and based on probable cause. Here we don't have that.

- Thomas Nolan

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Giuliani TV Ad

Ya, exactly.  If you data mine your news around may pre 9/11 you'll see 
we gave the Taliban a few billion in support for their "war on drugs" by 
not allowing the poppy fields.  Now that we've liberated the farmers are 
back in business.  Hell, that link from Peter says as much...

*Afghanistan and Opium*

Six years after the US invaded Afghanistan, neither the effort to defeat 
the Taliban nor the war on the opium poppy is going well. US and NATO 
casualties are up, and the poppy crop continues to hit new records every 
year. Afghanistan now accounts for 92% of the global opium supply, and 
the US and its NATO allies face a real dilemma: Go after the crops and 
drive the farmers into the waiting arms of the Taliban, or stand by and 
watch the Taliban profit handsomely from the traffic. Meanwhile, 
proposals to simply buy up the crop and divert it to legitimate 
medicinal uses are eroding the prohibitionist consensus, as everyone 
from Canadian think tanks 
<http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/476/canadian_think_tank_calls_for_afghan_opium_marketing_board> 
to British parliamentarians 
<http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/478/british_mps_want_licit_medical_use_afghan_opium> 
to the European Parliament 
<http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/502/european_union_committee_afghan_opium_medicine> 
came on board to support such a plan. At year's end, the US government 
announced it had given up efforts to spray the poppies 
<http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/512/no_aerial_eradication_of_afghan_opium_poppies_says_state_department> 
in the face of opposition from the Afghan government, NATO allies, and 
even the Pentagon and CIA. Now, the US is once again back to the drawing 
board, and Afghanistan is certain to remain a critical issue for the 
foreseeable future.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Green Nightclub in SF

Dancing in the Dark

>From SFBite

The Bite
You can't start a fire without a spark, but you might be able to power a
nightclub without one. Having recently debuted its vertical gardens, Zen
Compound - the SOMA entertainment center that isn't the Metreon - plans =
to
harness the power of your feet. Later this year, it will install a dance
floor that'll use the piezo effect to turn the pressure from dancing =
feet in
its Temple club into electrical power for its sound system and lighting.
Until then, soak up the eco atmosphere (complete with plant-covered =
outside
walls) before you toss back organic booze in corn-based cups. Say hello =
to
the new Boss of green nightclubs in SF.

Wanna Try?
Zen Compound, 540 Howard St. b/t First and Second Sts. (415-987-9953).

To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, January 16, 2008 12:29 AM
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Green Nightclub in SF


Dancing in the Dark

>From SFBite

The Bite
You can't start a fire without a spark, but you might be able to power a
nightclub without one. Having recently debuted its vertical gardens, Zen
Compound - the SOMA entertainment center that isn't the Metreon - plans to
harness the power of your feet. Later this year, it will install a dance
floor that'll use the piezo effect to turn the pressure from dancing feet in
its Temple club into electrical power for its sound system and lighting.
Until then, soak up the eco atmosphere (complete with plant-covered outside
walls) before you toss back organic booze in corn-based cups. Say hello to
the new Boss of green nightclubs in SF.

Wanna Try?
Zen Compound, 540 Howard St. b/t First and Second Sts. (415-987-9953).






apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace: http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet: http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe: www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101: http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is nothing
but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids look and look
and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Come Fairies, take me out of this dull world, for I would ride with you
upon the wind and dance upon the mountains like a flame!"
- W.B.YEATS

  Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0

Message-ID: <586348.26037.qm@web60315.mail.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Green Nightclub in SF

The dancefloor, unfortunately, will most likely be more symbolic than a significant source of power.  Dancers or no dancers, piezos are great at translating vibration into tiny, transient currents (that's why they're used as pickups on many acoustic instruments), but the currents are just that, tiny, and the returns for using bigger and bigger crystals decrease exponentially as you go up, unless they're talking about hundred-layer thick arrays of thin crystals...  They only way I could see this doing much is if the floor is split into smallish squares, each sitting on its own quartet of piezo stacks.  Otherwise, people's non-robotic dance moves might cancel one another out much of the time on a big monolithic floor.  Perhaps that's what they're planning!  If it works, my hat is officially off to their engineering prowess (and sense of cost-is-no-object innovation).

"Everybody, JUMP two three four JUMP two three four!  Damnit, the lights are dimming!  The turntables are slowing down, STOMP GODDAMN YOU PEOPLE!!"  (j/k)

Anyway, the rest of the venture sounds quite interesting.  Will check it out.

WHOOT APOLLO, so good to see you postin'! :)

-G

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Giuliani TV Ad

----- Original Message ----
From: Deepfog <sfo@deepfog.com>

everybody should be  
listening to every moment of michael savage's show, every single day  
he is on.
---

I used to listen to Mr. Savage on my way home from work, initially as a vista into the wacko right, to see where the craziness was coming from and in what form.  Weirdly, I found myself, over time, becoming able to tune out the self-aggrandizing rhetoric and ultraconservative-survivalist-crazy histrionics, and glean some really interesting bits from the show.  It was from him that I heard that investing in gold was the way forward (5 years ago or so, when gold was about 1/5th what it's worth today- wish I'd listened), and his vistas into Islam, immigration, and the importance (to him) of preserving national identity, are an interesting listen, when he's not battering you over the head with them.

That's not to so I agree with much of it, but it makes you think, for sure.  In comparison to folks like Coulter and Limbaugh, he's practically Einstein.  There've been more than a couple of times he's said something and I hurt a little inside, thinking "M*#@erF#@er, a goddamn Republican just taught me something...  *puke*". ;)

-G

----- Original Message ----

----- Original Message ----
From: Deepfog <sfo@deepfog.com>

everybody should be  
listening to every moment of michael savage's show, every single day  
he is on.
---

I used to listen to Mr. Savage on my way home from work, initially as a
 vista into the wacko right, to see where the craziness was coming from
 and in what form.  Weirdly, I found myself, over time, becoming able
 to tune out the self-aggrandizing rhetoric and
 ultraconservative-survivalist-crazy histrionics, and glean some really interesting bits from the
 show.  It was from him that I heard that investing in gold was the way
 forward (5 years ago or so, when gold was about 1/5th what it's worth
 today- wish I'd listened), and his vistas into Islam, immigration, and
 the importance (to him) of preserving national identity, are an
 interesting listen, when he's not battering you over the head with them.

That's not to so I agree with much of it, but it makes you think, for
 sure.  In comparison to folks like Coulter and Limbaugh, he's
 practically Einstein.  There've been more than a couple of times he's said
 something and I hurt a little inside, thinking "M*#@erF#@er, a goddamn
 Republican just taught me something...  *puke*". ;)

-G

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Giuliani TV Ad

Aha one of my favorite topics!

Properly known as the "infinite monkeys theorem":

"The infinite monkey theorem states that a monkey hitting keys at random on a typewriter keyboard for an infinite amount of time will almost surely type a particular chosen text, such as the complete works of William Shakespeare. In this context, 'almost surely' is a mathematical term with a precise meaning, and the 'monkey' is not an actual monkey; rather, it is a metaphor for an abstract device that produces a random sequence of letters ad infinitum. The theorem illustrates the perils of reasoning about infinity by imagining a vast but finite number, and vice versa. The probability of a monkey typing a given string of text as long as, say, Hamlet is so tiny that, were the experiment conducted, the chance of it actually occurring during a span of time of the order of the age of the universe is minuscule but not zero."

>From http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_monkey_theorem 

Oh and this: http://www.nutters.org/docs/monkeys

And this: http://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/multimedia/2003/05/58790 and this: http://www.vivaria.net/experiments/notes/documentation/

And check out this cool demo linked there: http://vlab.infotech.monash.edu.au/simulations/evolution/richard-dawkin-weasel/
 
There WILL be a test.

Peace,

Peter

You are cordially invited to help kick off MIXTAPE, a new monthly at Shine
on 4th Thursdays.

Eclectic is the key word here- almost no style of music will go
unrepresented- each month you'll be treated to top notch selectors from all
over the map, doing that thing they do best; some familiar, others maybe
not, but whatever the flavor, quality is assured........think of it kind of
like a mixtape made especially for you. ;)

The first installment happens Thursday, Jan 24...

guests:

LITTLE JOHN (Raindance)
www.raindancepresents.com

www.majitope.com

www.myspace.com/mozaicmusic

1337 Mission St @ 9th
San Francisco
www.shinesf.com

9:30pm - 2am

21+
