On Jan 16, 2008, at 12:17 PM, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> Aha one of my favorite topics!
>
> Properly known as the "infinite monkeys theorem":
>
> "The infinite monkey theorem states that a monkey hitting keys at  
> random on a typewriter keyboard for an infinite amount of time will  
> almost surely type a particular chosen text, such as the complete  
> works of William Shakespeare. In this context, 'almost surely' is a  
> mathematical term with a precise meaning, and the 'monkey' is not an  
> actual monkey; rather, it is a metaphor for an abstract device that  
> produces a random sequence of letters ad infinitum. The theorem  
> illustrates the perils of reasoning about infinity by imagining a  
> vast but finite number, and vice versa. The probability of a monkey  
> typing a given string of text as long as, say, Hamlet is so tiny  
> that, were the experiment conducted, the chance of it actually  
> occurring during a span of time of the order of the age of the  
> universe is minuscule but not zero."
>
> From http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_monkey_theorem
>
> Oh and this: http://www.nutters.org/docs/monkeys
>
> And this: http://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/multimedia/2003/05/58790 
>  and this: http://www.vivaria.net/experiments/notes/documentation/
>
> And check out this cool demo linked there: http://vlab.infotech.monash.edu.au/simulations/evolution/richard-dawkin-weasel/
>
> There WILL be a test.
>
> Peace,
>
> Peter
>

At 02:36 PM 1/16/2008, Phillip Mispagel wrote:
>Hi,
>
>Do ya'll think that having a party the same weekend as WMC will be a 
>big conflict?  I'm not personally aware of anyone going to WMC.  I 
>suspect that some people will be, but I don't think an exorbitant 
>number of people will be dropping a bunch of money to fly to Miami.


As a promoter I have deliberately thrown parties on the same weekend 
as WMC - and experienced nothing but gratitude from the attendees
for doing so.  Not that many people go, I don't think that the WMC is 
perceived as cool or 'must attend' as it was just a few years ago.
Put on the best party, with the best DJs you can - you should be fine !

people some on this board protest: Burners.  So only message me if you're
seriously interested.  I don't need drama and I don't need someone
generalizing or antagonizing a group of people.  Please keep this in mind

Other than Dragn'fly and myself - I am not sure that there were SFR 
people there -
and we were pretty directly involved - so take that into 
consideration in my comments -

We had over 450 people - the most diverse group I've ever seen at one 
of our events -
the dancefloor was rocking by 10 - never let up all night - and there 
were still about 150 people dancing
when we ended at 6am.  Dragn'fly was at her blistering best - and 
Spesh rocked harder
than I have EVER heard him - lots of eye candy, no matter what your 
taste, and everyone
seemed to get on really well - no problems from authorities or 
obnoxious drunks !

it's direct current, so they could charge batteries with it or 
something.  I'm imagining lots of small tiles connected to smaller 
crystal stacks.  piezos are also used in pressure sensors, knock 
sensors and BBQ ignitors, not to mention some lighters and most wand 
fireplace lighters.

as for running the sound system?  I kinda doubt it.. they'd have to 
dance with no music to charge it up first..


sarilion

At 11:11 AM 1/16/2008, georgeC | origami wrote:
>The dancefloor, unfortunately, will most likely be more symbolic 
>than a significant source of power.  Dancers or no dancers, piezos 
>are great at translating vibration into tiny, transient currents 
>(that's why they're used as pickups on many acoustic instruments), 
>but the currents are just that, tiny, and the returns for using 
>bigger and bigger crystals decrease exponentially as you go up, 
>unless they're talking about hundred-layer thick arrays of thin 
>crystals...  They only way I could see this doing much is if the 
>floor is split into smallish squares, each sitting on its own 
>quartet of piezo stacks.  Otherwise, people's non-robotic dance 
>moves might cancel one another out much of the time on a big 
>monolithic floor.  Perhaps that's what they're planning!  If it 
>works, my hat is officially off to their engineering prowess (and 
>sense of cost-is-no-object innovation).
>
>"Everybody, JUMP two three four JUMP two three four!  Damnit, the 
>lights are dimming!  The turntables are slowing down, STOMP GODDAMN 
>YOU PEOPLE!!"  (j/k)
>
>Anyway, the rest of the venture sounds quite interesting.  Will check it out.
>
>WHOOT APOLLO, so good to see you postin'! :)
>
>-G

> >> You can't start a fire without a spark, but you
> >> might be able to power a
> >> nightclub without one. Having recently debuted its
> >> vertical gardens, Zen
> >> Compound - the SOMA entertainment center that isn't
> >> the Metreon - plans to
> >> harness the power of your feet. Later this year, it
> >> will install a dance
> >> floor that'll use the piezo effect to turn the
> >> pressure from dancing feet in
> >> its Temple club into electrical power for its sound
> >> system and lighting.
> >> Until then, soak up the eco atmosphere (complete
> >> with plant-covered outside
> >> walls) before you toss back organic booze in
> >> corn-based cups. Say hello to
> >> the new Boss of green nightclubs in SF.

Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com> wrote: At 02:36 PM 1/16/2008, Phillip Mispagel wrote:
>Hi,
>
>Do ya'll think that having a party the same weekend as WMC will be a 
>big conflict?  I'm not personally aware of anyone going to WMC.  I 
>suspect that some people will be, but I don't think an exorbitant 
>number of people will be dropping a bunch of money to fly to Miami.


As a promoter I have deliberately thrown parties on the same weekend 
as WMC - and experienced nothing but gratitude from the attendees
for doing so.  Not that many people go, I don't think that the WMC is 
perceived as cool or 'must attend' as it was just a few years ago.
Put on the best party, with the best DJs you can - you should be fine !

-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Cyr [mailto:surfpunk@well.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, January 16, 2008 3:37 PM
To: Ben Haus; The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Sweet, how was it...?

At 02:54 PM 1/16/2008, Ben Haus wrote:
>I think it was supposed to go down on NYE...?  Did anyone make it out,
>reviews?  Never heard anything else about it.  It seems like there's a
real
>dearth of decent parties at the moment.


Other than Dragn'fly and myself - I am not sure that there were SFR 
people there -
and we were pretty directly involved - so take that into 
consideration in my comments -

We had over 450 people - the most diverse group I've ever seen at one 
of our events -
the dancefloor was rocking by 10 - never let up all night - and there 
were still about 150 people dancing
when we ended at 6am.  Dragn'fly was at her blistering best - and 
Spesh rocked harder
than I have EVER heard him - lots of eye candy, no matter what your 
taste, and everyone
seemed to get on really well - no problems from authorities or 
obnoxious drunks !

X-YMail-OSG: u09b10AVM1mPkmjewSVhD9ZO.ZMetpz2R6wdQNFS9VRiXlR3DzTcyoDFcNwiZrxPZ7JXyuS.2g--

From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: adriana <eesiad1@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <828530.56444.qm@web32411.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] WMC Weekend?

I agree.  I've been to WMC twice, in 2000 and 2001.  WMC is a total blast.   In 2000, we cosponsored a boat party with Essential Mix; the DJs were Juan Atkins, DJ Dan and Pete Tong.  In 2001 we were at the huge Ultra party where we sponsored the outdoor misting booth and gave away t-shirts.

Of course it helped that I was traveling with OPM (other people's money) but actually the place I stayed in 2001 was walking distance to the clubs, across the street from the beach, and had a small kitchenette  and it was only $85 a night.  OK not exactly a top of line swanky South Beach hotel but it served my needs nicely.

One day we came back from some mission or other around Miami and Donald Glaude was laying it down in the hotel lobby while two (2) girls danced.  I also saw Ken Ishi, Derrick May and Kevin Saunderson play at a tiny club at WMC, IMO some of the best music I've ever heard in any genre or category.   

I would recommned WMC if you can deal with the Miami BS, have the cash, and preferably have something to trade to get to help get into the best events.  Having some tickets to give out to a hot party yourself doesn't hurt that's for sure.  And traveling with a group of good looking women (which I was) is even better.

As to the original question, unlike BM I don't think enough people go from SF for it to make dent in the party scene here.  Some DJs and label people as well as a few punters do go of course so it might depend on your crowd.

So my advice is to damn the torpedos and party on...

Peace,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: adriana <eesiad1@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Wednesday, January 16, 2008 6:24:40 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] WMC Weekend?

actually WMC rocks...
still working out details as to if i'm gonna go..
maybe not sure, since i do want to go to burning man this year

Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com> wrote: At 02:36 PM 1/16/2008, Phillip Mispagel wrote:
>Hi,
>
>Do ya'll think that having a party the same weekend as WMC will be a 
>big conflict?  I'm not personally aware of anyone going to WMC.  I 
>suspect that some people will be, but I don't think an exorbitant 
>number of people will be dropping a bunch of money to fly to Miami.


As a promoter I have deliberately thrown parties on the same weekend 
as WMC - and experienced nothing but gratitude from the attendees
for doing so.  Not that many people go, I don't think that the WMC is 
perceived as cool or 'must attend' as it was just a few years ago.
Put on the best party, with the best DJs you can - you should be fine !

--0-1593871769-1200544991=:43555
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

yep..
our hotel last year was a long way from the actual wmc events...but it was just a bus ride...thou the beach was right behind our hotel...it was cool to go into the warm water while it rained...lots of fun..

some miami people are rude as hell....but i didn't really mind...people are rude everywhere..imo..

i'm undecided if i should tag along with other peeps for wmc...

if you get ur flight tickets now..its really cheap as fuck last year i just paid 200 bucks round trip..

all the parties that week were off the hook...thou drinks were pretty expensive..

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote: I agree.  I've been to WMC twice, in 2000 and 2001.  WMC is a total blast.   In 2000, we cosponsored a boat party with Essential Mix; the DJs were Juan Atkins, DJ Dan and Pete Tong.  In 2001 we were at the huge Ultra party where we sponsored the outdoor misting booth and gave away t-shirts.

Of course it helped that I was traveling with OPM (other people's money) but actually the place I stayed in 2001 was walking distance to the clubs, across the street from the beach, and had a small kitchenette  and it was only $85 a night.  OK not exactly a top of line swanky South Beach hotel but it served my needs nicely.

One day we came back from some mission or other around Miami and Donald Glaude was laying it down in the hotel lobby while two (2) girls danced.  I also saw Ken Ishi, Derrick May and Kevin Saunderson play at a tiny club at WMC, IMO some of the best music I've ever heard in any genre or category.   

I would recommned WMC if you can deal with the Miami BS, have the cash, and preferably have something to trade to get to help get into the best events.  Having some tickets to give out to a hot party yourself doesn't hurt that's for sure.  And traveling with a group of good looking women (which I was) is even better.

As to the original question, unlike BM I don't think enough people go from SF for it to make dent in the party scene here.  Some DJs and label people as well as a few punters do go of course so it might depend on your crowd.

So my advice is to damn the torpedos and party on...

Peace,

Peter

----- Original Message ----

actually WMC rocks...
still working out details as to if i'm gonna go..

Jim Cyr  wrote: At 02:36 PM 1/16/2008, Phillip Mispagel wrote:
>Hi,
>
>Do ya'll think that having a party the same weekend as WMC will be a 
>big conflict?  I'm not personally aware of anyone going to WMC.  I 
>suspect that some people will be, but I don't think an exorbitant 
>number of people will be dropping a bunch of money to fly to Miami.


As a promoter I have deliberately thrown parties on the same weekend 
as WMC - and experienced nothing but gratitude from the attendees
for doing so.  Not that many people go, I don't think that the WMC is 
perceived as cool or 'must attend' as it was just a few years ago.
Put on the best party, with the best DJs you can - you should be fine !

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Green Nightclub in SF

I had the same thought.

Some of the cardio machines at the gym have a setting which displays  
how many watts I'm generating while I workout.  And it's kind of  
stunning when I'm worked up into a high heart-rate and a lot of sweat,  
just how little of our household lighting I'd be able to power by  
continuously exerting myself on a bike or elliptical.  And we mostly  
have just plain old compact fluorescent bulbs...  no strobes, lasers,  
spotlights, fog machines, projectors, turntables, or anything.  And  
just how much wattage does your average club have in SOUND?  Good on  
them if they really HAVE found a way to juice all that off of pizeos  
in the dancefloor.  But I'm very Very VERY skeptical.

(And what if a DJ plays a song that's not a crowd pleaser and people  
stop dancing?!?!?)

OTOH, if they've found a way to violate the laws of thermodynamics or  
conservation of energy; they certainly deserve to be in the news for a  
lot more than being a "green" dance club.


cya,
john


On Jan 16, 2008, at 11:11 AM, georgeC | origami wrote:

> The dancefloor, unfortunately, will most likely be more symbolic  
> than a significant source of power.  Dancers or no dancers, piezos  
> are great at translating vibration into tiny, transient currents  
> (that's why they're used as pickups on many acoustic instruments),  
> but the currents are just that, tiny, and the returns for using  
> bigger and bigger crystals decrease exponentially as you go up,  
> unless they're talking about hundred-layer thick arrays of thin  
> crystals...  They only way I could see this doing much is if the  
> floor is split into smallish squares, each sitting on its own  
> quartet of piezo stacks.  Otherwise, people's non-robotic dance  
> moves might cancel one another out much of the time on a big  
> monolithic floor.  Perhaps that's what they're planning!  If it  
> works, my hat is officially off to their engineering prowess (and  
> sense of cost-is-no-object innovation).
>
> "Everybody, JUMP two three four JUMP two three four!  Damnit, the  
> lights are dimming!  The turntables are slowing down, STOMP GODDAMN  
> YOU PEOPLE!!"  (j/k)
>
> Anyway, the rest of the venture sounds quite interesting.  Will  
> check it out.
>
> WHOOT APOLLO, so good to see you postin'! :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Green Nightclub in SF

There's a nice demonstration at the Exploratorium that shows how unlikely this is...

Two people can sit and pedal to generate electricity.  There's a variety of different things to turn on including lightbulbs and a little space heater.  Turn on the bulbs and the heater and see how long you can pedal.  

No way this dance floor even powers one serious amp IMO, but I'd be impressed if I was wrong and it did!

Best,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
To: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
Cc: Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>; MOJO <orfsound@yahoo.com>; Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Wednesday, January 16, 2008 11:29:00 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Green Nightclub in SF

I had the same thought.

Some of the cardio machines at the gym have a setting which displays  
how many watts I'm generating while I workout.  And it's kind of  
stunning when I'm worked up into a high heart-rate and a lot of sweat,   
just how little of our household lighting I'd be able to power by  
continuously exerting myself on a bike or elliptical.  And we mostly  
have just plain old compact fluorescent bulbs...  no strobes, lasers,  
spotlights, fog machines, projectors, turntables, or anything.  And  
just how much wattage does your average club have in SOUND?  Good on  
them if they really HAVE found a way to juice all that off of pizeos  
in the dancefloor.  But I'm very Very VERY skeptical.

(And what if a DJ plays a song that's not a crowd pleaser and people  
stop dancing?!?!?)

OTOH, if they've found a way to violate the laws of thermodynamics or  
conservation of energy; they certainly deserve to be in the news for a   
lot more than being a "green" dance club.


cya,
john


On Jan 16, 2008, at 11:11 AM, georgeC | origami wrote:

> The dancefloor, unfortunately, will most likely be more symbolic  
> than a significant source of power.  Dancers or no dancers, piezos  
> are great at translating vibration into tiny, transient currents  
> (that's why they're used as pickups on many acoustic instruments),  
> but the currents are just that, tiny, and the returns for using  
> bigger and bigger crystals decrease exponentially as you go up,  
> unless they're talking about hundred-layer thick arrays of thin  
> crystals...  They only way I could see this doing much is if the  
> floor is split into smallish squares, each sitting on its own  
> quartet of piezo stacks.  Otherwise, people's non-robotic dance  
> moves might cancel one another out much of the time on a big  
> monolithic floor.  Perhaps that's what they're planning!  If it  
> works, my hat is officially off to their engineering prowess (and  
> sense of cost-is-no-object innovation).
>
> "Everybody, JUMP two three four JUMP two three four!  Damnit, the  
> lights are dimming!  The turntables are slowing down, STOMP GODDAMN  
> YOU PEOPLE!!"  (j/k)
>
> Anyway, the rest of the venture sounds quite interesting.  Will  
> check it out.
>
> WHOOT APOLLO, so good to see you postin'! :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Green Nightclub in SF

Wonder if you could put some on your shoes and keep your cell phone or 
other gear trickle charged while walking...  ;)

I still think the greenest solution we have for everything is to start 
covering all buildings with solar panels.  All the energy absorbed 
should help reduce cooling needed (themodynamics!).

Friend of mine had 9 on his roof.  They paid for themselves in 4 months, 
and he sold a lot of power back to the grid.   Powered all his servers, 
AC, heating, etc all the time.

> There's a nice demonstration at the Exploratorium that shows how unlikely 
> this is...
>
> Two people can sit and pedal to generate electricity.  There's a variety 
> of different things to turn on including lightbulbs and a little space 
> heater.  Turn on the bulbs and the heater and see how long you can pedal.
>
> No way this dance floor even powers one serious amp IMO, but I'd be 
> impressed if I was wrong and it did!
>
> Best,
>
> Peter
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
> To: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
> Cc: Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>; MOJO <orfsound@yahoo.com>; Apollo 
> <apollo@speakeasy.org>; sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Wednesday, January 16, 2008 11:29:00 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Green Nightclub in SF
>
> I had the same thought.
>
> Some of the cardio machines at the gym have a setting which displays
> how many watts I'm generating while I workout.  And it's kind of
> stunning when I'm worked up into a high heart-rate and a lot of sweat,
> just how little of our household lighting I'd be able to power by
> continuously exerting myself on a bike or elliptical.  And we mostly
> have just plain old compact fluorescent bulbs...  no strobes, lasers,
> spotlights, fog machines, projectors, turntables, or anything.  And
> just how much wattage does your average club have in SOUND?  Good on
> them if they really HAVE found a way to juice all that off of pizeos
> in the dancefloor.  But I'm very Very VERY skeptical.
>
> (And what if a DJ plays a song that's not a crowd pleaser and people
> stop dancing?!?!?)
>
> OTOH, if they've found a way to violate the laws of thermodynamics or
> conservation of energy; they certainly deserve to be in the news for a
> lot more than being a "green" dance club.
>
>
> cya,
> john
>
>
> On Jan 16, 2008, at 11:11 AM, georgeC | origami wrote:
>
>> The dancefloor, unfortunately, will most likely be more symbolic
>> than a significant source of power.  Dancers or no dancers, piezos
>> are great at translating vibration into tiny, transient currents
>> (that's why they're used as pickups on many acoustic instruments),
>> but the currents are just that, tiny, and the returns for using
>> bigger and bigger crystals decrease exponentially as you go up,
>> unless they're talking about hundred-layer thick arrays of thin
>> crystals...  They only way I could see this doing much is if the
>> floor is split into smallish squares, each sitting on its own
>> quartet of piezo stacks.  Otherwise, people's non-robotic dance
>> moves might cancel one another out much of the time on a big
>> monolithic floor.  Perhaps that's what they're planning!  If it
>> works, my hat is officially off to their engineering prowess (and
>> sense of cost-is-no-object innovation).
>>
>> "Everybody, JUMP two three four JUMP two three four!  Damnit, the
>> lights are dimming!  The turntables are slowing down, STOMP GODDAMN
>> YOU PEOPLE!!"  (j/k)
>>
>> Anyway, the rest of the venture sounds quite interesting.  Will
>> check it out.
>>
>> WHOOT APOLLO, so good to see you postin'! :)
>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Continuing sets from The Awakenings Festival on An Epiphany Of
 Sound

We 1st aired sets from Day one of last November's Awakenings Festival in 
Amsterdam back in December.  Today we are continuing with sets from Day 
two, featuring sets from Ortin Cam as well as a recording of the Live 
P.A. from Dualtek.  We're already into it, but will be going for another 
2+ hours.  Then, in celebration of Dr. MLK's birthday, we're hoping to 
end the show with his speech "A Time To Break The Silence" where he 
fervently spoke out against the war in Vietnam.  And, not too 
surprising, those words (words that likely got him killed) still hold 
quite true today.  So make sure that you hear them once again.  They're 
important.

We're on the air at 90.1 FM as well as streaming online at 
http://kzsulive.stanford.edu

Hope to have you listening in!



-- 
http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

If you're going to drive a Hummer and buy carbon offsets, that's like
getting drunk every night and getting into an AA meeting, throwing
money in the basket, and leaving.
-- Ed Begley Jr

KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Hotness!


----- Original Message ----
From: J.C. <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Thursday, January 17, 2008 9:55:30 AM
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Continuing sets from The Awakenings Festival on An Epiphany Of Sound

We 1st aired sets from Day one of last November's Awakenings Festival in 
Amsterdam back in December.  Today we are continuing with sets from Day 
two, featuring sets from Ortin Cam as well as a recording of the Live 
P.A. from Dualtek.  We're already into it, but will be going for another 
2+ hours.  Then, in celebration of Dr. MLK's birthday, we're hoping to 
end the show with his speech "A Time To Break The Silence" where he 
fervently spoke out against the war in Vietnam.  And, not too 
surprising, those words (words that likely got him killed) still hold 
quite true today.  So make sure that you hear them once again.  They're 
important.

We're on the air at 90.1 FM as well as streaming online at 
http://kzsulive.stanford.edu

Hope to have you listening in!



-- 
http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

getting drunk every night and getting into an AA meeting, throwing
money in the basket, and leaving.

My mood has gotten so sour and downright angry over this race bullshit 
this election cycle that for Doctor King's birthday this year I posted 
this Rock & Roll Hall of Fame induction performance from a year ago, 
instead of the U2 bit I usually throw up.

and the *very next* person to come on that stage at the Waldorf Astoria 
Hotel on Park Avenue in NYC on that cold winter night was none other 
than Al Sharpton, and he didn't say so much as the word "boo" to her or 
anybody else.

>>> Some of the cardio machines at the gym have a setting which displays
>>> how many watts I'm generating while I workout.  And it's kind of

>>> On Jan 16, 2008, at 11:11 AM, georgeC | origami wrote:
>>>
>>>
>>>> The dancefloor, unfortunately, will most likely be more symbolic
>>>> than a significant source of power.  Dancers or no dancers, piezos
>>>> are great at translating vibration into tiny, transient currents
>>>> (that's why they're used as pickups on many acoustic instruments),
>>>> but the currents are just that, tiny, and the returns for using
>>>> bigger and bigger crystals decrease exponentially as you go up,
>>>> unless they're talking about hundred-layer thick arrays of thin
>>>> crystals...  They only way I could see this doing much is if the
>>>> floor is split into smallish squares, each sitting on its own
>>>> quartet of piezo stacks.  Otherwise, people's non-robotic dance
>>>> moves might cancel one another out much of the time on a big
>>>> monolithic floor.  Perhaps that's what they're planning!  If it
>>>> works, my hat is officially off to their engineering prowess (and
>>>> sense of cost-is-no-object innovation).
>>>>
>>>> "Everybody, JUMP two three four JUMP two three four!  Damnit, the
>>>> lights are dimming!  The turntables are slowing down, STOMP GODDAMN
>>>> YOU PEOPLE!!"  (j/k)
>>>>
>>>> Anyway, the rest of the venture sounds quite interesting.  Will
>>>> check it out.
>>>>
>>>> WHOOT APOLLO, so good to see you postin'! :)
>>>>

http://www.zer01.net:1200/

8pm - 1am Pacific Time

Special guest:: DJ Amber (Sister SF/iamthedj.com)

Disconnect

References: <000801c859fe$41dbfac0$0400a8c0@smithpc> <47921BA4.3070303@sonic.net>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.915)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: ST11

Oh please no.  No more DS9.

And I guess I'm running a little bit contrary to popular opinion  
here.  But I really hope the pic that was posted here is NOT the new  
Enterprise.  They should stay true to the look and spirit of the  
original and just improve the detail and quality of the same design;  
like DS9 did in one of the few episodes that I really and truly DID  
enjoy: Trials and Tribbleations.

I don't know if this IS the new movie Enterprise, or not.  Too many  
sites proclaiming to have pics or trailers and whatnot, and many of  
them contradict each other.  But I really hate many of these fandom re- 
imaginings of the Enterprise, and even some of the official ones (1701- 
E and NX-01).  The dark and aggressive stylings make the Enterprise  
look like a warship.  And that's just so totally wrong that it's  
almost beyond words.

And here's where I fall into total Star Trek nerddom.... but lest we  
forget...

The Enterprise is not, Not, NOT a warship!!!  The Federation are not  
nazis or romans.  And Starfleet's mission is NOT one of war and  
conquest!  The Enterprise is a science vessel  And Starfleet's mission  
is one of diplomacy, research, and peaceful exploration.  It's not  
"... to explore strange new worlds... and conquer them for the emperor  
of earth", "to seek out new life... and kill it".  It's "To boldly go  
where no one has gone before."  Why?  For the same reason that Hillary  
climbed Everest:  Because it's there.

Remember, Roddenberry's vision was of an OPTIMISTIC future.  It was  
his hope and belief that we'd better ourselves, outgrow our baser  
instincts and do away with war and poverty and discrimination and  
religion and nationalism and hate as ways of life... consign all of  
those evils to the dustbin of history, never to be seen again.  And  
then we were supposed to go out into space... just to see what's out  
there.  It wasn't that Earth would build a fleet of battleships and go  
out to take over the galaxy!

That vision and optimism got lost, I think, with the later and lesser  
Treks.

You had DS9... Boldly... uh... sitting around on a space station.  Oh  
wait.  That's boring.  So we'll make the captain a religious prophet!   
(After Roddenberry had made it QUITE clear in TNG that we'd have  
outgrown religion by then.  Grrrr.)   Oh... that's turning out to be  
kind of stupid... so... eh... bring in Worf and take Starfleet to  
WAR.  woot...  We even got Section 31, the Federation's very own  
Gestapo.  uhh.... yay us.

Then there was Voyager.  Boldly running for home with out tails  
between our legs.  But Geri Ryan has BOOBIES at least.

And Enterprise was just a complete train wreck until the second half  
of the last season.  The less said there, the better.

Okay.  So dark and gritty and dystopian makes for some good SciFi.   
Blade Runner is a classic, I still miss Firefly, and the new  
Battlestar Galactica is one of the best shows on TV (When they're not  
wasting time with Starbuck and Apollo being all emo over each other  
that is.).  But that's not Star Trek.  Star Trek is about OPTIMISM and  
the belief that things will get better!  Is it too much to ask to have  
ONE optimistic vision of the future?  Does Paramount even remember how  
to write stories where the solution to every problem is NOT to shoot  
it or blow stuff up?

Clearly, there's a market for a bright outlook on the future and  
Roddenberry's original vision.  I don't think it's a coincidence that  
the two most beloved, well-known, and world-renowned Treks are the two  
which he controlled directly himself and kept true, before the berman  
took over.

Okay, I've ranted long enough, so I'll shut up now.  I need a cookie.

But I still hate that fugly battleship-looking I-hope-it's-not-the- 
Enterprise.  Sorry Ryan.


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: ST11

Without ranting myself...  ;)

I agree with you on most parts. 

If they are going for pre-trek then that ship looks pretty good.  You 
couldn't easily have it "retro-fit" into the one from the series.  
Interior designs will be my concern which was the worst part of 
Enterprise.  there was no logical progression from "post nasa" to STOS 
to STNG.  Just didn't work.  My problem is the whole numbering.  STOS 
was NCC-1701 and the first movie was NCC-1701A.  So this ship better be 
really close to the STOS one, or exactly like it, or it's not going to 
fly and a rip in the time space continuum will open up and a giant 
mecha-rodenberry will come through looking to strangle some financiers 
and producers.

As for DS9, yes, we had moved past religion, but that didn't mean other 
worlds did.  Federation was dealing with some backwater worlds.  The 
station made sense because they were getting a chance with a stable worm 
hole to explore a whole new quadrant that was unreachable by 
conventional means.  The galaxy is a huge place.  The religion was 
nothing more than the worship of aliens than came through the wormhole.  
It's pretty logical and very star trek.  Those aliens could have all 
struggled for power, caused wars and such, but they didn't.  they were 
nice and friendly.

Sisko being half alien was cool I thought.  Spok was half Vulcan, so why 
not half worm hole creature.  I want a DS9 movie to find out what 
happened after since they left it hanging.  This was what I liked about 
DS9, not the war aspect, but everything else.  What happens whhen he 
comes back, and what about Jake who's 1/4 worm hole flying spaghetti 
monster?

I couldn't handle watching Voyager until they brought in the borg.  Then 
it got interesting.

--S

John B wrote:
> Oh please no.  No more DS9.
>
> And I guess I'm running a little bit contrary to popular opinion 
> here.  But I really hope the pic that was posted here is NOT the new 
> Enterprise.  They should stay true to the look and spirit of the 
> original and just improve the detail and quality of the same design; 
> like DS9 did in one of the few episodes that I really and truly DID 
> enjoy: Trials and Tribbleations.
>
> I don't know if this IS the new movie Enterprise, or not.  Too many 
> sites proclaiming to have pics or trailers and whatnot, and many of 
> them contradict each other.  But I really hate many of these fandom 
> re-imaginings of the Enterprise, and even some of the official ones 
> (1701-E and NX-01).  The dark and aggressive stylings make the 
> Enterprise look like a warship.  And that's just so totally wrong that 
> it's almost beyond words.
>
> And here's where I fall into total Star Trek nerddom.... but lest we 
> forget...
>
> The Enterprise is not, Not, NOT a warship!!!  The Federation are not 
> nazis or romans.  And Starfleet's mission is NOT one of war and 
> conquest!  The Enterprise is a science vessel  And Starfleet's mission 
> is one of diplomacy, research, and peaceful exploration.  It's not 
> "... to explore strange new worlds... and conquer them for the emperor 
> of earth", "to seek out new life... and kill it".  It's "To boldly go 
> where no one has gone before."  Why?  For the same reason that Hillary 
> climbed Everest:  Because it's there.
>
> Remember, Roddenberry's vision was of an OPTIMISTIC future.  It was 
> his hope and belief that we'd better ourselves, outgrow our baser 
> instincts and do away with war and poverty and discrimination and 
> religion and nationalism and hate as ways of life... consign all of 
> those evils to the dustbin of history, never to be seen again.  And 
> then we were supposed to go out into space... just to see what's out 
> there.  It wasn't that Earth would build a fleet of battleships and go 
> out to take over the galaxy!
>
> That vision and optimism got lost, I think, with the later and lesser 
> Treks.
>
> You had DS9... Boldly... uh... sitting around on a space station.  Oh 
> wait.  That's boring.  So we'll make the captain a religious prophet!  
> (After Roddenberry had made it QUITE clear in TNG that we'd have 
> outgrown religion by then.  Grrrr.)   Oh... that's turning out to be 
> kind of stupid... so... eh... bring in Worf and take Starfleet to 
> WAR.  woot...  We even got Section 31, the Federation's very own 
> Gestapo.  uhh.... yay us.
>
> Then there was Voyager.  Boldly running for home with out tails 
> between our legs.  But Geri Ryan has BOOBIES at least.
>
> And Enterprise was just a complete train wreck until the second half 
> of the last season.  The less said there, the better.
>
> Okay.  So dark and gritty and dystopian makes for some good SciFi.  
> Blade Runner is a classic, I still miss Firefly, and the new 
> Battlestar Galactica is one of the best shows on TV (When they're not 
> wasting time with Starbuck and Apollo being all emo over each other 
> that is.).  But that's not Star Trek.  Star Trek is about OPTIMISM and 
> the belief that things will get better!  Is it too much to ask to have 
> ONE optimistic vision of the future?  Does Paramount even remember how 
> to write stories where the solution to every problem is NOT to shoot 
> it or blow stuff up?
>
> Clearly, there's a market for a bright outlook on the future and 
> Roddenberry's original vision.  I don't think it's a coincidence that 
> the two most beloved, well-known, and world-renowned Treks are the two 
> which he controlled directly himself and kept true, before the berman 
> took over.
>
> Okay, I've ranted long enough, so I'll shut up now.  I need a cookie.
>
> But I still hate that fugly battleship-looking 
> I-hope-it's-not-the-Enterprise.  Sorry Ryan.
>
>
> cya,
> john
>
>
>
> On Jan 19, 2008, at 7:47 AM, Shatter wrote:
>
>> They arn't going to do an "Enterprise" Movie are they?
>>
>> That series was horrid.  Bring back DS9

On Jan 19, 2008, at 5:43 PM, Shatter wrote:

> Without ranting myself...  ;)
>
> I agree with you on most parts.
> If they are going for pre-trek then that ship looks pretty good.   
> You couldn't easily have it "retro-fit" into the one from the  
> series.  Interior designs will be my concern which was the worst  
> part of Enterprise.  there was no logical progression from "post  
> nasa" to STOS to STNG.  Just didn't work.  My problem is the whole  
> numbering.  STOS was NCC-1701 and the first movie was NCC-1701A.   
> So this ship better be really close to the STOS one, or exactly  
> like it, or it's not going to fly and a rip in the time space  
> continuum will open up and a giant mecha-rodenberry will come  
> through looking to strangle some financiers and producers.
>
> As for DS9, yes, we had moved past religion, but that didn't mean  
> other worlds did.  Federation was dealing with some backwater  
> worlds.  The station made sense because they were getting a chance  
> with a stable worm hole to explore a whole new quadrant that was  
> unreachable by conventional means.  The galaxy is a huge place.   
> The religion was nothing more than the worship of aliens than came  
> through the wormhole.  It's pretty logical and very star trek.   
> Those aliens could have all struggled for power, caused wars and  
> such, but they didn't.  they were nice and friendly.
>
> Sisko being half alien was cool I thought.  Spok was half Vulcan,  
> so why not half worm hole creature.  I want a DS9 movie to find out  
> what happened after since they left it hanging.  This was what I  
> liked about DS9, not the war aspect, but everything else.  What  
> happens whhen he comes back, and what about Jake who's 1/4 worm  
> hole flying spaghetti monster?
>
> I couldn't handle watching Voyager until they brought in the borg.   
> Then it got interesting.

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Yeah, the "aliens being worshipped as gods" thing had been done in  
trek before.

But the very idea of getting caught up in some backwards world's  
superstitions about religious voodoo should have been an anathema to a  
Starfleet officer.  Remember Picard's utter revulsion at the mere  
suggestion of playing god with those pre-vulcans who mistook him as  
one?  He was ready to violate the prime directive and show the locals  
that "hey, we're space just travelers... any sufficient technology is  
indistinguishable from magic, and all that"; instead of following one  
of his scientific staffer's suggestion that he lay down some  
commandments on them!

*That* is  the sort of reaction we should have seen from Sisko.  Not  
all that "look at me, I am the emissary, let me bless your wedding,  
children, and dog" that he had going on.


cya,
john

> with a stable worm hole to explore a whole new quadrant that was  
> unreachable by conventional means.  The galaxy is a huge place.  The  
> religion was nothing more than the worship of aliens than came  
> through the wormhole.  It's pretty logical and very star trek.   
> Those aliens could have all struggled for power, caused wars and  
> such, but they didn't.  they were nice and friendly.


--Apple-Mail-1--828765392--

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
From: "t. toro" <torotoro@technoprisoners.org>
Date: Sun, 20 Jan 2008 05:01:40 -0800
To: John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.753)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: ST11

DS9 is widely accepted to have deviated from Roddenberry's ideal  
Federation. The plot involving the black-ops organization inside  
starfleet whose function was to commit genocide against the founders  
was the point at which DS9 went off the rails. Roddenberry's  
federation was supposed to be saintly and utopian-- a future of  
humanity that, in my opinion, is quite naive. :)

That said, I support a reboot of Star Trek. The same thing was done  
with Batman in Batman Begins. The Enterprise in the picture looks  
like a brilliant revisioning just like what they did with the most  
recent Batmobile. If they can do a treatment of Star Trek like they  
did with Batman in Batman Begins, I'm on board!

-andy

On Jan 19, 2008, at 3:17 PM, John B wrote:

> Oh please no.  No more DS9.
>
> And I guess I'm running a little bit contrary to popular opinion  
> here.  But I really hope the pic that was posted here is NOT the  
> new Enterprise.  They should stay true to the look and spirit of  
> the original and just improve the detail and quality of the same  
> design; like DS9 did in one of the few episodes that I really and  
> truly DID enjoy: Trials and Tribbleations.
>
> I don't know if this IS the new movie Enterprise, or not.  Too many  
> sites proclaiming to have pics or trailers and whatnot, and many of  
> them contradict each other.  But I really hate many of these fandom  
> re-imaginings of the Enterprise, and even some of the official ones  
> (1701-E and NX-01).  The dark and aggressive stylings make the  
> Enterprise look like a warship.  And that's just so totally wrong  
> that it's almost beyond words.
>
> And here's where I fall into total Star Trek nerddom.... but lest  
> we forget...
>
> The Enterprise is not, Not, NOT a warship!!!  The Federation are  
> not nazis or romans.  And Starfleet's mission is NOT one of war and  
> conquest!  The Enterprise is a science vessel  And Starfleet's  
> mission is one of diplomacy, research, and peaceful exploration.   
> It's not "... to explore strange new worlds... and conquer them for  
> the emperor of earth", "to seek out new life... and kill it".  It's  
> "To boldly go where no one has gone before."  Why?  For the same  
> reason that Hillary climbed Everest:  Because it's there.
>
> Remember, Roddenberry's vision was of an OPTIMISTIC future.  It was  
> his hope and belief that we'd better ourselves, outgrow our baser  
> instincts and do away with war and poverty and discrimination and  
> religion and nationalism and hate as ways of life... consign all of  
> those evils to the dustbin of history, never to be seen again.  And  
> then we were supposed to go out into space... just to see what's  
> out there.  It wasn't that Earth would build a fleet of battleships  
> and go out to take over the galaxy!
>
> That vision and optimism got lost, I think, with the later and  
> lesser Treks.
>
> You had DS9... Boldly... uh... sitting around on a space station.   
> Oh wait.  That's boring.  So we'll make the captain a religious  
> prophet!  (After Roddenberry had made it QUITE clear in TNG that  
> we'd have outgrown religion by then.  Grrrr.)   Oh... that's  
> turning out to be kind of stupid... so... eh... bring in Worf and  
> take Starfleet to WAR.  woot...  We even got Section 31, the  
> Federation's very own Gestapo.  uhh.... yay us.
>
> Then there was Voyager.  Boldly running for home with out tails  
> between our legs.  But Geri Ryan has BOOBIES at least.
>
> And Enterprise was just a complete train wreck until the second  
> half of the last season.  The less said there, the better.
>
> Okay.  So dark and gritty and dystopian makes for some good SciFi.   
> Blade Runner is a classic, I still miss Firefly, and the new  
> Battlestar Galactica is one of the best shows on TV (When they're  
> not wasting time with Starbuck and Apollo being all emo over each  
> other that is.).  But that's not Star Trek.  Star Trek is about  
> OPTIMISM and the belief that things will get better!  Is it too  
> much to ask to have ONE optimistic vision of the future?  Does  
> Paramount even remember how to write stories where the solution to  
> every problem is NOT to shoot it or blow stuff up?
>
> Clearly, there's a market for a bright outlook on the future and  
> Roddenberry's original vision.  I don't think it's a coincidence  
> that the two most beloved, well-known, and world-renowned Treks are  
> the two which he controlled directly himself and kept true, before  
> the berman took over.
>
> Okay, I've ranted long enough, so I'll shut up now.  I need a cookie.
>
> But I still hate that fugly battleship-looking I-hope-it's-not-the- 
> Enterprise.  Sorry Ryan.
>
>
> cya,
> john
>
>
>
> On Jan 19, 2008, at 7:47 AM, Shatter wrote:
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: ST11

True story:  When the first ST movie came out some friends of mine decided to take some mushrooms and go see it.  As we were coming out of the theater we saw a guy carrying a large aircraft propeller down the street.  When we asked him why he was carrying it, he said, "Because it doesn't fit in my car."

This past weekend I was helping out a friend that is a mobile DJ that has some developed some serious health problems at a party for a group of 13 year old girls.  I won't go into details about the party here, but it was held in one of the parents office space down off Broadway.  There on the wall in th eopen space that became the dance floor was the propeller or at least one almost identical to it.  

Unfortunately the original owner of the propeller wasn't there so I couldn't ask him if he had been carrying it down the street one day many years ago.

This has nothing do with ST really, but it reminded me of this recent event.

Best,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: t. toro <torotoro@technoprisoners.org>
To: John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Cc: Shatter <shatter@sonic.net>; Ryan Smith <sf_smith@comcast.net>; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Sunday, January 20, 2008 5:01:40 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: ST11

DS9 is widely accepted to have deviated from Roddenberry's ideal  
Federation. The plot involving the black-ops organization inside  
starfleet whose function was to commit genocide against the founders  
was the point at which DS9 went off the rails. Roddenberry's  
federation was supposed to be saintly and utopian-- a future of  
humanity that, in my opinion, is quite naive. :)

That said, I support a reboot of Star Trek. The same thing was done  
with Batman in Batman Begins. The Enterprise in the picture looks  
like a brilliant revisioning just like what they did with the most  
recent Batmobile. If they can do a treatment of Star Trek like they  
did with Batman in Batman Begins, I'm on board!

-andy

On Jan 19, 2008, at 3:17 PM, John B wrote:

> Oh please no.  No more DS9.
>
> And I guess I'm running a little bit contrary to popular opinion  
> here.  But I really hope the pic that was posted here is NOT the  
> new Enterprise.  They should stay true to the look and spirit of  
> the original and just improve the detail and quality of the same  
> design; like DS9 did in one of the few episodes that I really and  
> truly DID enjoy: Trials and Tribbleations.
>
> I don't know if this IS the new movie Enterprise, or not.  Too many  
> sites proclaiming to have pics or trailers and whatnot, and many of  
> them contradict each other.  But I really hate many of these fandom  
> re-imaginings of the Enterprise, and even some of the official ones  
> (1701-E and NX-01).  The dark and aggressive stylings make the  
> Enterprise look like a warship.  And that's just so totally wrong  
> that it's almost beyond words.
>
> And here's where I fall into total Star Trek nerddom.... but lest  
> we forget...
>
> The Enterprise is not, Not, NOT a warship!!!  The Federation are  
> not nazis or romans.  And Starfleet's mission is NOT one of war and  
> conquest!  The Enterprise is a science vessel  And Starfleet's  
> mission is one of diplomacy, research, and peaceful exploration.  
> It's not "... to explore strange new worlds... and conquer them for  
> the emperor of earth", "to seek out new life... and kill it".  It's  
> "To boldly go where no one has gone before."  Why?  For the same  
> reason that Hillary climbed Everest:  Because it's there.
>
> Remember, Roddenberry's vision was of an OPTIMISTIC future.  It was  
> his hope and belief that we'd better ourselves, outgrow our baser  
> instincts and do away with war and poverty and discrimination and  
> religion and nationalism and hate as ways of life... consign all of  
> those evils to the dustbin of history, never to be seen again.  And  
> then we were supposed to go out into space... just to see what's  
> out there.  It wasn't that Earth would build a fleet of battleships  
> and go out to take over the galaxy!
>
> That vision and optimism got lost, I think, with the later and  
> lesser Treks.
>
> You had DS9... Boldly... uh... sitting around on a space station.  
> Oh wait.  That's boring.  So we'll make the captain a religious  
> prophet!  (After Roddenberry had made it QUITE clear in TNG that  
> we'd have outgrown religion by then.  Grrrr.)  Oh... that's  
> turning out to be kind of stupid... so... eh... bring in Worf and  
> take Starfleet to WAR.  woot...  We even got Section 31, the  
> Federation's very own Gestapo.  uhh.... yay us.
>
> Then there was Voyager.  Boldly running for home with out tails  
> between our legs.  But Geri Ryan has BOOBIES at least.
>
> And Enterprise was just a complete train wreck until the second  
> half of the last season.  The less said there, the better.
>
> Okay.  So dark and gritty and dystopian makes for some good SciFi.  
> Blade Runner is a classic, I still miss Firefly, and the new  
> Battlestar Galactica is one of the best shows on TV (When they're  
> not wasting time with Starbuck and Apollo being all emo over each  
> other that is.).  But that's not Star Trek.  Star Trek is about  
> OPTIMISM and the belief that things will get better!  Is it too  
> much to ask to have ONE optimistic vision of the future?  Does  
> Paramount even remember how to write stories where the solution to  
> every problem is NOT to shoot it or blow stuff up?
>
> Clearly, there's a market for a bright outlook on the future and  
> Roddenberry's original vision.  I don't think it's a coincidence  
> that the two most beloved, well-known, and world-renowned Treks are  
> the two which he controlled directly himself and kept true, before  
> the berman took over.
>
> Okay, I've ranted long enough, so I'll shut up now.  I need a cookie.
>
> But I still hate that fugly battleship-looking I-hope-it's-not-the- 
> Enterprise.  Sorry Ryan.
>
>
> cya,
> john

References: <000801c859fe$41dbfac0$0400a8c0@smithpc> <47921BA4.3070303@sonic.net> <0E8D4696-D8C1-459F-AA58-75C60C75DAA9@yahoo.com> <27175B94-81E4-46B7-A5B1-44C3D33847FA@technoprisoners.org>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; delsp=yes; format=flowed

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
From: Deepfog <sfo@deepfog.com>
Date: Sun, 20 Jan 2008 10:04:16 -0800
To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.753)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: ST11

Well now the only thing is what about the movie The Undiscovered  
Country.  There you had criminal elements of 3 governments conspiring  
to start a war.  It might not have been an official, organized black- 
ops group, but killing the Klingon chancellor and blaming it on Kirk  
and McCoy certainly was, if you look at it it fits right in with the  
likes of Sept. 11, 7/7, and a host of others that are pretty much  
real life and common knowledge.  This to me in itself suggests that  
Gene Roddenberry knew that this kind of stuff goes on in the world.

Where I think Star Trek got too far off track was the long drawn out  
war between the Federation and the guys from the Gamma Quadrant, I  
can't really remember their names right now.  But that's just me and  
it's not like there weren't other wars in the Star Trek Universe.  I  
believe the real formula that Gene Roddenberry always wanted to hold  
to was to give the villian a chance to redeem himself, which was  
something that Malcolm McDowell did not do in Generations, the first  
movie after Roddenberry died.

A side note their last movie I had a hard time dealing with their  
killing and subsequent rebirth of Data, but I guess that would  
probably be the last time you see them on screen in those roles.

I could go on and on about Star Trek once I get going, this is not  
necessarily a good thing, it rolls me back to the days when I used to  
watch hours and hours of TV a day.

From: "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: ST11

Just saw Nimoy's ST IV for the first time in a long time yesterday, 
easily the best written and most playful of the bunch and made me sad to 
see how much the mad rush of money ruined SF in such a short period of 
time from when the movie was shot.

Sure the show was cheesy, the acting laughable, and the Art Direction a 
joke, but its impact in the era it was made can not be misunderestimated.

Hard to grasp it today, but Jeez Louise, a multi-racial crew, a black 
woman as an equal in a time when not only was TV lily-white, but the 
Supreme Court had just ruled that marriages between the races was legal?

Unheard of.

While self-serving as hell this really lays out a strong case as to just 
how much of an engine this show was in our culture:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_William_Shatner_Changed_the_World

I predict that the next innovation that we're going to see in our Modern 
World that can be traced back to Star Trek is Dr. McCoy's medical 
tricorder and it's going to happen in under 20 years, if not sooner.

~Nyc


Deepfog wrote:
> Well now the only thing is what about the movie The Undiscovered 
> Country.  There you had criminal elements of 3 governments conspiring 
> to start a war.  It might not have been an official, organized 
> black-ops group, but killing the Klingon chancellor and blaming it on 
> Kirk and McCoy certainly was, if you look at it it fits right in with 
> the likes of Sept. 11, 7/7, and a host of others that are pretty much 
> real life and common knowledge.  This to me in itself suggests that 
> Gene Roddenberry knew that this kind of stuff goes on in the world.
>
> Where I think Star Trek got too far off track was the long drawn out 
> war between the Federation and the guys from the Gamma Quadrant, I 
> can't really remember their names right now.  But that's just me and 
> it's not like there weren't other wars in the Star Trek Universe.  I 
> believe the real formula that Gene Roddenberry always wanted to hold 
> to was to give the villian a chance to redeem himself, which was 
> something that Malcolm McDowell did not do in Generations, the first 
> movie after Roddenberry died.
>
> A side note their last movie I had a hard time dealing with their 
> killing and subsequent rebirth of Data, but I guess that would 
> probably be the last time you see them on screen in those roles.
>
> I could go on and on about Star Trek once I get going, this is not 
> necessarily a good thing, it rolls me back to the days when I used to 
> watch hours and hours of TV a day.
>

>> federation was supposed to be saintly and utopian-- a future of 
>> humanity that, in my opinion, is quite naive. :)

>> On Jan 19, 2008, at 3:17 PM, John B wrote:
>>
>>> Oh please no.  No more DS9.
>>>
>>> And I guess I'm running a little bit contrary to popular opinion 
>>> here.  But I really hope the pic that was posted here is NOT the new 
>>> Enterprise.  They should stay true to the look and spirit of the 
>>> original and just improve the detail and quality of the same design; 
>>> like DS9 did in one of the few episodes that I really and truly DID 
>>> enjoy: Trials and Tribbleations.
>>>
>>> I don't know if this IS the new movie Enterprise, or not.  Too many 
>>> sites proclaiming to have pics or trailers and whatnot, and many of 
>>> them contradict each other.  But I really hate many of these fandom 
>>> re-imaginings of the Enterprise, and even some of the official ones 
>>> (1701-E and NX-01).  The dark and aggressive stylings make the 
>>> Enterprise look like a warship.  And that's just so totally wrong 
>>> that it's almost beyond words.
>>>
>>> And here's where I fall into total Star Trek nerddom.... but lest we 
>>> forget...
>>>
>>> The Enterprise is not, Not, NOT a warship!!!  The Federation are not 
>>> nazis or romans.  And Starfleet's mission is NOT one of war and 
>>> conquest!  The Enterprise is a science vessel  And Starfleet's 
>>> mission is one of diplomacy, research, and peaceful exploration.  
>>> It's not "... to explore strange new worlds... and conquer them for 
>>> the emperor of earth", "to seek out new life... and kill it".  It's 
>>> "To boldly go where no one has gone before."  Why?  For the same 
>>> reason that Hillary climbed Everest:  Because it's there.
>>>
>>> Remember, Roddenberry's vision was of an OPTIMISTIC future.  It was 
>>> his hope and belief that we'd better ourselves, outgrow our baser 
>>> instincts and do away with war and poverty and discrimination and 
>>> religion and nationalism and hate as ways of life... consign all of 
>>> those evils to the dustbin of history, never to be seen again.  And 
>>> then we were supposed to go out into space... just to see what's out 
>>> there.  It wasn't that Earth would build a fleet of battleships and 
>>> go out to take over the galaxy!
>>>
>>> That vision and optimism got lost, I think, with the later and 
>>> lesser Treks.
>>>
>>> You had DS9... Boldly... uh... sitting around on a space station.  
>>> Oh wait.  That's boring.  So we'll make the captain a religious 
>>> prophet!  (After Roddenberry had made it QUITE clear in TNG that 
>>> we'd have outgrown religion by then.  Grrrr.)   Oh... that's turning 
>>> out to be kind of stupid... so... eh... bring in Worf and take 
>>> Starfleet to WAR.  woot...  We even got Section 31, the Federation's 
>>> very own Gestapo.  uhh.... yay us.
>>>
>>> Then there was Voyager.  Boldly running for home with out tails 
>>> between our legs.  But Geri Ryan has BOOBIES at least.
>>>
>>> And Enterprise was just a complete train wreck until the second half 
>>> of the last season.  The less said there, the better.
>>>
>>> Okay.  So dark and gritty and dystopian makes for some good SciFi.  
>>> Blade Runner is a classic, I still miss Firefly, and the new 
>>> Battlestar Galactica is one of the best shows on TV (When they're 
>>> not wasting time with Starbuck and Apollo being all emo over each 
>>> other that is.).  But that's not Star Trek.  Star Trek is about 
>>> OPTIMISM and the belief that things will get better!  Is it too much 
>>> to ask to have ONE optimistic vision of the future?  Does Paramount 
>>> even remember how to write stories where the solution to every 
>>> problem is NOT to shoot it or blow stuff up?
>>>
>>> Clearly, there's a market for a bright outlook on the future and 
>>> Roddenberry's original vision.  I don't think it's a coincidence 
>>> that the two most beloved, well-known, and world-renowned Treks are 
>>> the two which he controlled directly himself and kept true, before 
>>> the berman took over.
>>>
>>> Okay, I've ranted long enough, so I'll shut up now.  I need a cookie.
>>>
>>> But I still hate that fugly battleship-looking 
>>> I-hope-it's-not-the-Enterprise.  Sorry Ryan.
>>>
>>>
>>> cya,
>>> john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: ST11

Ahhhh... but here's where I reveal how bad of a Star Trek nerd I used  
to be.

Back in the '90s, I actually bought and read some of the "making of"  
books about Trek.  Shatner's own "Star Trek Movie Memories" comes to  
mind.

By the time The Undiscovered Country was in production, Roddenberry's  
health was already failing, fairly badly. Towards the end of TNG, he  
had already been forced to relinquish most of the day to day control  
over the production to berman.  And Paramount used Roddenberry's  
illnesses as an excuse to cut him out of the movie production  
entirely.  Star Trek VI was almost totally under the control of it's  
director, Nicholas Meyer; with Roddenberry included only in a  
"consultant" role.  In reality, his wishes and input were totally  
ignored.

And his dissatisfaction with the script was well known.  He HATED that  
Meyer had Starfleet officers conspiring in presidential  
assassinations.  And he was disgusted with the racism shown by the  
Enterprise crew.  In fact, several of the ACTORS (I think Nichols,  
Takei, and Kelly were the most vocal, IIRC.) hated the racism and  
warmongering they were being called upon to sink to; and refused to  
perform certain several lines and at least one entire scene.  As dark  
as ST:VI was, the degeneration of the characters was actually LESS in  
the final movie than what was scripted!

Production was complete.... just barely.... in time for The  
Undiscovered Country to be screened for Roddenberry a couple of months  
before he died. And he hated it.  He publicly disavowed it; and  
declared it apocryphal, not a part of his vision of the future.


cya,
john

And let's not forget that if it weren't for Gene Rodenberry, it's 
unlikely that Barack Obama would have made this speech today as a 
Presidential front running candidate at Doctor Martin Luther King's 
Ebeneezer Baptist Church: 
http://silencedmajority.blogs.com/silenced_majority_portal/2008/01/barack-obama-sp.html


Sounds like a bold statement, not tied to objective reality, I know, but 
I can *completely* back it up, have a look at this:
http://www.wpri.org/blog/?p=111

I'd like to think that somewhere Gene is out there laughing his ass off 
at this shit.

Live Long And Prosper, and stuff.

~Nyc
..

Deepfog wrote:
> Well now the only thing is what about the movie The Undiscovered 
> Country.  There you had criminal elements of 3 governments conspiring 
> to start a war.  It might not have been an official, organized 
> black-ops group, but killing the Klingon chancellor and blaming it on 
> Kirk and McCoy certainly was, if you look at it it fits right in with 
> the likes of Sept. 11, 7/7, and a host of others that are pretty much 
> real life and common knowledge.  This to me in itself suggests that 
> Gene Roddenberry knew that this kind of stuff goes on in the world.
>
> Where I think Star Trek got too far off track was the long drawn out 
> war between the Federation and the guys from the Gamma Quadrant, I 
> can't really remember their names right now.  But that's just me and 
> it's not like there weren't other wars in the Star Trek Universe.  I 
> believe the real formula that Gene Roddenberry always wanted to hold 
> to was to give the villian a chance to redeem himself, which was 
> something that Malcolm McDowell did not do in Generations, the first 
> movie after Roddenberry died.
>
> A side note their last movie I had a hard time dealing with their 
> killing and subsequent rebirth of Data, but I guess that would 
> probably be the last time you see them on screen in those roles.
>
> I could go on and on about Star Trek once I get going, this is not 
> necessarily a good thing, it rolls me back to the days when I used to 
> watch hours and hours of TV a day.
>
>
> On Jan 20, 2008, at 5:01 AM, t. toro wrote:
>
>> DS9 is widely accepted to have deviated from Roddenberry's ideal 
>> Federation. The plot involving the black-ops organization inside 
>> starfleet whose function was to commit genocide against the founders 
>> was the point at which DS9 went off the rails. Roddenberry's 
>> federation was supposed to be saintly and utopian-- a future of 
>> humanity that, in my opinion, is quite naive. :)
>>
>> That said, I support a reboot of Star Trek. The same thing was done 
>> with Batman in Batman Begins. The Enterprise in the picture looks 
>> like a brilliant revisioning just like what they did with the most 
>> recent Batmobile. If they can do a treatment of Star Trek like they 
>> did with Batman in Batman Begins, I'm on board!
>>
>> -andy
>>
>> On Jan 19, 2008, at 3:17 PM, John B wrote:
>>
>>> Oh please no.  No more DS9.
>>>
>>> And I guess I'm running a little bit contrary to popular opinion 
>>> here.  But I really hope the pic that was posted here is NOT the new 
>>> Enterprise.  They should stay true to the look and spirit of the 
>>> original and just improve the detail and quality of the same design; 
>>> like DS9 did in one of the few episodes that I really and truly DID 
>>> enjoy: Trials and Tribbleations.
>>>
>>> I don't know if this IS the new movie Enterprise, or not.  Too many 
>>> sites proclaiming to have pics or trailers and whatnot, and many of 
>>> them contradict each other.  But I really hate many of these fandom 
>>> re-imaginings of the Enterprise, and even some of the official ones 
>>> (1701-E and NX-01).  The dark and aggressive stylings make the 
>>> Enterprise look like a warship.  And that's just so totally wrong 
>>> that it's almost beyond words.
>>>
>>> And here's where I fall into total Star Trek nerddom.... but lest we 
>>> forget...
>>>
>>> The Enterprise is not, Not, NOT a warship!!!  The Federation are not 
>>> nazis or romans.  And Starfleet's mission is NOT one of war and 
>>> conquest!  The Enterprise is a science vessel  And Starfleet's 
>>> mission is one of diplomacy, research, and peaceful exploration.  
>>> It's not "... to explore strange new worlds... and conquer them for 
>>> the emperor of earth", "to seek out new life... and kill it".  It's 
>>> "To boldly go where no one has gone before."  Why?  For the same 
>>> reason that Hillary climbed Everest:  Because it's there.
>>>
>>> Remember, Roddenberry's vision was of an OPTIMISTIC future.  It was 
>>> his hope and belief that we'd better ourselves, outgrow our baser 
>>> instincts and do away with war and poverty and discrimination and 
>>> religion and nationalism and hate as ways of life... consign all of 
>>> those evils to the dustbin of history, never to be seen again.  And 
>>> then we were supposed to go out into space... just to see what's out 
>>> there.  It wasn't that Earth would build a fleet of battleships and 
>>> go out to take over the galaxy!
>>>
>>> That vision and optimism got lost, I think, with the later and 
>>> lesser Treks.
>>>
>>> You had DS9... Boldly... uh... sitting around on a space station.  
>>> Oh wait.  That's boring.  So we'll make the captain a religious 
>>> prophet!  (After Roddenberry had made it QUITE clear in TNG that 
>>> we'd have outgrown religion by then.  Grrrr.)   Oh... that's turning 
>>> out to be kind of stupid... so... eh... bring in Worf and take 
>>> Starfleet to WAR.  woot...  We even got Section 31, the Federation's 
>>> very own Gestapo.  uhh.... yay us.
>>>
>>> Then there was Voyager.  Boldly running for home with out tails 
>>> between our legs.  But Geri Ryan has BOOBIES at least.
>>>
>>> And Enterprise was just a complete train wreck until the second half 
>>> of the last season.  The less said there, the better.
>>>
>>> Okay.  So dark and gritty and dystopian makes for some good SciFi.  
>>> Blade Runner is a classic, I still miss Firefly, and the new 
>>> Battlestar Galactica is one of the best shows on TV (When they're 
>>> not wasting time with Starbuck and Apollo being all emo over each 
>>> other that is.).  But that's not Star Trek.  Star Trek is about 
>>> OPTIMISM and the belief that things will get better!  Is it too much 
>>> to ask to have ONE optimistic vision of the future?  Does Paramount 
>>> even remember how to write stories where the solution to every 
>>> problem is NOT to shoot it or blow stuff up?
>>>
>>> Clearly, there's a market for a bright outlook on the future and 
>>> Roddenberry's original vision.  I don't think it's a coincidence 
>>> that the two most beloved, well-known, and world-renowned Treks are 
>>> the two which he controlled directly himself and kept true, before 
>>> the berman took over.
>>>
>>> Okay, I've ranted long enough, so I'll shut up now.  I need a cookie.
>>>
>>> But I still hate that fugly battleship-looking 
>>> I-hope-it's-not-the-Enterprise.  Sorry Ryan.
>>>
>>>
>>> cya,
>>> john
>>>
>>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: ST11

Yeah...  I loved The Voyage Home; and though the Enterprise herself is  
sadly lacking, I still think it's easily the best of the Star Trek  
movies.  I think it's really the truest to TOS and TNG of all of them.

Consider:  There's no villain or bad guy who needs to be blown up.  No  
fall from grace on the part of Starfleet or the Federation.  The  
entire drama of the movie is the result of a fucked-up situation we  
get ourselves into by our own short-sightedness.  And there's no  
simply shooting our way out of the problem.  Someone actually has to  
be clever.

Combine that, with a healthy injection of the humor that was present  
in TOS, but missing from the first three movies; and you've got one  
fine motion picture IMO.

FUN FACT:  The whales in Star Trek IV were robots built by Industrial  
Light and Magic and filmed in a local high-school swimming pool.  When  
the movie was released; the PETA types went into hystarics, and  
bombarded the studio with complaints and protests about how wrong it  
was for them to get that close and harass and molest whales in the wild!

I can see where parts of IV look dated too.  But by the standards of  
the day, those were some damn fine SFX.


cya,
john


On Jan 20, 2008, at 10:27 AM, Nyc W. Alberts wrote:

> Just saw Nimoy's ST IV for the first time in a long time yesterday,  
> easily the best written and most playful of the bunch and made me  
> sad to see how much the mad rush of money ruined SF in such a short  
> period of time from when the movie was shot.
>
> Sure the show was cheesy, the acting laughable, and the Art  
> Direction a joke, but its impact in the era it was made can not be  
> misunderestimated.
>
> Hard to grasp it today, but Jeez Louise, a multi-racial crew, a  
> black woman as an equal in a time when not only was TV lily-white,  
> but the Supreme Court had just ruled that marriages between the  
> races was legal?
>
> Unheard of.
>
> While self-serving as hell this really lays out a strong case as to  
> just how much of an engine this show was in our culture:
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_William_Shatner_Changed_the_World
>
> I predict that the next innovation that we're going to see in our  
> Modern World that can be traced back to Star Trek is Dr. McCoy's  
> medical tricorder and it's going to happen in under 20 years, if not  
> sooner.
>
> ~Nyc
>
>

>>>> Oh please no.  No more DS9.
>>>>
>>>> And I guess I'm running a little bit contrary to popular opinion  
>>>> here.  But I really hope the pic that was posted here is NOT the  
>>>> new Enterprise.  They should stay true to the look and spirit of  
>>>> the original and just improve the detail and quality of the same  
>>>> design; like DS9 did in one of the few episodes that I really and  
>>>> truly DID enjoy: Trials and Tribbleations.
>>>>
>>>> I don't know if this IS the new movie Enterprise, or not.  Too  
>>>> many sites proclaiming to have pics or trailers and whatnot, and  
>>>> many of them contradict each other.  But I really hate many of  
>>>> these fandom re-imaginings of the Enterprise, and even some of  
>>>> the official ones (1701-E and NX-01).  The dark and aggressive  
>>>> stylings make the Enterprise look like a warship.  And that's  
>>>> just so totally wrong that it's almost beyond words.
>>>>
>>>> And here's where I fall into total Star Trek nerddom.... but lest  
>>>> we forget...
>>>>
>>>> The Enterprise is not, Not, NOT a warship!!!  The Federation are  
>>>> not nazis or romans.  And Starfleet's mission is NOT one of war  
>>>> and conquest!  The Enterprise is a science vessel  And  
>>>> Starfleet's mission is one of diplomacy, research, and peaceful  
>>>> exploration.  It's not "... to explore strange new worlds... and  
>>>> conquer them for the emperor of earth", "to seek out new life...  
>>>> and kill it".  It's "To boldly go where no one has gone before."   
>>>> Why?  For the same reason that Hillary climbed Everest:  Because  
>>>> it's there.
>>>>
>>>> Remember, Roddenberry's vision was of an OPTIMISTIC future.  It  
>>>> was his hope and belief that we'd better ourselves, outgrow our  
>>>> baser instincts and do away with war and poverty and  
>>>> discrimination and religion and nationalism and hate as ways of  
>>>> life... consign all of those evils to the dustbin of history,  
>>>> never to be seen again.  And then we were supposed to go out into  
>>>> space... just to see what's out there.  It wasn't that Earth  
>>>> would build a fleet of battleships and go out to take over the  
>>>> galaxy!
>>>>
>>>> That vision and optimism got lost, I think, with the later and  
>>>> lesser Treks.
>>>>
>>>> You had DS9... Boldly... uh... sitting around on a space  
>>>> station.  Oh wait.  That's boring.  So we'll make the captain a  
>>>> religious prophet!  (After Roddenberry had made it QUITE clear in  
>>>> TNG that we'd have outgrown religion by then.  Grrrr.)   Oh...  
>>>> that's turning out to be kind of stupid... so... eh... bring in  
>>>> Worf and take Starfleet to WAR.  woot...  We even got Section 31,  
>>>> the Federation's very own Gestapo.  uhh.... yay us.
>>>>
>>>> Then there was Voyager.  Boldly running for home with out tails  
>>>> between our legs.  But Geri Ryan has BOOBIES at least.
>>>>
>>>> And Enterprise was just a complete train wreck until the second  
>>>> half of the last season.  The less said there, the better.
>>>>
>>>> Okay.  So dark and gritty and dystopian makes for some good  
>>>> SciFi.  Blade Runner is a classic, I still miss Firefly, and the  
>>>> new Battlestar Galactica is one of the best shows on TV (When  
>>>> they're not wasting time with Starbuck and Apollo being all emo  
>>>> over each other that is.).  But that's not Star Trek.  Star Trek  
>>>> is about OPTIMISM and the belief that things will get better!  Is  
>>>> it too much to ask to have ONE optimistic vision of the future?   
>>>> Does Paramount even remember how to write stories where the  
>>>> solution to every problem is NOT to shoot it or blow stuff up?
>>>>
>>>> Clearly, there's a market for a bright outlook on the future and  
>>>> Roddenberry's original vision.  I don't think it's a coincidence  
>>>> that the two most beloved, well-known, and world-renowned Treks  
>>>> are the two which he controlled directly himself and kept true,  
>>>> before the berman took over.
>>>>
>>>> Okay, I've ranted long enough, so I'll shut up now.  I need a  
>>>> cookie.
>>>>
>>>> But I still hate that fugly battleship-looking I-hope-it's-not- 
>>>> the-Enterprise.  Sorry Ryan.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] oakland "duffman" rave busted

While I agree with your point, the problem with condemned buildings is that in general you don't know WHy they are condemned.  Could be structurally unsound, contain toxic materials, etc. 

Some people are talking about having seen hazmat cleanup teams at this location and knowing the building I wouldn't be surprised, although personally I'd be more worried about some of the exterior elements of the building falling on people especially since the building was abandoned right after Loma Prieta.

(http://www.nationaltrust.org/Magazine/archives/arc_news_2005/050405.htm)

Peter

Subject: [sfraves] Groove The Movie

Hey all....

So, a couple of weeks ago someone was asking where they could find a  
copy of Groove.  I was out shopping today, and found it.  The Amoeba  
Records in the upper Haight has one copy in the DVDs area of their  
electronica section (I already have Groove, and was actually looking  
for Better Living Through Circuitry.... no luck tho.).

They have it stickered as "Out of Print" and it costs $35.  Good luck.


cya,
john

Subject: [sfraves] WR:  My Saturday Adventure

So like Sartuday, i got up early & went to a family gathering for a few
hours.. then i went to this Birthday party for former SFR reg Catt's kid
Tyler (she says HI if anyone remembers her) & had some yummy pizza & cake
& some mondo bonding time w/ Catt 'cause it's been forever.. Oooh.. So
Dope 'cause I Love My Catt so much & it was a much needed thing!!!

Then like ok.. so i was amost gonna go to Duff Man III, but well... things
just didn't work out like that & I ended up in the City going to the
Remarc shindig @ 222 Hyde.... like ok... so i never been there before &
like Wow... it's a Groovy lil hole in the wall spot... tiny & like just
really HOT.. the basement dancefloor was packed & I could only stand
dancing down there for like moments at a time.. Hello 2day... but it was
FUN!!  The DJ were War Breaker, SillyKid, & Frankie.. & they all just
busted some yummy raga jungle.. & alota atmo stuff too... i mean... rage &
atmo aren't really my flavors in Jungle tbh, but I needed to get my Groovy
on & it was good to just let loose & get free on the floor with...

Then like Remarc (the OG Raga Jungle producer/ dj who's, from what the
promoters were like sayin', never been out to SF yet) slammed out this
hella hard raga set to close.... it was fuckin' just i mean... he brought
it... he really did... from what people were sayin' that night, he didn't
play his usual Rock Jungle stuff (I was tinkin' like Dieselboy Rock jungle
kinda stuff, & as per his recent CDs & mixes), but he played a strait
proper raga set that made the floor go crazy... I mean... i was brokin'
out hard too 'cause just i kinda went w/ the energy flow all around me on
the dancefloor, so it was kinda fun just step kickin' around my space &
feelin' it!!

It was a good turn out for the night... the floor was always packed, I
hung out w/ alot my Jungle Familia, & it just felt reeeeeeally Awesome to
be there!!  Met some new people & actually bumped into an old online Homie
who i lost touch with a few years back.. so that was like hella bizzare
just catchin' up with him again :)  YAAAY!!  But it was a good night.. so
totally mondo Yummy!!!

Afterwards, my Homegirl Kenzie let me stay @ her place to wait for BART to
open & that was fun... we ate this burrito that she happily like shared w/
me  & YAAAY!  That was Dope!!  Then Her & our Girl Sara like passed out
while i watched Hairspray & RENT... but i just like totally felt like I
had to leave 'cause I didn't wanna well.. noisey from watchin' her DVDs...
so around 6AM, I cut & waited around for BART to open... i ended up kinda
hangin' out w/ these to homeless dudes @ the Powell station... this 1 guy
was like walkin' all over the place 'cause he was tellin' stories & usin'
himself as a visual aid by pantimiming the story & the other dude was just
like laughing & eating his 7-11 treats... oh yeah.. they gave me a swig of
their "adult drink" (this like liter & 1/2 bottle of aquirt mixed w/
vodka... oh yeah... to stay awake 'cause i was almost like on the edge of
like hella mondo fuckin' tired from alll the dancing... i had this caffine
pill on me that i just carry incase of emergancy & endedup taking 1/2 of
it @ Kenz's pad, then the other 1/2 when i was w/. the holeless guys...
Thankfully i was awake 'til i got home like by 10:30ish... YAAAY.. ok...
yeah!!

Hope y'all had a good weekend!!!

-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)
