Subject: RE: [sfraves] oakland "duffman" rave busted

I'm not so sure the after-party bust was so surprising. I've 
been to that renegade location before, and a caravan of cars would 
attract a lot of attention. (it's a crazy renegade spot though!)

The original party location was used successfully a number of 
times before, although the whole permission/arrangement is a bit 
weird. I got a little bit of a briefing from one of the guys 
first time the space was used. From what I've read, this weekend 
was a bit out of control. Their shuttle fell though (!?) so 
they used cars to shuttle, and they had an outdoor area setup 
too? Some "shuttle drivers" braggingly posted how they blasted 
HHC to-and-from the venue (?).

One thing's for sure, responsibility and ethics aside, these 
kids throwing parties these days have big balls, so the times their 
parties do go off it's pretty epic.

Myself, asleep by 11pm, I've been biking bay trails in the 
mornings lately, kind of a healthy change-of-pace thing. I'm 
coming back out doing visuals for Michael Liu's party and a 
Moksha coming up soon :-)

-terry

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] oakland "duffman" rave busted

It is an amazing building...I had been in there before Loma Prieta.

I don't know how safe I would feel in there knowing the building was condemned for being structurally unsound back in 89 and hasn't been repaired (just gutted) since.  Probably its fine unless there is another large quake while you are in there though.

This morning I see some of the kids over on BR are speculating that there was asbestos being removed from there.  I don't know if that's really true, but partying in a building during asbestos removal might not be such a great idea.  IMO.

Best,

Peter

PS Moksha?  You tease!

with residents Solekandi, Kontact (possible last SF appearances) and

integrated at the blissfactory with djs Amber, Sir Nod, and Dragn'fly.

turning on the main stacks and hooking up the smoke machine mit 
strobelight for some atmosphere. its really hard to play bang bang bang 
schranz to an empty room.. especially without the funnybone twitching, 
teeth rattling sound system. mmmm.

if anybody is interested in coming on down to the blissfactory for that 
night, friday the first/2-1-8, and you know where it is, just drop on by 
with enough byob to share and some snacks. if you don't know 'where its 
at' just e-mail me for directions to the blissfactory and you're always 
welcome by.

fucking start stop picking at the goddamned scab all the time.

I commune with the dead of the WTC by walking down named NYC streets 
that are pocked with filled potholes.

6.5 years in a little over a month and a half and they still haven't 
reached street level with the construction, face it the American Empire 
is dead, dead, dead and has been sold off to Dubai.

http://www.metropolismag.com/cda/story.php?artid=3047/
/
> /In the six years since the Twin Towers fell, a thousand skyscrapers 
> have been rising on the Arabian Gulf./
Please give this shit a rest, talk about Ron Paul's second place win in 
NV instead, m'kay?

We get it, the civilian deaths of 1/1000th of 1% of the US population, 
and the utter destruction of 25+ acres of prime American Real Estate, 
was used by PNAC as the excuse they needed to launch the war for oil 
against Iraq that they had been salivating over since 1998. What's your 
point in continually re-dredging any of this up, is anybody going to be 
miraculously resurrected from the dead, because short of that this seems 
like a waste of productive energy that can be applied elsewhere.

Like putting a Martin Luther King quote, on a day when his legacy is to 
be reflected on, underneath some tid-bit about Ron Paul, that no more 
than 10% of the voters care about.

Thanks!

You know and the funny thing is i actually went to Shine this weekend  
and I was thinking about writing a post just right now about it.  But  
I just don't know, maybe I should just consider leaving these rave  
lists altogether.  Everyone else I have ever hung out with left a  
long ass time ago.

If I do leave, I know that will probably make Philip, Nyc and  
especially Peter very happy if I do, but I'll wait a little bit to  
decide so I'm not making an emotional decision.  I'm sorry if this  
email seems a little crabby but I'm wondering if I should just move on.

Have a nice week guys and maybe I'll post something next week if I am  
feeling up to it.

MIME-Version: 1.0

	boundary="----=_Part_17125_29507336.1200958200144"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

------=_Part_17125_29507336.1200958200144
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I see it everywhere, and it's definitely a lot more obvious in SF than LA.
People hate trance here. I can see why, since the genre has lost most of its
integrity. However, I've dug deep, and I've found some (in my opinion)
recent, amazing stuff out there. It's my favorite genre, but sadly it's
difficult as hell to find good tracks; and even more importantly, it's
difficult to find good DJs (I'm not even going to mention parties). However,
I think the genre still has a ridiculous amount of potential and that it
should not be immediately dismissed. Does anyone else have similar
sentiments?

P.S. Check out the track Chase My Rabbit by Marcus Schossow if you want an
example of what I mean by "recent, amazing stuff." I like a lot of the
older, classic goa stuff (although a ton of crap was released then too).
Hallucinogen is an example of a goa trance artist that has consistently
released high quality stuff. Also, Union Jack definitely put out some good
trance. Does anyone disagree with my judgement of these artists? If so, then
why?

------=_Part_17125_29507336.1200958200144--

------=_Part_17159_33025157.1200958598151
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

No one seems to have any hope for trance. I see it everywhere, and it's
definitely a lot more prominent in SF than LA; people hate trance here. I
can see why, since the genre has lost most of its integrity. However, I've
dug deep, and I've found some (in my opinion) recent, amazing stuff out
there. It's my favorite genre, but sadly it's difficult as hell to find good
tracks; and even more importantly, it's difficult to find good DJs (I'm not
even going to mention parties). However, I think the genre still has a
ridiculous amount of potential and that it should not be immediately
dismissed. Does anyone else have similar sentiments?

P.S. Check out the track Chase My Rabbit by Marcus Schossow if you want an
example of what I mean by "recent, amazing stuff." I like a lot of the
older, classic goa stuff (although a ton of crap was released then too).
Hallucinogen is an example of a goa trance artist that has consistently
released high quality stuff. Also, Union Jack definitely put out some good
trance. Does anyone disagree with my judgement of these artists? If so, then
why?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

This subject gets rehashed on here quite a bit, but since it's rave AND 
music related, I certainly don't mind chiming in or seeing the thread 
develop.

Trance (for the most part) does indeed suck massive balls. It's lofty, 
arpeggiated crap at best most of the time, and typically seems to pull the 
euro-trash crowd, which, I think most of us can agree are not that damn fun 
to party alongside.

However, that all being said, I feel that at least historically there is a 
ton of good "trance" music out there. I pretty much stopped paying attention 
to the genre once Tiesto and the Armin's and Oakies became the 
be-all/end-alls of the scene, but I am sure there has to be some decent 
newer stuff floating around out there.

Speaking of trance, I am about to do another "vinyl purge" and a ton of my 
classic trance will be up for grabs.  Some stuff is just too rare for me to 
let go (and I haven't found high quality MP3's of it for replacement sake), 
but there's gonna be a grip of really nice, classic, hard to find or 
expensive to buy stuff for sale....list to follow in the next few days or 
so.

~ M

Subject: [sfraves] nrr: MDMA - in the Chronicle

--0-1523136661-1200959032=:71685
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Thanks to Brandon for this article..he posted it on another board...

thought i share on here..

adriana

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

/discuss

Excerpt from SF Chronicle: 
  
 http://www.sfgate.com/columnists/morford/
 
Over here, another drug. This one's been around awhile. World famous, beloved by millions, controversial for all the wrong reasons. It is currently very, very illegal. Producing and selling it in any quantity can result in severe punishment, years in prison. 
  
It has been deemed highly dangerous, potentially toxic, even lethal, and for years the government and the Centers for Disease Control and your own mother have issued all sorts of lies and alarmist B.S. about it, like how it drains spinal fluid, induces brain aneurisms, makes you vote Libertarian. Which is not to say taking it doesn't have its random dangers, but, you know, please. 
  
This drug is famous for producing incredible feelings of euphoria, openness, warmth and love and happiness in almost everyone who takes it. It is staggeringly effective, non-addictive, and when taken somewhat responsibly and with a slight hint of intelligence, has very few, if any, notable or permanent side effects. 
  
Its positives border on miraculous. It can effortlessly break down long-held psychological barriers, remove obstacles to communication and stifled emotion, make patients/users feel open and happy and much better able to handle stress, anxiety, all manner of trauma. 
  
It gets better. Some of the deeper emotional breakthroughs it produces last for weeks, months, or forever. Truly, entire loving relationships have been launched based on the deep bonding and raw emotional honesty a couple discovers while on it, and in many cases, those feelings become the foundation for long-term marriages (or, by way of the same raw honesty, encourage the end of unhappy, dying ones). 
  
Oh yes — this drug also frequently induces profound, life-changing spiritual awakenings, can eradicate neurosis, increase feelings of empathy and forgiveness and peace and overlay it all with an increased love of music and sensual pleasure. 
  
 Thank God it's illegal. 
  
This drug, as you've already guessed, is MDMA, or ecstasy. It has finally, after years of governmental ignorance and lack of balls/foresight/integrity in the psychiatric community, earned tacit approval for a precious handful of clinical psychiatric trials. Initial results? Turns out this scary illegal drug just might work wonders for treating post-traumatic stress disorder. Gosh, really? 
  
Yes. As reported by the Washington Post and the Guardian, as far as PTSD alone is concerned, some docs already see MDMA as potentially life-saving, a true wonder drug, which might even be administered to all our traumatized U.S. soldiers. Which could be good news indeed, given how an estimated 24 million Americans suffer from PTSD, whereas only a fraction of that number claim to have fibromyalgia. 
  
Oh, but there are problems. Major drawbacks. Terrible, unspeakable, anti-American issues that seriously trouble our drug-addled nation. 
  
Foremost: MDMA is not patented. Its formula is not owned by anyone. Hence, no single company (or handful of companies) stands to make billions from its potential legalization and the government cannot tax it and organized religion cannot control the power it has to help you totally reject its inane dogma, and they all really, really hate that. 
  
What's more, millions of people already take MDMA recreationally, for the sheer pleasure and joy of it, making it a huge threat to all authority everywhere, because God knows we can't have lots of people feeling peaceful and empathetic and nonviolent, as opposed to fearful and victimized and angry and sick sick sick, all those things governments and religions rely on to keep you meek and beaten down and in check. 
  
I know what you're thinking. That's a dangerous oversimplification, Mark. Read the literature! Ecstasy is scary! People can overdose! "Moderation" is not in America's DNA! With the possible exception of extreme PTSD cases, we should probably keep MDMA illegal forever — you know, just like that other toxic, wildly addictive drug that causes thousands of deaths every year, along with liver disease and violence and spousal abuse and trauma and impaired judgment and unwanted pregnancy and frat boys and which you can order as much as you want right now in any bar in the world. Oh wait. 
  
Maybe it really is just that simple, just that odious. One drug, nasty and of hugely questionable value, essentially designed to numb your body and mock your spirit and shut you down like a land mine shuts down a cat, is legal. Another drug, relatively safe, enormously effective in how it opens you up like a flower and pours white hot life straight down your throat and helps you feel God without forcing you to kneel before, well, anything at all, is violently illegal. And thus doth the brutal irony of the capitalist machine floweth over once again. 
  
It is, you could say, just another tale of the tense, vicious battle ever raging between the government/corporations/church, all of whom seek to control and profit by murdering any notion you may have that you might be far more powerful, divinely connected, empathetic than you imagine, and the humane, common-sensical universe of peaceful reality. Do you know that fight? Do you ever sense that common sense is losing? I have a suggestion for something you might want to try.

       
---------------------------------
Be a better friend, newshound, and know-it-all with Yahoo! Mobile.  Try it now.
--0-1523136661-1200959032=:71685--

> recent, amazing stuff out there. It's my favorite genre, but sadly it's
> difficult as hell to find good tracks; and even more importantly, it's
> difficult to find good DJs (I'm not even going to mention parties). 
> However,
> I think the genre still has a ridiculous amount of potential and that it
> should not be immediately dismissed. Does anyone else have similar
> sentiments?
>
> P.S. Check out the track Chase My Rabbit by Marcus Schossow if you want an
> example of what I mean by "recent, amazing stuff." I like a lot of the
> older, classic goa stuff (although a ton of crap was released then too).
> Hallucinogen is an example of a goa trance artist that has consistently
> released high quality stuff. Also, Union Jack definitely put out some good
> trance. Does anyone disagree with my judgement of these artists? If so, 
> then
> why?
> 


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

------=_Part_17257_26774017.1200959469273
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

This is what is bothering me the most: no one has the balls to put on a good
trance party. It seems completely feasible to me, even if classic tracks are
played the entire time. All you need are good DJs that aren't full of
themselves that will play good music, and that will make a damn good party
(it'd be nice if the crowd won't be pricks either, but hey, I'm here for the
music. And plus, there's always at least one cool person in a sea of
assholes).

The house scene in SF is badass (from my experience), and the techno scene
is pretty sexy too; but trance is pretty much nonexistent except for a few
renegade psytrance parties here and there. I don't want to listen to the
same music all the time though, and I don't want to miss out on what could
be some kickass trance parties if someone had the balls to do it well.

Now, I think the first reply will be: DIY (do it yourself). I'm an 18 year
old college student. I can't plausibly do it myself (nor would I want to).
However, don't say that I'm complaining because that's not what my intention
is. I want people to be aware that there's a big gap in the EDM scene of SF
and it's kind of a shame when that gap can readily be filled in... that's
all.

On Jan 21, 2008 3:35 PM, Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:

> This subject gets rehashed on here quite a bit, but since it's rave AND
> music related, I certainly don't mind chiming in or seeing the thread
> develop.
>
> Trance (for the most part) does indeed suck massive balls. It's lofty,
> arpeggiated crap at best most of the time, and typically seems to pull the
> euro-trash crowd, which, I think most of us can agree are not that damn
> fun
> to party alongside.
>
> However, that all being said, I feel that at least historically there is a
> ton of good "trance" music out there. I pretty much stopped paying
> attention
> to the genre once Tiesto and the Armin's and Oakies became the
> be-all/end-alls of the scene, but I am sure there has to be some decent
> newer stuff floating around out there.
>
> Speaking of trance, I am about to do another "vinyl purge" and a ton of my
> classic trance will be up for grabs.  Some stuff is just too rare for me
> to
> let go (and I haven't found high quality MP3's of it for replacement
> sake),
> but there's gonna be a grip of really nice, classic, hard to find or
> expensive to buy stuff for sale....list to follow in the next few days or
> so.
>
> ~ M
> ----- Original Message -----

SF than LA.
       > People hate trance here. I can see why, since the genre has =
lost most of=20
       > its
       > integrity. However, I've dug deep, and I've found some (in my =
opinion)
       > recent, amazing stuff out there. It's my favorite genre, but =
sadly it's
       > difficult as hell to find good tracks; and even more =
importantly, it's=20
       > difficult to find good DJs (I'm not even going to mention =
parties).
       > However,
       > I think the genre still has a ridiculous amount of potential =
and that it
       > should not be immediately dismissed. Does anyone else have =
similar=20
       > sentiments?
       >
       > P.S. Check out the track Chase My Rabbit by Marcus Schossow if =
you want an
       > example of what I mean by "recent, amazing stuff." I like a lot =
of the
       > older, classic goa stuff (although a ton of crap was released =
then too).=20
       > Hallucinogen is an example of a goa trance artist that has =
consistently
       > released high quality stuff. Also, Union Jack definitely put =
out some good
       > trance. Does anyone disagree with my judgement of these =
artists? If so,=20
       > then
       > why?
       >

Subject: [sfraves] [NRR] Soundless Dawn and The Labrynth of the Psychonaut

------=_Part_8479_14193483.1200960275137
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

One fresh voice in the new school of You Tube info-warriors is 25 year old
Steve Willner, whose blog - The Labrynth of the Psychonaut - and massive
output of YouTube formatted videos in merely a few months is a true
testimant to the power of new media.

Steve marries a Joseph Campbell-like encyclopedic knowledge of mysticism an=
d
the occult, as well as science fiction, combined with a love of conspiracy
theory and a keen ability to read popular culture like Camille Paglia.

Check out his work here. Remember, he's a newbie to the technology and
despite some irregular sound editing, his ability to see connections and ge=
t
a message out to a visual generation makes his work stand on his own.

http://www.youtube.com/profile?user=3Dsoundlessdawn

One of my favorites on the significance of the missing constellation Ophiuc=
hus
and the Doppelg=E4nger Universe that is doomed to repeat itself.

 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3D2AlJYWO_g_w


-Jennifer
--=20

www.myspace.com/filtersf

That may be true for some, but I don't think my schedule can fit it. I'm
taking 20.5 units (15 units = full time student, if you want an idea of how
much that is). Not to mention, I plan to go to grad school; so I need badass
grades to stand a chance (especially since I'm going for a doctorate). I'd
like to throw a badass party, but honestly, it's just not one of my top
priorities right now.

However, I'm down to help out whoever wants to throw an awesome trance
party. I'm not sure how much I can help, but I can definitely help with
setting up beforehand.

On Jan 21, 2008 3:52 PM, Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:

>  18 y/o student or not, you can DIY. I have seen 16 y/o kids throw
> undergrounds completely on their own steam....where there's a will (and some
> help) there's a way!
>
> I'm always down for dropping a classic trance set if someone wants me to.
>
> SHUT UP CJAX! lol
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> *From:* Mark <vileru@gmail.com>
> *To:* Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
> *Sent:* Monday, January 21, 2008 3:49 PM
> *Subject:* Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?
>
> This is what is bothering me the most: no one has the balls to put on a
> good trance party. It seems completely feasible to me, even if classic
> tracks are played the entire time. All you need are good DJs that aren't
> full of themselves that will play good music, and that will make a damn good
> party (it'd be nice if the crowd won't be pricks either, but hey, I'm here
> for the music. And plus, there's always at least one cool person in a sea of
> assholes).
>
> The house scene in SF is badass (from my experience), and the techno scene
> is pretty sexy too; but trance is pretty much nonexistent except for a few
> renegade psytrance parties here and there. I don't want to listen to the
> same music all the time though, and I don't want to miss out on what could
> be some kickass trance parties if someone had the balls to do it well.
>
> Now, I think the first reply will be: DIY (do it yourself). I'm an 18 year
> old college student. I can't plausibly do it myself (nor would I want to).
> However, don't say that I'm complaining because that's not what my intention
> is. I want people to be aware that there's a big gap in the EDM scene of SF
> and it's kind of a shame when that gap can readily be filled in... that's
> all.
>
> On Jan 21, 2008 3:35 PM, Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
> > This subject gets rehashed on here quite a bit, but since it's rave AND
> > music related, I certainly don't mind chiming in or seeing the thread
> > develop.
> >
> > Trance (for the most part) does indeed suck massive balls. It's lofty,
> > arpeggiated crap at best most of the time, and typically seems to pull
> > the
> > euro-trash crowd, which, I think most of us can agree are not that damn
> > fun
> > to party alongside.
> >
> > However, that all being said, I feel that at least historically there is
> > a
> > ton of good "trance" music out there. I pretty much stopped paying
> > attention
> > to the genre once Tiesto and the Armin's and Oakies became the
> > be-all/end-alls of the scene, but I am sure there has to be some decent
> > newer stuff floating around out there.
> >
> > Speaking of trance, I am about to do another "vinyl purge" and a ton of
> > my
> > classic trance will be up for grabs.  Some stuff is just too rare for me
> > to
> > let go (and I haven't found high quality MP3's of it for replacement
> > sake),
> > but there's gonna be a grip of really nice, classic, hard to find or
> > expensive to buy stuff for sale....list to follow in the next few days
> > or
> > so.
> >
> > ~ M
> >  ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "Mark" <vileru@gmail.com>

> > Subject: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?
> >
> >
> > >I see it everywhere, and it's definitely a lot more obvious in SF than
> > LA.
> > > People hate trance here. I can see why, since the genre has lost most
> > of
> > > its
> > > integrity. However, I've dug deep, and I've found some (in my opinion)
> >
> > > recent, amazing stuff out there. It's my favorite genre, but sadly
> > it's
> > > difficult as hell to find good tracks; and even more importantly, it's
> > > difficult to find good DJs (I'm not even going to mention parties).
> > > However,
> > > I think the genre still has a ridiculous amount of potential and that
> > it
> > > should not be immediately dismissed. Does anyone else have similar
> > > sentiments?
> > >
> > > P.S. Check out the track Chase My Rabbit by Marcus Schossow if you
> > want an
> > > example of what I mean by "recent, amazing stuff." I like a lot of the
> > > older, classic goa stuff (although a ton of crap was released then
> > too).
> > > Hallucinogen is an example of a goa trance artist that has
> > consistently
> > > released high quality stuff. Also, Union Jack definitely put out some
> > good
> > > trance. Does anyone disagree with my judgement of these artists? If
> > so,
> > > then
> > > why?
> > >

In honor of this thread I am having a mini-trance battle with myself.

Currently playing "peu ohm peu" by Qlap...

BTW anyone ever hear an old school trance track called "Fractalis" by Lorien Ferris?  That was produced for use in  virtual reality envirinment that my company built back in the mid-nineties.  I woulod be interested in any vinyl copies floating around.  I already have one his other records "Arboreal Sunrise" (backed with "Cosmic Dream") which we later used in another environment.

Best,

Peter

priorities right now.

party. I'm not sure how much I can help, but I can definitely help with
setting up beforehand.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

------=_Part_8670_26672102.1200965174422
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Say what you want about the music, but the best thing trance did add to the
overall concept of EDM partymaking was the emphasis on visuals and an
immersive environment for psychonautic activities, plus some continuity
among the partygoers to create an intentional vibe.

This is something house and techno parties could learn adapt and employ,
especially given the large concentration of media artists making original
material.

I can't recall the last time I went to a good techno party with any
psychonautic spaces or tools.
I did go to one recently where there were visuals, but rather than being
mind-expanding, artistically innovative or synchronistic, I watched over and
over an image of a hipster snorting a line of coke as a shot from underneath
a glass table.

-Jenn

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

------=_Part_17790_16325402.1200965956758
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

That's a damn good point. Seriously, trance parties (especially psytrance)
have RIDICULOUS decor. To make that distinction more clear: just look at
most techno parties. They're all just pretty much dark rooms, with maybe 1-2
projectors at most. Trance parties are usually drowned with black-lights and
all sorts of interesting visuals.

The "immersive environment for psychonautic activities" is even better when
there's a coherent theme. Back in the day (I wasn't there to experience it,
but I can read stories and I can hear stories): tribal themes and cosmic
themes were common. They seem like they'd be good for guiding you to think
about certain things (for example: a tribal theme would more likely bring
about thoughts of tribal rituals and "healing" ceremonies; whereas a cosmic
theme would more likely bring about thoughts of the universe, the origin of
life, etc etc.). That's awesome in my book!

The bottom line: it'd be amazing if the techno, house, etc. scenes
incorporated these ideas into their parties.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

Interesting point.  But I don't know if I totally accept it.

Back in day however parties weren't genre specific.  This is a recent and IMO unfortunate development.  But they did have visuals and decorations.  Discos and rock concerts had lights and decorations and special effects too well before raves even existed.

FWIW the best visuals I've ever seen were at a "faux rave" featuring trance, techno , and house music.  They had a 50' high stereoscopic projection screen powered by two GE light valve projectors and underwater stereo footage of sharks swimming.  The stereo effect was so strong that the sharks appeared to be swimming over the dance floor.  

But you did have to wear silly glasses ;)

Best,

Peter


----- Original Message ----
From: "filter.sf@gmail.com" <filter.sf@gmail.com>
To: Mark <vileru@gmail.com>
Cc: Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, January 21, 2008 5:26:14 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

Say what you want about the music, but the best thing trance did add to the
overall concept of EDM partymaking was the emphasis on visuals and an
immersive environment for psychonautic activities, plus some continuity
among the partygoers to create an intentional vibe.

This is something house and techno parties could learn adapt and employ,
especially given the large concentration of media artists making original
material.

I can't recall the last time I went to a good techno party with any
psychonautic spaces or tools.
I did go to one recently where there were visuals, but rather than being
mind-expanding, artistically innovative or synchronistic, I watched over and
over an image of a hipster snorting a line of coke as a shot from underneath
a glass table.

-Jenn

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

------=_Part_8714_11726259.1200966813517
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

the aesthetic of techno has traditionally been no more than a red strobe in
a dark room. the techno elite believe the music is enough, that any other
trappings are akin to displaying golden bulls.

so anything overt, blinky, glowy, black-light whatever is generally not
going to translate well, at least in the techno community.

however, the opportunity to intentionally seed any gathering with something
larger than our petty egos, the pursuit of numb-out substances and fueling
the circle of promotions (djs promoting to promoters who promote parties to
djs), is strangely...something that hasn't been taken up by any of the neo
EDM movements.

and that's an opportunity solely missed...especially during these times.


On 1/21/08, Mark <vileru@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> That's a damn good point. Seriously, trance parties (especially psytrance)
> have RIDICULOUS decor. To make that distinction more clear: just look at
> most techno parties. They're all just pretty much dark rooms, with maybe 1-2
> projectors at most. Trance parties are usually drowned with black-lights and
> all sorts of interesting visuals.
>
> The "immersive environment for psychonautic activities" is even better
> when there's a coherent theme. Back in the day (I wasn't there to experience
> it, but I can read stories and I can hear stories): tribal themes and cosmic
> themes were common. They seem like they'd be good for guiding you to think
> about certain things (for example: a tribal theme would more likely bring
> about thoughts of tribal rituals and "healing" ceremonies; whereas a cosmic
> theme would more likely bring about thoughts of the universe, the origin of
> life, etc etc.). That's awesome in my book!
>
> The bottom line: it'd be amazing if the techno, house, etc. scenes
> incorporated these ideas into their parties.
>
> On Jan 21, 2008 5:26 PM, < filter.sf@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> >
> > Say what you want about the music, but the best thing trance did add to
> > the overall concept of EDM partymaking was the emphasis on visuals and an
> > immersive environment for psychonautic activities, plus some continuity
> > among the partygoers to create an intentional vibe.
> >
> > This is something house and techno parties could learn adapt and employ,
> > especially given the large concentration of media artists making original
> > material.
> >
> > I can't recall the last time I went to a good techno party with any
> > psychonautic spaces or tools.
> > I did go to one recently where there were visuals, but rather than being
> > mind-expanding, artistically innovative or synchronistic, I watched over and
> > over an image of a hipster snorting a line of coke as a shot from underneath
> > a glass table.
> >
> > -Jenn
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >  On 1/21/08, Mark <vileru@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > > That may be true for some, but I don't think my schedule can fit it.
> > > I'm
> > > taking 20.5 units (15 units = full time student, if you want an idea
> > > of how
> > > much that is). Not to mention, I plan to go to grad school; so I need
> > > badass
> > > grades to stand a chance (especially since I'm going for a doctorate).
> > > I'd
> > > like to throw a badass party, but honestly, it's just not one of my
> > > top
> > > priorities right now.
> > >
> > > However, I'm down to help out whoever wants to throw an awesome trance
> > > party. I'm not sure how much I can help, but I can definitely help
> > > with
> > > setting up beforehand.
> > >
> > > On Jan 21, 2008 3:52 PM, Marco < electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > >
> > > >  18 y/o student or not, you can DIY. I have seen 16 y/o kids throw
> > > > undergrounds completely on their own steam....where there's a will
> > > (and some
> > > > help) there's a way!
> > > >
> > > > I'm always down for dropping a classic trance set if someone wants
> > > me to.
> > > >
> > > > SHUT UP CJAX! lol
> > > >

> > > classic
> > > > tracks are played the entire time. All you need are good DJs that
> > > aren't
> > > > full of themselves that will play good music, and that will make a
> > > damn good

> > > I'm here
> > > > for the music. And plus, there's always at least one cool person in
> > > a sea of
> > > > assholes).

> > > > renegade psytrance parties here and there. I don't want to listen to

> > > > same music all the time though, and I don't want to miss out on what

> > > > be some kickass trance parties if someone had the balls to do it
> > > well.
> > > >
> > > > Now, I think the first reply will be: DIY (do it yourself). I'm an
> > > 18 year
> > > > old college student. I can't plausibly do it myself (nor would I
> > > want to).
> > > > However, don't say that I'm complaining because that's not what my
> > > intention
> > > > is. I want people to be aware that there's a big gap in the EDM
> > > scene of SF
> > > > and it's kind of a shame when that gap can readily be filled in...

> > > > all.
> > > >

> > > > > a

> > > > > attention
> > > > > to the genre once Tiesto and the Armin's and Oakies became the

> > > decent
> > > > > newer stuff floating around out there.
> > > > >

> > > ton of

> > > > > to

> > > > > sake),

> > > > > or

/discuss

Excerpt from SF Chronicle: 
  
 http://www.sfgate.com/columnists/morford/
 
Over here, another drug. This one's been around awhile. World famous,
beloved by millions, controversial for all the wrong reasons. It is
currently very, very illegal. Producing and selling it in any quantity can
result in severe punishment, years in prison. 
  
It has been deemed highly dangerous, potentially toxic, even lethal, and for
years the government and the Centers for Disease Control and your own mother
have issued all sorts of lies and alarmist B.S. about it, like how it drains
spinal fluid, induces brain aneurisms, makes you vote Libertarian. Which is
not to say taking it doesn't have its random dangers, but, you know, please.

  
This drug is famous for producing incredible feelings of euphoria, openness,
warmth and love and happiness in almost everyone who takes it. It is
staggeringly effective, non-addictive, and when taken somewhat responsibly
and with a slight hint of intelligence, has very few, if any, notable or
permanent side effects. 
  
Its positives border on miraculous. It can effortlessly break down long-held
psychological barriers, remove obstacles to communication and stifled
emotion, make patients/users feel open and happy and much better able to
handle stress, anxiety, all manner of trauma. 
  
It gets better. Some of the deeper emotional breakthroughs it produces last
for weeks, months, or forever. Truly, entire loving relationships have been
launched based on the deep bonding and raw emotional honesty a couple
discovers while on it, and in many cases, those feelings become the
foundation for long-term marriages (or, by way of the same raw honesty,
encourage the end of unhappy, dying ones). 
  
Oh yes - this drug also frequently induces profound, life-changing spiritual
awakenings, can eradicate neurosis, increase feelings of empathy and
forgiveness and peace and overlay it all with an increased love of music and
sensual pleasure. 
  
 Thank God it's illegal. 
  
This drug, as you've already guessed, is MDMA, or ecstasy. It has finally,
after years of governmental ignorance and lack of balls/foresight/integrity
in the psychiatric community, earned tacit approval for a precious handful
of clinical psychiatric trials. Initial results? Turns out this scary
illegal drug just might work wonders for treating post-traumatic stress
disorder. Gosh, really? 
  
Yes. As reported by the Washington Post and the Guardian, as far as PTSD
alone is concerned, some docs already see MDMA as potentially life-saving, a
true wonder drug, which might even be administered to all our traumatized
U.S. soldiers. Which could be good news indeed, given how an estimated 24
million Americans suffer from PTSD, whereas only a fraction of that number
claim to have fibromyalgia. 
  
Oh, but there are problems. Major drawbacks. Terrible, unspeakable,
anti-American issues that seriously trouble our drug-addled nation. 
  
Foremost: MDMA is not patented. Its formula is not owned by anyone. Hence,
no single company (or handful of companies) stands to make billions from its
potential legalization and the government cannot tax it and organized
religion cannot control the power it has to help you totally reject its
inane dogma, and they all really, really hate that. 
  
What's more, millions of people already take MDMA recreationally, for the
sheer pleasure and joy of it, making it a huge threat to all authority
everywhere, because God knows we can't have lots of people feeling peaceful
and empathetic and nonviolent, as opposed to fearful and victimized and
angry and sick sick sick, all those things governments and religions rely on
to keep you meek and beaten down and in check. 
  
I know what you're thinking. That's a dangerous oversimplification, Mark.
Read the literature! Ecstasy is scary! People can overdose! "Moderation" is
not in America's DNA! With the possible exception of extreme PTSD cases, we
should probably keep MDMA illegal forever - you know, just like that other
toxic, wildly addictive drug that causes thousands of deaths every year,
along with liver disease and violence and spousal abuse and trauma and
impaired judgment and unwanted pregnancy and frat boys and which you can
order as much as you want right now in any bar in the world. Oh wait. 
  
Maybe it really is just that simple, just that odious. One drug, nasty and
of hugely questionable value, essentially designed to numb your body and
mock your spirit and shut you down like a land mine shuts down a cat, is
legal. Another drug, relatively safe, enormously effective in how it opens
you up like a flower and pours white hot life straight down your throat and
helps you feel God without forcing you to kneel before, well, anything at
all, is violently illegal. And thus doth the brutal irony of the capitalist
machine floweth over once again. 
  
It is, you could say, just another tale of the tense, vicious battle ever
raging between the government/corporations/church, all of whom seek to
control and profit by murdering any notion you may have that you might be
far more powerful, divinely connected, empathetic than you imagine, and the
humane, common-sensical universe of peaceful reality. Do you know that
fight? Do you ever sense that common sense is losing? I have a suggestion
for something you might want to try.

       
---------------------------------
Be a better friend, newshound, and know-it-all with Yahoo! Mobile.  Try it
now.



       
---------------------------------
Looking for last minute shopping deals?  Find them fast with Yahoo! Search.
--0-1288768440-1200970280=:61212--

From: "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fwd: (nrr) More Body Fragments Found at WTC site

Aw, dude, as you know, and others in the hyperreal universe know, 
Entropy is the Gold Standard for troll, and you're a far, far cry from 
anything remotely resembling that.

I've enjoyed your QOD's over the years and your posts, outside of these 
topics, are insightful, well thought out, and on point.

The 9/!! shite is a bit much for me to deal with though.

The morning of, I watched the second plane hit, in real-time, with a 
direct descendant of cotton gin Eli Whitney, (also of the Whitney Museum 
and Grand Central Whitney's), at our place in Redwood City right off of 
El Camino. I just recently found out an old HS friend was on the 39th 
floor of the North Tower that morning, (he got out), my favorite 
child-hood baby-sitter had the second plane fly directly over her head 
and she watched it fly right on in with a completely unobstructed view 
of NY Harbor for the full 5 mile stretch, I live 2 minutes by foot from 
a dramatic view of the Lower Manhattan Skyline, (aka 'a wretched hive of 
scum and villainy'), and I live and work in an area that has several 
named streets.

So, I'm a lot closer to it than I would have chosen to be.

It fucking *kills* me that in what used to be The Greatest City On 
Earth, place of my birth, they haven't even gotten past street level yet 
in 6.5 *years* and the whole project has been a financial boondoggle 
from the second the second tower came down, which I kinda had a hunch 
was going to happen.

Yeah, it's a fucking mess, but there's nothing, not a goddamned thing, 
we can do to change it.

For me, and I suspect for many others, we'd like the wound to start 
healing and that means for the time being, leaving it alone.

Best tribute I ever saw was the cover of the Beastie Boys last album 
that came out in the year 2004:
http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/d/d4/Tothe5boroughscorrectartwork.jpg

Shalom and Salam,

~Nyc

.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fwd: (nrr) More Body Fragments Found at WTC site

For the record, I am not happy when anyone leaves this list.  

I may not agree with what some people write and I might even speak out against it vocally. In the end I decided to filter those I can't tolerate.   I specifically do not support the spread of fear and hate and I actively oppose this whereever and whenever I encounter it.  And I do not understand this way of thinking as it relates to "rave".  But just to be clear I also do not support censorship.

I do think life online is unhealthy for some people always, and for many of us at various times in our lives.  Logging off is always an option.

I sincerely wish that everyone on the list would take better care of themselves and consider carefully just what they are putting in their bodies AND in their minds.  Ideas can be DANGRS.  I have learned this from experience, I did not take on my haqndle lightly, but I know not everyone will agree.

I do support all of your rights to make individual choices whatever they are and as long as they do not harm others.  As long as they do not harm others.  

Consider this point carefully.

Peace,

Peter

Wow. I'm not alone. Thank you for being a badass. What can I do to change
something (that's not too much trouble for a more-than-full-time student)?

On Jan 21, 2008 5:53 PM, <filter.sf@gmail.com> wrote:

> the aesthetic of techno has traditionally been no more than a red strobe
> in a dark room. the techno elite believe the music is enough, that any other
> trappings are akin to displaying golden bulls.
>
> so anything overt, blinky, glowy, black-light whatever is generally not
> going to translate well, at least in the techno community.
>
> however, the opportunity to intentionally seed any gathering with
> something larger than our petty egos, the pursuit of numb-out
> substances and fueling the circle of promotions (djs promoting to promoters
> who promote parties to djs), is strangely...something that hasn't been taken
> up by any of the neo EDM movements.
>
> and that's an opportunity solely missed...especially during these times.
>
>
> On 1/21/08, Mark <vileru@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > That's a damn good point. Seriously, trance parties (especially
> > psytrance) have RIDICULOUS decor. To make that distinction more clear: just
> > look at most techno parties. They're all just pretty much dark rooms, with
> > maybe 1-2 projectors at most. Trance parties are usually drowned with
> > black-lights and all sorts of interesting visuals.
> >
> > The "immersive environment for psychonautic activities" is even better
> > when there's a coherent theme. Back in the day (I wasn't there to experience
> > it, but I can read stories and I can hear stories): tribal themes and cosmic
> > themes were common. They seem like they'd be good for guiding you to think
> > about certain things (for example: a tribal theme would more likely bring
> > about thoughts of tribal rituals and "healing" ceremonies; whereas a cosmic
> > theme would more likely bring about thoughts of the universe, the origin of
> > life, etc etc.). That's awesome in my book!
> >
> > The bottom line: it'd be amazing if the techno, house, etc. scenes
> > incorporated these ideas into their parties.
> >
> > On Jan 21, 2008 5:26 PM, < filter.sf@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > >
> > > Say what you want about the music, but the best thing trance did add
> > > to the overall concept of EDM partymaking was the emphasis on visuals and an
> > > immersive environment for psychonautic activities, plus some continuity
> > > among the partygoers to create an intentional vibe.
> > >
> > > This is something house and techno parties could learn adapt and
> > > employ, especially given the large concentration of media artists making
> > > original material.
> > >
> > > I can't recall the last time I went to a good techno party with any
> > > psychonautic spaces or tools.
> > > I did go to one recently where there were visuals, but rather than
> > > being mind-expanding, artistically innovative or synchronistic, I watched
> > > over and over an image of a hipster snorting a line of coke as a shot from
> > > underneath a glass table.
> > >
> > > -Jenn
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >  On 1/21/08, Mark <vileru@gmail.com> wrote:

> > > > grades to stand a chance (especially since I'm going for a

> > > > > is. I want people to be aware that there's a big gap in the EDM

> > > > > all.

> > > > > >
> > > > > > Trance (for the most part) does indeed suck massive balls. It's
> > > > lofty,
> > > > > > arpeggiated crap at best most of the time, and typically seems
> > > > to pull

> > > > > > >I see it everywhere, and it's definitely a lot more obvious in
> > > > SF than
> > > > > > LA.
> > > > > > > People hate trance here. I can see why, since the genre has
> > > > lost most
> > > > > > of
> > > > > > > its
> > > > > > > integrity. However, I've dug deep, and I've found some (in my
> > > > opinion)
> > > > > >
> > > > > > > recent, amazing stuff out there. It's my favorite genre, but
> > > > sadly
> > > > > > it's
> > > > > > > difficult as hell to find good tracks; and even more
> > > > importantly, it's
> > > > > > > difficult to find good DJs (I'm not even going to mention
> > > > parties).
> > > > > > > However,
> > > > > > > I think the genre still has a ridiculous amount of potential
> > > > and that
> > > > > > it
> > > > > > > should not be immediately dismissed. Does anyone else have
> > > > similar
> > > > > > > sentiments?
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > P.S. Check out the track Chase My Rabbit by Marcus Schossow if
> > > > you
> > > > > > want an
> > > > > > > example of what I mean by "recent, amazing stuff." I like a
> > > > lot of the
> > > > > > > older, classic goa stuff (although a ton of crap was released
> > > > then
> > > > > > too).
> > > > > > > Hallucinogen is an example of a goa trance artist that has
> > > > > > consistently
> > > > > > > released high quality stuff. Also, Union Jack definitely put
> > > > out some
> > > > > > good
> > > > > > > trance. Does anyone disagree with my judgement of these
> > > > artists? If

A peaceful mindset? No way! Yeah, when I said don't feed the trolls, I
wasn't trying to shun the guy away. Really, I think he should be able to say
whatever the hell he wants. Getting rid of someone because of SOMETHING THEY
SAY is insanity. There's a difference between actions and words, and I think
it's blatantly obvious.

However, what I don't understand is why are people trying to provoke the
guy. What's the point of being an asshole? What benefit do you receive out
of it (other than getting rid of someone BECAUSE YOU DON'T LIKE WHAT THEY
SAY)?!? What I was trying to convey is this: YOU DON'T HAVE TO PICK A FIGHT
WITH EVERY SINGLE PERSON THAT SAYS SOMETHING THAT YOU DON'T LIKE. If you
think that you have to, then I'm sorry, but I find that pathetic.

Anyways, here's my reply to the WTC matters:

Yes, I know that everything that went down was/is completely fucked up. We
can't do anything on our own though, especially with mainstream media
influencing the majority of this nation. Before we even consider exposing
all this bs; we must first expose the mainstream media for what it is. Does
anyone else find it a problem that A FAKE NEWS SHOW IS THE MOST CREDIBLE
NEWS ON TELEVISION (I'm referring to the daily show if you missed the
hint... I don't get Democracy Now! where I am)?!?! The problem of the
mainstream media must first be addressed before we can even get a
substantial message out to the greater public.

On Jan 21, 2008 8:16 PM, <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

> For the record, I am not happy when anyone leaves this list.
>
> I may not agree with what some people write and I might even speak out
> against it vocally. In the end I decided to filter those I can't tolerate.
> I specifically do not support the spread of fear and hate and I actively
> oppose this whereever and whenever I encounter it.  And I do not understand
> this way of thinking as it relates to "rave".  But just to be clear I also
> do not support censorship.
>
> I do think life online is unhealthy for some people always, and for many
> of us at various times in our lives.  Logging off is always an option.
>
> I sincerely wish that everyone on the list would take better care of
> themselves and consider carefully just what they are putting in their bodies
> AND in their minds.  Ideas can be DANGRS.  I have learned this from
> experience, I did not take on my haqndle lightly, but I know not everyone
> will agree.
>
> I do support all of your rights to make individual choices whatever they
> are and as long as they do not harm others.  As long as they do not harm
> others.
>
> Consider this point carefully.
>
> Peace,

Subject: RE: [sfraves] DJ demo hosting

Sure you can, the links just dont have .mp3 at the end of them. Here are the
links to your Black Sunrise mix:

Download:
http://waxdj.com/download.php?band_id=1835&song_id=15128&mode=song_hifi
Stream: http://waxdj.com/play.php?band_id=1835&song_id=15128&mode=song_hifi

waxdj uses .php files with identifiers to launch the download or stream.

-Smith

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Tue)

Don't worry anyone, everyone, I'm not leaving the list, I was pretty =20
busy yesterday because I've got two papers and a play monologue due =20
tomorrow.  I'm working on memorizing the monologue today and the =20
papers are done, whew.  Sorry if I offended anyone with the off topic =20
9/11 post, I just get especially angry when I hear stuff like this.

The only reason I thought of leaving was so I wouldn't offend people =20
with too many (nrr) posts but when I really thought about it and =20
pulled a spectacular quote from the play I read yesterday, the quotes =20
themselves have now grown to have a life of their own; in a way, I =20
don't really feel like I control them anymore, I'm just an =20
administrator that posts them.

And as for the (nrr)/911/Alex Jones/Devvy Kidd/liberty movement thing =20
that's butted up neatly against now I realize the =20
libertarian/Christian conservative movement, when I really *look* at =20
that, I think I've still got a lot to say from what I've observed in =20
those movements that practically relate to our current day rave =20
experience, which, as we've all seen from the posts this weekend, is =20
still heavily subject to Imperial involvement.  So the nanny state is =20
still telling us where we can and cannot dance all these years later.

Well more on all that stuff later, I've got to eat breakfast and get =20
to class this morning.  Maybe see you this weekend?

Please get this song in your head and you'll be where I'm at right =20
now, it's that simple.

--

Later.  I like to play with things first, and then destroy them.

- Flash Gordon, The Movie

X-YMail-OSG: gZLw1QcVM1lS4jCTSt6.V3cT_RtQXa7waubUpvZmw2UAa3aZoQT9XjSAlKB7Tj8GLiTSOColGQ--

From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <965009.67056.qm@web32411.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Some thoughts on trance...

I don't consider myself a trance hater.  I like Heather Heart's mix of trance and techno when she gets it banging for example.  And I had a little fun playing some of my small number of trance records yesterday.  While I was doing this it occured to me why I like these records, but not much of the trance I hear elsewhere these days.

1. No or not enough funk, light on the bass or very simplistic bass lines.  -- nuff said here I think.  I think of Al Gore dancing when I hear some of this stuff.
2. Too many breaks!  -- Personally I don't need a 2-3 minute break every track. When I mix trance I mix out almost all the breaks.
3. Overused, reused, copycat, and almost idenitcal synth riffs- doo doo doo doot!  doo doo doo doot!  What song is that?  Its like 500 different trance tracks.  All of the trance tracks I have sound sort of different and don't reuse the same tired trance riffs.
4. Breaks are too "orchestral" -- its a rave not the symphony.  I'd rather listen to actually good orchestral music than this stuff.
5. Too happy sounding -- OK this is clearly a matter of taste, and see 1-4 above, but most of the trance I have is more mysterious, darker, and driving.  I don't like the feathery synths, angelic voices, and pretend orchestras.

Regards,

Peter

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

----- Original Message ----
From: Mark <vileru@gmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, January 21, 2008 3:36:38 PM
Subject: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

No one seems to have any hope for trance. I see it everywhere, and it's
definitely a lot more prominent in SF than LA; people hate trance here. I
can see why, since the genre has lost most of its integrity. However, I've
dug deep, and I've found some (in my opinion) recent, amazing stuff out
there. It's my favorite genre, but sadly it's difficult as hell to find good
tracks; and even more importantly, it's difficult to find good DJs (I'm not
even going to mention parties). However, I think the genre still has a
ridiculous amount of potential and that it should not be immediately
dismissed. Does anyone else have similar sentiments?

P.S. Check out the track Chase My Rabbit by Marcus Schossow if you want an
example of what I mean by "recent, amazing stuff." I like a lot of the
older, classic goa stuff (although a ton of crap was released then too).
Hallucinogen is an example of a goa trance artist that has consistently
released high quality stuff. Also, Union Jack definitely put out some good
trance. Does anyone disagree with my judgement of these artists? If so, then
why?

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

 <BAY110-DAV28EB521A47F8C4F7B5088853D0@phx.gbl> 
 <6a557de00801211644s4d9a1362w2dba5e28d2f2bd0c@mail.gmail.com> 
 <347df33a0801211726j79e3c0daw5206dd5f0760cddf@mail.gmail.com>
 <6a557de00801211739w571d2074m81e41a0dda7f7d14@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?


On Mon, 21 Jan 2008, Mark wrote:
-&e->That's a damn good point. Seriously, trance parties (especially psytrance)
-&e->have RIDICULOUS decor. To make that distinction more clear: just look at

I don't need another huge dayglow hindu avatar to eat my brain, I don't 
need a psychelic mushroom to remind me of, um, mushrooms I guess.  
RIDICULOUS is right in many cases.

-&e->most techno parties. They're all just pretty much dark rooms, with maybe 1-2
-&e->projectors at most. Trance parties are usually drowned with black-lights and
-&e->all sorts of interesting visuals.

First:
I've already managed to piss off a whole bunch of people on a techno list 
today, so it might not be the best day for me to speak on public lists... 
but here I go.

Second: 
I've worked closely with several intensely good visuals crews.  I love 
their work.  Eyes absorb information at a massive rate.  You can say a 
lot.  My opportunity to work with projects like Viberation and BiPole were 
some of the most fun I have ever had... both in the creation and 
presentation.  Cracking heads with thematic concepts that we tried to make 
all encompassing, often spanning past the synergy of music and visuals and 
going into the ticket design, the decor, events planned during the party, 
use of the space, party favors, etc.  We syncronized material, we 
coordinated times where things would happen, we worked with the lighting 
people to work certain color schemes with certain visual material, we 
hacked Max/MSP/Jitter, we changed the 4:3 aspect ratio of television to 
something that made you see differently, capitalizing on the ability to 
cross project, and use visuals as a simpler abstract form akin to lighting 
and then go back to being little tvs everywhere (was that a 4 wide/16:3 
screen at the creamery Terry?).  Nobody ever asked who was playing cause 
the DJs name was right there in 3-D spinning around over some brain 
gobbling CGI fractal brainsuck.

But...

I have this problem.  When I am talking to someone, if there is a TV 
behind their head, I start to zone out.  I still hear what they are 
saying, but I am a sucker for distraction, and words and images are the 
worst.  I've actually gotten to the point where I have to apologize for 
this tendency.  I prefer bars without TVs.

A projector is a television 90% of the time.  The aspect ratio, the 
pixels, it is ultimately a TV.  The age old "rave" ethic of sensory 
overload doesn't apply that well to the energy ride and hypnosis that is 
good dance music to me.  If I want to be flooded with sights and sounds, 
let it be at dawn, with the faces of friends and strangers herkin and 
jerkin away.

At night, I actually like as little light as possible.  One of my favorite 
sets in recent hazy memory, the only light in the room was a light bulb 
hanging right over the decks, and at one point I turned even that off.  
In a room like that by the light from the 1200s, you can still see bodies, 
glimpses of faces, celebrating music and only music.  You cut the record 
to silence and it never goes quiet because you hear the clapping, the 
shoes against dirty concrete, and people in the zone humming, barking, 
cheering, chanting.  It's a world of people and sound.  I can't see the 
zit on your nose, I can't tell what color you are, we're breathing the 
same air, feeling the same sounds, souls in the darkness part of the 
electronic hivemind and yet more in tune with ourselves than most days.

Visuals have a place, but I'm tired of them as this mandatory filler.  
Some visuals artists just plain fail to commit and feel their artform the 
same way a good DJ does on a moment by moment basis.  They don't go high 
concept, but rather just mix fairly canned content, chroma-keying here and 
there.  A DJ rarely if ever lets a record run out, but *damn* I've seen a 
lot of credits rolling on visuals screens.  It's more like channel surfing 
sometimes than a creative outlet for a compelled visual artist.

I think a big part of it is we ask visuals people to run visuals all night 
at parties and at some point just run out of stuff and burn out, and you 
can't really have "sets" like you do with DJs, as VJs like such disparate 
setups, but it would be a big boost in increasing the benefit of visuals 
at parties.

Visuals and decor can and have been a huge part of some of my favorite 
moments at parties, but without empathy, concept and foresight they're as 
banal as a DJ who skips on those same aspects.  And much like most art 
museums that abstain from playing music throughout most of the space, the 
best visual input for a given piece of music may be nothing, just like the 
best thing to put behind a Monet might just be an eggshell painted wall 
rather than some pimp ass wallpaper that's far more interesting but 
ultimately conflicting.

To take this full circle to the trance topic, the first indoor F8 
(arguably one of the more successful crews in SF if you consider the mark 
they made on Skills and other incubating groups at the time) parties 
failed to have any decor except for an F8 banner, and a couple black 
lights.  And it was a refreshing change from the then trend of totally 
immersing people in psychedelic blacklight 
Shiva/Ganesh/Chakramap/Mushroom/Schwa props and banners that had become so 
cliche (this is mid 90s SF underground-ish timeframe).

Trance got it's name from the fact that it was supposed to be hypnotic 
(entrancing, get it?).  I find good tracky house and techno do the job way 
better than that garbage ever did to be honest.  There's nothing 
entrancing about breakdowns that leave you wondering if you're still 
actually at a dance party, and short attention span changes that 
constantly leave you painfully aware of the passage of time.  Reduced to 
it's simplest failure (for me at least), trance is hardly trance inducing.

mooo!
andyw

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

 <Pine.LNX.4.62.0801221127020.22406@atari>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

Heh.  I love this post.

I already mentioned the 50' steroscopic projection screen I saw at a "faux" rave circa 1994, and of course Terry's (Viberation) visuals rocked Love Infusion back in 2006, but I'd have to say the overall best visuals I have ever experienced were in the basement of Club 6 when Dubtribe Soundsystem was playing.  

I think they had some Christmas lights and a candle.  ;) 

Best,

Peter

PS No offense to the VJs out there ...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

------=_Part_24544_19955622.1201066264829
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

You have some good points, and I'm aware that eastern mystical statues all
over the place isn't the most creative example. I just cited what is common;
I did not want to point out anecdotal evidence. In my experience, I've seen
some profound visual messages conveyed through the use of projectors;
especially through the use of juxtaposition. Obviously, there are far more
advanced visual devices that can be used to bring across a message, but I
don't think it's necessary to cite every possibility.

I understand your perspective, and at the same time I have to say that
personal, subjective opinion isn't necessarily the truth. Yes, it's possible
that people may be distracted by visuals, but what studies can we cite that
have proven that? It is also possible that we may be less judgemental when
we are deprived of sensory, (and therefore, it becomes unfeasible to judge
someone based upon appearances) but again, we have no studies that we can
cite to prove that (although common sense supports the assumption). However,
by that same ticket, I could argue that we should have the willpower to see
past our egos which project our personalities and expectations onto others.

I think what this issue boils down to is this: sensory overload or sensory
deprivation? My opinion is that there's no clear cut answer. Each has its
advantages and disadvantages, and what particular advantage and disadvantage
a certain visual feature (or lack thereof) will have on a party should be
considered during the preparation.

On Jan 22, 2008 12:33 PM, AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:

>
> On Mon, 21 Jan 2008, Mark wrote:
> -&e->That's a damn good point. Seriously, trance parties (especially
> psytrance)
> -&e->have RIDICULOUS decor. To make that distinction more clear: just look
> at
>
> I don't need another huge dayglow hindu avatar to eat my brain, I don't
> need a psychelic mushroom to remind me of, um, mushrooms I guess.
> RIDICULOUS is right in many cases.
>
> -&e->most techno parties. They're all just pretty much dark rooms, with
> maybe 1-2
> -&e->projectors at most. Trance parties are usually drowned with
> black-lights and
> -&e->all sorts of interesting visuals.
>
> First:
> I've already managed to piss off a whole bunch of people on a techno list
> today, so it might not be the best day for me to speak on public lists...
> but here I go.
>
> Second:
> I've worked closely with several intensely good visuals crews.  I love
> their work.  Eyes absorb information at a massive rate.  You can say a
> lot.  My opportunity to work with projects like Viberation and BiPole were
> some of the most fun I have ever had... both in the creation and
> presentation.  Cracking heads with thematic concepts that we tried to make
> all encompassing, often spanning past the synergy of music and visuals and
> going into the ticket design, the decor, events planned during the party,
> use of the space, party favors, etc.  We syncronized material, we
> coordinated times where things would happen, we worked with the lighting
> people to work certain color schemes with certain visual material, we
> hacked Max/MSP/Jitter, we changed the 4:3 aspect ratio of television to
> something that made you see differently, capitalizing on the ability to
> cross project, and use visuals as a simpler abstract form akin to lighting
> and then go back to being little tvs everywhere (was that a 4 wide/16:3
> screen at the creamery Terry?).  Nobody ever asked who was playing cause
> the DJs name was right there in 3-D spinning around over some brain
> gobbling CGI fractal brainsuck.
>
> But...
>
> I have this problem.  When I am talking to someone, if there is a TV
> behind their head, I start to zone out.  I still hear what they are
> saying, but I am a sucker for distraction, and words and images are the
> worst.  I've actually gotten to the point where I have to apologize for
> this tendency.  I prefer bars without TVs.
>
> A projector is a television 90% of the time.  The aspect ratio, the
> pixels, it is ultimately a TV.  The age old "rave" ethic of sensory
> overload doesn't apply that well to the energy ride and hypnosis that is
> good dance music to me.  If I want to be flooded with sights and sounds,
> let it be at dawn, with the faces of friends and strangers herkin and
> jerkin away.
>
> At night, I actually like as little light as possible.  One of my favorite
> sets in recent hazy memory, the only light in the room was a light bulb
> hanging right over the decks, and at one point I turned even that off.
> In a room like that by the light from the 1200s, you can still see bodies,
> glimpses of faces, celebrating music and only music.  You cut the record
> to silence and it never goes quiet because you hear the clapping, the
> shoes against dirty concrete, and people in the zone humming, barking,
> cheering, chanting.  It's a world of people and sound.  I can't see the
> zit on your nose, I can't tell what color you are, we're breathing the
> same air, feeling the same sounds, souls in the darkness part of the
> electronic hivemind and yet more in tune with ourselves than most days.
>
> Visuals have a place, but I'm tired of them as this mandatory filler.
> Some visuals artists just plain fail to commit and feel their artform the
> same way a good DJ does on a moment by moment basis.  They don't go high
> concept, but rather just mix fairly canned content, chroma-keying here and
> there.  A DJ rarely if ever lets a record run out, but *damn* I've seen a
> lot of credits rolling on visuals screens.  It's more like channel surfing
> sometimes than a creative outlet for a compelled visual artist.
>
> I think a big part of it is we ask visuals people to run visuals all night
> at parties and at some point just run out of stuff and burn out, and you
> can't really have "sets" like you do with DJs, as VJs like such disparate
> setups, but it would be a big boost in increasing the benefit of visuals
> at parties.
>
> Visuals and decor can and have been a huge part of some of my favorite
> moments at parties, but without empathy, concept and foresight they're as
> banal as a DJ who skips on those same aspects.  And much like most art
> museums that abstain from playing music throughout most of the space, the
> best visual input for a given piece of music may be nothing, just like the
> best thing to put behind a Monet might just be an eggshell painted wall
> rather than some pimp ass wallpaper that's far more interesting but
> ultimately conflicting.
>
> To take this full circle to the trance topic, the first indoor F8
> (arguably one of the more successful crews in SF if you consider the mark
> they made on Skills and other incubating groups at the time) parties
> failed to have any decor except for an F8 banner, and a couple black
> lights.  And it was a refreshing change from the then trend of totally
> immersing people in psychedelic blacklight
> Shiva/Ganesh/Chakramap/Mushroom/Schwa props and banners that had become so
> cliche (this is mid 90s SF underground-ish timeframe).
>
> Trance got it's name from the fact that it was supposed to be hypnotic
> (entrancing, get it?).  I find good tracky house and techno do the job way
> better than that garbage ever did to be honest.  There's nothing
> entrancing about breakdowns that leave you wondering if you're still
> actually at a dance party, and short attention span changes that
> constantly leave you painfully aware of the passage of time.  Reduced to
> it's simplest failure (for me at least), trance is hardly trance inducing.
>
> mooo!
> andyw
>

------=_Part_24544_19955622.1201066264829--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance? >>NO<<..well
 maybe.

any hope for trance? bwahahahah! ahem seriously.. NO. not trance as you 
know it but i have been hearing in all the new digital styled techno 
(can't rightly call it minimal.. cause its really not) strains of early 
trance sounds and edgy-close-to-it trance-like progressions. when chel-c 
and i were in berlin about a year ago people were calling it neo trance. 
artists like kaito on kompakt are a good example of this. people under 
this neo-trance moniker are more usually on the techno side of things 
and approach their music from that standpoint.. it just so happens to be 
trance-y.  although i think alot of the neo trance sound has faded out 
recently from what i gather. alot of the techno as of last year has been 
getting more melodic and that's good. this change is possibly  due to 
the result of trance's demise or the desire for the death of a trance 
formula which has been driven down people's throats ever since cj 
bolland retired his hardware sequencer ('i like that song airwave..CJ 
who? eye-q what's that?'). i think that alot of people have more room to 
be free as artists in the techno realm when they aren't afraid to be 
associated with being called trance. there's alot more room now for 
progressive chord development again in techno..if there is another 
trance movement brewing in techno, i'm not sure, but this time i'd say 
they're doing it right by studying detroit a bit more closely and 
rediscovering herbie hancock.

so in short trance is dead. we all saw it coming and i'm not shying away 
any crocodile tears/giddy riotous laughter..

sean o cean
dj disconnect

Mark wrote:
> I see it everywhere, and it's definitely a lot more obvious in SF than LA.
> People hate trance here. I can see why, since the genre has lost most of its
> integrity. However, I've dug deep, and I've found some (in my opinion)
> recent, amazing stuff out there. It's my favorite genre, but sadly it's
> difficult as hell to find good tracks; and even more importantly, it's
> difficult to find good DJs (I'm not even going to mention parties). However,
> I think the genre still has a ridiculous amount of potential and that it
> should not be immediately dismissed. Does anyone else have similar
> sentiments?
>
> P.S. Check out the track Chase My Rabbit by Marcus Schossow if you want an
> example of what I mean by "recent, amazing stuff." I like a lot of the
> older, classic goa stuff (although a ton of crap was released then too).
> Hallucinogen is an example of a goa trance artist that has consistently
> released high quality stuff. Also, Union Jack definitely put out some good
> trance. Does anyone disagree with my judgement of these artists? If so, then
> why?
>

 <Pine.LNX.4.62.0801221127020.22406@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

On Tue, 22 Jan 2008, AndyW wrote:

> My opportunity to work with projects like Viberation and BiPole were
> some of the most fun I have ever had...we changed the 4:3 
> aspect ratio of television tosomething that made you see 
> differently... (was that a 4 wide/16:3 screen at the creamery Terry?).

Yes, it was a jumbotron processor that we reconfigured to 
display content 16:3 with 4 projectors wide, like this:

1  2  3  4

Instead of a standard Jumbotron that displays like this:

1  2
3  4

We had to create the digital video content in such a way that it 
spit out correctly from the processor, that was uber rad. 
More uber that we got other VJ's (D7 & OpticalAssault) to 
collaborate with us for that party :-)

I'm not sure how this turned into a thread about visuals, but 
the one thing I keep feeling is that promoters/organizers 
continually downplay and underestimate the role of visuals at 
parties. Some people just think it's psychedelic flashing 
images, that's not true. Perhaps people are just used to 
run-of-the-mill visuals. Visuals is about story telling, just 
like music, and alongside it. Good visuals can tell stories and 
provoke emotions across any genre. As long as the people 
telling that story give a shit and know what they're 
doing.

I do think it's really cool that hardware/software is beginning 
to catch up (you should have seen what our VJ rig looked like 12 
years ago), so the ability for VJs to explore and present 
content is becoming more accessible, flexible, and robust :-)

-terry
