Message-ID: <20080122233929.E43461@taz3>
References: <6a557de00801211530q123bf8ddw7a009b8f6d96c1bc@mail.gmail.com> 
 <BAY110-DAV1C9ADBA185814D7F23E64853D0@phx.gbl> 
 <6a557de00801211549g5dd7737cp10833e2c60d4ca99@mail.gmail.com> 
 <BAY110-DAV28EB521A47F8C4F7B5088853D0@phx.gbl> 
 <6a557de00801211644s4d9a1362w2dba5e28d2f2bd0c@mail.gmail.com> 
 <347df33a0801211726j79e3c0daw5206dd5f0760cddf@mail.gmail.com>
 <6a557de00801211739w571d2074m81e41a0dda7f7d14@mail.gmail.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.62.0801221127020.22406@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for trance?

Okay, part 2 of my response since CandyAndyW brought up another 
good point...

On Tue, 22 Jan 2008, AndyW wrote:
>
> Visuals have a place, but I'm tired of them as this mandatory filler.
> Some visuals artists just plain fail to commit and feel their artform the
> same way a good DJ does on a moment by moment basis.  They don't go high
> concept, but rather just mix fairly canned content, chroma-keying here and
> there.  A DJ rarely if ever lets a record run out, but *damn* I've seen a
> lot of credits rolling on visuals screens.  It's more like channel surfing
> sometimes than a creative outlet for a compelled visual artist.
>
> I think a big part of it is we ask visuals people to run visuals all night
> at parties and at some point just run out of stuff and burn out, and you
> can't really have "sets" like you do with DJs, as VJs like such disparate
> setups, but it would be a big boost in increasing the benefit of visuals
> at parties.

Andy I hope you're not talking about me, because I have let 
credits roll on a number of occasions (I'm getting better!), 
however I still distinctly remember at a CF where you went into 
the crowd to hear your record, spaced out, and *forgot* you 
were spinning. 
((hugz)) ;-)

Visuals are a tough job because:

- we're ususally one of the first people to setup and the last 
to leave in the morning. We usually have far more tehnical 
limitations, constraints, and overall support than a standard 
DJ.

- we don't have to spin 1 set, we do a 8-10 hour set.

I appreciate your comment that organizers should become more 
involved in the Visuals presentation, because usually, they don't. And 
more so, even if they did, they're usually not savvy enough to 
know what they're asking for.

In a few cases we're on the same page as the organizers, so we 
have direction and a plan. In many cases it's up to us to 
dissect the lineup, and formulate an approach that will tie in 
to the flow. In a lot of cases we're flying by the 
seat-of-our-pants, adjusting video content, speed, texture, 
color to-the-moment. But that's hard to do for 10 hours 
straight.

Lately, a lot of time, I try to break out content into "sets", 
meaning I make sure the content/style transitions at some 
level between music sets. Sometimes it's subtle, sometimes  (in 
the case of a techno headliner), I might shut the visuals OFF for a 
good segment of the set. In fact, I try to shut off visuals 
periodically, especially after a peak during a dance floor 
"come-down" But it's always hard to anticipate what will be 
played and what the crowd response will be.

Utimately, at 5-6am I'm almost always tired, and often faded, so 
I usually throw up something that I think fits best on 
auto-pilot.

Sorry about that.

-tery








---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Friday, January 25
The Final Showdown
With Kontrol's Craig Kuna + Filter's Kontakt
Anu-Bar
46 Sixth St
Free before 11, $5


We've been taking up the techno cause weekly, sometimes twice a week and of
course monthly for over a year now --  and it's time to pass on le baton!

Before we skip off into the sunset (compass currently pointing far to the
North), we're spending our last San Francisco event this Friday pumping the
techno jams with Kontrol's Craig Kuna.

This one's for all of you, past, present and future SF technorati....

Be well and soon to be "farewell"....

-Solekandi

ye's events that many people on this list do not like but the girl on the p=
icture Ultra Dance 09 is so damn good looking it is worth a peek...=20

nel because I am a Sirius subscriber but I hope Sirius and XM merge so they=
 can combine for even better beats!=20

alked about parties in NY that were hard as hell with people coming through=

This Friday in San Francisco @ Ruby Skye please join us for COSMIC GATE's C=
D Release party."Back2back3" is in stores now! They have always been, first=
 and foremost about their fans. The ability to adapt their musical style wi=
th the everchanging face of dance music has seen the Cosmic Gate sound deve=
lop and move on from the harder edge trance of the 90's through to their cu=
rrent, more progressive yet still driving energetic music style. Supporting=
 them for the night is SYD GRIS and in the Jungle room JONATHAN WILLIAMS. C=
lick here for the Guest-list!
Saturday @ Avaland in Hollywood please join us for the ONE YEAR ANNIVERSARY=
 of MADE IN BRAZIL with GUI BORATTO. He has been at the forefront of Brazil=
=92s techno scene for over 10 years, but it was his decision to concentrate=
 on producing his own music and the 2007 release of his debut album Chromop=
hobia that really caught the world=92s attention. A MixMag 2007 album of th=
e year, Chromophobia and Boratto=92s tracks soon found themselves on the pl=
aylists of the world=92s biggest DJs. Supporting him are DJ's JOAN LEE and =
RODRIGO AYALA. The Terrace will be hosted by DROOG. Get on the Discount-lis=
t!=20
ULTRA RECORDS presents the latest installment in their famed annual series,=
 ULTRA DANCE O9!! 2XCDs filled with all of the massive hits and remixes fro=
m your favorite artists: Ti=EBsto, Shiny Toy Guns, Rihanna, Seal, Justice, =
Daft Punk, Armand Van Helden, David Guetta, Axwell, Nelly Furtado, and the =
monster breakthrough hit, Enur feat. Natasja 'Calabria 2008'!!! Get yours t=
oday! Click on the image to preview, buy, and see more of Ultra Dance 09!
        =20

--- dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> Heh.  I love this post.
> 
> I already mentioned the 50' steroscopic projection
> screen I saw at a "faux" rave circa 1994, and of
> course Terry's (Viberation) visuals rocked Love
> Infusion back in 2006, but I'd have to say the
> overall best visuals I have ever experienced were in
> the basement of Club 6 when Dubtribe Soundsystem was
> playing.  
> 
> I think they had some Christmas lights and a candle.
>  ;) 
> 
> Best,
> 
> Peter
> 
> PS No offense to the VJs out there ...
> 
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
> To: Mark <vileru@gmail.com>
> Cc: filter.sf@gmail.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Tuesday, January 22, 2008 12:33:09 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for
> trance?
> 
> 
> On Mon, 21 Jan 2008, Mark wrote:
> -&e->That's a damn good point. Seriously, trance
> parties (especially psytrance)
> -&e->have RIDICULOUS decor. To make that distinction
> more clear: just look at
> 
> I don't need another huge dayglow hindu avatar to
> eat my brain, I don't 
> need a psychelic mushroom to remind me of, um,
> mushrooms I guess.  
> RIDICULOUS is right in many cases.
> 
> -&e->most techno parties. They're all just pretty
> much dark rooms, with maybe 1-2
> -&e->projectors at most. Trance parties are usually
> drowned with black-lights and
> -&e->all sorts of interesting visuals.
> 
> First:
> I've already managed to piss off a whole bunch of
> people on a techno list 
> today, so it might not be the best day for me to
> speak on public lists... 
> but here I go.
> 
> Second: 
> I've worked closely with several intensely good
> visuals crews.  I love 
> their work.  Eyes absorb information at a massive
> rate.  You can say a 
> lot.  My opportunity to work with projects like
> Viberation and BiPole were 
> some of the most fun I have ever had... both in the
> creation and 
> presentation.  Cracking heads with thematic concepts
> that we tried to make 
> all encompassing, often spanning past the synergy of
> music and visuals and 
> going into the ticket design, the decor, events
> planned during the party, 
> use of the space, party favors, etc.  We syncronized
> material, we 
> coordinated times where things would happen, we
> worked with the lighting 
> people to work certain color schemes with certain
> visual material, we 
> hacked Max/MSP/Jitter, we changed the 4:3 aspect
> ratio of television to 
> something that made you see differently,
> capitalizing on the ability to 
> cross project, and use visuals as a simpler abstract
> form akin to lighting 
> and then go back to being little tvs everywhere (was
> that a 4 wide/16:3 
> screen at the creamery Terry?).  Nobody ever asked
> who was playing cause 
> the DJs name was right there in 3-D spinning around
> over some brain 
> gobbling CGI fractal brainsuck.
> 
> But...
> 
> I have this problem.  When I am talking to someone,
> if there is a TV 
> behind their head, I start to zone out.  I still
> hear what they are 
> saying, but I am a sucker for distraction, and words
> and images are the 
> worst.  I've actually gotten to the point where I
> have to apologize for 
> this tendency.  I prefer bars without TVs.
> 
> A projector is a television 90% of the time.  The
> aspect ratio, the 
> pixels, it is ultimately a TV.  The age old "rave"
> ethic of sensory 
> overload doesn't apply that well to the energy ride
> and hypnosis that is 
> good dance music to me.  If I want to be flooded
> with sights and sounds, 
> let it be at dawn, with the faces of friends and
> strangers herkin and 
> jerkin away.
> 
> At night, I actually like as little light as
> possible.  One of my favorite 
> sets in recent hazy memory, the only light in the
> room was a light bulb 
> hanging right over the decks, and at one point I
> turned even that off.   
> In a room like that by the light from the 1200s, you
> can still see bodies, 
> glimpses of faces, celebrating music and only music.
>  You cut the record 
> to silence and it never goes quiet because you hear
> the clapping, the 
> shoes against dirty concrete, and people in the zone
> humming, barking, 
> cheering, chanting.  It's a world of people and
> sound.  I can't see the 
> zit on your nose, I can't tell what color you are,
> we're breathing the 
> same air, feeling the same sounds, souls in the
> darkness part of the 
> electronic hivemind and yet more in tune with
> ourselves than most days.
> 
> Visuals have a place, but I'm tired of them as this
> mandatory filler.  
> Some visuals artists just plain fail to commit and
> feel their artform the 
> same way a good DJ does on a moment by moment basis.
>  They don't go high 
> concept, but rather just mix fairly canned content,
> chroma-keying here and 
> there.  A DJ rarely if ever lets a record run out,
> but *damn* I've seen a 
> lot of credits rolling on visuals screens.  It's
> more like channel surfing 
> sometimes than a creative outlet for a compelled
> visual artist.
> 
> I think a big part of it is we ask visuals people to
> run visuals all night 
> at parties and at some point just run out of stuff
> and burn out, and you 
> can't really have "sets" like you do with DJs, as
> VJs like such disparate 
> setups, but it would be a big boost in increasing
> the benefit of visuals 
> at parties.
> 
> Visuals and decor can and have been a huge part of
> some of my favorite 
> moments at parties, but without empathy, concept and
> foresight they're as 
> banal as a DJ who skips on those same aspects.  And
> much like most art 
> museums that abstain from playing music throughout
> most of the space, the 
> best visual input for a given piece of music may be
> nothing, just like the 
> best thing to put behind a Monet might just be an
> eggshell painted wall 
> rather than some pimp ass wallpaper that's far more
> interesting but 
> ultimately conflicting.
> 
> To take this full circle to the trance topic, the
> first indoor F8 
> (arguably one of the more successful crews in SF if
> you consider the mark 
> they made on Skills and other incubating groups at
> the time) parties 
> failed to have any decor except for an F8 banner,
> and a couple black 
> lights.  And it was a refreshing change from the
> then trend of totally 
> immersing people in psychedelic blacklight 
> Shiva/Ganesh/Chakramap/Mushroom/Schwa props and
> banners that had become so 
> cliche (this is mid 90s SF underground-ish
> timeframe).
> 
> Trance got it's name from the fact that it was
> supposed to be hypnotic 
> (entrancing, get it?).  I find good tracky house and
> techno do the job way 
> better than that garbage ever did to be honest. 
> There's nothing 
> entrancing about breakdowns that leave you wondering
> if you're still 
> actually at a dance party, and short attention span
> changes 
=== message truncated ===

Subject: [sfraves] nrr: intolerence surrounding heath ledgers death..Fuck you anti-gay groups

--0-1845121612-1201149836=:97641
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         i also found this article in regards to the anti gay christian groups
God Hates Fags freaks to picket Heath Ledger’s funeral



this is the flier that they posted on the web..

Flier posted on the wed to picket his funeral


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Bottom article REPOST

article written in regards to the anti gay groups
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Very intense and it shows just how fucked up some people in this country can be. Pretty fucking sad actually that people would do this =/


This is an article my sister Alyssa wrote for CSUN's newspaper. I thought I would repost it for those of you who are unaware of what else is going on beside him dying.

It's pretty fucked. Read on.

Oh one more thing.. Fuck you anti-gay groups and the covered wagon you rode in on!


-------------------------------

By Alyssa Lofgren

On Tuesday, January 22, 2008, 28-year-old Heathcliff Andrew Ledger was found dead in his New York apartment. Several sources have speculated that the cause of his death was a lethal mix of prescription sleeping pills and narcotics. The sudden death of a young actor and father left many young people in the nation shocked, as his rugged, boyish good looks captured the hearts of many women and men around the globe. As the general public mourns the loss of an iconic actor, most notably known for his commendable role in "Brokeback Mountain," a radical Baptist church in Kansas is planning the picketing of his funeral.

They will come in hoards, with signs claiming that "God hates fags" and the opinion that Ledger is burning in hell because of his portrayal as a gay man. This church also runs the website www.godhatesfags.com, and has frequently picketed funerals of soldiers who perished in Iraq. As an open-minded person, I respect everybody's right to individual opinion and religion.

What I do not respect is the horribly offensive, blatant disregard to Ledger's family and friends during their most heart-wrenching personal mourning. A funeral is not a place for picketing, protest or conflict. A funeral is a somber place, perhaps one of the most painful events surrounding a person's passing. There is absolutely no sound reason or moral obligation for the Westboro Baptist Church to invade anybody's funeral with their messages of hate.

Christian people often wonder why their religion is so often poked fun at, and the answer comes from hateful, obsessive people who spread their message of god's supposed love through offensive acts of worship - like picketing an actor's funeral because of the roles he played.

Heath Ledger was an actor who played a gay man, but he is a person. He has a two-year-old daughter, and a family that cares about him. These people are not just Hollywood casualties or the leftovers of a great tabloid story. They are real people with emotions, who are most likely suffering excruciating grief.

I cannot even begin to express my anger that any group of people, no matter what religious affiliation they are, would think it's morally sound to protest at somebody's funeral. America clashes over opinions, and it's rightfully so that we are allowed to argue about them. We are lucky to have the opportunity to express our beliefs in loud, unabashed ways, but I think there is a time and place for everything. If you want to picket homosexuality, the funeral of a STRAIGHT actor who played a gay man is not the place to do it. A funeral is not a place for ANY kind of picketing, no matter what it regards.

Living in a politically charged country, people seem to forget that there are common practices and procedures in life that should be gone about with courtesy. Think about any person in your life, and something they may have done that was considered "controversial" by certain groups. Was it ok for PETA to picket Colonel Sander's funeral because he was the creator of KFC and may have raised and slaughtered chickens in an inhumane way? Would you endorse picketing at a CSUN public safety officer's funeral because there is not enough on-campus parking? If your mother taught you manners, your answer should be "no!"

Although I disagree vehemently with Westboro Baptist Church's opinion about homosexuality in general, I respect their rights to their opinions. However, I will never respect their decision to picket at funerals. Like a stubborn line of ants, they seem to show up at inopportune times, and are resistant to acts of decency and polite requests to leave. The organizations owns several other websites, including www.godhatesamerica.com, and more that include the condemnation of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people, Muslims, Roman Catholics and Jews. They have been classified as a hate group by the Southern Poverty Law Center and are monitored by the Anti-Defamation league.

As a group that clearly serves with an agenda, it's safe to say that their goals are to change the moral fiber of sinful America into a perfect place. Unfortunately, America will never be a perfect place. This country is too full of diversity, opportunity and joy to ever be controlled by one supreme religion- especially one that touts God's redeeming powers but tries to empower through hate.

For all of the people that will be picketing Heath Ledger's funeral, I have one thing to say - shame on you. I understand if you were offended by his role in Brokeback Mountain. I understand if you think he was just another stupid drug addict, fueled by excess time and money. I even understand if you think he was just a crappy actor – but I cannot understand why you think it's ok to show up at somebody's funeral and denounce the meaning of their life.

There is no doubt that some people will support the picketers at Ledger's funeral. They have likely supported things like this in the past. Place aside your opinions of homosexuality, race, religion and politics for just an instant and consider the thought of your own family. Imagine obnoxious protestors standing by your weary and mourning family, spouting their opinions that your deceased loved one is rotting in Hell.

It probably doesn't feel too nice, and in the end, it doesn't even matter what they're protesting about. What matters is the fact that a person you love very much is being remembered, and this is your last time to say "goodbye." Who would ever want to ruin a moment like that?
       
---------------------------------
Never miss a thing.   Make Yahoo your homepage.
--0-1845121612-1201149836=:97641--

-------------------------------

By Alyssa Lofgren

On Tuesday, January 22, 2008, 28-year-old Heathcliff Andrew Ledger was found dead in his New York apartment. Several sources have speculated that the cause of his death was a lethal mix of prescription sleeping pills and narcotics. The sudden death of a young actor and father left many young people in the nation shocked, as his rugged, boyish good looks captured the hearts of many women and men around the globe. As the general public mourns the loss of an iconic actor, most notably known for his commendable role in "Brokeback Mountain," a radical Baptist church in Kansas is planning the picketing of his funeral.

They will come in hoards, with signs claiming that "God hates fags" and the opinion that Ledger is burning in hell because of his portrayal as a gay man. This church also runs the website www.godhatesfags.com, and has frequently picketed funerals of soldiers who perished in Iraq. As an open-minded person, I respect everybody's right to individual opinion and religion.

What I do not respect is the horribly offensive, blatant disregard to Ledger's family and friends during their most heart-wrenching personal mourning. A funeral is not a place for picketing, protest or conflict. A funeral is a somber place, perhaps one of the most painful events surrounding a person's passing. There is absolutely no sound reason or moral obligation for the Westboro Baptist Church to invade anybody's funeral with their messages of hate.

Christian people often wonder why their religion is so often poked fun at, and the answer comes from hateful, obsessive people who spread their message of god's supposed love through offensive acts of worship - like picketing an actor's funeral because of the roles he played.

Heath Ledger was an actor who played a gay man, but he is a person. He has a two-year-old daughter, and a family that cares about him. These people are not just Hollywood casualties or the leftovers of a great tabloid story. They are real people with emotions, who are most likely suffering excruciating grief.

I cannot even begin to express my anger that any group of people, no matter what religious affiliation they are, would think it's morally sound to protest at somebody's funeral. America clashes over opinions, and it's rightfully so that we are allowed to argue about them. We are lucky to have the opportunity to express our beliefs in loud, unabashed ways, but I think there is a time and place for everything. If you want to picket homosexuality, the funeral of a STRAIGHT actor who played a gay man is not the place to do it. A funeral is not a place for ANY kind of picketing, no matter what it regards.

Living in a politically charged country, people seem to forget that there are common practices and procedures in life that should be gone about with courtesy. Think about any person in your life, and something they may have done that was considered "controversial" by certain groups. Was it ok for PETA to picket Colonel Sander's funeral because he was the creator of KFC and may have raised and slaughtered chickens in an inhumane way? Would you endorse picketing at a CSUN public safety officer's funeral because there is not enough on-campus parking? If your mother taught you manners, your answer should be "no!"

Although I disagree vehemently with Westboro Baptist Church's opinion about homosexuality in general, I respect their rights to their opinions. However, I will never respect their decision to picket at funerals. Like a stubborn line of ants, they seem to show up at inopportune times, and are resistant to acts of decency and polite requests to leave. The organizations owns several other websites, including www.godhatesamerica.com, and more that include the condemnation of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people, Muslims, Roman Catholics and Jews. They have been classified as a hate group by the Southern Poverty Law Center and are monitored by the Anti-Defamation league.

As a group that clearly serves with an agenda, it's safe to say that their goals are to change the moral fiber of sinful America into a perfect place. Unfortunately, America will never be a perfect place. This country is too full of diversity, opportunity and joy to ever be controlled by one supreme religion- especially one that touts God's redeeming powers but tries to empower through hate.

For all of the people that will be picketing Heath Ledger's funeral, I have one thing to say - shame on you. I understand if you were offended by his role in Brokeback Mountain. I understand if you think he was just another stupid drug addict, fueled by excess time and money. I even understand if you think he was just a crappy actor – but I cannot understand why you think it's ok to show up at somebody's funeral and denounce the meaning of their life.

There is no doubt that some people will support the picketers at Ledger's funeral. They have likely supported things like this in the past. Place aside your opinions of homosexuality, race, religion and politics for just an instant and consider the thought of your own family. Imagine obnoxious protestors standing by your weary and mourning family, spouting their opinions that your deceased loved one is rotting in Hell.

It probably doesn't feel too nice, and in the end, it doesn't even matter what they're protesting about. What matters is the fact that a person you love very much is being remembered, and this is your last time to say "goodbye." Who would ever want to ruin a moment like that?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: intolerence surrounding heath ledgers death..Fuck you anti-gay groups

It's odd to me that people would want to spend their time and energy =20
on going out and actually picketing a man's funeral, though I am a =20
proponent of free speech.  If any violence were to come out of the =20
protest, however, I'd want to start delving more into who was =20
responsible.  My guess is it won't, I believe the establishment likes =20=

things that create divisiveness among the masses, and for now, =20
godhatesfags.com appears to me, in the five minutes of research I =20
did, a benign extreme Calvinist group of people that definitely don't =20=

like homosexuals, among other things, and they use various Bible =20
passages to prove their point, sort of like the lady that is =20
convinced the Earth rests on the shell of a giant turtle and will not =20=

be convinced otherwise.

Now while on this subject of Christian conservatism and the belief =20
that homosexuality is a sin, there are a few things to note, the gay =20
preacher scandals, the allegations of young boy pages in Congress,  =20
gay males coming to the White House, and of course the news articles =20
we've all seen about male prostitutes visiting the Bohemian Grove in =20
Northern California to entertain an all-male membership.  That =20
bothers me because it's hypocritical.  Here we have people who run =20
our government and pretend to be one thing, but they're really =20
another, and in some cases they're into really sick stuff and doing =20
it against their will.  Maybe.  What you do between the sheets in my =20
opinion your business but public officials have a little more to be =20
responsible for.  So does godhatesfags.com ever go out and picket the =20=

Bohemian Grove?

Now one of the Christian conservative points of view is the people =20
trying to usher in World Communist government sought to weaken people =20=

by deemphasizing 'moral' behavior and once people grew up with =20
nothing to stand for anymore, they would embrace a socialist =20
revolution, then they could have a one child policy and allow people =20
to have as much sex as they want and homosexuality is great because =20
it produces no children.  Honestly I don't know for sure if this is =20
true but I've heard and read quite a bit and where before I heard =20
about this stuff I didn't think I would have any kids and I was sold =20
on the whole idea that having them is somehow bad, but honestly it =20
makes me want to have like 10 or 15 kids just to say fuck you to =20
David Rockefeller.

Anyway I thought I'd post a little background and opinion.  It's a =20
shame to lose Heath Ledger, not only was he a good actor I think but =20
also a pretty handsome guy.  I don't know what happened there that =20
would make him do this if it was a suicide but sometimes you just =20
have to live with it.

-DF

> prostitutes visiting the Bohemian Grove in Northern California to entertain 
> an all-male membership.  That bothers me because it's hypocritical.  Here we 
> have people who run our government and pretend to be one thing, but they're 
> really another, and in some cases they're into really sick stuff and doing it

> 'moral' behavior and once people grew up with nothing to stand for anymore,

> policy and allow people to have as much sex as they want and homosexuality is

> this is true but I've heard and read quite a bit and where before I heard

adriana wrote:
>                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          i also found this article in regards to the anti gay christian groups
> God Hates Fags freaks to picket Heath Ledger’s funeral
>
>
>
> this is the flier that they posted on the web..
>
> Flier posted on the wed to picket his funeral
>
>
> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> Bottom article REPOST
>
> article written in regards to the anti gay groups
> -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> Very intense and it shows just how fucked up some people in this country can be. Pretty fucking sad actually that people would do this =/
>
>
> This is an article my sister Alyssa wrote for CSUN's newspaper. I thought I would repost it for those of you who are unaware of what else is going on beside him dying.
>
> It's pretty fucked. Read on.
>
> Oh one more thing.. Fuck you anti-gay groups and the covered wagon you rode in on!
>
>
> -------------------------------
>
> By Alyssa Lofgren
>
> On Tuesday, January 22, 2008, 28-year-old Heathcliff Andrew Ledger was found dead in his New York apartment. Several sources have speculated that the cause of his death was a lethal mix of prescription sleeping pills and narcotics. The sudden death of a young actor and father left many young people in the nation shocked, as his rugged, boyish good looks captured the hearts of many women and men around the globe. As the general public mourns the loss of an iconic actor, most notably known for his commendable role in "Brokeback Mountain," a radical Baptist church in Kansas is planning the picketing of his funeral.
>
> They will come in hoards, with signs claiming that "God hates fags" and the opinion that Ledger is burning in hell because of his portrayal as a gay man. This church also runs the website www.godhatesfags.com, and has frequently picketed funerals of soldiers who perished in Iraq. As an open-minded person, I respect everybody's right to individual opinion and religion.
>
> What I do not respect is the horribly offensive, blatant disregard to Ledger's family and friends during their most heart-wrenching personal mourning. A funeral is not a place for picketing, protest or conflict. A funeral is a somber place, perhaps one of the most painful events surrounding a person's passing. There is absolutely no sound reason or moral obligation for the Westboro Baptist Church to invade anybody's funeral with their messages of hate.
>
> Christian people often wonder why their religion is so often poked fun at, and the answer comes from hateful, obsessive people who spread their message of god's supposed love through offensive acts of worship - like picketing an actor's funeral because of the roles he played.
>
> Heath Ledger was an actor who played a gay man, but he is a person. He has a two-year-old daughter, and a family that cares about him. These people are not just Hollywood casualties or the leftovers of a great tabloid story. They are real people with emotions, who are most likely suffering excruciating grief.
>
> I cannot even begin to express my anger that any group of people, no matter what religious affiliation they are, would think it's morally sound to protest at somebody's funeral. America clashes over opinions, and it's rightfully so that we are allowed to argue about them. We are lucky to have the opportunity to express our beliefs in loud, unabashed ways, but I think there is a time and place for everything. If you want to picket homosexuality, the funeral of a STRAIGHT actor who played a gay man is not the place to do it. A funeral is not a place for ANY kind of picketing, no matter what it regards.
>
> Living in a politically charged country, people seem to forget that there are common practices and procedures in life that should be gone about with courtesy. Think about any person in your life, and something they may have done that was considered "controversial" by certain groups. Was it ok for PETA to picket Colonel Sander's funeral because he was the creator of KFC and may have raised and slaughtered chickens in an inhumane way? Would you endorse picketing at a CSUN public safety officer's funeral because there is not enough on-campus parking? If your mother taught you manners, your answer should be "no!"
>
> Although I disagree vehemently with Westboro Baptist Church's opinion about homosexuality in general, I respect their rights to their opinions. However, I will never respect their decision to picket at funerals. Like a stubborn line of ants, they seem to show up at inopportune times, and are resistant to acts of decency and polite requests to leave. The organizations owns several other websites, including www.godhatesamerica.com, and more that include the condemnation of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people, Muslims, Roman Catholics and Jews. They have been classified as a hate group by the Southern Poverty Law Center and are monitored by the Anti-Defamation league.
>
> As a group that clearly serves with an agenda, it's safe to say that their goals are to change the moral fiber of sinful America into a perfect place. Unfortunately, America will never be a perfect place. This country is too full of diversity, opportunity and joy to ever be controlled by one supreme religion- especially one that touts God's redeeming powers but tries to empower through hate.
>
> For all of the people that will be picketing Heath Ledger's funeral, I have one thing to say - shame on you. I understand if you were offended by his role in Brokeback Mountain. I understand if you think he was just another stupid drug addict, fueled by excess time and money. I even understand if you think he was just a crappy actor – but I cannot understand why you think it's ok to show up at somebody's funeral and denounce the meaning of their life.
>
> There is no doubt that some people will support the picketers at Ledger's funeral. They have likely supported things like this in the past. Place aside your opinions of homosexuality, race, religion and politics for just an instant and consider the thought of your own family. Imagine obnoxious protestors standing by your weary and mourning family, spouting their opinions that your deceased loved one is rotting in Hell.
>
> It probably doesn't feel too nice, and in the end, it doesn't even matter what they're protesting about. What matters is the fact that a person you love very much is being remembered, and this is your last time to say "goodbye." Who would ever want to ruin a moment like that?
>        
> ---------------------------------
> Never miss a thing.   Make Yahoo your homepage.
>   


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>Very intense and it shows just how fucked up=20
>some people in this country can be. Pretty=20
>fucking sad actually that people would do this =3D/
>
>
>This is an article my sister Alyssa wrote for=20
>CSUN's newspaper. I thought I would repost it=20
>for those of you who are unaware of what else is going on beside him dying.
>
>It's pretty fucked. Read on.
>
>Oh one more thing.. Fuck you anti-gay groups and=20
>the covered wagon you rode in on!
>
>
>-------------------------------
>
>By Alyssa Lofgren
>
>On Tuesday, January 22, 2008, 28-year-old=20
>Heathcliff Andrew Ledger was found dead in his=20
>New York apartment. Several sources have=20
>speculated that the cause of his death was a=20
>lethal mix of prescription sleeping pills and=20
>narcotics. The sudden death of a young actor and=20
>father left many young people in the nation=20
>shocked, as his rugged, boyish good looks=20
>captured the hearts of many women and men around=20
>the globe. As the general public mourns the loss=20
>of an iconic actor, most notably known for his=20
>commendable role in "Brokeback Mountain," a=20
>radical Baptist church in Kansas is planning the picketing of his funeral.
>
>They will come in hoards, with signs claiming=20
>that "God hates fags" and the opinion that=20
>Ledger is burning in hell because of his=20
>portrayal as a gay man. This church also runs=20
>the website www.godhatesfags.com, and has=20
>frequently picketed funerals of soldiers who=20
>perished in Iraq. As an open-minded person, I=20
>respect everybody's right to individual opinion and religion.
>
>What I do not respect is the horribly offensive,=20
>blatant disregard to Ledger's family and friends=20
>during their most heart-wrenching personal=20
>mourning. A funeral is not a place for=20
>picketing, protest or conflict. A funeral is a=20
>somber place, perhaps one of the most painful=20
>events surrounding a person's passing. There is=20
>absolutely no sound reason or moral obligation=20
>for the Westboro Baptist Church to invade=20
>anybody's funeral with their messages of hate.
>
>Christian people often wonder why their religion=20
>is so often poked fun at, and the answer comes=20
>from hateful, obsessive people who spread their=20
>message of god's supposed love through offensive=20
>acts of worship - like picketing an actor's=20
>funeral because of the roles he played.
>
>Heath Ledger was an actor who played a gay man,=20
>but he is a person. He has a two-year-old=20
>daughter, and a family that cares about him.=20
>These people are not just Hollywood casualties=20
>or the leftovers of a great tabloid story. They=20
>are real people with emotions, who are most=20
>likely suffering excruciating grief.
>
>I cannot even begin to express my anger that any=20
>group of people, no matter what religious=20
>affiliation they are, would think it's morally=20
>sound to protest at somebody's funeral. America=20
>clashes over opinions, and it's rightfully so=20
>that we are allowed to argue about them. We are=20
>lucky to have the opportunity to express our=20
>beliefs in loud, unabashed ways, but I think=20
>there is a time and place for everything. If you=20
>want to picket homosexuality, the funeral of a=20
>STRAIGHT actor who played a gay man is not the=20
>place to do it. A funeral is not a place for ANY=20
>kind of picketing, no matter what it regards.
>
>Living in a politically charged country, people=20
>seem to forget that there are common practices=20
>and procedures in life that should be gone about=20
>with courtesy. Think about any person in your=20
>life, and something they may have done that was=20
>considered "controversial" by certain groups.=20
>Was it ok for PETA to picket Colonel Sander's=20
>funeral because he was the creator of KFC and=20
>may have raised and slaughtered chickens in an=20
>inhumane way? Would you endorse picketing at a=20
>CSUN public safety officer's funeral because=20
>there is not enough on-campus parking? If your=20
>mother taught you manners, your answer should be "no!"
>
>Although I disagree vehemently with Westboro=20
>Baptist Church's opinion about homosexuality in=20
>general, I respect their rights to their=20
>opinions. However, I will never respect their=20
>decision to picket at funerals. Like a stubborn=20
>line of ants, they seem to show up at=20
>inopportune times, and are resistant to acts of=20
>decency and polite requests to leave. The=20
>organizations owns several other websites,=20
>including www.godhatesamerica.com, and more that=20
>include the condemnation of gay, lesbian,=20
>bisexual and transgender people, Muslims, Roman=20
>Catholics and Jews. They have been classified as=20
>a hate group by the Southern Poverty Law Center=20
>and are monitored by the Anti-Defamation league.
>
>As a group that clearly serves with an agenda,=20
>it's safe to say that their goals are to change=20
>the moral fiber of sinful America into a perfect=20
>place. Unfortunately, America will never be a=20
>perfect place. This country is too full of=20
>diversity, opportunity and joy to ever be=20
>controlled by one supreme religion- especially=20
>one that touts God's redeeming powers but tries to empower through hate.
>
>For all of the people that will be picketing=20
>Heath Ledger's funeral, I have one thing to say=20
>- shame on you. I understand if you were=20
>offended by his role in Brokeback Mountain. I=20
>understand if you think he was just another=20
>stupid drug addict, fueled by excess time and=20
>money. I even understand if you think he was=20
>just a crappy actor =AD but I cannot understand=20
>why you think it's ok to show up at somebody's=20
>funeral and denounce the meaning of their life.
>
>There is no doubt that some people will support=20
>the picketers at Ledger's funeral. They have=20
>likely supported things like this in the past.=20
>Place aside your opinions of homosexuality,=20
>race, religion and politics for just an instant=20
>and consider the thought of your own family.=20
>Imagine obnoxious protestors standing by your=20
>weary and mourning family, spouting their=20
>opinions that your deceased loved one is rotting in Hell.
>
>It probably doesn't feel too nice, and in the=20
>end, it doesn't even matter what they're=20
>protesting about. What matters is the fact that=20
>a person you love very much is being remembered,=20
>and this is your last time to say "goodbye." Who=20
>would ever want to ruin a moment like that?

On 24 January 2008, Sarilion wrote:

> go away.  or not be heard, whatever.

And if folks haven't seen the movie Jesus Camp, GO!  It's a documentary 
that covers these same type of folks from Kansas too (I think it's 
primarily filmed in Kansas City, and I've BEEN to services at these 
sorts of places.)  An eye opener.  I'd be willing to talk more about it 
in private, but I think a large factor is ignorance and manipulation 
(sounds like another powerful entity, no?)

that I attended.  They were at a Vineyard church:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vineyard_Movement

See what you think of what they believe.

From: "dead boy" <bringyugod@yahoo.com>

> there's only one hope.............gabber
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> --- dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>
>> Heh.  I love this post.
>>
>> I already mentioned the 50' steroscopic projection
>> screen I saw at a "faux" rave circa 1994, and of
>> course Terry's (Viberation) visuals rocked Love
>> Infusion back in 2006, but I'd have to say the
>> overall best visuals I have ever experienced were in
>> the basement of Club 6 when Dubtribe Soundsystem was
>> playing.
>>
>> I think they had some Christmas lights and a candle.
>>  ;)
>>
>> Best,
>>
>> Peter
>>
>> PS No offense to the VJs out there ...
>>
>> ----- Original Message ----
>> From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
>> To: Mark <vileru@gmail.com>
>> Cc: filter.sf@gmail.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
>> Sent: Tuesday, January 22, 2008 12:33:09 PM
>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for
>> trance?
>>
>>
>> On Mon, 21 Jan 2008, Mark wrote:
>> -&e->That's a damn good point. Seriously, trance
>> parties (especially psytrance)
>> -&e->have RIDICULOUS decor. To make that distinction
>> more clear: just look at
>>
>> I don't need another huge dayglow hindu avatar to
>> eat my brain, I don't
>> need a psychelic mushroom to remind me of, um,
>> mushrooms I guess.
>> RIDICULOUS is right in many cases.
>>
>> -&e->most techno parties. They're all just pretty
>> much dark rooms, with maybe 1-2
>> -&e->projectors at most. Trance parties are usually
>> drowned with black-lights and
>> -&e->all sorts of interesting visuals.
>>
>> First:
>> I've already managed to piss off a whole bunch of
>> people on a techno list
>> today, so it might not be the best day for me to
>> speak on public lists...
>> but here I go.
>>
>> Second:
>> I've worked closely with several intensely good
>> visuals crews.  I love
>> their work.  Eyes absorb information at a massive
>> rate.  You can say a
>> lot.  My opportunity to work with projects like
>> Viberation and BiPole were
>> some of the most fun I have ever had... both in the
>> creation and
>> presentation.  Cracking heads with thematic concepts
>> that we tried to make
>> all encompassing, often spanning past the synergy of
>> music and visuals and
>> going into the ticket design, the decor, events
>> planned during the party,
>> use of the space, party favors, etc.  We syncronized
>> material, we
>> coordinated times where things would happen, we
>> worked with the lighting
>> people to work certain color schemes with certain
>> visual material, we
>> hacked Max/MSP/Jitter, we changed the 4:3 aspect
>> ratio of television to
>> something that made you see differently,
>> capitalizing on the ability to
>> cross project, and use visuals as a simpler abstract
>> form akin to lighting
>> and then go back to being little tvs everywhere (was
>> that a 4 wide/16:3
>> screen at the creamery Terry?).  Nobody ever asked
>> who was playing cause
>> the DJs name was right there in 3-D spinning around
>> over some brain
>> gobbling CGI fractal brainsuck.
>>
>> But...
>>
>> I have this problem.  When I am talking to someone,
>> if there is a TV
>> behind their head, I start to zone out.  I still
>> hear what they are
>> saying, but I am a sucker for distraction, and words
>> and images are the
>> worst.  I've actually gotten to the point where I
>> have to apologize for
>> this tendency.  I prefer bars without TVs.
>>
>> A projector is a television 90% of the time.  The
>> aspect ratio, the
>> pixels, it is ultimately a TV.  The age old "rave"
>> ethic of sensory
>> overload doesn't apply that well to the energy ride
>> and hypnosis that is
>> good dance music to me.  If I want to be flooded
>> with sights and sounds,
>> let it be at dawn, with the faces of friends and
>> strangers herkin and
>> jerkin away.
>>
>> At night, I actually like as little light as
>> possible.  One of my favorite
>> sets in recent hazy memory, the only light in the
>> room was a light bulb
>> hanging right over the decks, and at one point I
>> turned even that off.
>> In a room like that by the light from the 1200s, you
>> can still see bodies,
>> glimpses of faces, celebrating music and only music.
>>  You cut the record
>> to silence and it never goes quiet because you hear
>> the clapping, the
>> shoes against dirty concrete, and people in the zone
>> humming, barking,
>> cheering, chanting.  It's a world of people and
>> sound.  I can't see the
>> zit on your nose, I can't tell what color you are,
>> we're breathing the
>> same air, feeling the same sounds, souls in the
>> darkness part of the
>> electronic hivemind and yet more in tune with
>> ourselves than most days.
>>
>> Visuals have a place, but I'm tired of them as this
>> mandatory filler.
>> Some visuals artists just plain fail to commit and
>> feel their artform the
>> same way a good DJ does on a moment by moment basis.
>>  They don't go high
>> concept, but rather just mix fairly canned content,
>> chroma-keying here and
>> there.  A DJ rarely if ever lets a record run out,
>> but *damn* I've seen a
>> lot of credits rolling on visuals screens.  It's
>> more like channel surfing
>> sometimes than a creative outlet for a compelled
>> visual artist.
>>
>> I think a big part of it is we ask visuals people to
>> run visuals all night
>> at parties and at some point just run out of stuff
>> and burn out, and you
>> can't really have "sets" like you do with DJs, as
>> VJs like such disparate
>> setups, but it would be a big boost in increasing
>> the benefit of visuals
>> at parties.
>>
>> Visuals and decor can and have been a huge part of
>> some of my favorite
>> moments at parties, but without empathy, concept and
>> foresight they're as
>> banal as a DJ who skips on those same aspects.  And
>> much like most art
>> museums that abstain from playing music throughout
>> most of the space, the
>> best visual input for a given piece of music may be
>> nothing, just like the
>> best thing to put behind a Monet might just be an
>> eggshell painted wall
>> rather than some pimp ass wallpaper that's far more
>> interesting but
>> ultimately conflicting.
>>
>> To take this full circle to the trance topic, the
>> first indoor F8
>> (arguably one of the more successful crews in SF if
>> you consider the mark
>> they made on Skills and other incubating groups at
>> the time) parties
>> failed to have any decor except for an F8 banner,
>> and a couple black
>> lights.  And it was a refreshing change from the
>> then trend of totally
>> immersing people in psychedelic blacklight
>> Shiva/Ganesh/Chakramap/Mushroom/Schwa props and
>> banners that had become so
>> cliche (this is mid 90s SF underground-ish
>> timeframe).
>>
>> Trance got it's name from the fact that it was
>> supposed to be hypnotic
>> (entrancing, get it?).  I find good tracky house and
>> techno do the job way
>> better than that garbage ever did to be honest.
>> There's nothing
>> entrancing about breakdowns that leave you wondering
>> if you're still
>> actually at a dance party, and short attention span
>> changes
> === message truncated ===

> there's only one hope.............gabber
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> --- dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>
>> Heh.  I love this post.
>>
>> I already mentioned the 50' steroscopic projection
>> screen I saw at a "faux" rave circa 1994, and of
>> course Terry's (Viberation) visuals rocked Love
>> Infusion back in 2006, but I'd have to say the
>> overall best visuals I have ever experienced were in
>> the basement of Club 6 when Dubtribe Soundsystem was
>> playing.
>>
>> I think they had some Christmas lights and a candle.
>>  ;)
>>
>> Best,
>>
>> Peter
>>
>> PS No offense to the VJs out there ...
>>
>> ----- Original Message ----
>> From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
>> To: Mark <vileru@gmail.com>
>> Cc: filter.sf@gmail.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
>> Sent: Tuesday, January 22, 2008 12:33:09 PM
>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Does anyone have any hope for
>> trance?
>>
>>
>> On Mon, 21 Jan 2008, Mark wrote:
>> -&e->That's a damn good point. Seriously, trance
>> parties (especially psytrance)
>> -&e->have RIDICULOUS decor. To make that distinction
>> more clear: just look at
>>
>> I don't need another huge dayglow hindu avatar to
>> eat my brain, I don't
>> need a psychelic mushroom to remind me of, um,
>> mushrooms I guess.
>> RIDICULOUS is right in many cases.
>>
>> -&e->most techno parties. They're all just pretty
>> much dark rooms, with maybe 1-2
>> -&e->projectors at most. Trance parties are usually
>> drowned with black-lights and
>> -&e->all sorts of interesting visuals.
>>
>> First:
>> I've already managed to piss off a whole bunch of
>> people on a techno list
>> today, so it might not be the best day for me to
>> speak on public lists...
>> but here I go.
>>
>> Second:
>> I've worked closely with several intensely good
>> visuals crews.  I love
>> their work.  Eyes absorb information at a massive
>> rate.  You can say a
>> lot.  My opportunity to work with projects like
>> Viberation and BiPole were
>> some of the most fun I have ever had... both in the
>> creation and
>> presentation.  Cracking heads with thematic concepts
>> that we tried to make
>> all encompassing, often spanning past the synergy of
>> music and visuals and
>> going into the ticket design, the decor, events
>> planned during the party,
>> use of the space, party favors, etc.  We syncronized
>> material, we
>> coordinated times where things would happen, we
>> worked with the lighting
>> people to work certain color schemes with certain
>> visual material, we
>> hacked Max/MSP/Jitter, we changed the 4:3 aspect
>> ratio of television to
>> something that made you see differently,
>> capitalizing on the ability to
>> cross project, and use visuals as a simpler abstract
>> form akin to lighting
>> and then go back to being little tvs everywhere (was
>> that a 4 wide/16:3
>> screen at the creamery Terry?).  Nobody ever asked
>> who was playing cause
>> the DJs name was right there in 3-D spinning around
>> over some brain
>> gobbling CGI fractal brainsuck.
>>
>> But...
>>
>> I have this problem.  When I am talking to someone,
>> if there is a TV
>> behind their head, I start to zone out.  I still
>> hear what they are
>> saying, but I am a sucker for distraction, and words
>> and images are the
>> worst.  I've actually gotten to the point where I
>> have to apologize for
>> this tendency.  I prefer bars without TVs.
>>
>> A projector is a television 90% of the time.  The
>> aspect ratio, the
>> pixels, it is ultimately a TV.  The age old "rave"
>> ethic of sensory
>> overload doesn't apply that well to the energy ride
>> and hypnosis that is
>> good dance music to me.  If I want to be flooded
>> with sights and sounds,
>> let it be at dawn, with the faces of friends and
>> strangers herkin and
>> jerkin away.
>>
>> At night, I actually like as little light as
>> possible.  One of my favorite
>> sets in recent hazy memory, the only light in the
>> room was a light bulb
>> hanging right over the decks, and at one point I
>> turned even that off.
>> In a room like that by the light from the 1200s, you
>> can still see bodies,
>> glimpses of faces, celebrating music and only music.
>>  You cut the record
>> to silence and it never goes quiet because you hear
>> the clapping, the
>> shoes against dirty concrete, and people in the zone
>> humming, barking,
>> cheering, chanting.  It's a world of people and
>> sound.  I can't see the
>> zit on your nose, I can't tell what color you are,
>> we're breathing the
>> same air, feeling the same sounds, souls in the
>> darkness part of the
>> electronic hivemind and yet more in tune with
>> ourselves than most days.
>>
>> Visuals have a place, but I'm tired of them as this
>> mandatory filler.
>> Some visuals artists just plain fail to commit and
>> feel their artform the
>> same way a good DJ does on a moment by moment basis.
>>  They don't go high
>> concept, but rather just mix fairly canned content,
>> chroma-keying here and
>> there.  A DJ rarely if ever lets a record run out,
>> but *damn* I've seen a
>> lot of credits rolling on visuals screens.  It's
>> more like channel surfing
>> sometimes than a creative outlet for a compelled
>> visual artist.
>>
>> I think a big part of it is we ask visuals people to
>> run visuals all night
>> at parties and at some point just run out of stuff
>> and burn out, and you
>> can't really have "sets" like you do with DJs, as
>> VJs like such disparate
>> setups, but it would be a big boost in increasing
>> the benefit of visuals
>> at parties.
>>
>> Visuals and decor can and have been a huge part of
>> some of my favorite
>> moments at parties, but without empathy, concept and
>> foresight they're as
>> banal as a DJ who skips on those same aspects.  And
>> much like most art
>> museums that abstain from playing music throughout
>> most of the space, the
>> best visual input for a given piece of music may be
>> nothing, just like the
>> best thing to put behind a Monet might just be an
>> eggshell painted wall
>> rather than some pimp ass wallpaper that's far more
>> interesting but
>> ultimately conflicting.
>>
>> To take this full circle to the trance topic, the
>> first indoor F8
>> (arguably one of the more successful crews in SF if
>> you consider the mark
>> they made on Skills and other incubating groups at
>> the time) parties
>> failed to have any decor except for an F8 banner,
>> and a couple black
>> lights.  And it was a refreshing change from the
>> then trend of totally
>> immersing people in psychedelic blacklight
>> Shiva/Ganesh/Chakramap/Mushroom/Schwa props and
>> banners that had become so
>> cliche (this is mid 90s SF underground-ish
>> timeframe).
>>
>> Trance got it's name from the fact that it was
>> supposed to be hypnotic
>> (entrancing, get it?).  I find good tracky house and
>> techno do the job way
>> better than that garbage ever did to be honest.
>> There's nothing
>> entrancing about breakdowns that leave you wondering
>> if you're still
>> actually at a dance party, and short attention span
>> changes
> === message truncated ===

"J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote: Hi all,
I'm happy to let everyone know that I'll be having a return appearance 
from Indigo on the show this week (Thur. from 9a-Noon Pacific Time.) 
He's promised to keep it funky and make you wish that you weren't 
sitting behind a desk.  So expect LOTS of Funky House with a topping of 
some Tech House to finish it off.  I'd recommend that you don't miss it!

Tune in live at 90.1 FM in the bay area or online at 
http://kzsulive.stanford.edu

Remember, 9a-Noon Pacific Time this Thur.

Hope to have you listening!

Peace.



http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

getting drunk every night and getting into an AA meeting, throwing
money in the basket, and leaving.
-- Ed Begley Jr

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] nrr: Undercover Investigation Uncovers Horrors at PetSmart Supplier's Breeding Mill

--0-322048068-1201202230=:45313
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

http://www.peta.org/

Video footage obtained in a new PETA undercover investigation reveals horrific nightmare conditions for small animals and birds bred and brokered by a major supplier to PetSmart.
In addition to the ever-present misery caused by extremely crowded cages, filthy conditions, a lack of basic enrichment, an often inadequate food and water supply, and excessive noise, PETA's investigation of a massive breeding mill and one of PetSmart's main animal suppliers, Rainbow World Exotics in Hamilton, Texas, also revealed that live animals were thrown into the trash, were deprived of desperately needed veterinary care, were suffering and dying alone in their cages, and were cannibalizing each other; that rabbits underwent crude neuter surgeries at the hands of a layperson in a filthy, dark room; and more. Click here  -->   http://getactive.peta.org/campaign/petsmart_investigation/explanation   to read the details.
  
 See where PetSmart's animal victims are bred. View the video footage -->   http://www.petatv.com/tvpopup/Prefs.asp?video=RWE_web_edit_01_2008
 and photos --> http://www.petsmartcruelty.com/photo_gallery.asp   taken by PETA's undercover investigator. 
  Unsuspecting PetSmart customers have reported buying unsocialized, sick, and injured animals, including guinea pigs with eye and upper respiratory infections, hamsters with deadly diseases, sick and dying betta fish, and suffering birds. As PETA's investigator documented at this breeding mill, overcrowding, lack of veterinary care, and lack of socialization are the norm, not the exception, for the tens of thousands of animals at Rainbow. Click here-->   http://blog.peta.org/archives/Log_Notes.pdf   to read more about what the investigator found.
  PetSmart's trade in live animals supports this mass-breeding industry that is just as cruel as—and even less regulated than—the puppy mill industry. It results in abysmal treatment of tiny, vulnerable beings, and it ultimately leads to their overpopulation, homelessness, neglect, and suffering.

Lonely?


On Thu, 24 Jan 2008, adriana wrote:

> http://www.peta.org/
>
> Video footage obtained in a new PETA undercover investigation reveals horrific nightmare conditions for small animals and birds bred and brokered by a major supplier to PetSmart.
> In addition to the ever-present misery caused by extremely crowded cages, filthy conditions, a lack of basic enrichment, an often inadequate food and water supply, and excessive noise, PETA's investigation of a massive breeding mill and one of PetSmart's main animal suppliers, Rainbow World Exotics in Hamilton, Texas, also revealed that live animals were thrown into the trash, were deprived of desperately needed veterinary care, were suffering and dying alone in their cages, and were cannibalizing each other; that rabbits underwent crude neuter surgeries at the hands of a layperson in a filthy, dark room; and more. Click here  -->   http://getactive.peta.org/campaign/petsmart_investigation/explanation   to read the details.
>
> See where PetSmart's animal victims are bred. View the video footage -->   http://www.petatv.com/tvpopup/Prefs.asp?video=RWE_web_edit_01_2008
> and photos --> http://www.petsmartcruelty.com/photo_gallery.asp   taken by PETA's undercover investigator.
>  Unsuspecting PetSmart customers have reported buying unsocialized, sick, and injured animals, including guinea pigs with eye and upper respiratory infections, hamsters with deadly diseases, sick and dying betta fish, and suffering birds. As PETA's investigator documented at this breeding mill, overcrowding, lack of veterinary care, and lack of socialization are the norm, not the exception, for the tens of thousands of animals at Rainbow. Click here-->   http://blog.peta.org/archives/Log_Notes.pdf   to read more about what the investigator found.
>  PetSmart's trade in live animals supports this mass-breeding industry that is just as cruel as—and even less regulated than—the puppy mill industry. It results in abysmal treatment of tiny, vulnerable beings, and it ultimately leads to their overpopulation, homelessness, neglect, and suffering.
>
>
>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: "We don't let freaks and dogs like you on."

(And it isn't safe for her to reel her leash in herself should there be 
an emergency?)



http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20080123/od_nm/girl_leash1_dc_1
"Pet" girl kicked off bus for wearing leash Wed Jan 23, 1:24 PM ET



A British bus company has apologized to a girl who is
led around on a leash by her boyfriend and describes
herself as a human pet after one of its drivers threw
her off a bus.

Tasha Maltby, 19, told British newspapers she was the
"pet" of her 25-year-old fiance Dani Graves.

Pictures showed her dressed in black Gothic-style
clothing with silver buckles on a silver chain --
which the driver of a bus from the firm Arriva took
exception to.

She told the Daily Mail newspaper Wednesday she was
thrown off and told: "We don't let freaks and dogs
like you on."

Arriva would not comment on specifics but said it
apologized if the couple felt they had been
discriminated against. It added, however, that the
driver was worried about safety and the company told
Maltby to take the leash off in the future.

"We have spoken to the driver who has talked about
health and safety," a spokesman said. "Should she be
attached to a chain and something happens on the bus,
that could be dangerous. All we are saying is that she
is very welcome to use the buses but not when she is
on her lead."

Maltby -- who lives on state benefits and got engaged
in November -- said her choice of lifestyle might seem
unusual but was harmless.

"I am a pet," she told the Daily Mail. "I generally
act animal-like and I lead a really easy life. I don't
cook or clean and I don't go anywhere without Dani. It
might seem strange but it makes us both happy. It's my
culture and my choice. It isn't hurting anyone."

> adriana wrote:
>>                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          
>> i also found this article in regards to the anti gay christian groups
>> God Hates Fags freaks to picket Heath Ledger’s funeral
>>
>>
>>
>> this is the flier that they posted on the web..
>>
>> Flier posted on the wed to picket his funeral
>>
>>
>> ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
>>
>> Bottom article REPOST
>>
>> article written in regards to the anti gay groups
>> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
>>
>> Very intense and it shows just how fucked up some people in this 
>> country can be. Pretty fucking sad actually that people would do this =/
>>
>>
>> This is an article my sister Alyssa wrote for CSUN's newspaper. I 
>> thought I would repost it for those of you who are unaware of what 
>> else is going on beside him dying.
>>
>> It's pretty fucked. Read on.
>>
>> Oh one more thing.. Fuck you anti-gay groups and the covered wagon 
>> you rode in on!
>>
>>
>> -------------------------------
>>
>> By Alyssa Lofgren
>>
>> On Tuesday, January 22, 2008, 28-year-old Heathcliff Andrew Ledger 
>> was found dead in his New York apartment. Several sources have 
>> speculated that the cause of his death was a lethal mix of 
>> prescription sleeping pills and narcotics. The sudden death of a 
>> young actor and father left many young people in the nation shocked, 
>> as his rugged, boyish good looks captured the hearts of many women 
>> and men around the globe. As the general public mourns the loss of an 
>> iconic actor, most notably known for his commendable role in 
>> "Brokeback Mountain," a radical Baptist church in Kansas is planning 
>> the picketing of his funeral.
>>
>> They will come in hoards, with signs claiming that "God hates fags" 
>> and the opinion that Ledger is burning in hell because of his 
>> portrayal as a gay man. This church also runs the website 
>> www.godhatesfags.com, and has frequently picketed funerals of 
>> soldiers who perished in Iraq. As an open-minded person, I respect 
>> everybody's right to individual opinion and religion.
>>
>> What I do not respect is the horribly offensive, blatant disregard to 
>> Ledger's family and friends during their most heart-wrenching 
>> personal mourning. A funeral is not a place for picketing, protest or 
>> conflict. A funeral is a somber place, perhaps one of the most 
>> painful events surrounding a person's passing. There is absolutely no 
>> sound reason or moral obligation for the Westboro Baptist Church to 
>> invade anybody's funeral with their messages of hate.
>>
>> Christian people often wonder why their religion is so often poked 
>> fun at, and the answer comes from hateful, obsessive people who 
>> spread their message of god's supposed love through offensive acts of 
>> worship - like picketing an actor's funeral because of the roles he 
>> played.
>>
>> Heath Ledger was an actor who played a gay man, but he is a person. 
>> He has a two-year-old daughter, and a family that cares about him. 
>> These people are not just Hollywood casualties or the leftovers of a 
>> great tabloid story. They are real people with emotions, who are most 
>> likely suffering excruciating grief.
>>
>> I cannot even begin to express my anger that any group of people, no 
>> matter what religious affiliation they are, would think it's morally 
>> sound to protest at somebody's funeral. America clashes over 
>> opinions, and it's rightfully so that we are allowed to argue about 
>> them. We are lucky to have the opportunity to express our beliefs in 
>> loud, unabashed ways, but I think there is a time and place for 
>> everything. If you want to picket homosexuality, the funeral of a 
>> STRAIGHT actor who played a gay man is not the place to do it. A 
>> funeral is not a place for ANY kind of picketing, no matter what it 
>> regards.
>>
>> Living in a politically charged country, people seem to forget that 
>> there are common practices and procedures in life that should be gone 
>> about with courtesy. Think about any person in your life, and 
>> something they may have done that was considered "controversial" by 
>> certain groups. Was it ok for PETA to picket Colonel Sander's funeral 
>> because he was the creator of KFC and may have raised and slaughtered 
>> chickens in an inhumane way? Would you endorse picketing at a CSUN 
>> public safety officer's funeral because there is not enough on-campus 
>> parking? If your mother taught you manners, your answer should be "no!"
>>
>> Although I disagree vehemently with Westboro Baptist Church's opinion 
>> about homosexuality in general, I respect their rights to their 
>> opinions. However, I will never respect their decision to picket at 
>> funerals. Like a stubborn line of ants, they seem to show up at 
>> inopportune times, and are resistant to acts of decency and polite 
>> requests to leave. The organizations owns several other websites, 
>> including www.godhatesamerica.com, and more that include the 
>> condemnation of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people, 
>> Muslims, Roman Catholics and Jews. They have been classified as a 
>> hate group by the Southern Poverty Law Center and are monitored by 
>> the Anti-Defamation league.
>>
>> As a group that clearly serves with an agenda, it's safe to say that 
>> their goals are to change the moral fiber of sinful America into a 
>> perfect place. Unfortunately, America will never be a perfect place. 
>> This country is too full of diversity, opportunity and joy to ever be 
>> controlled by one supreme religion- especially one that touts God's 
>> redeeming powers but tries to empower through hate.
>>
>> For all of the people that will be picketing Heath Ledger's funeral, 
>> I have one thing to say - shame on you. I understand if you were 
>> offended by his role in Brokeback Mountain. I understand if you think 
>> he was just another stupid drug addict, fueled by excess time and 
>> money. I even understand if you think he was just a crappy actor – 
>> but I cannot understand why you think it's ok to show up at 
>> somebody's funeral and denounce the meaning of their life.
>>
>> There is no doubt that some people will support the picketers at 
>> Ledger's funeral. They have likely supported things like this in the 
>> past. Place aside your opinions of homosexuality, race, religion and 
>> politics for just an instant and consider the thought of your own 
>> family. Imagine obnoxious protestors standing by your weary and 
>> mourning family, spouting their opinions that your deceased loved one 
>> is rotting in Hell.
>>
>> It probably doesn't feel too nice, and in the end, it doesn't even 
>> matter what they're protesting about. What matters is the fact that a 
>> person you love very much is being remembered, and this is your last 
>> time to say "goodbye." Who would ever want to ruin a moment like that?
>>        ---------------------------------
>> Never miss a thing.   Make Yahoo your homepage.
>>   
>
>

> (And it isn't safe for her to reel her leash in
> herself should there be 
> an emergency?)

>
http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20080123/od_nm/girl_leash1_dc_1
> "Pet" girl kicked off bus for wearing leash Wed Jan
> 23, 1:24 PM ET
> 
> 
> 
> A British bus company has apologized to a girl who
> is
> led around on a leash by her boyfriend and describes
> herself as a human pet after one of its drivers
> threw
> her off a bus.
> 
> Tasha Maltby, 19, told British newspapers she was
> the
> "pet" of her 25-year-old fiance Dani Graves.
> 
> Pictures showed her dressed in black Gothic-style
> clothing with silver buckles on a silver chain --
> which the driver of a bus from the firm Arriva took
> exception to.
> 
> She told the Daily Mail newspaper Wednesday she was
> thrown off and told: "We don't let freaks and dogs
> like you on."
> 
> Arriva would not comment on specifics but said it
> apologized if the couple felt they had been
> discriminated against. It added, however, that the
> driver was worried about safety and the company told
> Maltby to take the leash off in the future.
> 
> "We have spoken to the driver who has talked about
> health and safety," a spokesman said. "Should she be
> attached to a chain and something happens on the
> bus,
> that could be dangerous. All we are saying is that
> she
> is very welcome to use the buses but not when she is
> on her lead."
> 
> Maltby -- who lives on state benefits and got
> engaged
> in November -- said her choice of lifestyle might
> seem
> unusual but was harmless.
> 
> "I am a pet," she told the Daily Mail. "I generally
> act animal-like and I lead a really easy life. I
> don't
> cook or clean and I don't go anywhere without Dani.
> It
> might seem strange but it makes us both happy. It's
> my
> culture and my choice. It isn't hurting anyone."
>

>>> Pictures showed her dressed in black Gothic-style
>>> clothing with silver buckles on a silver chain --
>>> which the driver of a bus from the firm Arriva took
>>> exception to.
>>>
>>> She told the Daily Mail newspaper Wednesday she was
>>> thrown off and told: "We don't let freaks and dogs
>>> like you on."
>>>
>>> Arriva would not comment on specifics but said it
>>> apologized if the couple felt they had been
>>> discriminated against. It added, however, that the
>>> driver was worried about safety and the company told
>>> Maltby to take the leash off in the future.
>>>
>>> "We have spoken to the driver who has talked about
>>> health and safety," a spokesman said. "Should she be
>>> attached to a chain and something happens on the
>>> bus,
>>> that could be dangerous. All we are saying is that
>>> she
>>> is very welcome to use the buses but not when she is
>>> on her lead."
>>>
>>> Maltby -- who lives on state benefits and got
>>> engaged
>>> in November -- said her choice of lifestyle might
>>> seem
>>> unusual but was harmless.
>>>
>>> "I am a pet," she told the Daily Mail. "I generally
>>> act animal-like and I lead a really easy life. I
>>> don't
>>> cook or clean and I don't go anywhere without Dani.
>>> It
>>> might seem strange but it makes us both happy. It's
>>> my
>>> culture and my choice. It isn't hurting anyone."
>>>
>>>
>>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
>>> To unsubscribe, e-mail:
>>> sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

> >>>>> 
> >>>>> A British bus company has apologized to a girl who
> >>>>> is
> >>>>> led around on a leash by her boyfriend and describes
> >>>>> herself as a human pet after one of its drivers
> >>>>> threw
> >>>>> her off a bus.
> >>>>> 
> >>>>> Tasha Maltby, 19, told British newspapers she was
> >>>>> the
> >>>>> "pet" of her 25-year-old fiance Dani Graves.
> >>>>> 
> >>>>> Pictures showed her dressed in black Gothic-style
> >>>>> clothing with silver buckles on a silver chain --
> >>>>> which the driver of a bus from the firm Arriva took
> >>>>> exception to.
> >>>>> 
> >>>>> She told the Daily Mail newspaper Wednesday she was
> >>>>> thrown off and told: "We don't let freaks and dogs
> >>>>> like you on."
> >>>>> 
> >>>>> Arriva would not comment on specifics but said it
> >>>>> apologized if the couple felt they had been
> >>>>> discriminated against. It added, however, that the
> >>>>> driver was worried about safety and the company told
> >>>>> Maltby to take the leash off in the future.
> >>>>> 
> >>>>> "We have spoken to the driver who has talked about
> >>>>> health and safety," a spokesman said. "Should she be
> >>>>> attached to a chain and something happens on the
> >>>>> bus,
> >>>>> that could be dangerous. All we are saying is that
> >>>>> she
> >>>>> is very welcome to use the buses but not when she is
> >>>>> on her lead."
> >>>>> 
> >>>>> Maltby -- who lives on state benefits and got
> >>>>> engaged
> >>>>> in November -- said her choice of lifestyle might
> >>>>> seem
> >>>>> unusual but was harmless.
> >>>>> 
> >>>>> "I am a pet," she told the Daily Mail. "I generally
> >>>>> act animal-like and I lead a really easy life. I
> >>>>> don't
> >>>>> cook or clean and I don't go anywhere without Dani.
> >>>>> It
> >>>>> might seem strange but it makes us both happy. It's
> >>>>> my
> >>>>> culture and my choice. It isn't hurting anyone."

Peter Glikshtern (Liquid, Club 6, Mighty) to take 1015 into a new direction:

Will 1015 survive as a rock club?  Does its demise say somethign about the EDM scene in SF?  And how does it all impact th eundergound?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 1015 to become a rock club

I for one could care less....1015 is one of my least favorite venues in 
town. The sound is awful quite a lot of the time, and the crowd can be 
REALLY hit or miss as far as vibe. It seems more suited to a live music 
venue (at least in the main room) than it is for DJ's. I think the 
downstairs and upstairs lounges are much more suited to DJ's. Maybe they'll 
do a dual format?

I doubt this means much to the local EDM scene...we have so much stuff 
happening all the time, that 1015 going rock most likely won't effect things 
one way or the other. Especially w/ Temple and other big venues around to 
fill its shoes.
