Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Sat.Feb.2nd [KONTROL] w/ Donnacha Costello - exclusive 2 hour LIVE PA!

------=_Part_4541_5975609.1201309787359
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Saturday, February 2nd, 2008

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup


featuring from Dublin, Ireland in an
exclusive North American appearance:

DONNACHA COSTELLO
*2 hour extended live pa*
(minimise . kompakt . force inc . mille plateaux)


"Well...that's enough. Fuck it." To anyone paying attention, those
words will instantly bring to mind one of the most unique and
memorable techno tracks of last year. The man behind it is Dublin's
Donnacha Costello, who has been producing for over a decade but
really came into the international spotlight in 2004 with the release
of his acclaimed "Colorseries", a monthly sequence of 10 color-
coded EP's created using entirely analog gear and released on his
own Minimise label. Influenced by minimal pioneers like Mike Ink,
Plastikman, and Basic Channel, Donnacha creates warm, dubby
techno that intoxicates the mind as it compels the body to move.
After witnessing his stirring live PA at the 2006 DEMF, we knew we
needed to bring him out to SF, but in the nearly two years since,
he's been nowhere near these parts. Tired of waiting, this month
we've finally decided to say "fuck it" ourselves and fly him over for
an exclusive North American appearance you definitely won't want
to miss.


with [KONTROL] residents:

==> SAMMY D
classic . utensil . dirtybird . magnificent 7

==> CRAIG KUNA
platform . esdjco

==> ALLAND BYALLO
nightlight music . auralism . leibe*detail

==> NIKOLA BAYTALA
s.w.a.t . robsoul . junior boys own

____________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________


full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

February flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K32/K32FB.jpg

February flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K32/K32BB.jpg

February poster:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K32/K32P.jpg

____________________________________________________


DONNACHA COSTELLO is many things to many people.

In the past he has been: Child, Brother, Pianist, Teenager, Guitarist,
Student, Techno Musician, Philosopher, Expatriate, Label Owner, Audio
Engineer, Bereaved, Ambient Musician, Visual Artist, Techno Musician,
University Lecturer, Composer for Film, Experimental Musician, Techno
Musician, Husband.

He has been releasing records since 1996 and his talent has long been
recognized by those in the know including Johnny Marr (Ex-Smiths) and Richie
Hawtin. The list of DJs who support his work reads like a Who's Who of
techno, many of whom have licensed his work for their mix CDs, most recently
including Ricardo Villalobos, Luciano, Magda, Tiefschwarz and Josh Wink. As
a live performer, and more recently as a DJ, Costello regularly performs
around the globe from Europe to the U.S. to Japan and runs his renowned
'MINIMISE' record label from his hometown of Dublin.


____________________________________________________


About Donnacha's recently re-issued "Colorseries":

The Colorseries was a series of ten records released in rapid succession by
Donnacha Costello in 2004 and marked the breakthrough point in his career.
The collection is special in that these records were produced solely with
analog equipment, without a computer in sight. The hand crafted coherence of
the music made and speed of the release process marked the series almost as
a stream of consciousness, with each color embodying a different chapter,
mood and season, with all elements inextricably linked to one another in far
more than just name.

Throughout 2004, the Colorseries consistently appeared in the charts of big
name DJs and eventually appeared in end of year top ten lists in many
publications including The Wire and The New York Times.  In the intervening
years, Donnacha has scored a number of hit releases, including last year's
unstoppable "6.6", and has broadened his fan base considerably. The
Colorseries CD will therefore appeal to those who were not around for the
original releases, those who have discovered Donnacha's work through artist
mixes or through witnessing one of his famed live appearances.  Minimise is
proud to present these tracks on CD for the first time, offering the
full-spectrum sound-rainbow for your listening pleasure. Colorseries
influences include: Farley Jackmaster Funk, Steve Silk Hurley, Inner City,
808 State, Plastikman, F.U.S.E., Aphex Twin, The Black Dog, Lobe, LFO,
Maurizio, Basic Channel, Model 500, Baby Ford, Mike Ink, The Modernist,
Studio One, Thomas Brinkmann.



LINKS:

Donnacha's website: (with Colorseries music samples)
http://minimise.com/

Donnacha's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/donnacha%20costello

A recent ResidentAdvisor feature on the Colorseries:
http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature-read.aspx?id=852

Reviews of Donnacha's music:
http://www.forcedexposure.com/artists/costello.donnacha.html


VIDEO:

Donnacha Costello live @ POGO, Dublin 2007
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EMf7fuGqLSg

Donnacha Costello live @ Loft Club, Barcelona 2007
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rzboORQMR0c


AUDIO:

Donnacha Costello - 6.6 (sample)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K32/dc6.6.mp3

http://sound.modelfruit.com/sets/r_elliott-minimise_mixed-color_series.mp3

...and the letter and spreadsheet(!) he accompanied it with:
http://sound.modelfruit.com/images/elliott1.jpg
http://sound.modelfruit.com/images/elliott2.jpg

A recent 2007 retrospective DJ mix:
http://minimise.com/mixes/costello_lbff.zip



See you on the dancefloor February 2nd!

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

This week on DEF's Radio Integrated : Friday, January 25th, 2008 :

Tonight we'll be broadcasting live from the final edition of one of our
favorite techno club nights, Filter at Anu in San Francisco. We of course
highly recommend that you come down to the party in person... But if you
have the flu, are visiting family in Argentina, or just can't find that
other prosthetic leg anywhere, tune in to Radio Integrated to hear what
you're missing!

Tonight's broadcast will be from approximately 10pm - 2am Pacific Standard
Time, and will feature sets from Kontrol's Craig Kuna, and Filter's Kontakt.


Tune in this Friday and every Friday at http://www.zer01.net:1200/


 * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *
* * * * * * * * * * *

Radio Integrated :: radiointegrated@gmail.com ::  http://www.zer01.net:1200/::
Broadcasting live from Bliss Factory Studios, Alameda, CA every Friday night

spots around the city to just get the feel of them, I didn't go into =20
any of them.  I know, hard to get a feel of a place without going in.  =20
It just seems like everything is small bars that close at 2am and have =20
a DJ table.  I see that and clamor to be back in Palma, or back in =20
Torremolinos, or to Barcelona, or up in Riga, or in Poland, where I =20
either went to stuff that's open late every night or seemed like it =20
anyway.  Maybe that's just my perception.  Saturday night I went up to =20
Alameda and hung out with Chris.  Where's Jasmine these days?  I heard =20
Cassandra's like 15 now.  Hahh, anyway, I'm just rambling on.

Speaking as a sensualist, and by this I mean a very narrow-minded, =20
incentered (?) man of peace... Travel.  I recently went to Europe.  I =20
think everyone should see it for a week.  You really see what's wrong =20
with this country when you visit a European utopia. Things like a =20
journey, public transportation, health care, leather shorts, =20
mustaches.  When I went to Belize, I helped some villagers clear
some land for an environmentally-friendly coal mine.  We've all got to
make some sacrifices if we're going to get anywhere.  My dad gave me the
money to set up an exciting trust there.

- Grand Theft Auto:  Vice City (Vice City Public Radio)

=64=75=29 =73=68=6F=77 =6F=6E =4D=6F=6E =4E=69=74=65=2F=54=75=65=73 =4D=6F=
=72=6E=2E =31=32-=33=41=4D

----- Original Message ----
From: Holt Sorenson <hso@hsomusic.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, January 28, 2008 3:15:00 PM
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: This week on KZSU - Joey Tek


Please tune in to KZSU by listening to 90.1 in the Bay Area or pointing
your web browser to http://kzsulive.stanford.edu.

Big Love Show with Jack Wang - Mondays from 3PM-6PM PST
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

This week Jack is proud to host Joey Tek. Joey is a Producer/DJ that has been
DJing for 18 years and has several releases to his credit.

The mix is about toget started right now with house and other electronica.
Lock it in!!!

More infos:
hsomusic.com/sh/G


Eclecktronik Groove with Holt Sorenson - Mon Nite (Tues) from 12AM-3AM PST
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Eclecktronik Groove will not be on air this week, as Holt is returning from
a weekend of gigs in LA and MX. He'll return next week on February 5th.

Epiphany of Sound with J.C. - Thursday from 9AM-12PM PST
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

After 14 years, DJ J.C.'s techno/house/electronica showcase has
garnered much attention and devotion. Like most folks at Stanford's
radio station, he's a volunteer, proving that his motivation isn't
a paycheck; it's his passion to share his interest in one of music's
most eclectic genres. With his conversational style, inclusion of
producers and musicians from both the local & international scene,
and his stewardship of the station's 24-hour marathons during
Solstices and Equinoxes, it's no wonder that DJ J.C has made a
connection with listeners in a very crowded market. Catch his live
broadcasts or listen to the previous week's program at underheard.org.

J.C. will email this week if he has an update on any guests.

Thanks for your support!!!

--
Holt Sorenson/Eclektronik Groove
hso@hsomusic.com
hsomusic.com - myspace.com/hsomusic
KZSU (kzsulive.stanford.edu) show on Mon Nite/Tues Morn. 12-3AM

I don't know where your conscience stands, but for a while mine has been=20
one to not make enough money to worry about paying taxes (the 4th=20

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 28 Jan 2008 23:48:30 -0800
From: Scott Munson <scott@planttrees.org>
Reply-To: sf_indie_politics@yahoogroups.com
To: undisclosed-recipients:  ;
Subject: [sf_indie_politics] War Tax Resistance Workshop 2/16: Please Forwa=
rd!

This Year, Together, We Can Defund the War!
War Tax Resistance Workshop
Saturday, February 16, 10am-12:30pm

SF Friends Meeting
65-9th St. between Mission and Market
San Francisco (Civic Center BART)

More than half of our federal income taxes are spent on war.
Find out more about this form of conscientious objection and
Join the 2008 War Tax Boycott and the
Code Pink =93Don=92t Buy Bush=92s War=94 campaign.

Topics will include:
-- Creative legal protests
-- Refusing to pay all or part of federal taxes
-- Possible consequences of this form of civil disobedience
-- Living below the level of taxable income
-- Phone tax resistance
-- Redirecting resisted taxes to local alternative funds and/or
community organizations
-- Local support networks for war tax resisters

For more information:
Northern California War Tax Resistance
(510) 843-9877 =80 http://www.nowartax.org
Thank you for working for peace!
This workshop is co-sponsored by Code Pink Women for Peace.
Northern California War Tax Resistance provides information and
support for conscientious war tax resisters in the San Francisco Bay
Area.

http://www.nowartax.org  (510) 843-9877

Interesting concept! I work as a Paralegal in IP litigation and I am in no =
way giving legal advice but this movement does not seem like a good idea. I=
nteresting but from what I have learned working in the legal field and from=
 classes I took when I was earning my BS a couple years ago do not cheat th=
e government with taxes.=20
=20
If you do not earn to much and do not report certain things you may slide t=
hrough the system. However, eventually the government may catch-on especial=
ly if you earn quite a bit and owe the government.=20
=20
The Iraq War has no value but it does no good to not pay taxes and to screw=
 around with the IRS. A high profile case would be Wesley Snipes who believ=
es there is a tax conspiracy although he is now being forced to pay back ta=
xes. I think our taxes go to much more then the war effort so think twice. =
  =20
=20
Does anyone remember what happened to Will Smith in the movie Pursuit of Ha=
ppiness? They took Smith's money and believe me it happens the government c=
an seize your money if you owe back taxes in some circumstances. Here is so=
me common knowledge you could easily find on the web for instance in Bankru=
ptcy law if you filed a bankruptcy petition almost no matter what chapter y=
ou qualify to file under the first order of distribution of claims to be pa=
id is priority secured administrative claims which taxes falls right under.=
=20
=20
Something I learned when I earned my paralegal certificate is that you can =
never cheat a sleazy lawyer from getting paid a retainer fee and you can ne=
ver cheat the IRS!
=20
=20
Isaac =20
=20
=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: War Tax Resistance Workshop 2/16

Uh... there's plenty of laws regarding income tax. Stop reading internet 
conspiracy theory drivel. For instance:

The 16th amendment:
"The Congress shall have power to lay and collect taxes on incomes, from 
whatever source derived, without apportionment among the several States, 
and without regard to any census or enumeration."

Besides, quite a bit of how our government works is not from laws on the 
books, but rather from case law.

There's an entire wikipedia page on income tax within the united states 
and related cases:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Income_tax_in_the_United_States

Please, post stuff related to the list, enough of the politico-bullshit.

Alex Mingoia

> Uh... there's plenty of laws regarding income tax. Stop reading internet

>
> The 16th amendment:
> "The Congress shall have power to lay and collect taxes on incomes, from 
> whatever source derived, without apportionment among the several States, 
> and without regard to any census or enumeration."
>
> Besides, quite a bit of how our government works is not from laws on the 
> books, but rather from case law.

> and related cases:
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Income_tax_in_the_United_States

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager

I wanted to see what anyone thinks about this article, I know I buy =20
very few CD's, and oddly enough one of them was U2's CD from a few =20
years ago, I would love to contact the manager and find out if there =20
is a way I can just return this CD and get my money back, I really =20
don't want to support someone that supports an unrealistic push to =20
nanny what everyone does on their personal computers and support an =20
industry that generally does not have the well-being of the artist in =20
mind, rather big corporate profits.

--

http://www.telegraph.co.uk/connected/main.jhtml;jsessionid=3D3EKD2RI2OKH0XQF=
IQMFCFFOAVCBQYIV0?xml=3D/connected/2008/01/29/dlutwo129.xml

Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager
By Nicole Martin, Digital and Media Correspondent, in Cannes
Last Updated: 12:01am GMT 29/01/2008

Music fans who repeatedly download songs illegally should have their =20
internet connections severed, the manager of U2 has said.

Telegraph Arts coverage in full
Telegraph Digital Life
Paul McGuinness, who has managed the best-selling group for 30 years, =20
attacked internet service providers for failing to clamp down on =20
illegal file-sharing.



The manager of U2 has called for ISPs to take action against repeat offender=
s
He said the refusal of internet firms to punish those who download =20
music without paying was "the single biggest failure in the digital =20
music market".

He called on them to adopt a "three strikes and you're out" =20
enforcement policy under which illegal downloaders would have to start =20
paying for music or face having their ISP subscriptions terminated.

"We must shame them into wanting to help us. Their snouts have been at =20
our trough feeding free for too long," Mr McGuinness said at the Midem =20
music industry conference in Cannes.

"For ISPs in general, the days of prevaricating over their =20
responsibilities for helping protect music must end. The ISP lobbyists =20
who say they should not have to 'police the internet' are living in =20
the past - relying on outdated excuses from an earlier technological =20
age."

His call follows a report last week which showed that while worldwide =20
sales of digital music grew by 40 per cent last year, they were still =20
not enough to offset a sharp fall in CD sales.

The International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, which =20
represents record companies across the world, warned that the "crisis" =20
in the music industry would deepen unless ISPs took action against the =20
millions of people who illegally download music.

Many ISPs have been reluctant to police the illegal activities of =20
their customers, preferring to rely on record labels to bring cases =20
against them.

advertisement

But Mr McGuinness said it was time to challenge the belief that ISPs =20
should not be held accountable for their customers' behaviour.

"If you were publishing a magazine that was advertising stolen cars, =20
processing payments for them and arranging delivery of them you'd =20
expect to get a visit from the police wouldn't you?" he said, in a =20
speech titled The Online Bonanza: Who is Making All The Money and Why =20
Aren't They Sharing It?

"What's the difference? With a laptop, a broadband account, an MP3 =20
player and a smartphone you can now steal all the content, music, =20
video and literary in the world without any money going to the content =20
owners.

"On the other hand, if you get caught stealing a laptop in the =20
computer store or don't pay your broadband bill there are obvious =20
consequences. You get nicked or you get your access cut off."

A survey last year by Quantum Markets in Australia found that of the =20
2.8 billion people who regularly download illegally, 75 per cent said =20
they did not believe they were hurting the music industry.

When asked why, the vast majority said they did not feel at risk of =20
being punished for downloading songs for free.

Mr McGuinness called on the Government to follow the lead of Nicolas =20
Sarkozy, the French President, and introduce legislation if voluntary =20
talks with ISPs failed to produce a commitment to disconnect =20
file-sharers. A spokesman for the Internet Service Providers' =20
Association said its members preferred self regulation to legislation.

"We do not support abuses of copyright and intellectual property =20
theft. However, ISPs cannot monitor or record the type of information =20
passed over their networks," he said.

"ISPs are no more able to inspect and filter every single packet =20
passing across their network than the Post Office is able to open =20
every envelope."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: War Tax Resistance Workshop 2/16

my only comment to this is it sounds like a good thing, but one thing =20
and aaron russo's film addresses this, income tax does not go to pay =20
for anything but the national debt.  income tax is not so much a war =20
tax as INFLATION is.

so while if everyone stopped paying income tax tomorrow, it would hurt =20
them, but they can just use the Fed to print more money and we end up =20
paying for it down the road with the hidden tax called inflation.  =20
also, since the IRS, the illegal 'tax' courts, and the government are =20
all playing on the same team, it's likely you could end up in prison =20
like Ed Brown is right now.  i think this is one of those things you =20
have to choose to either speak out against it or quietly just not fill =20
out the paperwork, but do your homework if you go that route.

i'm not going to tell anyone not to pay the slave tax.  i will =20
recommend getting rid of the illegal privately owned Central Bank that =20
is I believe the root cause of most of the problems we have destroying =20
this country today.

i have put this on my calendar and i'm interested to see how much they =20
will talk about the related problems.

I was a war tax resister from about 2004 to 2007. This year is the first
year I'm going to file taxes since about 2004, it'll be interesting to see
what the IRS has to say about it. I figure I gotta start paying taxes if I'=
m
going to (eventually) become a (somewhat) respectable member of society,
especially since I currently make way more money than the government is
willing to overlook.

So yeah, fuck the government, especially if you don't need anything from
them. Tell them to go to hell and keep your money.

>
>http://www.telegraph.co.uk/connected/main.jhtml;jsessionid=3EKD2RI2OKH0XQFIQMFCFFOAVCBQYIV0?xml=/connected/2008/01/29/dlutwo129.xml
>
>Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager
>By Nicole Martin, Digital and Media Correspondent, in Cannes
>Last Updated: 12:01am GMT 29/01/2008
>
>Music fans who repeatedly download songs illegally should have their  
>internet connections severed, the manager of U2 has said.
>
>Telegraph Arts coverage in full
>Telegraph Digital Life
>Paul McGuinness, who has managed the best-selling group for 30 years,  
>attacked internet service providers for failing to clamp down on  
>illegal file-sharing.
>
>
>
>The manager of U2 has called for ISPs to take action against repeat offenders
>He said the refusal of internet firms to punish those who download  
>music without paying was "the single biggest failure in the digital  
>music market".
>
>He called on them to adopt a "three strikes and you're out"  
>enforcement policy under which illegal downloaders would have to start  
>paying for music or face having their ISP subscriptions terminated.
>
>"We must shame them into wanting to help us. Their snouts have been at  
>our trough feeding free for too long," Mr McGuinness said at the Midem  
>music industry conference in Cannes.
>
>"For ISPs in general, the days of prevaricating over their  
>responsibilities for helping protect music must end. The ISP lobbyists  
>who say they should not have to 'police the internet' are living in  
>the past - relying on outdated excuses from an earlier technological  
>age."
>
>His call follows a report last week which showed that while worldwide  
>sales of digital music grew by 40 per cent last year, they were still  
>not enough to offset a sharp fall in CD sales.
>
>The International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, which  
>represents record companies across the world, warned that the "crisis"  
>in the music industry would deepen unless ISPs took action against the  
>millions of people who illegally download music.
>
>Many ISPs have been reluctant to police the illegal activities of  
>their customers, preferring to rely on record labels to bring cases  
>against them.
>
>advertisement
>
>But Mr McGuinness said it was time to challenge the belief that ISPs  
>should not be held accountable for their customers' behaviour.
>
>"If you were publishing a magazine that was advertising stolen cars,  
>processing payments for them and arranging delivery of them you'd  
>expect to get a visit from the police wouldn't you?" he said, in a  
>speech titled The Online Bonanza: Who is Making All The Money and Why  
>Aren't They Sharing It?
>
>"What's the difference? With a laptop, a broadband account, an MP3  
>player and a smartphone you can now steal all the content, music,  
>video and literary in the world without any money going to the content  
>owners.
>
>"On the other hand, if you get caught stealing a laptop in the  
>computer store or don't pay your broadband bill there are obvious  
>consequences. You get nicked or you get your access cut off."
>
>A survey last year by Quantum Markets in Australia found that of the  
>2.8 billion people who regularly download illegally, 75 per cent said  
>they did not believe they were hurting the music industry.
>
>When asked why, the vast majority said they did not feel at risk of  
>being punished for downloading songs for free.
>
>Mr McGuinness called on the Government to follow the lead of Nicolas  
>Sarkozy, the French President, and introduce legislation if voluntary  
>talks with ISPs failed to produce a commitment to disconnect  
>file-sharers. A spokesman for the Internet Service Providers'  
>Association said its members preferred self regulation to legislation.
>
>"We do not support abuses of copyright and intellectual property  
>theft. However, ISPs cannot monitor or record the type of information  
>passed over their networks," he said.
>
>"ISPs are no more able to inspect and filter every single packet  
>passing across their network than the Post Office is able to open  
>every envelope."
>
>
>
>
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>
>

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> On Tuesday, January 29, 2008, at 01:14PM, "Deepfog" <sfo@deepfog.com> 
> wrote:
>>I wanted to see what anyone thinks about this article, I know I buy
>>very few CD's, and oddly enough one of them was U2's CD from a few
>>years ago, I would love to contact the manager and find out if there
>>is a way I can just return this CD and get my money back, I really
>>don't want to support someone that supports an unrealistic push to
>>nanny what everyone does on their personal computers and support an
>>industry that generally does not have the well-being of the artist in
>>mind, rather big corporate profits.
>>
>>--
>>
>>http://www.telegraph.co.uk/connected/main.jhtml;jsessionid=3EKD2RI2OKH0XQFIQMFCFFOAVCBQYIV0?xml=/connected/2008/01/29/dlutwo129.xml
>>
>>Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager
>>By Nicole Martin, Digital and Media Correspondent, in Cannes
>>Last Updated: 12:01am GMT 29/01/2008
>>
>>Music fans who repeatedly download songs illegally should have their
>>internet connections severed, the manager of U2 has said.
>>
>>Telegraph Arts coverage in full
>>Telegraph Digital Life
>>Paul McGuinness, who has managed the best-selling group for 30 years,
>>attacked internet service providers for failing to clamp down on
>>illegal file-sharing.
>>
>>
>>
>>The manager of U2 has called for ISPs to take action against repeat 
>>offenders
>>He said the refusal of internet firms to punish those who download
>>music without paying was "the single biggest failure in the digital
>>music market".
>>
>>He called on them to adopt a "three strikes and you're out"
>>enforcement policy under which illegal downloaders would have to start
>>paying for music or face having their ISP subscriptions terminated.
>>
>>"We must shame them into wanting to help us. Their snouts have been at
>>our trough feeding free for too long," Mr McGuinness said at the Midem
>>music industry conference in Cannes.
>>
>>"For ISPs in general, the days of prevaricating over their
>>responsibilities for helping protect music must end. The ISP lobbyists
>>who say they should not have to 'police the internet' are living in
>>the past - relying on outdated excuses from an earlier technological
>>age."
>>
>>His call follows a report last week which showed that while worldwide
>>sales of digital music grew by 40 per cent last year, they were still
>>not enough to offset a sharp fall in CD sales.
>>
>>The International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, which
>>represents record companies across the world, warned that the "crisis"
>>in the music industry would deepen unless ISPs took action against the
>>millions of people who illegally download music.
>>
>>Many ISPs have been reluctant to police the illegal activities of
>>their customers, preferring to rely on record labels to bring cases
>>against them.
>>
>>advertisement
>>
>>But Mr McGuinness said it was time to challenge the belief that ISPs
>>should not be held accountable for their customers' behaviour.
>>
>>"If you were publishing a magazine that was advertising stolen cars,
>>processing payments for them and arranging delivery of them you'd
>>expect to get a visit from the police wouldn't you?" he said, in a
>>speech titled The Online Bonanza: Who is Making All The Money and Why
>>Aren't They Sharing It?
>>
>>"What's the difference? With a laptop, a broadband account, an MP3
>>player and a smartphone you can now steal all the content, music,
>>video and literary in the world without any money going to the content
>>owners.
>>
>>"On the other hand, if you get caught stealing a laptop in the
>>computer store or don't pay your broadband bill there are obvious
>>consequences. You get nicked or you get your access cut off."
>>
>>A survey last year by Quantum Markets in Australia found that of the
>>2.8 billion people who regularly download illegally, 75 per cent said
>>they did not believe they were hurting the music industry.
>>
>>When asked why, the vast majority said they did not feel at risk of
>>being punished for downloading songs for free.
>>
>>Mr McGuinness called on the Government to follow the lead of Nicolas
>>Sarkozy, the French President, and introduce legislation if voluntary
>>talks with ISPs failed to produce a commitment to disconnect
>>file-sharers. A spokesman for the Internet Service Providers'
>>Association said its members preferred self regulation to legislation.
>>
>>"We do not support abuses of copyright and intellectual property
>>theft. However, ISPs cannot monitor or record the type of information
>>passed over their networks," he said.
>>
>>"ISPs are no more able to inspect and filter every single packet
>>passing across their network than the Post Office is able to open
>>every envelope."
>>

From: Sean Allen <sean_allen@mac.com>

Yeah, 

U2 are the new Metallica. And both couldn't be less relevant to innovative music today.  I also especially love how he tried to diss Radiohead for *gasp* giving people the choice to pay what they thought the music was worth. Its amusing to watch the death-throes of an antiquated business model and the shrill bleating of those who realize their vastly inflated paychecks are rasterizing and disappearing down the  tubes that lead to Al Gore's basement.

Personally, I'm loling as I download relevant music from digital retailers while watching Boner disappear up his own arse...

On Tuesday, January 29, 2008, at 01:14PM, "Deepfog" <sfo@deepfog.com> wrote:

>very few CD's, and oddly enough one of them was U2's CD from a few

>nanny what everyone does on their personal computers and support an

>--
>
>http://www.telegraph.co.uk/connected/main.jhtml;jsessionid=3EKD2RI2OKH0XQFIQMFCFFOAVCBQYIV0?xml=/connected/2008/01/29/dlutwo129.xml
>
>Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager
>By Nicole Martin, Digital and Media Correspondent, in Cannes
>Last Updated: 12:01am GMT 29/01/2008
>
>Music fans who repeatedly download songs illegally should have their  
>internet connections severed, the manager of U2 has said.
>
>Telegraph Arts coverage in full
>Telegraph Digital Life
>Paul McGuinness, who has managed the best-selling group for 30 years,  
>attacked internet service providers for failing to clamp down on  
>illegal file-sharing.
>
>
>
>The manager of U2 has called for ISPs to take action against repeat offenders
>He said the refusal of internet firms to punish those who download  
>music without paying was "the single biggest failure in the digital  
>music market".
>
>He called on them to adopt a "three strikes and you're out"  
>enforcement policy under which illegal downloaders would have to start  
>paying for music or face having their ISP subscriptions terminated.
>
>"We must shame them into wanting to help us. Their snouts have been at  
>our trough feeding free for too long," Mr McGuinness said at the Midem  
>music industry conference in Cannes.
>
>"For ISPs in general, the days of prevaricating over their  
>responsibilities for helping protect music must end. The ISP lobbyists  
>who say they should not have to 'police the internet' are living in  
>the past - relying on outdated excuses from an earlier technological  
>age."
>
>His call follows a report last week which showed that while worldwide  
>sales of digital music grew by 40 per cent last year, they were still  
>not enough to offset a sharp fall in CD sales.
>
>The International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, which  
>represents record companies across the world, warned that the "crisis"  
>in the music industry would deepen unless ISPs took action against the  
>millions of people who illegally download music.
>
>Many ISPs have been reluctant to police the illegal activities of  
>their customers, preferring to rely on record labels to bring cases  
>against them.
>
>advertisement
>
>But Mr McGuinness said it was time to challenge the belief that ISPs  
>should not be held accountable for their customers' behaviour.
>
>"If you were publishing a magazine that was advertising stolen cars,  
>processing payments for them and arranging delivery of them you'd  
>expect to get a visit from the police wouldn't you?" he said, in a  
>speech titled The Online Bonanza: Who is Making All The Money and Why  
>Aren't They Sharing It?
>
>"What's the difference? With a laptop, a broadband account, an MP3  
>player and a smartphone you can now steal all the content, music,  
>video and literary in the world without any money going to the content  
>owners.
>
>"On the other hand, if you get caught stealing a laptop in the  
>computer store or don't pay your broadband bill there are obvious  
>consequences. You get nicked or you get your access cut off."
>
>A survey last year by Quantum Markets in Australia found that of the  
>2.8 billion people who regularly download illegally, 75 per cent said  
>they did not believe they were hurting the music industry.
>
>When asked why, the vast majority said they did not feel at risk of  
>being punished for downloading songs for free.
>
>Mr McGuinness called on the Government to follow the lead of Nicolas  
>Sarkozy, the French President, and introduce legislation if voluntary  
>talks with ISPs failed to produce a commitment to disconnect  
>file-sharers. A spokesman for the Internet Service Providers'  
>Association said its members preferred self regulation to legislation.
>
>"We do not support abuses of copyright and intellectual property  
>theft. However, ISPs cannot monitor or record the type of information  
>passed over their networks," he said.
>
>"ISPs are no more able to inspect and filter every single packet  
>passing across their network than the Post Office is able to open  
>every envelope."

The music industry has been in decline this whole decade. It is sad in many=
 ways because many musicians will not get a chance to make it in the busine=
ss. The concept of less sales =3D less talent available to sign because the=
 industry is tight...=20
=20
The ISP's might eventually have to upgrade and obtain the proper equipment =
to police the internet. Who knows at this point anything is possible, I am =
sure both sides have a case in federal court with great points and their in=
terpretation of HIGHLY COMPLEX IP laws. You can think of it like this, the =
music industry may be willing to spend millions in court over this which in=
 the long run is cheaper then another decade of decline (i.e., Exploding Fo=
rd Pinto and ethical decisions made by Ford to keep the car on the road in =
the 1970's).
=20
I remember P. Diddy on MTV's MTB 4 saying artists that use to sell millions=
 of CD's are now selling a couple of hundred thousand. Also today artists e=
arn more money because they sign better contracts geared toward their right=
s and protection of their art as an artist. Record companies do not like th=
at because it cuts into their profit. Money to be made now in the music ind=
ustry is all in the LIVE SHOWS. I also hear somewhere that record sales in =
history actually took off in the mid to late 1960's like never before in hi=
story and record companies made a lot of money. They peaked at some point i=
n the eighties or nineties.
=20
=20
Isaac

> Uh... there's plenty of laws regarding income tax. Stop reading internet 
> conspiracy theory drivel. For instance:
>
> The 16th amendment:
> "The Congress shall have power to lay and collect taxes on incomes, from 
> whatever source derived, without apportionment among the several States, 
> and without regard to any census or enumeration."
>
> Besides, quite a bit of how our government works is not from laws on the 
> books, but rather from case law.
>
> There's an entire wikipedia page on income tax within the united states 
> and related cases:
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Income_tax_in_the_United_States

From: "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed

(note: note: wrote the below a few months back on this subject, can't=20
remember if I x-posted it here @ the time, if it is all apologies for=20
the repeat. If not, I'd like to hear some thoughts on the idea of taking =

the Arts out of the hands of Corporate Ownership and transferring it=20
into the realm of Public Utility and how feasible an idea people think=20
that is. Again, this is just the start of the idea and it's got plenty=20
of room to expand, which I'd like to do, but I could use a little help=20
from my friends. ~Nyc)

(note: this started off as a flippant, one line, reply to an email I=20
recently got, and it mushroomed into a something quite unexpected essay=20
on the subject of Intellectual Property and Media as it exists in the=20
USA today. If you like what you read, or don't, I'd like some feedback=20
on it, (since I plan to develop it further, via a wiki/open source=20
format eventually) this being only a 1/4 complete First Draft, and if=20
you think the ideas within have any merit, please feel free to forward=20
it along to anyone else that may find it of interest. Thanks! ~nwa)


 > s@umn.edu wrote:
 >> Will all of the music disappear?
 >>
 >> http://www.docudharma.com/showDiary.do?diaryId=3D1527

"One Murdoch to Rule Them All" http://tinyurl.com/3yhlhm
heheheh, nice comment, in a too funny,  lolocaust, sort of way.

But seriously, this whole argument that the content distributors are=20
making is fallacious on its face.

A friend of mine signs all his emails with this quote which I find=20
germane to this discussion:

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the =

rest of society because it explores, much faster than material reality=20
can, the entire range of possibilities in a given code. It makes audible =

the new world that will gradually become visible. What is noise to the=20
old order is harmony to the new."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise" http://tinyurl.com/yate6k

Every day there is a story about how the record/tv/film industry is=20
losing billions of dollars a year in "lost revenue" to online P2P=20
networks, and other forms of media 'piracy'.

Cosmo Kramer, please.

Bite me.

That's nonsense, it's generally monies that they've gotten so used to=20
stealing from content creators, (now that their extortionist=20
distribution channels have been rendered obsolete by the advent of the=20
internet, and exposed for the fraud that it is, and has been), that=20
never really "belonged" to them in the first place, that they're whining =

about "losing."

It's time to change the rules from the top down and the bottom up and=20
drive these fat, parasitc, infectious pieces of human waste, money=20
changing, middle-men, (who are the real 'pirate' villains in this=20
piece), out of The Temple of Mass Media, and turn that Mass Media away=20
from being a privately run Coprporate Enterprise and into a Public=20
Utility, no different from the gas, electric, water and other utilities=20
that are the support system of modern life.

And I have a pretty clear idea as to how to do it.

(But before I get into that I'd like to briefly point out that the word=20
'talent' derives from the same source as the word 'dollar', which is the =

Latin word 'Taler', which is what the Romans in Caeser's day called=20
their base unit of money.)

What needs to happen from this point on to get to the next place we need =

to be at in getting to having our Media become a Public Utility is to=20
remove all Corporate ownership over any, and all, media and art forms.

Time, and time again, the Corporations have proven themselves to be=20
lousy Stewards of The Public Trust, be it in not paying the artists=20
their proper due for their works, to raging conflicts of interests, as=20
most recently seen by Corporate News Networks running ads from the same=20
predatory lenders who created the largest financial crisis of our era,=20
(see: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DZwYvhPdCces  ), and it's now past =

time to thank them for the work that they've done so far in building the =

media production and distribution infrastructure and begin to transition =

away from their private ownership of it, and they're being the Toll-Gate =

keepers our common cultural heritage, and begin asserting our rights=20
towards returning it back to the commons.

Sounds good, I know, but how in the world do I propose *to pay* for=20
something like that?

After all, for example, if it weren't for Corporate Sponsorship, then=20
there would be no television programming, since it is their capital that =

pays the bills that provides the revenue that makes it possible for=20
sitcoms, soap operas, police procedurals, reality shows, news,=20
dysfunctional family dramas, talk shows, variety shows, documentaries,=20
and all other shows to exist.

None of that is cheap to produce, and the money has got to come from=20
somewhere.

But from where?

Like I said, our Media needs to treated as a Public Utility, and the way =

to pay for it is to create a central, common source of funding, just=20
like is done with all other Public Utilities.

Through buying Bonds.

Consider this.

The film industry in the United States is currently a $5+ billion dollar =

a year enterprise, in terms of gross annual revenue.

That's a lot of shekels.

The installed base of users of the internet in the United States is=20
currently at about 70% of the population, roughly 230 million people.

Now, if part of the price for access to the internet were to include a=20
$10 tax a month, over, or from, the ISPs, that would be $120 a year, per =

person, which would raise just about $28 billion dollars.

Were that $28 billion dollars to be invested in US Treasuries, at=20
current rates of about 5% they would return about $1.5 billion dollars=20
in interest, (invested more aggressively in the equity, currency and=20
commodities markets, it could go to 10% or higher, which would double=20
that rate of return, but that is a much riskier proposition, so, for=20
sake of argument, I'd like to concentrate on just bond investing), which =

would go a long way towards infrastructure maintenance and upkeep,=20
salaries, rent,  and all other forms of overhead.

However, it's not all the money that would be needed for such a vast=20
undertaking, more, significantly much more will be needed to pull a plan =

like this off.

So where does that come from?

Same place, all other media outlets and channels come with a similar tax =

for use and access to the public resource.

Cable TV, phone services, (landlines and cellular), a percentage of the=20
price of every magazine, DVD, book, vinyl record, Blu-Ray disk,=20
newspaper, CD, movie, concert, theatre, movie ticket, video game, etc,=20
sold also gets thrown into the pool that's to be invested in.

And that's just on the software/content end of it.

Apply a similar tax to every radio, TV, computer, flash drive, camera,=20
time shifting DVR/TiVo recorder, paper copier and paper, typewriter,=20
pen, pencil, mp3 player, cell phone, and any other piece of hardware=20
that's sold to produce and distribute content and all of a sudden the=20
monies raised for this balloons, in the course of a single year, every=20
year, to something close to approaching what the USA has already spent=20
over the course of the ongoing Iraq Occupation, well near a trillion=20
dollars.

Every year, like clockwork, so raising the money isn't the issue.

And through the investing in US Treasuries, it generates interest in the =

$10s of billions of dollars every year, which means that in a "Never=20
Touch Principal" sort of way, it can not only be self-supporting, but=20
also self-sustaining as well, for as long as the United States makes=20
payments on their bonds, which in the past 200 odd years has never=20
happened, not that past performance is any indicator of future results.

Now at this point, I can hear the argument that in order to do this it=20
would require Nationalizing the Mass Media's production and distribution =

facilities and there are many examples of other industries in which that =

has happened where that kind of action has ended rather poorly, and do=20
we want to create the same sort of mess  as that would do with a plan=20
like this?

Of course not.

First off, the last thing one would want to have to happen is to seize=20
these assets by force, that always hurts the one doing the seizing, and=20
leaves the dispossessed with a raft of hurt, bad, and resentful=20
feelings, and so that course of action is to be avoided, because it just =

doesn't work.

An alternative approach is to make them see that it would be worth their =

while to transfer those assets over to the Common Weal, and that can be=20
done without even raising the idea that for many of the current owners=20
of these properties they should consider themselves grateful that=20
they're not being sent to prison, for their decades worth of=20
malfeasance, corruption, and outright larceny from artists and the=20
public on a grand and felonious scale.

No need to get into all that.

By using the monies raised from these Media Taxes, ear-mark a certain=20
percentage of those monies to buy out the principal owners out of their=20
current production and distribution positions; also to include a=20
life-time severance package for them and pay for the education and=20
health-care of their heirs, and they get to keep all their current=20
assets, to include their housing, luxury cars, yachts, planes, villas,=20
and any other gains they may have reaped exploiting the current way=20
things are done today.

In other words, pay these rat-fuck RIAA/Music-Film Industry greed-heads o=
ff.

Buy 'em out.

They're the real thieves, always have beeen, and I'm sure that they've=20
all got their price.

And if they want to stay on after the transition, offer them a salaried=20
position doing the work that they had been doing.

Now, it's no secret that a lot of Corporations, particularly the=20
advertisers are already looking for a way to get out of the=20
ownership/sponsorship game already.

This is because of the advent of the TiVo/DVR time shifting technology=20
that has emerged and become wildly popular over the course of this last=20
decade.

In their view, why should they continue to pay billions of dollars a=20
year, to not only produce and distribute television, if their target=20
audience is simply going to fast-forward through all the advertising=20
that is the their whole point of paying all that money for, if nobody is =

going to bother to watch the commercials anymore?

Where's the business sense in that?

That's money they can keep for themselves and apply to their businesses=20
elsewhere, which they'd probably be better off with.

This offers them a way to get out of the business that is from a=20
cost/benefit analysis, fiscally sound and allow them to meet their=20
fiduciary responsibilities to their shareholders.

---

And that's as far as I got, so far.

~Nyc

--

o punish those who download > music without paying was "the single bigges=
t failure in the digital > music market".> > He called on them to adopt a=

On 1/29/08, Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> (note: note: wrote the below a few months back on this subject, can't
> remember if I x-posted it here @ the time, if it is all apologies for
> the repeat. If not, I'd like to hear some thoughts on the idea of taking
> the Arts out of the hands of Corporate Ownership and transferring it
> into the realm of Public Utility and how feasible an idea people think
> that is. Again, this is just the start of the idea and it's got plenty
> of room to expand, which I'd like to do, but I could use a little help
> from my friends. ~Nyc)
>
> (note: this started off as a flippant, one line, reply to an email I
> recently got, and it mushroomed into a something quite unexpected essay
> on the subject of Intellectual Property and Media as it exists in the
> USA today. If you like what you read, or don't, I'd like some feedback
> on it, (since I plan to develop it further, via a wiki/open source
> format eventually) this being only a 1/4 complete First Draft, and if
> you think the ideas within have any merit, please feel free to forward
> it along to anyone else that may find it of interest. Thanks! ~nwa)
>
>
> > s@umn.edu wrote:
> >> Will all of the music disappear?
> >>
> >> http://www.docudharma.com/showDiary.do?diaryId=1527
>
> "One Murdoch to Rule Them All" http://tinyurl.com/3yhlhm
> heheheh, nice comment, in a too funny,  lolocaust, sort of way.
>
> But seriously, this whole argument that the content distributors are
> making is fallacious on its face.
>
> A friend of mine signs all his emails with this quote which I find
> germane to this discussion:
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> rest of society because it explores, much faster than material reality
> can, the entire range of possibilities in a given code. It makes audible
> the new world that will gradually become visible. What is noise to the
> old order is harmony to the new."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise" http://tinyurl.com/yate6k
>
> Every day there is a story about how the record/tv/film industry is
> losing billions of dollars a year in "lost revenue" to online P2P
> networks, and other forms of media 'piracy'.
>
> Cosmo Kramer, please.
>
> Bite me.
>
> That's nonsense, it's generally monies that they've gotten so used to
> stealing from content creators, (now that their extortionist
> distribution channels have been rendered obsolete by the advent of the
> internet, and exposed for the fraud that it is, and has been), that
> never really "belonged" to them in the first place, that they're whining
> about "losing."
>
> It's time to change the rules from the top down and the bottom up and
> drive these fat, parasitc, infectious pieces of human waste, money
> changing, middle-men, (who are the real 'pirate' villains in this
> piece), out of The Temple of Mass Media, and turn that Mass Media away
> from being a privately run Coprporate Enterprise and into a Public
> Utility, no different from the gas, electric, water and other utilities
> that are the support system of modern life.
>
> And I have a pretty clear idea as to how to do it.
>
> (But before I get into that I'd like to briefly point out that the word
> 'talent' derives from the same source as the word 'dollar', which is the
> Latin word 'Taler', which is what the Romans in Caeser's day called
> their base unit of money.)
>
> What needs to happen from this point on to get to the next place we need
> to be at in getting to having our Media become a Public Utility is to
> remove all Corporate ownership over any, and all, media and art forms.
>
> Time, and time again, the Corporations have proven themselves to be
> lousy Stewards of The Public Trust, be it in not paying the artists
> their proper due for their works, to raging conflicts of interests, as
> most recently seen by Corporate News Networks running ads from the same
> predatory lenders who created the largest financial crisis of our era,
> (see: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZwYvhPdCces  ), and it's now past
> time to thank them for the work that they've done so far in building the
> media production and distribution infrastructure and begin to transition
> away from their private ownership of it, and they're being the Toll-Gate
> keepers our common cultural heritage, and begin asserting our rights
> towards returning it back to the commons.
>
> Sounds good, I know, but how in the world do I propose *to pay* for
> something like that?
>
> After all, for example, if it weren't for Corporate Sponsorship, then
> there would be no television programming, since it is their capital that
> pays the bills that provides the revenue that makes it possible for
> sitcoms, soap operas, police procedurals, reality shows, news,
> dysfunctional family dramas, talk shows, variety shows, documentaries,
> and all other shows to exist.
>
> None of that is cheap to produce, and the money has got to come from
> somewhere.
>
> But from where?
>
> Like I said, our Media needs to treated as a Public Utility, and the way
> to pay for it is to create a central, common source of funding, just
> like is done with all other Public Utilities.
>
> Through buying Bonds.
>
> Consider this.
>
> The film industry in the United States is currently a $5+ billion dollar
> a year enterprise, in terms of gross annual revenue.
>
> That's a lot of shekels.
>
> The installed base of users of the internet in the United States is
> currently at about 70% of the population, roughly 230 million people.
>
> Now, if part of the price for access to the internet were to include a
> $10 tax a month, over, or from, the ISPs, that would be $120 a year, per
> person, which would raise just about $28 billion dollars.
>
> Were that $28 billion dollars to be invested in US Treasuries, at
> current rates of about 5% they would return about $1.5 billion dollars
> in interest, (invested more aggressively in the equity, currency and
> commodities markets, it could go to 10% or higher, which would double
> that rate of return, but that is a much riskier proposition, so, for
> sake of argument, I'd like to concentrate on just bond investing), which
> would go a long way towards infrastructure maintenance and upkeep,
> salaries, rent,  and all other forms of overhead.
>
> However, it's not all the money that would be needed for such a vast
> undertaking, more, significantly much more will be needed to pull a plan
> like this off.
>
> So where does that come from?
>
> Same place, all other media outlets and channels come with a similar tax
> for use and access to the public resource.
>
> Cable TV, phone services, (landlines and cellular), a percentage of the
> price of every magazine, DVD, book, vinyl record, Blu-Ray disk,
> newspaper, CD, movie, concert, theatre, movie ticket, video game, etc,
> sold also gets thrown into the pool that's to be invested in.
>
> And that's just on the software/content end of it.
>
> Apply a similar tax to every radio, TV, computer, flash drive, camera,
> time shifting DVR/TiVo recorder, paper copier and paper, typewriter,
> pen, pencil, mp3 player, cell phone, and any other piece of hardware
> that's sold to produce and distribute content and all of a sudden the
> monies raised for this balloons, in the course of a single year, every
> year, to something close to approaching what the USA has already spent
> over the course of the ongoing Iraq Occupation, well near a trillion
> dollars.
>
> Every year, like clockwork, so raising the money isn't the issue.
>
> And through the investing in US Treasuries, it generates interest in the
> $10s of billions of dollars every year, which means that in a "Never
> Touch Principal" sort of way, it can not only be self-supporting, but
> also self-sustaining as well, for as long as the United States makes
> payments on their bonds, which in the past 200 odd years has never
> happened, not that past performance is any indicator of future results.
>
> Now at this point, I can hear the argument that in order to do this it
> would require Nationalizing the Mass Media's production and distribution
> facilities and there are many examples of other industries in which that
> has happened where that kind of action has ended rather poorly, and do
> we want to create the same sort of mess  as that would do with a plan
> like this?
>
> Of course not.
>
> First off, the last thing one would want to have to happen is to seize
> these assets by force, that always hurts the one doing the seizing, and
> leaves the dispossessed with a raft of hurt, bad, and resentful
> feelings, and so that course of action is to be avoided, because it just
> doesn't work.
>
> An alternative approach is to make them see that it would be worth their
> while to transfer those assets over to the Common Weal, and that can be
> done without even raising the idea that for many of the current owners
> of these properties they should consider themselves grateful that
> they're not being sent to prison, for their decades worth of
> malfeasance, corruption, and outright larceny from artists and the
> public on a grand and felonious scale.
>
> No need to get into all that.
>
> By using the monies raised from these Media Taxes, ear-mark a certain
> percentage of those monies to buy out the principal owners out of their
> current production and distribution positions; also to include a
> life-time severance package for them and pay for the education and
> health-care of their heirs, and they get to keep all their current
> assets, to include their housing, luxury cars, yachts, planes, villas,
> and any other gains they may have reaped exploiting the current way
> things are done today.
>
> In other words, pay these rat-fuck RIAA/Music-Film Industry greed-heads
> off.
>
> Buy 'em out.
>
> They're the real thieves, always have beeen, and I'm sure that they've
> all got their price.
>
> And if they want to stay on after the transition, offer them a salaried
> position doing the work that they had been doing.
>
> Now, it's no secret that a lot of Corporations, particularly the
> advertisers are already looking for a way to get out of the
> ownership/sponsorship game already.
>
> This is because of the advent of the TiVo/DVR time shifting technology
> that has emerged and become wildly popular over the course of this last
> decade.
>
> In their view, why should they continue to pay billions of dollars a
> year, to not only produce and distribute television, if their target
> audience is simply going to fast-forward through all the advertising
> that is the their whole point of paying all that money for, if nobody is
> going to bother to watch the commercials anymore?
>
> Where's the business sense in that?
>
> That's money they can keep for themselves and apply to their businesses
> elsewhere, which they'd probably be better off with.
>
> This offers them a way to get out of the business that is from a
> cost/benefit analysis, fiscally sound and allow them to meet their
> fiduciary responsibilities to their shareholders.
>
> ---
>
> And that's as far as I got, so far.
>
> ~Nyc
>
> --
>
> Isaac wrote:
> > The music industry has been in decline this whole decade. It is sad in
> many ways because many musicians will not get a chance to make it in the
> business. The concept of less sales = less talent available to sign because
> the industry is tight...
> >
> > The ISP's might eventually have to upgrade and obtain the proper
> equipment to police the internet. Who knows at this point anything is
> possible, I am sure both sides have a case in federal court with great
> points and their interpretation of HIGHLY COMPLEX IP laws. You can think of
> it like this, the music industry may be willing to spend millions in court
> over this which in the long run is cheaper then another decade of decline (
> i.e., Exploding Ford Pinto and ethical decisions made by Ford to keep the
> car on the road in the 1970's).
> >
> > I remember P. Diddy on MTV's MTB 4 saying artists that use to sell
> millions of CD's are now selling a couple of hundred thousand. Also today
> artists earn more money because they sign better contracts geared toward
> their rights and protection of their art as an artist. Record companies do
> not like that because it cuts into their profit. Money to be made now in the
> music industry is all in the LIVE SHOWS. I also hear somewhere that record
> sales in history actually took off in the mid to late 1960's like never
> before in history and record companies made a lot of money. They peaked at
> some point in the eighties or nineties.
> >
> >
> > Isaac
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >

> http://www.telegraph.co.uk/connected/main.jhtml;jsessionid=3EKD2RI2OKH0XQFIQMFCFFOAVCBQYIV0?xml=/connected/2008/01/29/dlutwo129.xml>
> > Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager> By Nicole Martin, Digital and
> Media Correspondent, in Cannes> Last Updated: 12:01am GMT 29/01/2008> >
> Music fans who repeatedly download songs illegally should have their >
> internet connections severed, the manager of U2 has said.> > Telegraph Arts
> coverage in full> Telegraph Digital Life> Paul McGuinness, who has managed
> the best-selling group for 30 years, > attacked internet service providers
> for failing to clamp down on > illegal file-sharing.> > > > The manager of
> U2 has called for ISPs to take action against repeat offenders> He said the
> refusal of internet firms to punish those who download > music without
> paying was "the single biggest failure in the digital > music market".> > He
> called on them to adopt a "three strikes and you're out" > enforcement
> policy under which illegal downloaders would have to start > paying for
> music or face having their ISP subscriptions terminated.> > "We must shame
> them into wanting to help us. Their snouts have been at > our trough feeding
> free for too long," Mr McGuinness said at the Midem > music industry
> conference in Cannes.> > "For ISPs in general, the days of prevaricating
> over their > responsibilities for helping protect music must end. The ISP
> lobbyists > who say they should not have to 'police the internet' are living
> in > the past - relying on outdated excuses from an earlier technological >
> age."> > His call follows a report last week which showed that while
> worldwide > sales of digital music grew by 40 per cent last year, they were
> still > not enough to offset a sharp fall in CD sales.> > The International
> Federation of the Phonographic Industry, which > represents record companies
> across the world, warned that the "crisis" > in the music industry would
> deepen unless ISPs took action against the > millions of people who
> illegally download music.> > Many ISPs have been reluctant to police the
> illegal activities of > their customers, preferring to rely on record labels
> to bring cases > against them.> > advertisement> > But Mr McGuinness said it
> was time to challenge the belief that ISPs > should not be held accountable
> for their customers' behaviour.> > "If you were publishing a magazine that
> was advertising stolen cars, > processing payments for them and arranging
> delivery of them you'd > expect to get a visit from the police wouldn't
> you?" he said, in a > speech titled The Online Bonanza: Who is Making All
> The Money and Why > Aren't They Sharing It?> > "What's the difference? With
> a laptop, a broadband account, an MP3 > player and a smartphone you can now
> steal all the content, music, > video and literary in the world without any
> money going to the content > owners.> > "On the other hand, if you get
> caught stealing a laptop in the > computer store or don't pay your broadband
> bill there are obvious > consequences. You get nicked or you get your access
> cut off."> > A survey last year by Quantum Markets in Australia found that
> of the > 2.8 billion people who regularly download illegally, 75 per cent
> said > they did not believe they were hurting the music industry.> > When
> asked why, the vast majority said they did not feel at risk of > being
> punished for downloading songs for free.> > Mr McGuinness called on the
> Government to follow the lead of Nicolas > Sarkozy, the French President,
> and introduce legislation if voluntary > talks with ISPs failed to produce a
> commitment to disconnect > file-sharers. A spokesman for the Internet
> Service Providers' > Association said its members preferred self regulation
> to legislation.> > "We do not support abuses of copyright and intellectual
> property > theft. However, ISPs cannot monitor or record the type of
> information > passed over their networks," he said.> > "ISPs are no more
> able to inspect and filter every single packet > passing across their
> network than the Post Office is able to open > every envelope."> > > > > >

(note: note: wrote the below a few months back on this subject, can'trememb=

If not, I'd like to hear some thoughts on the idea of takingthe Arts out of=

ic Utility and how feasible an idea people thinkthat is. Again, this is jus=
t the start of the idea and it's got plentyof room to expand, which I'd lik=

rted off as a flippant, one line, reply to an email Irecently got, and it m=
ushroomed into a something quite unexpected essayon the subject of Intellec=
tual Property and Media as it exists in theUSA today. If you like what you =
read, or don't, I'd like some feedbackon it, (since I plan to develop it fu=
rther, via a wiki/open sourceformat eventually) this being only a 1/4 compl=
ete First Draft, and ifyou think the ideas within have any merit, please fe=
el free to forwardit along to anyone else that may find it of interest. Tha=
nks! ~nwa)> s@umn.edu wrote:>> Will all of the music disappear?>>>> http://=
www.docudharma.com/showDiary.do?diaryId=3D1527"One Murdoch to Rule Them All=
" http://tinyurl.com/3yhlhmheheheh, nice comment, in a too funny,  lolocaus=
t, sort of way.But seriously, this whole argument that the content distribu=
tors aremaking is fallacious on its face.A friend of mine signs all his ema=
ils with this quote which I findgermane to this discussion:"Music is prophe=
cy, its style and economic organization are ahead of therest of society bec=
ause it explores, much faster than material realitycan, the entire range of=
 possibilities in a given code. It makes audiblethe new world that will gra=
dually become visible. What is noise to theold order is harmony to the new.=
"-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise" http://tinyurl.com/yate6kEvery=
 day there is a story about how the record/tv/film industry islosing billio=
ns of dollars a year in "lost revenue" to online P2Pnetworks, and other for=
ms of media 'piracy'.Cosmo Kramer, please.Bite me.That's nonsense, it's gen=
erally monies that they've gotten so used tostealing from content creators,=
 (now that their extortionistdistribution channels have been rendered obsol=
ete by the advent of theinternet, and exposed for the fraud that it is, and=
 has been), thatnever really "belonged" to them in the first place, that th=
ey're whiningabout "losing."It's time to change the rules from the top down=
 and the bottom up anddrive these fat, parasitc, infectious pieces of human=
 waste, moneychanging, middle-men, (who are the real 'pirate' villains in t=
hispiece), out of The Temple of Mass Media, and turn that Mass Media awayfr=
om being a privately run Coprporate Enterprise and into a PublicUtility, no=
 different from the gas, electric, water and other utilitiesthat are the su=
pport system of modern life.And I have a pretty clear idea as to how to do =
it.(But before I get into that I'd like to briefly point out that the word'=
talent' derives from the same source as the word 'dollar', which is theLati=
n word 'Taler', which is what the Romans in Caeser's day calledtheir base u=
nit of money.)What needs to happen from this point on to get to the next pl=
ace we needto be at in getting to having our Media become a Public Utility =
is toremove all Corporate ownership over any, and all, media and art forms.=
Time, and time again, the Corporations have proven themselves to belousy St=
ewards of The Public Trust, be it in not paying the artiststheir proper due=
 for their works, to raging conflicts of interests, asmost recently seen by=
 Corporate News Networks running ads from the samepredatory lenders who cre=
ated the largest financial crisis of our era,(see: http://www.youtube.com/w=
atch?v=3DZwYvhPdCces  ), and it's now pasttime to thank them for the work t=
hat they've done so far in building themedia production and distribution in=
frastructure and begin to transitionaway from their private ownership of it=
, and they're being the Toll-Gatekeepers our common cultural heritage, and =
begin asserting our rightstowards returning it back to the commons.Sounds g=
ood, I know, but how in the world do I propose *to pay* forsomething like t=
hat?After all, for example, if it weren't for Corporate Sponsorship, thenth=
ere would be no television programming, since it is their capital thatpays =
the bills that provides the revenue that makes it possible forsitcoms, soap=
 operas, police procedurals, reality shows, news,dysfunctional family drama=
s, talk shows, variety shows, documentaries,and all other shows to exist.No=
ne of that is cheap to produce, and the money has got to come fromsomewhere=
.But from where?Like I said, our Media needs to treated as a Public Utility=
, and the wayto pay for it is to create a central, common source of funding=
, justlike is done with all other Public Utilities.Through buying Bonds.Con=
sider this.The film industry in the United States is currently a $5+ billio=
n dollara year enterprise, in terms of gross annual revenue.That's a lot of=
 shekels.The installed base of users of the internet in the United States i=
scurrently at about 70% of the population, roughly 230 million people.Now, =
if part of the price for access to the internet were to include a$10 tax a =
month, over, or from, the ISPs, that would be $120 a year, perperson, which=
 would raise just about $28 billion dollars.Were that $28 billion dollars t=
o be invested in US Treasuries, atcurrent rates of about 5% they would retu=
rn about $1.5 billion dollarsin interest, (invested more aggressively in th=
e equity, currency andcommodities markets, it could go to 10% or higher, wh=
ich would doublethat rate of return, but that is a much riskier proposition=
, so, forsake of argument, I'd like to concentrate on just bond investing),=
 whichwould go a long way towards infrastructure maintenance and upkeep,sal=
aries, rent,  and all other forms of overhead.However, it's not all the mon=
ey that would be needed for such a vastundertaking, more, significantly muc=
h more will be needed to pull a planlike this off.So where does that come f=
rom?Same place, all other media outlets and channels come with a similar ta=
xfor use and access to the public resource.Cable TV, phone services, (landl=
ines and cellular), a percentage of theprice of every magazine, DVD, book, =
vinyl record, Blu-Ray disk,newspaper, CD, movie, concert, theatre, movie ti=
cket, video game, etc,sold also gets thrown into the pool that's to be inve=
sted in.And that's just on the software/content end of it.Apply a similar t=
ax to every radio, TV, computer, flash drive, camera,time shifting DVR/TiVo=
 recorder, paper copier and paper, typewriter,pen, pencil, mp3 player, cell=
 phone, and any other piece of hardwarethat's sold to produce and distribut=
e content and all of a sudden themonies raised for this balloons, in the co=
urse of a single year, everyyear, to something close to approaching what th=
e USA has already spentover the course of the ongoing Iraq Occupation, well=
 near a trilliondollars.Every year, like clockwork, so raising the money is=
n't the issue.And through the investing in US Treasuries, it generates inte=
rest in the$10s of billions of dollars every year, which means that in a "N=
everTouch Principal" sort of way, it can not only be self-supporting, butal=
so self-sustaining as well, for as long as the United States makespayments =
on their bonds, which in the past 200 odd years has neverhappened, not that=
 past performance is any indicator of future results.Now at this point, I c=
an hear the argument that in order to do this itwould require Nationalizing=
 the Mass Media's production and distributionfacilities and there are many =
examples of other industries in which thathas happened where that kind of a=
ction has ended rather poorly, and dowe want to create the same sort of mes=
s  as that would do with a planlike this?Of course not.First off, the last =
thing one would want to have to happen is to seizethese assets by force, th=
at always hurts the one doing the seizing, andleaves the dispossessed with =
a raft of hurt, bad, and resentfulfeelings, and so that course of action is=
 to be avoided, because it justdoesn't work.An alternative approach is to m=
ake them see that it would be worth theirwhile to transfer those assets ove=
r to the Common Weal, and that can bedone without even raising the idea tha=
t for many of the current ownersof these properties they should consider th=
emselves grateful thatthey're not being sent to prison, for their decades w=
orth ofmalfeasance, corruption, and outright larceny from artists and thepu=
blic on a grand and felonious scale.No need to get into all that.By using t=
he monies raised from these Media Taxes, ear-mark a certainpercentage of th=
ose monies to buy out the principal owners out of theircurrent production a=
nd distribution positions; also to include alife-time severance package for=
 them and pay for the education andhealth-care of their heirs, and they get=
 to keep all their currentassets, to include their housing, luxury cars, ya=
chts, planes, villas,and any other gains they may have reaped exploiting th=
e current waythings are done today.In other words, pay these rat-fuck RIAA/=
Music-Film Industry greed-heads off.Buy 'em out.They're the real thieves, a=
lways have beeen, and I'm sure that they'veall got their price.And if they =
want to stay on after the transition, offer them a salariedposition doing t=
he work that they had been doing.Now, it's no secret that a lot of Corporat=
ions, particularly theadvertisers are already looking for a way to get out =
of theownership/sponsorship game already.This is because of the advent of t=
he TiVo/DVR time shifting technologythat has emerged and become wildly popu=
lar over the course of this lastdecade.In their view, why should they conti=
nue to pay billions of dollars ayear, to not only produce and distribute te=
levision, if their targetaudience is simply going to fast-forward through a=
ll the advertisingthat is the their whole point of paying all that money fo=
r, if nobody isgoing to bother to watch the commercials anymore?Where's the=
 business sense in that?That's money they can keep for themselves and apply=
 to their businesseselsewhere, which they'd probably be better off with.Thi=
s offers them a way to get out of the business that is from acost/benefit a=
nalysis, fiscally sound and allow them to meet theirfiduciary responsibilit=
ies to their shareholders.---And that's as far as I got, so far.~Nyc--Isaac=

2:01am GMT 29/01/2008> > Music fans who repeatedly download songs illegally=
 should have their > internet connections severed, the manager of U2 has sa=
id.> > Telegraph Arts coverage in full> Telegraph Digital Life> Paul McGuin=
ness, who has managed the best-selling group for 30 years, > attacked inter=
net service providers for failing to clamp down on > illegal file-sharing.>=
 > > > The manager of U2 has called for ISPs to take action against repeat =
offenders> He said the refusal of internet firms to punish those who downlo=
ad > music without paying was "the single biggest failure in the digital > =
music market".> > He called on them to adopt a "three strikes and you're ou=
t" > enforcement policy under which illegal downloaders would have to start=
 > paying for music or face having their ISP subscriptions terminated.> > "=
We must shame them into wanting to help us. Their snouts have been at > our=
 trough feeding free for too long," Mr McGuinness said at the Midem > music=
 industry conference in Cannes.> > "For ISPs in general, the days of prevar=
icating over their > responsibilities for helping protect music must end. T=
he ISP lobbyists > who say they should not have to 'police the internet' ar=
e living in > the past - relying on outdated excuses from an earlier techno=
logical > age."> > His call follows a report last week which showed that wh=
ile worldwide > sales of digital music grew by 40 per cent last year, they =
were still > not enough to offset a sharp fall in CD sales.> > The Internat=
ional Federation of the Phonographic Industry, which > represents record co=
mpanies across the world, warned that the "crisis" > in the music industry =
would deepen unless ISPs took action against the > millions of people who i=
llegally download music.> > Many ISPs have been reluctant to police the ill=
egal activities of > their customers, preferring to rely on record labels t=
o bring cases > against them.> > advertisement> > But Mr McGuinness said it=
 was time to challenge the belief that ISPs > should not be held accountabl=
e for their customers' behaviour.> > "If you were publishing a magazine tha=
t was advertising stolen cars, > processing payments for them and arranging=
 delivery of them you'd > expect to get a visit from the police wouldn't yo=
u?" he said, in a > speech titled The Online Bonanza: Who is Making All The=
 Money and Why > Aren't They Sharing It?> > "What's the difference? With a =
laptop, a broadband account, an MP3 > player and a smartphone you can now s=
teal all the content, music, > video and literary in the world without any =
money going to the content > owners.> > "On the other hand, if you get caug=
ht stealing a laptop in the > computer store or don't pay your broadband bi=
ll there are obvious > consequences. You get nicked or you get your access =
cut off."> > A survey last year by Quantum Markets in Australia found that =
of the > 2.8 billion people who regularly download illegally, 75 per cent s=
aid > they did not believe they were hurting the music industry.> > When as=
ked why, the vast majority said they did not feel at risk of > being punish=
ed for downloading songs for free.> > Mr McGuinness called on the Governmen=
t to follow the lead of Nicolas > Sarkozy, the French President, and introd=
uce legislation if voluntary > talks with ISPs failed to produce a commitme=
nt to disconnect > file-sharers. A spokesman for the Internet Service Provi=
ders' > Association said its members preferred self regulation to legislati=
on.> > "We do not support abuses of copyright and intellectual property > t=
heft. However, ISPs cannot monitor or record the type of information > pass=
ed over their networks," he said.> > "ISPs are no more able to inspect and =
filter every single packet > passing across their network than the Post Off=
ice is able to open > every envelope."> > > > > > -------------------------=
