Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager

Not talking about ISP's policing the internets, I'm talking about a=20
surcharge being placed on hardware/software/distribution and pooling=20
those monies raised from that to pay the artists.

The more bittorrent dl's you have, the more you get paid.

You think mininova/piratebay doesn't already keep track?

We can go RIAA =3D BAD all we want, but until a plan is figured out to=20
compensate artists for their work, it's all just talk, and so far I=20
haven't seen anybody talking about that end of it.

=2E.

> On 1/29/08, Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote:=20
> (note: note: wrote the below a few months back on this subject, can'tre=
member if I x-posted it here @ the time, if it is all apologies forthe re=
peat. If not, I'd like to hear some thoughts on the idea of takingthe Art=
s out of the hands of Corporate Ownership and transferring itinto the rea=
lm of Public Utility and how feasible an idea people thinkthat is. Again,=
 this is just the start of the idea and it's got plentyof room to expand,=
 which I'd like to do, but I could use a little helpfrom my friends. ~Nyc=
)(note: this started off as a flippant, one line, reply to an email Irece=
ntly got, and it mushroomed into a something quite unexpected essayon the=
 subject of Intellectual Property and Media as it exists in theUSA today.=
 If you like what you read, or don't, I'd like some feedbackon it, (since=
 I plan to develop it further, via a wiki/open sourceformat eventually) t=
his being only a 1/4 complete First Draft, and ifyou think the ideas with=
in have any merit, please feel free to forwardit along to anyone else tha=
t may find it of interest. Thanks! ~nwa)> s@umn.edu wrote:>> Will all of =
the music disappear?>>>> http://www.docudharma.com/showDiary.do?diaryId=3D=
1527"One Murdoch to Rule Them All" http://tinyurl.com/3yhlhmheheheh, nice=
 comment, in a too funny,  lolocaust, sort of way.But seriously, this who=
le argument that the content distributors aremaking is fallacious on its =
face.A friend of mine signs all his emails with this quote which I findge=
rmane to this discussion:"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organ=
ization are ahead of therest of society because it explores, much faster =
than material realitycan, the entire range of possibilities in a given co=
de. It makes audiblethe new world that will gradually become visible. Wha=
t is noise to theold order is harmony to the new."-Jacques Attali in his =
seminal text "Noise" http://tinyurl.com/yate6kEvery day there is a story =
about how the record/tv/film industry islosing billions of dollars a year=
 in "lost revenue" to online P2Pnetworks, and other forms of media 'pirac=
y'.Cosmo Kramer, please.Bite me.That's nonsense, it's generally monies th=
at they've gotten so used tostealing from content creators, (now that the=
ir extortionistdistribution channels have been rendered obsolete by the a=
dvent of theinternet, and exposed for the fraud that it is, and has been)=
, thatnever really "belonged" to them in the first place, that they're wh=
iningabout "losing."It's time to change the rules from the top down and t=
he bottom up anddrive these fat, parasitc, infectious pieces of human was=
te, moneychanging, middle-men, (who are the real 'pirate' villains in thi=
spiece), out of The Temple of Mass Media, and turn that Mass Media awayfr=
om being a privately run Coprporate Enterprise and into a PublicUtility, =
no different from the gas, electric, water and other utilitiesthat are th=
e support system of modern life.And I have a pretty clear idea as to how =
to do it.(But before I get into that I'd like to briefly point out that t=
he word'talent' derives from the same source as the word 'dollar', which =
is theLatin word 'Taler', which is what the Romans in Caeser's day called=
their base unit of money.)What needs to happen from this point on to get =
to the next place we needto be at in getting to having our Media become a=
 Public Utility is toremove all Corporate ownership over any, and all, me=
dia and art forms.Time, and time again, the Corporations have proven them=
selves to belousy Stewards of The Public Trust, be it in not paying the a=
rtiststheir proper due for their works, to raging conflicts of interests,=
 asmost recently seen by Corporate News Networks running ads from the sam=
epredatory lenders who created the largest financial crisis of our era,(s=
ee: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DZwYvhPdCces  ), and it's now pasttim=
e to thank them for the work that they've done so far in building themedi=
a production and distribution infrastructure and begin to transitionaway =
from their private ownership of it, and they're being the Toll-Gatekeeper=
s our common cultural heritage, and begin asserting our rightstowards ret=
urning it back to the commons.Sounds good, I know, but how in the world d=
o I propose *to pay* forsomething like that?After all, for example, if it=
 weren't for Corporate Sponsorship, thenthere would be no television prog=
ramming, since it is their capital thatpays the bills that provides the r=
evenue that makes it possible forsitcoms, soap operas, police procedurals=
, reality shows, news,dysfunctional family dramas, talk shows, variety sh=
ows, documentaries,and all other shows to exist.None of that is cheap to =
produce, and the money has got to come fromsomewhere.But from where?Like =
I said, our Media needs to treated as a Public Utility, and the wayto pay=
 for it is to create a central, common source of funding, justlike is don=
e with all other Public Utilities.Through buying Bonds.Consider this.The =
film industry in the United States is currently a $5+ billion dollara yea=
r enterprise, in terms of gross annual revenue.That's a lot of shekels.Th=
e installed base of users of the internet in the United States iscurrentl=
y at about 70% of the population, roughly 230 million people.Now, if part=
 of the price for access to the internet were to include a$10 tax a month=
, over, or from, the ISPs, that would be $120 a year, perperson, which wo=
uld raise just about $28 billion dollars.Were that $28 billion dollars to=
 be invested in US Treasuries, atcurrent rates of about 5% they would ret=
urn about $1.5 billion dollarsin interest, (invested more aggressively in=
 the equity, currency andcommodities markets, it could go to 10% or highe=
r, which would doublethat rate of return, but that is a much riskier prop=
osition, so, forsake of argument, I'd like to concentrate on just bond in=
vesting), whichwould go a long way towards infrastructure maintenance and=
 upkeep,salaries, rent,  and all other forms of overhead.However, it's no=
t all the money that would be needed for such a vastundertaking, more, si=
gnificantly much more will be needed to pull a planlike this off.So where=
 does that come from?Same place, all other media outlets and channels com=
e with a similar taxfor use and access to the public resource.Cable TV, p=
hone services, (landlines and cellular), a percentage of theprice of ever=
y magazine, DVD, book, vinyl record, Blu-Ray disk,newspaper, CD, movie, c=
oncert, theatre, movie ticket, video game, etc,sold also gets thrown into=
 the pool that's to be invested in.And that's just on the software/conten=
t end of it.Apply a similar tax to every radio, TV, computer, flash drive=
, camera,time shifting DVR/TiVo recorder, paper copier and paper, typewri=
ter,pen, pencil, mp3 player, cell phone, and any other piece of hardwaret=
hat's sold to produce and distribute content and all of a sudden themonie=
s raised for this balloons, in the course of a single year, everyyear, to=
 something close to approaching what the USA has already spentover the co=
urse of the ongoing Iraq Occupation, well near a trilliondollars.Every ye=
ar, like clockwork, so raising the money isn't the issue.And through the =
investing in US Treasuries, it generates interest in the$10s of billions =
of dollars every year, which means that in a "NeverTouch Principal" sort =
of way, it can not only be self-supporting, butalso self-sustaining as we=
ll, for as long as the United States makespayments on their bonds, which =
in the past 200 odd years has neverhappened, not that past performance is=
 any indicator of future results.Now at this point, I can hear the argume=
nt that in order to do this itwould require Nationalizing the Mass Media'=
s production and distributionfacilities and there are many examples of ot=
her industries in which thathas happened where that kind of action has en=
ded rather poorly, and dowe want to create the same sort of mess  as that=
 would do with a planlike this?Of course not.First off, the last thing on=
e would want to have to happen is to seizethese assets by force, that alw=
ays hurts the one doing the seizing, andleaves the dispossessed with a ra=
ft of hurt, bad, and resentfulfeelings, and so that course of action is t=
o be avoided, because it justdoesn't work.An alternative approach is to m=
ake them see that it would be worth theirwhile to transfer those assets o=
ver to the Common Weal, and that can bedone without even raising the idea=
 that for many of the current ownersof these properties they should consi=
der themselves grateful thatthey're not being sent to prison, for their d=
ecades worth ofmalfeasance, corruption, and outright larceny from artists=
 and thepublic on a grand and felonious scale.No need to get into all tha=
t.By using the monies raised from these Media Taxes, ear-mark a certainpe=
rcentage of those monies to buy out the principal owners out of theircurr=
ent production and distribution positions; also to include alife-time sev=
erance package for them and pay for the education andhealth-care of their=
 heirs, and they get to keep all their currentassets, to include their ho=
using, luxury cars, yachts, planes, villas,and any other gains they may h=
ave reaped exploiting the current waythings are done today.In other words=
, pay these rat-fuck RIAA/Music-Film Industry greed-heads off.Buy 'em out=
=2EThey're the real thieves, always have beeen, and I'm sure that they've=
all got their price.And if they want to stay on after the transition, off=
er them a salariedposition doing the work that they had been doing.Now, i=
t's no secret that a lot of Corporations, particularly theadvertisers are=
 already looking for a way to get out of theownership/sponsorship game al=
ready.This is because of the advent of the TiVo/DVR time shifting technol=
ogythat has emerged and become wildly popular over the course of this las=
tdecade.In their view, why should they continue to pay billions of dollar=
s ayear, to not only produce and distribute television, if their targetau=
dience is simply going to fast-forward through all the advertisingthat is=
 the their whole point of paying all that money for, if nobody isgoing to=
 bother to watch the commercials anymore?Where's the business sense in th=
at?That's money they can keep for themselves and apply to their businesse=
selsewhere, which they'd probably be better off with.This offers them a w=
ay to get out of the business that is from acost/benefit analysis, fiscal=
ly sound and allow them to meet theirfiduciary responsibilities to their =
shareholders.---And that's as far as I got, so far.~Nyc--Isaac wrote:> Th=
e music industry has been in decline this whole decade. It is sad in many=
 ways because many musicians will not get a chance to make it in the busi=
ness. The concept of less sales =3D less talent available to sign because=

d obtain the proper equipment to police the internet. Who knows at this p=

>On 1/29/08, Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote:
>(note: note: wrote the below a few months back on this subject, 
>can'tremember if I x-posted it here @ the time, if it is all 
>apologies forthe repeat. If not, I'd like to hear some thoughts on 
>the idea of takingthe Arts out of the hands of Corporate Ownership 
>and transferring itinto the realm of Public Utility and how feasible 
>an idea people thinkthat is. Again, this is just the start of the 
>idea and it's got plentyof room to expand, which I'd like to do, but 
>I could use a little helpfrom my friends. ~Nyc)(note: this started 
>off as a flippant, one line, reply to an email Irecently got, and it 
>mushroomed into a something quite unexpected essayon the subject of 
>Intellectual Property and Media as it exists in theUSA today. If you 
>like what you read, or don't, I'd like some feedbackon it, (since I 
>plan to develop it further, via a wiki/open sourceformat eventually) 
>this being only a 1/4 complete First Draft, and ifyou think the 
>ideas within have any merit, please feel free to forwardit along to 
>anyone else that may find it of interest. Thanks! ~nwa)> s@umn.edu 
>wrote:>> Will all of the music disappear?>>>> 
>http://www.docudharma.com/showDiary.do?diaryId=1527"One Murdoch to 
>Rule Them All" http://tinyurl.com/3yhlhmheheheh, nice comment, in a 
>too funny,  lolocaust, sort of way.But seriously, this whole 
>argument that the content distributors aremaking is fallacious on 
>its face.A friend of mine signs all his emails with this quote which 
>I findgermane to this discussion:"Music is prophecy, its style and 
>economic organization are ahead of therest of society because it 
>explores, much faster than material realitycan, the entire range of 
>possibilities in a given code. It makes audiblethe new world that 
>will gradually become visible. What is noise to theold order is 
>harmony to the new."-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise" 
>http://tinyurl.com/yate6kEvery day there is a story about how the 
>record/tv/film industry islosing billions of dollars a year in "lost 
>revenue" to online P2Pnetworks, and other forms of media 
>'piracy'.Cosmo Kramer, please.Bite me.That's nonsense, it's 
>generally monies that they've gotten so used tostealing from content 
>creators, (now that their extortionistdistribution channels have 
>been rendered obsolete by the advent of theinternet, and exposed for 
>the fraud that it is, and has been), thatnever really "belonged" to 
>them in the first place, that they're whiningabout "losing."It's 
>time to change the rules from the top down and the bottom up 
>anddrive these fat, parasitc, infectious pieces of human waste, 
>moneychanging, middle-men, (who are the real 'pirate' villains in 
>thispiece), out of The Temple of Mass Media, and turn that Mass 
>Media awayfrom being a privately run Coprporate Enterprise and into 
>a PublicUtility, no different from the gas, electric, water and 
>other utilitiesthat are the support system of modern life.And I have 
>a pretty clear idea as to how to do it.(But before I get into that 
>I'd like to briefly point out that the word'talent' derives from the 
>same source as the word 'dollar', which is theLatin word 'Taler', 
>which is what the Romans in Caeser's day calledtheir base unit of 
>money.)What needs to happen from this point on to get to the next 
>place we needto be at in getting to having our Media become a Public 
>Utility is toremove all Corporate ownership over any, and all, media 
>and art forms.Time, and time again, the Corporations have proven 
>themselves to belousy Stewards of The Public Trust, be it in not 
>paying the artiststheir proper due for their works, to raging 
>conflicts of interests, asmost recently seen by Corporate News 
>Networks running ads from the samepredatory lenders who created the 
>largest financial crisis of our era,(see: 
>http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZwYvhPdCces  ), and it's now pasttime 
>to thank them for the work that they've done so far in building 
>themedia production and distribution infrastructure and begin to 
>transitionaway from their private ownership of it, and they're being 
>the Toll-Gatekeepers our common cultural heritage, and begin 
>asserting our rightstowards returning it back to the commons.Sounds 
>good, I know, but how in the world do I propose *to pay* 
>forsomething like that?After all, for example, if it weren't for 
>Corporate Sponsorship, thenthere would be no television programming, 
>since it is their capital thatpays the bills that provides the 
>revenue that makes it possible forsitcoms, soap operas, police 
>procedurals, reality shows, news,dysfunctional family dramas, talk 
>shows, variety shows, documentaries,and all other shows to 
>exist.None of that is cheap to produce, and the money has got to 
>come fromsomewhere.But from where?Like I said, our Media needs to 
>treated as a Public Utility, and the wayto pay for it is to create a 
>central, common source of funding, justlike is done with all other 
>Public Utilities.Through buying Bonds.Consider this.The film 
>industry in the United States is currently a $5+ billion dollara 
>year enterprise, in terms of gross annual revenue.That's a lot of 
>shekels.The installed base of users of the internet in the United 
>States iscurrently at about 70% of the population, roughly 230 
>million people.Now, if part of the price for access to the internet 
>were to include a$10 tax a month, over, or from, the ISPs, that 
>would be $120 a year, perperson, which would raise just about $28 
>billion dollars.Were that $28 billion dollars to be invested in US 
>Treasuries, atcurrent rates of about 5% they would return about $1.5 
>billion dollarsin interest, (invested more aggressively in the 
>equity, currency andcommodities markets, it could go to 10% or 
>higher, which would doublethat rate of return, but that is a much 
>riskier proposition, so, forsake of argument, I'd like to 
>concentrate on just bond investing), whichwould go a long way 
>towards infrastructure maintenance and upkeep,salaries, rent,  and 
>all other forms of overhead.However, it's not all the money that 
>would be needed for such a vastundertaking, more, significantly much 
>more will be needed to pull a planlike this off.So where does that 
>come from?Same place, all other media outlets and channels come with 
>a similar taxfor use and access to the public resource.Cable TV, 
>phone services, (landlines and cellular), a percentage of theprice 
>of every magazine, DVD, book, vinyl record, Blu-Ray disk,newspaper, 
>CD, movie, concert, theatre, movie ticket, video game, etc,sold also 
>gets thrown into the pool that's to be invested in.And that's just 
>on the software/content end of it.Apply a similar tax to every 
>radio, TV, computer, flash drive, camera,time shifting DVR/TiVo 
>recorder, paper copier and paper, typewriter,pen, pencil, mp3 
>player, cell phone, and any other piece of hardwarethat's sold to 
>produce and distribute content and all of a sudden themonies raised 
>for this balloons, in the course of a single year, everyyear, to 
>something close to approaching what the USA has already spentover 
>the course of the ongoing Iraq Occupation, well near a 
>trilliondollars.Every year, like clockwork, so raising the money 
>isn't the issue.And through the investing in US Treasuries, it 
>generates interest in the$10s of billions of dollars every year, 
>which means that in a "NeverTouch Principal" sort of way, it can not 
>only be self-supporting, butalso self-sustaining as well, for as 
>long as the United States makespayments on their bonds, which in the 
>past 200 odd years has neverhappened, not that past performance is 
>any indicator of future results.Now at this point, I can hear the 
>argument that in order to do this itwould require Nationalizing the 
>Mass Media's production and distributionfacilities and there are 
>many examples of other industries in which thathas happened where 
>that kind of action has ended rather poorly, and dowe want to create 
>the same sort of mess  as that would do with a planlike this?Of 
>course not.First off, the last thing one would want to have to 
>happen is to seizethese assets by force, that always hurts the one 
>doing the seizing, andleaves the dispossessed with a raft of hurt, 
>bad, and resentfulfeelings, and so that course of action is to be 
>avoided, because it justdoesn't work.An alternative approach is to 
>make them see that it would be worth theirwhile to transfer those 
>assets over to the Common Weal, and that can bedone without even 
>raising the idea that for many of the current ownersof these 
>properties they should consider themselves grateful thatthey're not 
>being sent to prison, for their decades worth ofmalfeasance, 
>corruption, and outright larceny from artists and thepublic on a 
>grand and felonious scale.No need to get into all that.By using the 
>monies raised from these Media Taxes, ear-mark a certainpercentage 
>of those monies to buy out the principal owners out of theircurrent 
>production and distribution positions; also to include alife-time 
>severance package for them and pay for the education andhealth-care 
>of their heirs, and they get to keep all their currentassets, to 
>include their housing, luxury cars, yachts, planes, villas,and any 
>other gains they may have reaped exploiting the current waythings 
>are done today.In other words, pay these rat-fuck RIAA/Music-Film 
>Industry greed-heads off.Buy 'em out.They're the real thieves, 
>always have beeen, and I'm sure that they'veall got their price.And 
>if they want to stay on after the transition, offer them a 
>salariedposition doing the work that they had been doing.Now, it's 
>no secret that a lot of Corporations, particularly theadvertisers 
>are already looking for a way to get out of theownership/sponsorship 
>game already.This is because of the advent of the TiVo/DVR time 
>shifting technologythat has emerged and become wildly popular over 
>the course of this lastdecade.In their view, why should they 
>continue to pay billions of dollars ayear, to not only produce and 
>distribute television, if their targetaudience is simply going to 
>fast-forward through all the advertisingthat is the their whole 
>point of paying all that money for, if nobody isgoing to bother to 
>watch the commercials anymore?Where's the business sense in 
>that?That's money they can keep for themselves and apply to their 
>businesseselsewhere, which they'd probably be better off with.This 
>offers them a way to get out of the business that is from 
>acost/benefit analysis, fiscally sound and allow them to meet 
>theirfiduciary responsibilities to their shareholders.---And that's 
>as far as I got, so far.~Nyc--Isaac wrote:> The music industry has 
>been in decline this whole decade. It is sad in many ways because 
>many musicians will not get a chance to make it in the business. The 
>concept of less sales = less talent available to sign because the 
>industry is tight...>> The ISP's might eventually have to upgrade 
>and obtain the proper equipment to police the internet. Who knows at

> > Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager> By Nicole Martin, 
>Digital and Media Correspondent, in Cannes> Last Updated: 12:01am

>has said.> > Telegraph Arts coverage in full> Telegraph Digital

>years, > attacked internet service providers for failing to clamp 
>down on > illegal file-sharing.> > > > The manager of U2 has called 
>for ISPs to take action against repeat offenders> He said the 
>refusal of internet firms to punish those who download > music 
>without paying was "the single biggest failure in the digital > 
>music market".> > He called on them to adopt a "three strikes and 
>you're out" > enforcement policy under which illegal downloaders 
>would have to start > paying for music or face having their ISP 
>subscriptions terminated.> > "We must shame them into wanting to 
>help us. Their snouts have been at > our trough feeding free for too 
>long," Mr McGuinness said at the Midem > music industry conference 
>in Cannes.> > "For ISPs in general, the days of prevaricating over 
>their > responsibilities for helping protect music must end. The ISP 
>lobbyists > who say they should not have to 'police the internet' 
>are living in > the past - relying on outdated excuses from an 
>earlier technological > age."> > His call follows a report last week 
>which showed that while worldwide > sales of digital music grew by 
>40 per cent last year, they were still > not enough to offset a 
>sharp fall in CD sales.> > The International Federation of the 
>Phonographic Industry, which > represents record companies across 
>the world, warned that the "crisis" > in the music industry would 
>deepen unless ISPs took action against the > millions of people who 
>illegally download music.> > Many ISPs have been reluctant to police 
>the illegal activities of > their customers, preferring to rely on 
>record labels to bring cases > against them.> > advertisement> > But 
>Mr McGuinness said it was time to challenge the belief that ISPs > 
>should not be held accountable for their customers' behaviour.> > 
>"If you were publishing a magazine that was advertising stolen 
>cars, > processing payments for them and arranging delivery of them 
>you'd > expect to get a visit from the police wouldn't you?" he 
>said, in a > speech titled The Online Bonanza: Who is Making All The 
>Money and Why > Aren't They Sharing It?> > "What's the difference? 
>With a laptop, a broadband account, an MP3 > player and a smartphone 
>you can now steal all the content, music, > video and literary in 
>the world without any money going to the content > owners.> > "On 
>the other hand, if you get caught stealing a laptop in the > 
>computer store or don't pay your broadband bill there are obvious > 
>consequences. You get nicked or you get your access cut off."> > A 
>survey last year by Quantum Markets in Australia found that of the > 
>2.8 billion people who regularly download illegally, 75 per cent 
>said > they did not believe they were hurting the music industry.> > 
>When asked why, the vast majority said they did not feel at risk 
>of > being punished for downloading songs for free.> > Mr McGuinness 
>called on the Government to follow the lead of Nicolas > Sarkozy, 
>the French President, and introduce legislation if voluntary > talks 
>with ISPs failed to produce a commitment to disconnect > 
>file-sharers. A spokesman for the Internet Service Providers' > 
>Association said its members preferred self regulation to 
>legislation.> > "We do not support abuses of copyright and 
>intellectual property > theft. However, ISPs cannot monitor or 
>record the type of information > passed over their networks," he 
>said.> > "ISPs are no more able to inspect and filter every single 
>packet > passing across their network than the Post Office is able 
>to open > every envelope."> > > > > >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager

Actually there are/were several things like this...

First of all, from my personal experience, there is for Internet radio SoundExchange which is supposed to collect (outrageous and unaffordable) fees and play data from Internet streaming broadcasters and then distribute this money 50/50 to the artists and labels.  But they actually distribute the majority of the money to the RIAA and its members through a rather simple accounting trick which I discovered.  This is known and has been widely discussed in the industry and yet it continues today. 

Of course then there is Shawn Fanning's company Snocap which does almost exactly what you've described only for <EVIL>...

Ever wonder what would have happened if Luke had gone over to the dark side?  Its Snocap.

Finally I'd like to mention Weedshare which tried to do it right, but wasn't given the time of the day by the industry.  RIP Weedshare.

See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weed_music_distribution_service

Best,

Peter


----- Original Message ----
From: Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
To: Isaac <greylane@hotmail.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Tuesday, January 29, 2008 7:06:10 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager

Not talking about ISP's policing the internets, I'm talking about a 
surcharge being placed on hardware/software/distribution and pooling 
those monies raised from that to pay the artists.

The more bittorrent dl's you have, the more you get paid.

You think mininova/piratebay doesn't already keep track?

We can go RIAA = BAD all we want, but until a plan is figured out to 
compensate artists for their work, it's all just talk, and so far I 
haven't seen anybody talking about that end of it.

..

> Date: Tue, 29 Jan 2008 18:24:44 -0800From: prayformojo524@gmail.comTo: digitalcomponents@gmail.comSubject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 managerCC: greylane@hotmail.com; sfraves@hyperreal.orgTL;DR for some of this, but if you ask me this is like banning someone from leaving their house because they got a ticket while driving.and fuck U2.peace,Matt
> On 1/29/08, Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote: 
> (note: note: wrote the below a few months back on this subject, can'tremember if I x-posted it here @ the time, if it is all apologies forthe repeat. If not, I'd like to hear some thoughts on the idea of takingthe Arts out of the hands of Corporate Ownership and transferring itinto the realm of Public Utility and how feasible an idea people thinkthat is. Again, this is just the start of the idea and it's got plentyof room to expand, which I'd like to do, but I could use a little helpfrom my friends. ~Nyc)(note: this started off as a flippant, one line, reply to an email Irecently got, and it mushroomed into a something quite unexpected essayon the subject of Intellectual Property and Media as it exists in theUSA today. If you like what you read, or don't, I'd like some feedbackon it, (since I plan to develop it further, via a wiki/open sourceformat eventually) this being only a 1/4 complete First Draft, and ifyou think the ideas within have any merit,
 please feel free to forwardit along to anyone else that may find it of interest. Thanks! ~nwa)> s@umn.edu wrote:>> Will all of the music disappear?>>>> http://www.docudharma.com/showDiary.do?diaryId=1527"One Murdoch to Rule Them All" http://tinyurl.com/3yhlhmheheheh, nice comment, in a too funny,  lolocaust, sort of way.But seriously, this whole argument that the content distributors aremaking is fallacious on its face.A friend of mine signs all his emails with this quote which I findgermane to this discussion:"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of therest of society because it explores, much faster than material realitycan, the entire range of possibilities in a given code. It makes audiblethe new world that will gradually become visible. What is noise to theold order is harmony to the new."-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise" http://tinyurl.com/yate6kEvery day there is a story about how the record/tv/film industry
 islosing billions of dollars a year in "lost revenue" to online P2Pnetworks, and other forms of media 'piracy'.Cosmo Kramer, please.Bite me.That's nonsense, it's generally monies that they've gotten so used tostealing from content creators, (now that their extortionistdistribution channels have been rendered obsolete by the advent of theinternet, and exposed for the fraud that it is, and has been), thatnever really "belonged" to them in the first place, that they're whiningabout "losing."It's time to change the rules from the top down and the bottom up anddrive these fat, parasitc, infectious pieces of human waste, moneychanging, middle-men, (who are the real 'pirate' villains in thispiece), out of The Temple of Mass Media, and turn that Mass Media awayfrom being a privately run Coprporate Enterprise and into a PublicUtility, no different from the gas, electric, water and other utilitiesthat are the support system of modern life.And I have a pretty
 clear idea as to how to do it.(But before I get into that I'd like to briefly point out that the word'talent' derives from the same source as the word 'dollar', which is theLatin word 'Taler', which is what the Romans in Caeser's day calledtheir base unit of money.)What needs to happen from this point on to get to the next place we needto be at in getting to having our Media become a Public Utility is toremove all Corporate ownership over any, and all, media and art forms.Time, and time again, the Corporations have proven themselves to belousy Stewards of The Public Trust, be it in not paying the artiststheir proper due for their works, to raging conflicts of interests, asmost recently seen by Corporate News Networks running ads from the samepredatory lenders who created the largest financial crisis of our era,(see: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZwYvhPdCces  ), and it's now pasttime to thank them for the work that they've done so far in building
 themedia production and distribution infrastructure and begin to transitionaway from their private ownership of it, and they're being the Toll-Gatekeepers our common cultural heritage, and begin asserting our rightstowards returning it back to the commons.Sounds good, I know, but how in the world do I propose *to pay* forsomething like that?After all, for example, if it weren't for Corporate Sponsorship, thenthere would be no television programming, since it is their capital thatpays the bills that provides the revenue that makes it possible forsitcoms, soap operas, police procedurals, reality shows, news,dysfunctional family dramas, talk shows, variety shows, documentaries,and all other shows to exist.None of that is cheap to produce, and the money has got to come fromsomewhere.But from where?Like I said, our Media needs to treated as a Public Utility, and the wayto pay for it is to create a central, common source of funding, justlike is done with all
 other Public Utilities.Through buying Bonds.Consider this.The film industry in the United States is currently a $5+ billion dollara year enterprise, in terms of gross annual revenue.That's a lot of shekels.The installed base of users of the internet in the United States iscurrently at about 70% of the population, roughly 230 million people.Now, if part of the price for access to the internet were to include a$10 tax a month, over, or from, the ISPs, that would be $120 a year, perperson, which would raise just about $28 billion dollars.Were that $28 billion dollars to be invested in US Treasuries, atcurrent rates of about 5% they would return about $1.5 billion dollarsin interest, (invested more aggressively in the equity, currency andcommodities markets, it could go to 10% or higher, which would doublethat rate of return, but that is a much riskier proposition, so, forsake of argument, I'd like to concentrate on just bond investing), whichwould go a
 long way towards infrastructure maintenance and upkeep,salaries, rent,  and all other forms of overhead.However, it's not all the money that would be needed for such a vastundertaking, more, significantly much more will be needed to pull a planlike this off.So where does that come from?Same place, all other media outlets and channels come with a similar taxfor use and access to the public resource.Cable TV, phone services, (landlines and cellular), a percentage of theprice of every magazine, DVD, book, vinyl record, Blu-Ray disk,newspaper, CD, movie, concert, theatre, movie ticket, video game, etc,sold also gets thrown into the pool that's to be invested in.And that's just on the software/content end of it.Apply a similar tax to every radio, TV, computer, flash drive, camera,time shifting DVR/TiVo recorder, paper copier and paper, typewriter,pen, pencil, mp3 player, cell phone, and any other piece of hardwarethat's sold to produce and distribute content
 and all of a sudden themonies raised for this balloons, in the course of a single year, everyyear, to something close to approaching what the USA has already spentover the course of the ongoing Iraq Occupation, well near a trilliondollars.Every year, like clockwork, so raising the money isn't the issue.And through the investing in US Treasuries, it generates interest in the$10s of billions of dollars every year, which means that in a "NeverTouch Principal" sort of way, it can not only be self-supporting, butalso self-sustaining as well, for as long as the United States makespayments on their bonds, which in the past 200 odd years has neverhappened, not that past performance is any indicator of future results.Now at this point, I can hear the argument that in order to do this itwould require Nationalizing the Mass Media's production and distributionfacilities and there are many examples of other industries in which thathas happened where that kind of
 action has ended rather poorly, and dowe want to create the same sort of mess  as that would do with a planlike this?Of course not.First off, the last thing one would want to have to happen is to seizethese assets by force, that always hurts the one doing the seizing, andleaves the dispossessed with a raft of hurt, bad, and resentfulfeelings, and so that course of action is to be avoided, because it justdoesn't work.An alternative approach is to make them see that it would be worth theirwhile to transfer those assets over to the Common Weal, and that can bedone without even raising the idea that for many of the current ownersof these properties they should consider themselves grateful thatthey're not being sent to prison, for their decades worth ofmalfeasance, corruption, and outright larceny from artists and thepublic on a grand and felonious scale.No need to get into all that.By using the monies raised from these Media Taxes, ear-mark a
 certainpercentage of those monies to buy out the principal owners out of theircurrent production and distribution positions; also to include alife-time severance package for them and pay for the education andhealth-care of their heirs, and they get to keep all their currentassets, to include their housing, luxury cars, yachts, planes, villas,and any other gains they may have reaped exploiting the current waythings are done today.In other words, pay these rat-fuck RIAA/Music-Film Industry greed-heads off.Buy 'em out.They're the real thieves, always have beeen, and I'm sure that they'veall got their price.And if they want to stay on after the transition, offer them a salariedposition doing the work that they had been doing.Now, it's no secret that a lot of Corporations, particularly theadvertisers are already looking for a way to get out of theownership/sponsorship game already.This is because of the advent of the TiVo/DVR time shifting technologythat has
 emerged and become wildly popular over the course of this lastdecade.In their view, why should they continue to pay billions of dollars ayear, to not only produce and distribute television, if their targetaudience is simply going to fast-forward through all the advertisingthat is the their whole point of paying all that money for, if nobody isgoing to bother to watch the commercials anymore?Where's the business sense in that?That's money they can keep for themselves and apply to their businesseselsewhere, which they'd probably be better off with.This offers them a way to get out of the business that is from acost/benefit analysis, fiscally sound and allow them to meet theirfiduciary responsibilities to their shareholders.---And that's as far as I got, so far.~Nyc--Isaac wrote:> The music industry has been in decline this whole decade. It is sad in many ways because many musicians will not get a chance to make it in the business. The concept of less
 sales = less talent available to sign because the industry is tight...>> The ISP's might eventually have to upgrade and obtain the proper equipment to police the internet. Who knows at this point anything is possible, I am sure both sides have a case in federal court with great points and their interpretation of HIGHLY COMPLEX IP laws. You can think of it like this, the music industry may be willing to spend millions in court over this which in the long run is cheaper then another decade of decline (i.e., Exploding Ford Pinto and ethical decisions made by Ford to keep the car on the road in the 1970's).>> I remember P. Diddy on MTV's MTB 4 saying artists that use to sell millions of CD's are now selling a couple of hundred thousand. Also today artists earn more money because they sign better contracts geared toward their rights and protection of their art as an artist. Record companies do not like that because it cuts into their profit. Money to be made
 now in the music industry is all in the LIVE SHOWS. I also hear somewhere that record sales in history actually took off in the mid to late 1960's like never before in history and record companies made a lot of money. They peaked at some point in the eighties or nineties.>>> Isaac>>>>>>>> Date: Tue, 29 Jan 2008 17:39:55 -0500> From: sfo@deepfog.com> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org> Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager> > I wanted to see what anyone thinks about this article, I know I buy > very few CD's, and oddly enough one of them was U2's CD from a few > years ago, I would love to contact the manager and find out if there > is a way I can just return this CD and get my money back, I really > don't want to support someone that supports an unrealistic push to > nanny what everyone does on their personal computers and support an > industry that generally does not have the well-being of the artist in > mind, rather big corporate

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager

I generally like the way you think NYC, but here you've gone in the wrong direction I think.  Most importanntly you've forgotten just how much of the music business is run by criminals and is run as if it was a criminal enterprise.  At the very highlest levels these companies would move to crush anything like 
a tax or bond initiative that would take their control of the distribution of music away.  They spend millions influencing political candidates for exactly this reason.  Check out Ms. Clinton's donor list for example.  

While this criminal culture has been around for over 50 years, it isn't widely known or talked about outside of a few people like Moses avalon that are out there trying to warn young musicians.  No sensible redistribution of wealth will ever be accepted by the industry; they created the RIAA specifically to prevent this.

The good news for the music consumer and the musician is that we don't need them anymore.  Need to find some music?   The best place to start is Google not the record store or the radio.  The stock prices of the big labels reflect this reality even if their legal maneuvering doesn't.

If you don't buy or steal their products, they can't sue you.  Oh wait you say, if I buy the records how can they sue me?  

Well remember the RIAA doesn't sell you the recording they "license" it to you.  And that means they can try to change the rules about what you can do with the recording even after you've bought it. For example by continuing to argue in court that you don't have the right to rip CDs for any reason even though the American Home Recording Act, an existing  law of our great land, says you can.  And yet the RIAA continues to pursue this argument over and over again in court.

These people don't repect the rule of law and they don't fear prosecution.

Regards,

Peter



----- Original Message ----
From: Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
To: Isaac <greylane@hotmail.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Tuesday, January 29, 2008 6:16:43 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager

(note: note: wrote the below a few months back on this subject, can't 
remember if I x-posted it here @ the time, if it is all apologies for 
the repeat. If not, I'd like to hear some thoughts on the idea of taking 
the Arts out of the hands of Corporate Ownership and transferring it 
into the realm of Public Utility and how feasible an idea people think 
that is. Again, this is just the start of the idea and it's got plenty 
of room to expand, which I'd like to do, but I could use a little help 
from my friends. ~Nyc)

(note: this started off as a flippant, one line, reply to an email I 
recently got, and it mushroomed into a something quite unexpected essay 
on the subject of Intellectual Property and Media as it exists in the 
USA today. If you like what you read, or don't, I'd like some feedback 
on it, (since I plan to develop it further, via a wiki/open source 
format eventually) this being only a 1/4 complete First Draft, and if 
you think the ideas within have any merit, please feel free to forward 
it along to anyone else that may find it of interest. Thanks! ~nwa)


> s@umn.edu wrote:
>> Will all of the music disappear?
>>
>> http://www.docudharma.com/showDiary.do?diaryId=1527

"One Murdoch to Rule Them All" http://tinyurl.com/3yhlhm
heheheh, nice comment, in a too funny,  lolocaust, sort of way.

But seriously, this whole argument that the content distributors are 
making is fallacious on its face.

A friend of mine signs all his emails with this quote which I find 
germane to this discussion:

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society because it explores, much faster than material reality 
can, the entire range of possibilities in a given code. It makes audible 
the new world that will gradually become visible. What is noise to the 
old order is harmony to the new."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise" http://tinyurl.com/yate6k

Every day there is a story about how the record/tv/film industry is 
losing billions of dollars a year in "lost revenue" to online P2P 
networks, and other forms of media 'piracy'.

Cosmo Kramer, please.

Bite me.

That's nonsense, it's generally monies that they've gotten so used to 
stealing from content creators, (now that their extortionist 
distribution channels have been rendered obsolete by the advent of the 
internet, and exposed for the fraud that it is, and has been), that 
never really "belonged" to them in the first place, that they're whining 
about "losing."

It's time to change the rules from the top down and the bottom up and 
drive these fat, parasitc, infectious pieces of human waste, money 
changing, middle-men, (who are the real 'pirate' villains in this 
piece), out of The Temple of Mass Media, and turn that Mass Media away 
from being a privately run Coprporate Enterprise and into a Public 
Utility, no different from the gas, electric, water and other utilities 
that are the support system of modern life.

And I have a pretty clear idea as to how to do it.

(But before I get into that I'd like to briefly point out that the word 
'talent' derives from the same source as the word 'dollar', which is the 
Latin word 'Taler', which is what the Romans in Caeser's day called 
their base unit of money.)

What needs to happen from this point on to get to the next place we need 
to be at in getting to having our Media become a Public Utility is to 
remove all Corporate ownership over any, and all, media and art forms.

Time, and time again, the Corporations have proven themselves to be 
lousy Stewards of The Public Trust, be it in not paying the artists 
their proper due for their works, to raging conflicts of interests, as 
most recently seen by Corporate News Networks running ads from the same 
predatory lenders who created the largest financial crisis of our era, 
(see: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZwYvhPdCces  ), and it's now past 
time to thank them for the work that they've done so far in building the 
media production and distribution infrastructure and begin to transition 
away from their private ownership of it, and they're being the Toll-Gate 
keepers our common cultural heritage, and begin asserting our rights 
towards returning it back to the commons.

Sounds good, I know, but how in the world do I propose *to pay* for 
something like that?

After all, for example, if it weren't for Corporate Sponsorship, then 
there would be no television programming, since it is their capital that 
pays the bills that provides the revenue that makes it possible for 
sitcoms, soap operas, police procedurals, reality shows, news, 
dysfunctional family dramas, talk shows, variety shows, documentaries, 
and all other shows to exist.

None of that is cheap to produce, and the money has got to come from 
somewhere.

But from where?

Like I said, our Media needs to treated as a Public Utility, and the way 
to pay for it is to create a central, common source of funding, just 
like is done with all other Public Utilities.

Through buying Bonds.

Consider this.

The film industry in the United States is currently a $5+ billion dollar 
a year enterprise, in terms of gross annual revenue.

That's a lot of shekels.

The installed base of users of the internet in the United States is 
currently at about 70% of the population, roughly 230 million people.

Now, if part of the price for access to the internet were to include a 
$10 tax a month, over, or from, the ISPs, that would be $120 a year, per 
person, which would raise just about $28 billion dollars.

Were that $28 billion dollars to be invested in US Treasuries, at 
current rates of about 5% they would return about $1.5 billion dollars 
in interest, (invested more aggressively in the equity, currency and 
commodities markets, it could go to 10% or higher, which would double 
that rate of return, but that is a much riskier proposition, so, for 
sake of argument, I'd like to concentrate on just bond investing), which 
would go a long way towards infrastructure maintenance and upkeep, 
salaries, rent,  and all other forms of overhead.

However, it's not all the money that would be needed for such a vast 
undertaking, more, significantly much more will be needed to pull a plan 
like this off.

So where does that come from?

Same place, all other media outlets and channels come with a similar tax 
for use and access to the public resource.

Cable TV, phone services, (landlines and cellular), a percentage of the 
price of every magazine, DVD, book, vinyl record, Blu-Ray disk, 
newspaper, CD, movie, concert, theatre, movie ticket, video game, etc, 
sold also gets thrown into the pool that's to be invested in.

And that's just on the software/content end of it.

Apply a similar tax to every radio, TV, computer, flash drive, camera, 
time shifting DVR/TiVo recorder, paper copier and paper, typewriter, 
pen, pencil, mp3 player, cell phone, and any other piece of hardware 
that's sold to produce and distribute content and all of a sudden the 
monies raised for this balloons, in the course of a single year, every 
year, to something close to approaching what the USA has already spent 
over the course of the ongoing Iraq Occupation, well near a trillion 
dollars.

Every year, like clockwork, so raising the money isn't the issue.

And through the investing in US Treasuries, it generates interest in the 
$10s of billions of dollars every year, which means that in a "Never 
Touch Principal" sort of way, it can not only be self-supporting, but 
also self-sustaining as well, for as long as the United States makes 
payments on their bonds, which in the past 200 odd years has never 
happened, not that past performance is any indicator of future results.

Now at this point, I can hear the argument that in order to do this it 
would require Nationalizing the Mass Media's production and distribution 
facilities and there are many examples of other industries in which that 
has happened where that kind of action has ended rather poorly, and do 
we want to create the same sort of mess  as that would do with a plan 
like this?

Of course not.

First off, the last thing one would want to have to happen is to seize 
these assets by force, that always hurts the one doing the seizing, and 
leaves the dispossessed with a raft of hurt, bad, and resentful 
feelings, and so that course of action is to be avoided, because it just 
doesn't work.

An alternative approach is to make them see that it would be worth their 
while to transfer those assets over to the Common Weal, and that can be 
done without even raising the idea that for many of the current owners 
of these properties they should consider themselves grateful that 
they're not being sent to prison, for their decades worth of 
malfeasance, corruption, and outright larceny from artists and the 
public on a grand and felonious scale.

No need to get into all that.

By using the monies raised from these Media Taxes, ear-mark a certain 
percentage of those monies to buy out the principal owners out of their 
current production and distribution positions; also to include a 
life-time severance package for them and pay for the education and 
health-care of their heirs, and they get to keep all their current 
assets, to include their housing, luxury cars, yachts, planes, villas, 
and any other gains they may have reaped exploiting the current way 
things are done today.

In other words, pay these rat-fuck RIAA/Music-Film Industry greed-heads off.

Buy 'em out.

They're the real thieves, always have beeen, and I'm sure that they've 
all got their price.

And if they want to stay on after the transition, offer them a salaried 
position doing the work that they had been doing.

Now, it's no secret that a lot of Corporations, particularly the 
advertisers are already looking for a way to get out of the 
ownership/sponsorship game already.

This is because of the advent of the TiVo/DVR time shifting technology 
that has emerged and become wildly popular over the course of this last 
decade.

In their view, why should they continue to pay billions of dollars a 
year, to not only produce and distribute television, if their target 
audience is simply going to fast-forward through all the advertising 
that is the their whole point of paying all that money for, if nobody is 
going to bother to watch the commercials anymore?

Where's the business sense in that?

That's money they can keep for themselves and apply to their businesses 
elsewhere, which they'd probably be better off with.

This offers them a way to get out of the business that is from a 
cost/benefit analysis, fiscally sound and allow them to meet their 
fiduciary responsibilities to their shareholders.

---

And that's as far as I got, so far.

~Nyc

--

I also hear somewhere that record sales in history actually took off in the mid to late 1960's like never before in history and record companies made a lot of money.  29/01/2008> > Music fans who repeatedly download songs illegally should have their > internet connections severed, the manager of U2 has said.> > Telegraph Arts coverage in full> Telegraph Digital Life> Paul McGuinness, who has managed the best-selling group for 30 years, > attacked internet service providers for failing to clamp down on > illegal file-sharing.> > > > The manager of U2 has called for ISPs to take action against repeat offenders> He said the refusal of internet firms to punish those who download > music without paying was "the single biggest failure in the digital > music market".> > He called on them to adopt a "three strikes and you're out" > enforcement policy under which illegal downloaders would have to start > paying for music or face having their ISP subscriptions terminated.> > "We must shame them into wanting to help us. Their snouts have been at > our trough feeding free for too long," Mr McGuinness said at the Midem > music
 industry conference in Cannes.> > "For ISPs in general, the days of prevaricating over their > responsibilities for helping protect music must end. The ISP lobbyists > who say they should not have to 'police the internet' are living in > the past - relying on outdated excuses from an earlier technological > age."> > His call follows a report last week which showed that while worldwide > sales of digital music grew by 40 per cent last year, they were still > not enough to offset a sharp fall in CD sales.> > The International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, which > represents record companies across the world, warned that the "crisis" > in the music industry would deepen unless ISPs took action against the > millions of people who illegally download music.> > Many ISPs have been reluctant to police the illegal activities of > their customers, preferring to rely on record labels to bring cases > against them.> > advertisement> > But Mr McGuinness
 said it was time to challenge the belief that ISPs > should not be held accountable for their customers' behaviour.> > "If you were publishing a magazine that was advertising stolen cars, > processing payments for them and arranging delivery of them you'd > expect to get a visit from the police wouldn't you?" he said, in a > speech titled The Online Bonanza: Who is Making All The Money and Why > Aren't They Sharing It?> > "What's the difference? With a laptop, a broadband account, an MP3 > player and a smartphone you can now steal all the content, music, > video and literary in the world without any money going to the content > owners.> > "On the other hand, if you get caught stealing a laptop in the > computer store or don't pay your broadband bill there are obvious > consequences. You get nicked or you get your access cut off."> > A survey last year by Quantum Markets in Australia found that of the > 2.8 billion people who regularly download
 illegally, 75 per cent said > they did not believe they were hurting the music industry.> > When asked why, the vast majority said they did not feel at risk of > being punished for downloading songs for free.> > Mr McGuinness called on the Government to follow the lead of Nicolas > Sarkozy, the French President, and introduce legislation if voluntary > talks with ISPs failed to produce a commitment to disconnect > file-sharers. A spokesman for the Internet Service Providers' > Association said its members preferred self regulation to legislation.> > "We do not support abuses of copyright and intellectual property > theft. However, ISPs cannot monitor or record the type of information > passed over their networks," he said.> > "ISPs are no more able to inspect and filter every single packet > passing across their network than the Post Office is able to open > every envelope."> > > > > >

----- Original Message ----
From: Isaac <greylane@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Tuesday, January 29, 2008 6:53:31 PM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager


For the ISP's policing the internet is a heavy burden and costly IT VIOLATES OUR PRIVACY and if the record industry gets what they want which I doubt then the ISP's will be sued for all sorts of privacy issues. 


Since we are on the subject I always get good music mixes from links provided on emails from SFRaves so I am going to list a few tracks to check-out if you have not already. You can download them from anywhere and some are on itunes listed under a certain mix as indicated below. Some of these tracks are old but I change my iPod around all the time and these are on my rotation at this time:


Lost and Found (DJ Dan Radio edit) - Delerium feat. Jael
Beautiful Day (Sunburst Mix) - Matt Darey feat Antoine & Marcia
The Anthem - Filo & Peri feat Eric Lumiere 
Let Me Think About It - Fedde Le Grande Mix - Ida Corr
White Lies (Dave Spoon Vocal Mix) - Paul van Dyk feat. Jessica Sutt
We Are Alive - Out There and Back - Paul Van Dyk 
Scream (Original Mix) - Starkillers 
Swing 2 Harmony - Perasma
Always & Forever (Original Mix) - Chocolate Puma
Tidal Flow - Thirdmember (also records and DJ's under Stoneybridge)
Let Everything Drop -Third Member
Sacramento - Deep Dish
This is New York - Sander Kleinenberg
Somebody - Richard Vission

Omniman (from this is Industrial CD)-Download 
Die In Winter - Wumpscut feat Haujobb



Isaac 




Date: Tue, 29 Jan 2008 18:24:44 -0800From: prayformojo524@gmail.comTo: digitalcomponents@gmail.comSubject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 managerCC: greylane@hotmail.com; sfraves@hyperreal.orgTL;DR for some of this, but if you ask me this is like banning someone from leaving their house because they got a ticket while driving.and fuck U2.peace,Matt
On 1/29/08, Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote: 
(note: note: wrote the below a few months back on this subject, can'tremember if I x-posted it here @ the time, if it is all apologies forthe repeat. If not, I'd like to hear some thoughts on the idea of takingthe Arts out of the hands of Corporate Ownership and transferring itinto the realm of Public Utility and how feasible an idea people thinkthat is. Again, this is just the start of the idea and it's got plentyof room to expand, which I'd like to do, but I could use a little helpfrom my friends. ~Nyc)(note: this started off as a flippant, one line, reply to an email Irecently got, and it mushroomed into a something quite unexpected essayon the subject of Intellectual Property and Media as it exists in theUSA today. If you like what you read, or don't, I'd like some feedbackon it, (since I plan to develop it further, via a wiki/open sourceformat eventually) this being only a 1/4 complete First Draft, and ifyou think the ideas within have any merit,
 please feel free to forwardit along to anyone else that may find it of interest. Thanks! ~nwa)> s@umn.edu wrote:>> Will all of the music disappear?>>>> http://www.docudharma.com/showDiary.do?diaryId=1527"One Murdoch to Rule Them All" http://tinyurl.com/3yhlhmheheheh, nice comment, in a too funny,  lolocaust, sort of way.But seriously, this whole argument that the content distributors aremaking is fallacious on its face.A friend of mine signs all his emails with this quote which I findgermane to this discussion:"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of therest of society because it explores, much faster than material realitycan, the entire range of possibilities in a given code. It makes audiblethe new world that will gradually become visible. What is noise to theold order is harmony to the new."-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise" http://tinyurl.com/yate6kEvery day there is a story about how the record/tv/film industry
 islosing billions of dollars a year in "lost revenue" to online P2Pnetworks, and other forms of media 'piracy'.Cosmo Kramer, please.Bite me.That's nonsense, it's generally monies that they've gotten so used tostealing from content creators, (now that their extortionistdistribution channels have been rendered obsolete by the advent of theinternet, and exposed for the fraud that it is, and has been), thatnever really "belonged" to them in the first place, that they're whiningabout "losing."It's time to change the rules from the top down and the bottom up anddrive these fat, parasitc, infectious pieces of human waste, moneychanging, middle-men, (who are the real 'pirate' villains in thispiece), out of The Temple of Mass Media, and turn that Mass Media awayfrom being a privately run Coprporate Enterprise and into a PublicUtility, no different from the gas, electric, water and other utilitiesthat are the support system of modern life.And I have a pretty
 clear idea as to how to do it.(But before I get into that I'd like to briefly point out that the word'talent' derives from the same source as the word 'dollar', which is theLatin word 'Taler', which is what the Romans in Caeser's day calledtheir base unit of money.)What needs to happen from this point on to get to the next place we needto be at in getting to having our Media become a Public Utility is toremove all Corporate ownership over any, and all, media and art forms.Time, and time again, the Corporations have proven themselves to belousy Stewards of The Public Trust, be it in not paying the artiststheir proper due for their works, to raging conflicts of interests, asmost recently seen by Corporate News Networks running ads from the samepredatory lenders who created the largest financial crisis of our era,(see: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZwYvhPdCces  ), and it's now pasttime to thank them for the work that they've done so far in building
 themedia production and distribution infrastructure and begin to transitionaway from their private ownership of it, and they're being the Toll-Gatekeepers our common cultural heritage, and begin asserting our rightstowards returning it back to the commons.Sounds good, I know, but how in the world do I propose *to pay* forsomething like that?After all, for example, if it weren't for Corporate Sponsorship, thenthere would be no television programming, since it is their capital thatpays the bills that provides the revenue that makes it possible forsitcoms, soap operas, police procedurals, reality shows, news,dysfunctional family dramas, talk shows, variety shows, documentaries,and all other shows to exist.None of that is cheap to produce, and the money has got to come fromsomewhere.But from where?Like I said, our Media needs to treated as a Public Utility, and the wayto pay for it is to create a central, common source of funding, justlike is done with all
 other Public Utilities.Through buying Bonds.Consider this.The film industry in the United States is currently a $5+ billion dollara year enterprise, in terms of gross annual revenue.That's a lot of shekels.The installed base of users of the internet in the United States iscurrently at about 70% of the population, roughly 230 million people.Now, if part of the price for access to the internet were to include a$10 tax a month, over, or from, the ISPs, that would be $120 a year, perperson, which would raise just about $28 billion dollars.Were that $28 billion dollars to be invested in US Treasuries, atcurrent rates of about 5% they would return about $1.5 billion dollarsin interest, (invested more aggressively in the equity, currency andcommodities markets, it could go to 10% or higher, which would doublethat rate of return, but that is a much riskier proposition, so, forsake of argument, I'd like to concentrate on just bond investing), whichwould go a
 long way towards infrastructure maintenance and upkeep,salaries, rent,  and all other forms of overhead.However, it's not all the money that would be needed for such a vastundertaking, more, significantly much more will be needed to pull a planlike this off.So where does that come from?Same place, all other media outlets and channels come with a similar taxfor use and access to the public resource.Cable TV, phone services, (landlines and cellular), a percentage of theprice of every magazine, DVD, book, vinyl record, Blu-Ray disk,newspaper, CD, movie, concert, theatre, movie ticket, video game, etc,sold also gets thrown into the pool that's to be invested in.And that's just on the software/content end of it.Apply a similar tax to every radio, TV, computer, flash drive, camera,time shifting DVR/TiVo recorder, paper copier and paper, typewriter,pen, pencil, mp3 player, cell phone, and any other piece of hardwarethat's sold to produce and distribute content
 and all of a sudden themonies raised for this balloons, in the course of a single year, everyyear, to something close to approaching what the USA has already spentover the course of the ongoing Iraq Occupation, well near a trilliondollars.Every year, like clockwork, so raising the money isn't the issue.And through the investing in US Treasuries, it generates interest in the$10s of billions of dollars every year, which means that in a "NeverTouch Principal" sort of way, it can not only be self-supporting, butalso self-sustaining as well, for as long as the United States makespayments on their bonds, which in the past 200 odd years has neverhappened, not that past performance is any indicator of future results.Now at this point, I can hear the argument that in order to do this itwould require Nationalizing the Mass Media's production and distributionfacilities and there are many examples of other industries in which thathas happened where that kind of
 action has ended rather poorly, and dowe want to create the same sort of mess  as that would do with a planlike this?Of course not.First off, the last thing one would want to have to happen is to seizethese assets by force, that always hurts the one doing the seizing, andleaves the dispossessed with a raft of hurt, bad, and resentfulfeelings, and so that course of action is to be avoided, because it justdoesn't work.An alternative approach is to make them see that it would be worth theirwhile to transfer those assets over to the Common Weal, and that can bedone without even raising the idea that for many of the current ownersof these properties they should consider themselves grateful thatthey're not being sent to prison, for their decades worth ofmalfeasance, corruption, and outright larceny from artists and thepublic on a grand and felonious scale.No need to get into all that.By using the monies raised from these Media Taxes, ear-mark a
 certainpercentage of those monies to buy out the principal owners out of theircurrent production and distribution positions; also to include alife-time severance package for them and pay for the education andhealth-care of their heirs, and they get to keep all their currentassets, to include their housing, luxury cars, yachts, planes, villas,and any other gains they may have reaped exploiting the current waythings are done today.In other words, pay these rat-fuck RIAA/Music-Film Industry greed-heads off.Buy 'em out.They're the real thieves, always have beeen, and I'm sure that they'veall got their price.And if they want to stay on after the transition, offer them a salariedposition doing the work that they had been doing.Now, it's no secret that a lot of Corporations, particularly theadvertisers are already looking for a way to get out of theownership/sponsorship game already.This is because of the advent of the TiVo/DVR time shifting technologythat has
 emerged and become wildly popular over the course of this lastdecade.In their view, why should they continue to pay billions of dollars ayear, to not only produce and distribute television, if their targetaudience is simply going to fast-forward through all the advertisingthat is the their whole point of paying all that money for, if nobody isgoing to bother to watch the commercials anymore?Where's the business sense in that?That's money they can keep for themselves and apply to their businesseselsewhere, which they'd probably be better off with.This offers them a way to get out of the business that is from acost/benefit analysis, fiscally sound and allow them to meet theirfiduciary responsibilities to their shareholders.---And that's as far as I got, so far.~Nyc--Isaac wrote:> The music industry has been in decline this whole decade. It is sad in many ways because many musicians will not get a chance to make it in the business. The concept of less
 sales = less talent available to sign because the industry is tight...>> The ISP's might eventually have to upgrade and obtain the proper equipment to police the internet. Who knows at this point anything is possible, I am sure both sides have a case in federal court with great points and their interpretation of HIGHLY COMPLEX IP laws. You can think of it like this, the music industry may be willing to spend millions in court over this which in the long run is cheaper then another decade of decline (i.e., Exploding Ford Pinto and ethical decisions made by Ford to keep the car on the road in the 1970's).>> I remember P. Diddy on MTV's MTB 4 saying artists that use to sell millions of CD's are now selling a couple of hundred thousand. Record companies do not like that because it cuts into their profit. Money to be made
 now in the music industry is all in the LIVE SHOWS. I also hear somewhere that record sales in history actually took off in the mid to late 1960's like never before in history and record companies made a lot of money. They peaked at some point in the eighties or nineties.>>> Isaac>>>>>>>> Date: Tue, 29 Jan 2008 17:39:55 -0500> From: sfo@deepfog.com> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org> Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager> > I wanted to see what anyone thinks about this article, I know I buy > very few CD's, and oddly enough one of them was U2's CD from a few > years ago, I would love to contact the manager and find out if there > is a way I can just return this CD and get my money back, I really > don't want to support someone that supports an unrealistic push to > nanny what everyone does on their personal computers and support an > industry that generally does not have the well-being of the artist in > mind, rather big corporate
 profits.> > --> > http://www.telegraph.co.uk/connected/main.jhtml;jsessionid=3EKD2RI2OKH0XQFIQMFCFFOAVCBQYIV0?xml=/connected/2008/01/29/dlutwo129.xml> > Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager> By Nicole Martin, Digital and Media Correspondent, in Cannes> Last Updated: 12:01am GMT 29/01/2008> > Music fans who repeatedly download songs illegally should have their > internet connections severed, the manager of U2 has said.> > Telegraph Arts coverage in full> Telegraph Digital Life> Paul McGuinness, who has managed the best-selling group for 30 years, > attacked internet service providers for failing to clamp down on > illegal file-sharing.> > > > The manager of U2 has called for ISPs to take action against repeat offenders> He said the refusal of internet firms to punish those who download > music without paying was "the single biggest failure in the digital > music market".> > He called on them to adopt a "three strikes and you're out" > enforcement
 policy under which illegal downloaders would have to start > paying for music or face having their ISP subscriptions terminated.> > "We must shame them into wanting to help us. Their snouts have been at > our trough feeding free for too long," Mr McGuinness said at the Midem > music industry conference in Cannes.> > "For ISPs in general, the days of prevaricating over their > responsibilities for helping protect music must end. The ISP lobbyists > who say they should not have to 'police the internet' are living in > the past - relying on outdated excuses from an earlier technological > age."> > His call follows a report last week which showed that while worldwide > sales of digital music grew by 40 per cent last year, they were still > not enough to offset a sharp fall in CD sales.> > The International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, which > represents record companies across the world, warned that the "crisis" > in the music industry would
 deepen unless ISPs took action against the > millions of people who illegally download music.> > Many ISPs have been reluctant to police the illegal activities of > their customers, preferring to rely on record labels to bring cases > against them.> > advertisement> > But Mr McGuinness said it was time to challenge the belief that ISPs > should not be held accountable for their customers' behaviour.> > "If you were publishing a magazine that was advertising stolen cars, > processing payments for them and arranging delivery of them you'd > expect to get a visit from the police wouldn't you?" he said, in a > speech titled The Online Bonanza: Who is Making All The Money and Why > Aren't They Sharing It?> > "What's the difference? With a laptop, a broadband account, an MP3 > player and a smartphone you can now steal all the content, music, > video and literary in the world without any money going to the content > owners.> > "On the other hand, if you get
 caught stealing a laptop in the > computer store or don't pay your broadband bill there are obvious > consequences. You get nicked or you get your access cut off."> > A survey last year by Quantum Markets in Australia found that of the > 2.8 billion people who regularly download illegally, 75 per cent said > they did not believe they were hurting the music industry.> > When asked why, the vast majority said they did not feel at risk of > being punished for downloading songs for free.> > Mr McGuinness called on the Government to follow the lead of Nicolas > Sarkozy, the French President, and introduce legislation if voluntary > talks with ISPs failed to produce a commitment to disconnect > file-sharers. A spokesman for the Internet Service Providers' > Association said its members preferred self regulation to legislation.> > "We do not support abuses of copyright and intellectual property > theft.
