Subject: RE: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager

Definitely an interesting argument, although I kind of shudder at the
idea of "[paying] these rat-f.ck RIAA/Music-Film Industry greed-heads
off". And there's just something slimy about giving them any opportunity
to stay involved in an industry that has been run by them for decades
and shafting artists out of their due. We would ultimately still be
playing their game by their rules, and there's no guarantee that the
officials of this newly founded Public Utility system wouldn't
eventually participate in the same system of greed and payola that is
happening in the industry now.

Personally, I would rather see artists taking an Anarcho-Syndicalist
position, educating themselves about the business end of their craft,
investing in their own means of recording, promotion and distribution of
their works, and ultimately having the work speak for itself
commercially. There are too many talented artists out there that don't
have a clue what they're getting themselves into when they sign
recording contracts and that's a big part of where the problem lies... a
majority of new major-label artists are seeing only dollar signs and
saying to themselves "WOW, look at that advance! Finally we don't have
to live out of a van eating ramen every night! WOO HOO!" -- and then
signing the rights of their works (and the residual income from them)
over to the label.

In other words, DIY. It may take longer for artists to grab that
proverbial brass ring and start making real money, but that is
ultimately what will make the RIAA and the major labels crumble and die.
And the added benefit of everyone going DIY -- that process will weed
out the stupid, lazy, and socially irrelevant artists from crowding our
airwaves.=20

Oh, and good luck trying to legislate the major labels out of the
industry. They have the money to pay for lawyers and lobbyists and
thwart attempts to remove them. It would have to be done by a good
old-fashioned grassroots popular referendum, rather than through
Congress...=20

I don't know, I probably went off topic for a bit there. But your idea
is definitely a good start.

-D

-----Original Message-----
From: Nyc W. Alberts [mailto:digitalcomponents@gmail.com]=20
Sent: Tuesday, January 29, 2008 6:17 PM
To: Isaac
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Ban music thieves from web, says U2 manager

(note: note: wrote the below a few months back on this subject, can't=20
remember if I x-posted it here @ the time, if it is all apologies for=20
the repeat. If not, I'd like to hear some thoughts on the idea of taking

the Arts out of the hands of Corporate Ownership and transferring it=20
into the realm of Public Utility and how feasible an idea people think=20
that is. Again, this is just the start of the idea and it's got plenty=20
of room to expand, which I'd like to do, but I could use a little help=20
from my friends. ~Nyc)

(note: this started off as a flippant, one line, reply to an email I=20
recently got, and it mushroomed into a something quite unexpected essay=20
on the subject of Intellectual Property and Media as it exists in the=20
USA today. If you like what you read, or don't, I'd like some feedback=20
on it, (since I plan to develop it further, via a wiki/open source=20
format eventually) this being only a 1/4 complete First Draft, and if=20
you think the ideas within have any merit, please feel free to forward=20
it along to anyone else that may find it of interest. Thanks! ~nwa)


 > s@umn.edu wrote:
 >> Will all of the music disappear?
 >>
 >> http://www.docudharma.com/showDiary.do?diaryId=3D1527

"One Murdoch to Rule Them All" http://tinyurl.com/3yhlhm
heheheh, nice comment, in a too funny,  lolocaust, sort of way.

But seriously, this whole argument that the content distributors are=20
making is fallacious on its face.

A friend of mine signs all his emails with this quote which I find=20
germane to this discussion:

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the

rest of society because it explores, much faster than material reality=20
can, the entire range of possibilities in a given code. It makes audible

the new world that will gradually become visible. What is noise to the=20
old order is harmony to the new."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise" http://tinyurl.com/yate6k

Every day there is a story about how the record/tv/film industry is=20
losing billions of dollars a year in "lost revenue" to online P2P=20
networks, and other forms of media 'piracy'.

Cosmo Kramer, please.

Bite me.

That's nonsense, it's generally monies that they've gotten so used to=20
stealing from content creators, (now that their extortionist=20
distribution channels have been rendered obsolete by the advent of the=20
internet, and exposed for the fraud that it is, and has been), that=20
never really "belonged" to them in the first place, that they're whining

about "losing."

It's time to change the rules from the top down and the bottom up and=20
drive these fat, parasitc, infectious pieces of human waste, money=20
changing, middle-men, (who are the real 'pirate' villains in this=20
piece), out of The Temple of Mass Media, and turn that Mass Media away=20
from being a privately run Coprporate Enterprise and into a Public=20
Utility, no different from the gas, electric, water and other utilities=20
that are the support system of modern life.

And I have a pretty clear idea as to how to do it.

(But before I get into that I'd like to briefly point out that the word=20
'talent' derives from the same source as the word 'dollar', which is the

Latin word 'Taler', which is what the Romans in Caeser's day called=20
their base unit of money.)

What needs to happen from this point on to get to the next place we need

to be at in getting to having our Media become a Public Utility is to=20
remove all Corporate ownership over any, and all, media and art forms.

Time, and time again, the Corporations have proven themselves to be=20
lousy Stewards of The Public Trust, be it in not paying the artists=20
their proper due for their works, to raging conflicts of interests, as=20
most recently seen by Corporate News Networks running ads from the same=20
predatory lenders who created the largest financial crisis of our era,=20
(see: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DZwYvhPdCces  ), and it's now past =

time to thank them for the work that they've done so far in building the

media production and distribution infrastructure and begin to transition

away from their private ownership of it, and they're being the Toll-Gate

keepers our common cultural heritage, and begin asserting our rights=20
towards returning it back to the commons.

Sounds good, I know, but how in the world do I propose *to pay* for=20
something like that?

After all, for example, if it weren't for Corporate Sponsorship, then=20
there would be no television programming, since it is their capital that

pays the bills that provides the revenue that makes it possible for=20
sitcoms, soap operas, police procedurals, reality shows, news,=20
dysfunctional family dramas, talk shows, variety shows, documentaries,=20
and all other shows to exist.

None of that is cheap to produce, and the money has got to come from=20
somewhere.

But from where?

Like I said, our Media needs to treated as a Public Utility, and the way

to pay for it is to create a central, common source of funding, just=20
like is done with all other Public Utilities.

Through buying Bonds.

Consider this.

The film industry in the United States is currently a $5+ billion dollar

a year enterprise, in terms of gross annual revenue.

That's a lot of shekels.

The installed base of users of the internet in the United States is=20
currently at about 70% of the population, roughly 230 million people.

Now, if part of the price for access to the internet were to include a=20
$10 tax a month, over, or from, the ISPs, that would be $120 a year, per

person, which would raise just about $28 billion dollars.

Were that $28 billion dollars to be invested in US Treasuries, at=20
current rates of about 5% they would return about $1.5 billion dollars=20
in interest, (invested more aggressively in the equity, currency and=20
commodities markets, it could go to 10% or higher, which would double=20
that rate of return, but that is a much riskier proposition, so, for=20
sake of argument, I'd like to concentrate on just bond investing), which

would go a long way towards infrastructure maintenance and upkeep,=20
salaries, rent,  and all other forms of overhead.

However, it's not all the money that would be needed for such a vast=20
undertaking, more, significantly much more will be needed to pull a plan

like this off.

So where does that come from?

Same place, all other media outlets and channels come with a similar tax

for use and access to the public resource.

Cable TV, phone services, (landlines and cellular), a percentage of the=20
price of every magazine, DVD, book, vinyl record, Blu-Ray disk,=20
newspaper, CD, movie, concert, theatre, movie ticket, video game, etc,=20
sold also gets thrown into the pool that's to be invested in.

And that's just on the software/content end of it.

Apply a similar tax to every radio, TV, computer, flash drive, camera,=20
time shifting DVR/TiVo recorder, paper copier and paper, typewriter,=20
pen, pencil, mp3 player, cell phone, and any other piece of hardware=20
that's sold to produce and distribute content and all of a sudden the=20
monies raised for this balloons, in the course of a single year, every=20
year, to something close to approaching what the USA has already spent=20
over the course of the ongoing Iraq Occupation, well near a trillion=20
dollars.

Every year, like clockwork, so raising the money isn't the issue.

And through the investing in US Treasuries, it generates interest in the

$10s of billions of dollars every year, which means that in a "Never=20
Touch Principal" sort of way, it can not only be self-supporting, but=20
also self-sustaining as well, for as long as the United States makes=20
payments on their bonds, which in the past 200 odd years has never=20
happened, not that past performance is any indicator of future results.

Now at this point, I can hear the argument that in order to do this it=20
would require Nationalizing the Mass Media's production and distribution

facilities and there are many examples of other industries in which that

has happened where that kind of action has ended rather poorly, and do=20
we want to create the same sort of mess  as that would do with a plan=20
like this?

Of course not.

First off, the last thing one would want to have to happen is to seize=20
these assets by force, that always hurts the one doing the seizing, and=20
leaves the dispossessed with a raft of hurt, bad, and resentful=20
feelings, and so that course of action is to be avoided, because it just

doesn't work.

An alternative approach is to make them see that it would be worth their

while to transfer those assets over to the Common Weal, and that can be=20
done without even raising the idea that for many of the current owners=20
of these properties they should consider themselves grateful that=20
they're not being sent to prison, for their decades worth of=20
malfeasance, corruption, and outright larceny from artists and the=20
public on a grand and felonious scale.

No need to get into all that.

By using the monies raised from these Media Taxes, ear-mark a certain=20
percentage of those monies to buy out the principal owners out of their=20
current production and distribution positions; also to include a=20
life-time severance package for them and pay for the education and=20
health-care of their heirs, and they get to keep all their current=20
assets, to include their housing, luxury cars, yachts, planes, villas,=20
and any other gains they may have reaped exploiting the current way=20
things are done today.

In other words, pay these rat-fuck RIAA/Music-Film Industry greed-heads
off.

Buy 'em out.

They're the real thieves, always have beeen, and I'm sure that they've=20
all got their price.

And if they want to stay on after the transition, offer them a salaried=20
position doing the work that they had been doing.

Now, it's no secret that a lot of Corporations, particularly the=20
advertisers are already looking for a way to get out of the=20
ownership/sponsorship game already.

This is because of the advent of the TiVo/DVR time shifting technology=20
that has emerged and become wildly popular over the course of this last=20
decade.

In their view, why should they continue to pay billions of dollars a=20
year, to not only produce and distribute television, if their target=20
audience is simply going to fast-forward through all the advertising=20
that is the their whole point of paying all that money for, if nobody is

going to bother to watch the commercials anymore?

Where's the business sense in that?

That's money they can keep for themselves and apply to their businesses=20
elsewhere, which they'd probably be better off with.

This offers them a way to get out of the business that is from a=20
cost/benefit analysis, fiscally sound and allow them to meet their=20
fiduciary responsibilities to their shareholders.

---

And that's as far as I got, so far.

~Nyc

--

Isaac wrote:
> The music industry has been in decline this whole decade. It is sad in
many ways because many musicians will not get a chance to make it in the
business. The concept of less sales =3D less talent available to sign
because the industry is tight...=20
> =20
> The ISP's might eventually have to upgrade and obtain the proper
equipment to police the internet. Who knows at this point anything is
possible, I am sure both sides have a case in federal court with great
points and their interpretation of HIGHLY COMPLEX IP laws. You can think
of it like this, the music industry may be willing to spend millions in
court over this which in the long run is cheaper then another decade of
decline (i.e., Exploding Ford Pinto and ethical decisions made by Ford
to keep the car on the road in the 1970's).
> =20
> I remember P. Diddy on MTV's MTB 4 saying artists that use to sell
millions of CD's are now selling a couple of hundred thousand. Also
today artists earn more money because they sign better contracts geared
toward their rights and protection of their art as an artist. Record
companies do not like that because it cuts into their profit. Money to
be made now in the music industry is all in the LIVE SHOWS. I also hear
somewhere that record sales in history actually took off in the mid to
late 1960's like never before in history and record companies made a lot
of money. They peaked at some point in the eighties or nineties.
> =20

>
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/connected/main.jhtml;jsessionid=3D3EKD2RI2OKH0=
X
QFIQMFCFFOAVCBQYIV0?xml=3D/connected/2008/01/29/dlutwo129.xml> > Ban =
music
thieves from web, says U2 manager> By Nicole Martin, Digital and Media
Correspondent, in Cannes> Last Updated: 12:01am GMT 29/01/2008> > Music
fans who repeatedly download songs illegally should have their >
internet connections severed, the manager of U2 has said.> > Telegraph
Arts coverage in full> Telegraph Digital Life> Paul McGuinness, who has
managed the best-selling group for 30 years, > attacked internet service
providers for failing to clamp down on > illegal file-sharing.> > > >
The manager of U2 has called for ISPs to take action against repeat
offenders> He said the refusal of internet firms to punish those who
download > music without paying was "the single biggest failure in the
digital > music market".> > He called on them to adopt a "three strikes
and you're out" > enforcement policy under which illegal downloaders
would have to start > paying for music or face having their ISP
subscriptions terminated.> > "We must shame them into wanting to help
us. Their snouts have been at > our trough feeding free for too long,"
Mr McGuinness said at the Midem > music industry conference in Cannes.>
> "For ISPs in general, the days of prevaricating over their >
responsibilities for helping protect music must end. The ISP lobbyists >
who say they should not have to 'police the internet' are living in >
the past - relying on outdated excuses from an earlier technological >
age."> > His call follows a report last week which showed that while
worldwide > sales of digital music grew by 40 per cent last year, they
were still > not enough to offset a sharp fall in CD sales.> > The
International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, which >
represents record companies across the world, warned that the "crisis" >
in the music industry would deepen unless ISPs took action against the >
millions of people who illegally download music.> > Many ISPs have been
reluctant to police the illegal activities of > their customers,
preferring to rely on record labels to bring cases > against them.> >
advertisement> > But Mr McGuinness said it was time to challenge the
belief that ISPs > should not be held accountable for their customers'
behaviour.> > "If you were publishing a magazine that was advertising
stolen cars, > processing payments for them and arranging delivery of
them you'd > expect to get a visit from the police wouldn't you?" he
said, in a > speech titled The Online Bonanza: Who is Making All The
Money and Why > Aren't They Sharing It?> > "What's the difference? With
a laptop, a broadband account, an MP3 > player and a smartphone you can
now steal all the content, music, > video and literary in the world
without any money going to the content > owners.> > "On the other hand,
if you get caught stealing a laptop in the > computer store or don't pay
your broadband bill there are obvious > consequences. You get nicked or
you get your access cut off."> > A survey last year by Quantum Markets
in Australia found that of the > 2.8 billion people who regularly
download illegally, 75 per cent said > they did not believe they were
hurting the music industry.> > When asked why, the vast majority said
they did not feel at risk of > being punished for downloading songs for
free.> > Mr McGuinness called on the Government to follow the lead of
Nicolas > Sarkozy, the French President, and introduce legislation if
voluntary > talks with ISPs failed to produce a commitment to disconnect
> file-sharers. A spokesman for the Internet Service Providers' >
Association said its members preferred self regulation to legislation.>
> "We do not support abuses of copyright and intellectual property >
theft. However, ISPs cannot monitor or record the type of information >
passed over their networks," he said.> > "ISPs are no more able to
inspect and filter every single packet > passing across their network
than the Post Office is able to open > every envelope."> > > > > >

*nix account with quotas in the MBs.  (Well, not the ONLY one I'm sure.)

adjustment allows hundreds of others (yes, in this specific case not 
hundreds, but it's pointing out the possibility in this specific case) 
not to have to make that same adjustment on their own, son't you think 
it's best for the one to do so?  Saving a much greater total of man 
hours?

For the handful of psytrance devotees on this list, from the "Rawlist"


On with our BSP (Blatant Slef Promotion)-

::Resonance::

Saturday Feb 2nd 2008


Psymonthly is a regular Psy gathering here in the bay area that is =20
focused to strengthen and empower our community. We will concentrate =20
our energies on featuring local and guest artists of all mediums on a =20=

monthly circuit here in the Bay Area.

Alters: Raw Heaven, Happy Camp & Friends

BOM Tribe

"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is =20
nothing but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids =20
look and look and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of =20
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will =20
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--Apple-Mail-1-99287109--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Greg Palast quote

I don't think we fully disagree across the board, and I don't 
consider my position here regressive.  That sounds more like a snide 
insult.  I'm not opposed to improving the lives of poor people.  I'm 
poor myself - but there's not much incentive to making a million 
dollars if I have to bail everyone else out too.

I'm no where close to libertarian.  I'm a registered Democrat, so I 
can affect the primaries and the general election.  I have mixed 
views across the board, and can't easily be categorized, ie, 
government regulation isn't black and white.  Some things need more 
regulation than others.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Trim your replies please.

When I was a Tech/Ops guy @ www.alt.com in '02/'03 the shop was still 
using Pine instead of those bullshit kludgy web-based programs which I 
loathe, (thanks, Thunderbird for keeping me away from gmail's context 
based advertising), and we'd have contests as to who could churn out the 
most in a shift.

The record before I got there was a little over 800 in an 8 hour shift, 
but I blew that away one night when I did 776 Pine emails, all keyboard, 
no mouse, in one 4 hour stretch.
I rock.

Another thing I learned there that Linux is hands down the best and most 
stable OS out there, we never turned the boxes off, the place ran 24/7, 
and it was a solid 6 months before I saw a one of them crash.

.

Subject: [sfraves] Is trance on the ropes?

From: http://dancemusic.blogspot.com/2008/01/last-dance.html

"Are big-room dance nights becoming extinct? That could be the case at one of the California's more legendary clubs, San Francisco's 1015 Folsom, once the home of Spundae and still a spot to see big-name trance spinners. The venue is getting a makeover that will have it explore a more live-oriented booking policy.

'My feeling is that [live acts] have been the trend for a while now,' general manager Peter Glikshtern tells SF Weekly, 'and we need to get with the program.'

In L.A., Gene La Pietra, owner of two major big rooms, Arena and Circus Disco, planned to sell the venues to a developer who wants to tear them down. That looming loss -- apparently on hold for now -- doesn't appear to be a result of music-market whims; but still, the big-room scene certainly seems to be downsizing on the West Coast. Add to that an influx of stage-based dance acts (see below) and a backlash against big-room-filling trance (Avalon Hollywood has gone trance-less lately, and Coachella is trance-free this year), and we could have a dance floor exodus on our hands."

And just when I was going to proclaim my love for that new trance remix of Phil Collins' In the Air Tonight...


Peace,

Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Greg Palast quote

But if the 16th Amendment was never fully ratified and the Supreme  
Court has ruled that the income tax refers to corporate profits, not  
someone exchanging their time for work (that's not the same thing as  
profit), this is all a moot point.  I'm all for helping the poor and  
sick and needy too, but I propose that we are never going to be able  
to properly do that with a system set up like this.

Bush talking about giving these paltry tax cuts when the government  
shouldn't be taking them in the first place is reminiscent of George  
Orwell's 1984 when the ministry reports that chocolate rations  
weren't cut as much as expected, when if you know the right people  
you can have as much chocolate as you want.  The bankers want more  
socialism because they control the strings from behind the scenes.

The bankers created the problem in the first place.  The dollar is  
worth 4 cents what it was in 1913.  Let's break that down.  Your  
$1000/mo closet you live in the trendy Panhandle of SF (I'm just  
making this up don't email me saying I'm racist and I don't like the  
Panhandle) would have cost about $40 perhaps, personally I think even  
less.  Your $5 Carlsberg at Shine (guys please make sure you have  
that stuff on tap every time!) should cost a quarter.  Can you  
IMAGINE the return of the nickel phone call?  The sick and needy  
wouldn't need our help then.

THIS I propose is the reason we were seen as the greatest country in  
the world and the Times of London wrote an article in the 1860's  
saying we need to destroy America otherwise it will ruin the good  
thing all the monarchies in Europe had going on.  And look, they've  
done a damn good job of it.  But now people are starting to wake up  
to this scheme and I hope it's not too late!

FREE - Dirty Hippies in Trees (berkeley) 
---------------------------------
 Reply to: sale-558039129@craigslist.org
 Date: 2008-01-30, 10:56PM PST
 
 
 Please, somebody come take them. They'll need a bath, a spanking and a lecture as to how they've been acting like spoiled brats. That most Americans get up every day, go to their jobs and are productive, contributing members of society. 
 
(Speaking of jobs, how many local jobs are the geniuses stifling while trying to save 3 dozen non-endangered trees and holding up this construction project.) 
 
 They should be easy to catch as they'll be slow and lethargic from sitting around and smoking dope all day. 
 
You can find them on Piedmont Avenue north of Bancroft way in Berkeley in and amongst the oak trees, pooping in buckets and generally causing a scene. 
 
If somebody doesn't take them soon, its time for Plan B: We go down to Home Depot and pick up some illegal aliens, bring them back and tell them there's a big Piñata Party. 
 
 Thank you and have a great day. God Bless America. Long live free speech!!! 
 
 "I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it."  E.B. Hall (Friends of Voltaire)

Subject: [sfraves] Steve Jobs, You Have A Call On The White Courtesy PSP/Skype Telephone,
 c/o Silenced Majority Portal

As promised, Sony released the Skype software for the PSP yesterday
afternoon, and it's *not* vaporware.

Don't have the headset yet, so users can't hear me speak, yet, but the
sound comes in clear with no VoIP latency. Right now, I have people
speak and I reply by text chat in the Skype app.

Simply amazing, free Skype to Skype calls, $40 a year to call *any*
phone in the USA, with *no* per-minute charges, and $0.02 a minute to
call anywhere in China, or over a hundred other foreign countries.

Been waiting for this since the early 1990s when VoIP was invented in
Isreal by VocalTek, it's about time this finally happened.

http://silencedmajority.blogs.com/silenced_majority_portal/2008/01/steve-jobs-you.html

~Nyc

Deepfog wrote:
> But if the 16th Amendment was never fully ratified and the Supreme 
> Court has ruled that the income tax refers to corporate profits, not 
> someone exchanging their time for work (that's not the same thing as 
> profit), this is all a moot point.  I'm all for helping the poor and 
> sick and needy too, but I propose that we are never going to be able 
> to properly do that with a system set up like this.
>

> shouldn't be taking them in the first place is reminiscent of George 
> Orwell's 1984 when the ministry reports that chocolate rations weren't 
> cut as much as expected, when if you know the right people you can 
> have as much chocolate as you want.  The bankers want more socialism 
> because they control the strings from behind the scenes.
>
> The bankers created the problem in the first place.  The dollar is 
> worth 4 cents what it was in 1913.  Let's break that down.  Your 
> $1000/mo closet you live in the trendy Panhandle of SF (I'm just 
> making this up don't email me saying I'm racist and I don't like the 
> Panhandle) would have cost about $40 perhaps, personally I think even 
> less.  Your $5 Carlsberg at Shine (guys please make sure you have that 
> stuff on tap every time!) should cost a quarter.  Can you IMAGINE the 
> return of the nickel phone call?  The sick and needy wouldn't need our 
> help then.
>
> THIS I propose is the reason we were seen as the greatest country in 
> the world and the Times of London wrote an article in the 1860's 
> saying we need to destroy America otherwise it will ruin the good 
> thing all the monarchies in Europe had going on.  And look, they've 
> done a damn good job of it.  But now people are starting to wake up to 
> this scheme and I hope it's not too late!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Steve Jobs, You Have A Call On The White Courtesy PSP/Skype
 Telephone, c/o Silenced Majority Portal

If peeps wise up, flat rate VoIP/wi-fi fones will eat Apple's iPhone 
per-minute, pay as you go, cash on the barrel-head, or else, metered lunch.

And everybody else's, too.

Right now those on "unlimited" calling plans offered by the major 
cable/telcos run about $600 a year, Skype charges less than $40 for the 
same damned thing.

Which would you choose?

The PSP being Sony, the headset/remote combo is proprietary, and retails 
for $50, but will be sure to drop in price when when the bundle comes 
along.

Sony's actually really good about not raping folks on price on the PSPs 
accesories.

It's rare that I do 1st Gen *anything* but in this case I'll make an 
exception and will have this personal unit operational before the cock 
crows three times today.

I've been waiting almost 15 yrs for this and I ain't a gonna wait for a 
3rd party USB peripheral to come along.

Besides I'm going to need that top USB slot for the cam when it gets 
released in the US:
http://forevergeek.com/images/pspcamera.jpg though I like this mock up 
better:
http://img405.imageshack.us/img405/3860/pspslimcw4.jpg

oh, btw, thanks to RealPlayer, (of all people), it's a snap to get 
YouTube/YouPorn vids on to the PSP and onto the TV.

What's not to like?

..

> (Speaking of jobs, how many local jobs are the geniuses stifling while trying to save 3 dozen non-endangered trees and holding up this construction project.) 
>  
>  They should be easy to catch as they'll be slow and lethargic from sitting around and smoking dope all day. 
>  
> You can find them on Piedmont Avenue north of Bancroft way in Berkeley in and amongst the oak trees, pooping in buckets and generally causing a scene. 
>  
> If somebody doesn't take them soon, its time for Plan B: We go down to Home Depot and pick up some illegal aliens, bring them back and tell them there's a big Piñata Party. 
>  
>  Thank you and have a great day. God Bless America. Long live free speech!!! 
>  
>  "I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it."  E.B. Hall (Friends of Voltaire)

>>needy wouldn't need our help then.

Howdy list....

Well, seems my un-ending stream of financial woes didn't stop when we =
switched from 2K7 to 2K8. My bank is putting a hold on a huge chunk of =
my funds for a week or more, rendering it impossible for me to pay my =
rent on time. To make matters worse, my lovely roomates have been late =
on rent almost every month (even though combined they make triple what I =
make). Our landlord has us on month-to-month lease right noww, and most =
likely will want us to vacate the premises next month. There's no way =
I'm gonna be able to come up with the funds to move to a new spot by =
then.

So...looks like Marco will be having a final record sale this weekend. I =
will dig through my stacks and get a list together tonight, and post it =
tomorrow. If anyone wants any of what I have for sale, and can pay THIS =
WEEKEND, that would be really freackin' awesome. Please, once I post the =
list, don't try and nickel and dime me on prices...I need to make money =
off this stuff.

I also have some assorted stuff like a barely used (worn maybe a dozen =
times), really nice leather cafe racing jacket that looks pretty much =
identical to this:=20

http://i2.ebayimg.com/04/i/000/d6/0e/95b7_1.JPG

Bla bla bla....

Anyhoo - any help would be greatly appreciated.=20

Thanks folks...

Date: Thu, 31 Jan 2008 14:14:44 -0800 (PST)
From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <329226.45901.qm@web32412.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
Message-ID: <903683.12995.qm@web32012.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] an idea


As many of you know, I live in southern California (OC
baby!) and I'm a member of the SoCal-Raves list as
well.  A number of years back, producers from that
list got together and put out a limited run of a
compilation CD of tunes, SCR.COMP.001.  Folks liked it
a lot, so in 2003, I decided to spearhead the
production of a second compilation album, SCR.COMP.002
showing the producing diversity of the list at that
point in time.  It was well received and quite fun to
produce.

I talked to SFR about the album and was summarily torn
a new asshole, called a shill for the RIAA and accused
of exploiting The Scene by committing the heinous
crime of selling electronic music.

Today, I can provide you with independent refutation
of the claim that I'm a shill for the RIAA here:
http://www.riaaradar.com/search.asp?searchtype=AsinSearch&keyword=B000CA6YLW

I stand guilty of the charge of selling music, as you
can find SCR.COMP.002 on the iTunes store (
http://phobos.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewAlbum?playListId=66650280
) and you can find physical copies of the CD in some
brick & mortar as well as online retail outlets.

To the charges of exploitation, I can only offer the
same refutation I had before, which is that I entered
into legally binding contracts with each artist on the
album independently, paid each to license his track
for use on the compilation and wrote into the contract
that he retained all writing and publishing rights to
his work.  I (as "Abduction Productions") retained
copyright on the compilation as a whole for the
purposes of sales, marketing and distribution.  None
of the artists have made any claims of unfair
treatment or lack of compensation.  Contact
information for each of the artists is listed in the
liner notes, and I encourage you to contact them on
your own if you have any questions in this area.  I
can also say honestly that I've seen no huge profits
from the project.  In fact, the issue of whether the
break-even point was ever hit remains a matter of
internal discussion for me, depending on how I add up
the costs on any given day.

With all that said, the biggest lesson that I learned
from that project is that it's very expensive to put
out a CD.  Minimum replication orders typically start
at 1000 units and while that doesn't seem like many, I
can tell you that I've still got unopened boxes of
discs stacked up in my house nearly 5 years after
production.

In trying to get the album out there, I started a
relationship with CDBaby.com which is an online
distributor for independent artists and labels.  The
sales of physical CDs hasn't been too good, but they
also handle digital distribution -- that's how I got
the album into the iTunes store (and Rhapsody and a
number of other online digital distribution spots).

CDBaby has now started offering a digital-only
distribution option, which means that only a very very
small run of physical CDs need to be produced and then
CDBaby encodes the tracks and gets them to their
digital music partners.  This means that the most
expensive step of the process (physical CD production
and replication) can be completely avoided, thus
significantly reducing the overall costs of the
project.

I understand the mechanics of producing this type of
compilation album, I have the means to facilitate its
digital distribution and I'd really like to do another
one.  But instead of going back to the well with SCR,
I would really like to put together something that
features the work of independent artists from SFR.  So
the only question is: are there folks on here
producing tunes who would like to participate?

A whipped dog is a wiser dog, as my Father often tells
me, so I'm well aware that many of you will feel
compelled to attack me again for discussing this idea.
 I would only ask that you try to give room to those
who might be interested first, and then if there isn't
enough interest to warrant the project feel no ill
toward me, as I will not bring it up to the list
again.

Thanks for taking the time to read this and I hope we
can make this happen together.

PLUR, etc.





      ____________________________________________________________________________________
Be a better friend, newshound, and 
know-it-all with Yahoo! Mobile.  Try it now.  http://mobile.yahoo.com/;_ylt=Ahu06i62sR8HDtDypao8Wcj9tAcJ

crime of selling electronic music.

Today, I can provide you with independent refutation
of the claim that I'm a shill for the RIAA here:
http://www.riaaradar.com/search.asp?searchtype=AsinSearch&keyword=B000CA6YLW

I stand guilty of the charge of selling music, as you
can find SCR.COMP.002 on the iTunes store (
http://phobos.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewAlbum?playListId=66650280
) and you can find physical copies of the CD in some
brick & mortar as well as online retail outlets.

To the charges of exploitation, I can only offer the
same refutation I had before, which is that I entered
into legally binding contracts with each artist on the
album independently, paid each to license his track
for use on the compilation and wrote into the contract
that he retained all writing and publishing rights to
his work.  I (as "Abduction Productions") retained
copyright on the compilation as a whole for the
purposes of sales, marketing and distribution.  None
of the artists have made any claims of unfair
treatment or lack of compensation.  Contact
information for each of the artists is listed in the
liner notes, and I encourage you to contact them on
your own if you have any questions in this area.  I
can also say honestly that I've seen no huge profits
from the project.  In fact, the issue of whether the
break-even point was ever hit remains a matter of
internal discussion for me, depending on how I add up
the costs on any given day.

With all that said, the biggest lesson that I learned
from that project is that it's very expensive to put
out a CD.  Minimum replication orders typically start
at 1000 units and while that doesn't seem like many, I
can tell you that I've still got unopened boxes of
discs stacked up in my house nearly 5 years after
production.

In trying to get the album out there, I started a
relationship with CDBaby.com which is an online
distributor for independent artists and labels.  The
sales of physical CDs hasn't been too good, but they
also handle digital distribution -- that's how I got
the album into the iTunes store (and Rhapsody and a
number of other online digital distribution spots).

CDBaby has now started offering a digital-only
distribution option, which means that only a very very
small run of physical CDs need to be produced and then
CDBaby encodes the tracks and gets them to their
digital music partners.  This means that the most
expensive step of the process (physical CD production
and replication) can be completely avoided, thus
significantly reducing the overall costs of the
project.

I understand the mechanics of producing this type of
compilation album, I have the means to facilitate its
digital distribution and I'd really like to do another
one.  But instead of going back to the well with SCR,
I would really like to put together something that
features the work of independent artists from SFR.  So
the only question is: are there folks on here
producing tunes who would like to participate?

A whipped dog is a wiser dog, as my Father often tells
me, so I'm well aware that many of you will feel
compelled to attack me again for discussing this idea.
I would only ask that you try to give room to those
who might be interested first, and then if there isn't
enough interest to warrant the project feel no ill
toward me, as I will not bring it up to the list
again.

Thanks for taking the time to read this and I hope we
can make this happen together.

PLUR, etc.





      ____________________________________________________________________________________

Subject: [sfraves] Don't drive in rain with Cruise Control on

--0-1852498532-1201818267=:292
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

A coworker of mine sent the below out, I figure it's worth passing along:
 
How many people know about this…?
 
A person had an accident and totaled her car. It was raining, though not excessively, when her car suddenly began to hydro-plane and literally flew through the air. She was not seriously injured but very stunned at the sudden occurrence!
 
When she explained to the highway patrolman what had happened he told her something that every driver should know? Never drive in the rain with your cruise control on. She thought she was being cautious by setting the cruise control and maintaining a safe consistent speed in the rain. But the highway patrolman told her that if the cruise control is on when your car begins to hydro-plane and your tires lose contact with the pavement, your car will accelerate to a higher rate of speed, making you take off like an airplane. She told the patrolman that was exactly what had occurred.
 
The patrolman said this warning should be listed on the driver\'s seat sun-visor. Never use the cruise Control when the pavement is wet or icy, along with the airbag warning.
 
If you send this to 15 people and only one of them doesn’t know about this, then it was all worth it. You might have saved a life.
 
Note: some vehicles (like the Toyota sienna Limited xle) will not allow you to set the cruise Control when the windshield wipers are on.
 




--0-1852498532-1201818267=:292--

> As many of you know, I live in southern California (OC

> list got together and put out a limited run of a
> compilation CD of tunes, SCR.COMP.001.  Folks liked it
> a lot, so in 2003, I decided to spearhead the
> production of a second compilation album, SCR.COMP.002
> showing the producing diversity of the list at that
> point in time.  It was well received and quite fun to
> produce.
>
> I talked to SFR about the album and was summarily torn
> a new asshole, called a shill for the RIAA and accused
> of exploiting The Scene by committing the heinous
> crime of selling electronic music.
>
> Today, I can provide you with independent refutation
> of the claim that I'm a shill for the RIAA here:

> ) and you can find physical copies of the CD in some
> brick & mortar as well as online retail outlets.

> same refutation I had before, which is that I entered
> into legally binding contracts with each artist on the
> album independently, paid each to license his track
> for use on the compilation and wrote into the contract
> that he retained all writing and publishing rights to
> his work.  I (as "Abduction Productions") retained
> copyright on the compilation as a whole for the
> purposes of sales, marketing and distribution.  None
> of the artists have made any claims of unfair
> treatment or lack of compensation.  Contact

> liner notes, and I encourage you to contact them on

> break-even point was ever hit remains a matter of
> internal discussion for me, depending on how I add up
> the costs on any given day.
>
> With all that said, the biggest lesson that I learned
> from that project is that it's very expensive to put
> out a CD.  Minimum replication orders typically start
> at 1000 units and while that doesn't seem like many, I
> can tell you that I've still got unopened boxes of
> discs stacked up in my house nearly 5 years after
> production.

> relationship with CDBaby.com which is an online

> number of other online digital distribution spots).

> and replication) can be completely avoided, thus
> significantly reducing the overall costs of the
> project.

> digital distribution and I'd really like to do another

> producing tunes who would like to participate?

> > >
> > > How many people know about this…?
> > >
> > > A person had an accident and totaled her car. It was
> raining,
> > > though not excessively, when her car suddenly began to
> > > hydro-plane and literally flew through the air. She was
> not
> > > seriously injured but very stunned at the sudden
> occurrence!
> > >
> > > When she explained to the highway patrolman what had
> happened
> > > he told her something that every driver should know?
> Never
> > > drive in the rain with your cruise control on. She
> thought
> > > she was being cautious by setting the cruise control and
> > > maintaining a safe consistent speed in the rain. But the
> > > highway patrolman told her that if the cruise control is
> on
> > > when your car begins to hydro-plane and your tires lose
> > > contact with the pavement, your car will accelerate to a
> > > higher rate of speed, making you take off like an
> airplane.
> > > She told the patrolman that was exactly what had
> occurred.
> > >
> > > The patrolman said this warning should be listed on the
> > > driver\'s seat sun-visor. Never use the cruise Control
> when
> > > the pavement is wet or icy, along with the airbag
> warning.
> > >
> > > If you send this to 15 people and only one of them
> doesn't
> > > know about this, then it was all worth it. You might have
> > > saved a life.
> > >
> > > Note: some vehicles (like the Toyota sienna Limited xle)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] an idea

Theres a really easy way to do a CD without people freaking out, first 
it helps if your working with friends...

Second, get the $2k you need to get a pressed run, third pay the artists 
in CDs based on some reasonable common sence price.

Sell the CDs that are left over.

Everyone wins, if thats too much of a burden then people should just 
stick to mp3 releases.

peace,

Uncle Noah wrote:

>As many of you know, I live in southern California (OC
>baby!) and I'm a member of the SoCal-Raves list as
>well.  A number of years back, producers from that
>list got together and put out a limited run of a
>compilation CD of tunes, SCR.COMP.001.  Folks liked it
>a lot, so in 2003, I decided to spearhead the
>production of a second compilation album, SCR.COMP.002
>showing the producing diversity of the list at that
>point in time.  It was well received and quite fun to
>produce.
>
>I talked to SFR about the album and was summarily torn
>a new asshole, called a shill for the RIAA and accused
>of exploiting The Scene by committing the heinous
>crime of selling electronic music.
>
>Today, I can provide you with independent refutation
>of the claim that I'm a shill for the RIAA here:
>http://www.riaaradar.com/search.asp?searchtype=AsinSearch&keyword=B000CA6YLW
>
>I stand guilty of the charge of selling music, as you
>can find SCR.COMP.002 on the iTunes store (
>http://phobos.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewAlbum?playListId=66650280
>) and you can find physical copies of the CD in some
>brick & mortar as well as online retail outlets.
>
>To the charges of exploitation, I can only offer the
>same refutation I had before, which is that I entered
>into legally binding contracts with each artist on the
>album independently, paid each to license his track
>for use on the compilation and wrote into the contract
>that he retained all writing and publishing rights to
>his work.  I (as "Abduction Productions") retained
>copyright on the compilation as a whole for the
>purposes of sales, marketing and distribution.  None
>of the artists have made any claims of unfair
>treatment or lack of compensation.  Contact
>information for each of the artists is listed in the
>liner notes, and I encourage you to contact them on
>your own if you have any questions in this area.  I
>can also say honestly that I've seen no huge profits
>from the project.  In fact, the issue of whether the
>break-even point was ever hit remains a matter of
>internal discussion for me, depending on how I add up
>the costs on any given day.
>
>With all that said, the biggest lesson that I learned
>from that project is that it's very expensive to put
>out a CD.  Minimum replication orders typically start
>at 1000 units and while that doesn't seem like many, I
>can tell you that I've still got unopened boxes of
>discs stacked up in my house nearly 5 years after
>production.
>
>In trying to get the album out there, I started a
>relationship with CDBaby.com which is an online
>distributor for independent artists and labels.  The
>sales of physical CDs hasn't been too good, but they
>also handle digital distribution -- that's how I got
>the album into the iTunes store (and Rhapsody and a
>number of other online digital distribution spots).
>
>CDBaby has now started offering a digital-only
>distribution option, which means that only a very very
>small run of physical CDs need to be produced and then
>CDBaby encodes the tracks and gets them to their
>digital music partners.  This means that the most
>expensive step of the process (physical CD production
>and replication) can be completely avoided, thus
>significantly reducing the overall costs of the
>project.
>
>I understand the mechanics of producing this type of
>compilation album, I have the means to facilitate its
>digital distribution and I'd really like to do another
>one.  But instead of going back to the well with SCR,
>I would really like to put together something that
>features the work of independent artists from SFR.  So
>the only question is: are there folks on here
>producing tunes who would like to participate?
>
>A whipped dog is a wiser dog, as my Father often tells
>me, so I'm well aware that many of you will feel
>compelled to attack me again for discussing this idea.
> I would only ask that you try to give room to those
>who might be interested first, and then if there isn't
>enough interest to warrant the project feel no ill
>toward me, as I will not bring it up to the list
>again.
>
>Thanks for taking the time to read this and I hope we
>can make this happen together.
>
>PLUR, etc.
>
>
>
>
>
>      ____________________________________________________________________________________
>Be a better friend, newshound, and 
>know-it-all with Yahoo! Mobile.  Try it now.  http://mobile.yahoo.com/;_ylt=Ahu06i62sR8HDtDypao8Wcj9tAcJ 
>
>

On Jan 31, 2008, at 2:14 PM, Uncle Noah wrote:

>
> As many of you know, I live in southern California (OC
> baby!) and I'm a member of the SoCal-Raves list as
> well.  A number of years back, producers from that
> list got together and put out a limited run of a
> compilation CD of tunes, SCR.COMP.001.  Folks liked it
> a lot, so in 2003, I decided to spearhead the
> production of a second compilation album, SCR.COMP.002
> showing the producing diversity of the list at that
> point in time.  It was well received and quite fun to
> produce.
>
> I talked to SFR about the album and was summarily torn
> a new asshole, called a shill for the RIAA and accused
> of exploiting The Scene by committing the heinous
> crime of selling electronic music.
>
> Today, I can provide you with independent refutation
> of the claim that I'm a shill for the RIAA here:
> http://www.riaaradar.com/search.asp? 
> searchtype=AsinSearch&keyword=B000CA6YLW
>
> I stand guilty of the charge of selling music, as you
> can find SCR.COMP.002 on the iTunes store (
> http://phobos.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewAlbum? 
> playListId=66650280
> ) and you can find physical copies of the CD in some
> brick & mortar as well as online retail outlets.
>
> To the charges of exploitation, I can only offer the
> same refutation I had before, which is that I entered
> into legally binding contracts with each artist on the
> album independently, paid each to license his track
> for use on the compilation and wrote into the contract
> that he retained all writing and publishing rights to
> his work.  I (as "Abduction Productions") retained
> copyright on the compilation as a whole for the
> purposes of sales, marketing and distribution.  None
> of the artists have made any claims of unfair
> treatment or lack of compensation.  Contact
> information for each of the artists is listed in the
> liner notes, and I encourage you to contact them on
> your own if you have any questions in this area.  I
> can also say honestly that I've seen no huge profits
> from the project.  In fact, the issue of whether the
> break-even point was ever hit remains a matter of
> internal discussion for me, depending on how I add up
> the costs on any given day.
>
> With all that said, the biggest lesson that I learned
> from that project is that it's very expensive to put
> out a CD.  Minimum replication orders typically start
> at 1000 units and while that doesn't seem like many, I
> can tell you that I've still got unopened boxes of
> discs stacked up in my house nearly 5 years after
> production.
>
> In trying to get the album out there, I started a
> relationship with CDBaby.com which is an online
> distributor for independent artists and labels.  The
> sales of physical CDs hasn't been too good, but they
> also handle digital distribution -- that's how I got
> the album into the iTunes store (and Rhapsody and a
> number of other online digital distribution spots).
>
> CDBaby has now started offering a digital-only
> distribution option, which means that only a very very
> small run of physical CDs need to be produced and then
> CDBaby encodes the tracks and gets them to their
> digital music partners.  This means that the most
> expensive step of the process (physical CD production
> and replication) can be completely avoided, thus
> significantly reducing the overall costs of the
> project.
>
> I understand the mechanics of producing this type of
> compilation album, I have the means to facilitate its
> digital distribution and I'd really like to do another
> one.  But instead of going back to the well with SCR,
> I would really like to put together something that
> features the work of independent artists from SFR.  So
> the only question is: are there folks on here
> producing tunes who would like to participate?
>
> A whipped dog is a wiser dog, as my Father often tells
> me, so I'm well aware that many of you will feel
> compelled to attack me again for discussing this idea.
>  I would only ask that you try to give room to those
> who might be interested first, and then if there isn't
> enough interest to warrant the project feel no ill
> toward me, as I will not bring it up to the list
> again.
>
> Thanks for taking the time to read this and I hope we
> can make this happen together.
>
> PLUR, etc.
>
>
>
>
>
>

> ______________

> know-it-all with Yahoo! Mobile.  Try it now.  http://

Subject: [sfraves] BSP - This week on Radio Integrated : The Hard Edition . . . Friday 2/1/08

This week on Radio Integrated : *The Hard Edition*
Friday, February 1st 2008
8pm-ish to 1am-ish Pacific Standard Time

We love minimal...We love tech house... We love neo-trance... We love
Detroit... But the hard stuff hasn't been getting much love lately. So
turn the time machine back to 2000 (or into the future for the
neo-Schranz revival of 2011...?), break out the strobe light and bring
your ear plugs, because this week Radio Integrated will be banging out
the hard beats with DJs:


*AMBER (Sister SF, iamthedj.com)
*SIR NOD (Cloudfactory)
*DRAGN'FLY (djdragnfly.com)


......Rave On!


Tune in this Friday and every Friday at http://www.zer01.net:1200/


Radio Integrated :: radiointegrated@gmail.com ::
http://www.zer01.net:1200/ :: Broadcasting live from Bliss Factory
Studios, Alameda, CA

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
